Top financial concern: ‚ÄúWe have a wedding coming up next year. We want to pay for it out of pocket and have our debt paid off by November.‚Äù  Recently engaged, Cara and Will have two financial goals in 2023: to pay off their debt and start saving for their wedding.  Most of the couple‚Äôs $160,000 income is going toward repaying their sizable debt, which stems from hefty vet bills when their dog was a puppy, the purchase of an engagement ring and overspending. Cara is paying $1,500 a month toward a student loan, credit card debt and a line of credit. She is prioritizing the credit card payments, which have the highest interest. Will is on the hook for $500 a month with credit card debt and a line of credit.  Their wedding, which will take place next May at a golf course, will cost them $11,500. ‚ÄúThe wedding is about 50 people. There is no honeymoon planned,‚Äù she said.  In a province with Canada‚Äôs priciest housing, the couple is paying just $1,780 a month to rent their Langley, B.C., apartment. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre renting a two-bedroom apartment that‚Äôs 1,100 square feet. It‚Äôs a steal of a deal for the size,‚Äù says Cara.  And they aren‚Äôt fazed by their lack of savings; they have just $346 in a savings account, $352 in a TFSA and $311 in RRSPs.  Neither Cara nor Will had financial support from their parents for their postsecondary studies. Cara, who worked three jobs while in school, graduated from Kwantlen Polytechnic University with a degree in geography and $30,000 in debt. She has since whittled that down to $6,442.  ‚ÄúMy parents both worked and had six kids ‚Äì they basically did everything so we could have a better life than they did,‚Äù she says.  Cara admits that she and Will lived beyond their means as students. These days, they prepare meals for the week ahead, go only on mini-vacations and limit their spending on clothing. Their dog, a one-and-a-half-year-old dachshund, is one of their larger expenses, as are two gym memberships, which set them back $105 a month.  Another significant expense they hope will lead to some side gigs is the rental of two workshops and tools, which cost the couple $683 a month. Cara uses the space to create jewellery and paintings she aims to sell while Will makes pocket knives and cutting boards.  As for the future, Cara wants to continue renting and to buy a cottage, but Will would prefer to buy a townhome.  Neither option is cheap: Townhomes in the area sell for $650,000 while cottages start at $400,000.  ‚ÄúI personally feel like we‚Äôll be shut out,‚Äù Cara says about home ownership. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking at other provinces versus staying in B.C.‚Äù  Their typical monthly expenses:  Investment and savings: $200  $200 to TFSA. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs with a credit union.‚Äù  $0 to RRSP. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm contributing nothing to my retirement right now. His goal is to purchase a bow but they‚Äôre actually quite expensive.‚Äù  $10 on fishing. ‚ÄúWe go fishing in the summer.‚Äù  $50 on dog food. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a dachshund ‚Äì a pandemic dog. Sylviana Hamdani  ANN/THE JAKARTA POST ‚Äì Designers and experts in the industry talk about emerging wedding trends in Indonesia after the pandemic. Indonesia‚Äôs penchant for big weddings, which often host thousands of guests in luxurious settings, is likely to return now that the COVID-19 pandemic is ending.  As seen in a string of wedding expos in Jakarta since the end of last year, beaming brides-and-grooms-to-be have thronging vendors‚Äô booths as they plan for their perfect day.  ‚ÄúThe industry‚Äôs been steadily looking up since 2022,‚Äù Indonesian wedding community Weddingku chief executive officer Tono Raharja said when interviewed by The Jakarta Post at the Indonesia Dream Wedding Festival 2023 (IDWF 2023) at the Jakarta Convention Centre.  Prior to the pandemic, Indonesia was known to be among a few countries that maintains the tradition of celebrating weddings with large-scale parties.  ‚ÄúI think Indonesia has the largest (scale) of wedding parties in Asia, after India and Thailand,‚Äù Tono added. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm optimistic that these (large-scale) weddings will return as soon as the pandemic ends.‚Äù  Here are some new trends the pandemic has brought into weddings:  HOTEL BALLROOMS WITH A DREAMY DECOR  ‚ÄúBusiness is going back to normal now,‚Äù Priyanto, representative of the wedding organiser Anastasia Project, said at the IDWF 2023. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre handling weddings with 400 to 1,000 invitees every week.‚Äù  While outdoor parties were the preference at the height of the pandemic, many brides and grooms choose to host their weddings in hotel ballrooms again these days.  ‚Äú(Having weddings in hotel‚Äôs ballrooms) has always been the main preference of many Indonesians before the pandemic,‚Äù Priyanto added. ‚ÄúIt seems that the trend‚Äôs returning now.‚Äù  Michelle Paris Decorations representative Mey Lie agreed.  ‚ÄúHotels have (all the facilities) that clients need for a big wedding,‚Äù Mey Lie said. ‚ÄúPlus, (hosting weddings in a hotel ballroom) is weather-safe.‚Äù Ayana Midplaza Jakarta has seen the number of wedding reservations almost return to normal.  ‚Äú(The number of reservations) are getting almost normal,‚Äù senior sales manager of Ayana Midplaza Jakarta Silva Rosalia said at the IDWF 2023.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been seeing an 85 per cent increase in ballroom bookings for weddings (since the pandemic)‚Äù, But there is a slight change in behaviour among customers due to COVID-19.  ‚ÄúBefore the pandemic, customers usually made their (ballroom) bookings at least a year before the planned event,‚Äù Silva said.  ‚ÄúBut these days, they book the venue just three or six months beforehand as many of them are still worried that (the infection rate of COVID-19 will rise again.‚Äù  Aston Sentul Lake Resort and Conference Centre has also received many ballroom wedding bookings these days.  ‚ÄúOur clients are excited that there are no more social restrictions,‚Äù sales executive of the hotel Novita Sari said.  ‚ÄúMany of them now request for (weddings with) a full decor, which includes lots of flowers and (indoor) pergolas.‚Äù  Mey Lie of Michelle Paris Decorations greatly enjoys the hike of exciting new client demands.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been so long since we‚Äôve created such exciting wedding decors,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd now, our artistic brains are exploding with new ideas.‚Äù  During the IDWF 2023, the decorator presented a platform designed like a storybook page, embellished with carved wooden horses and lighted wire butterflies. A mix of blue and magenta ambient lighting creates a dreamy feel about the decor.  ‚Äú(The blue, magenta ambient lighting) is trending now in Jakarta,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs quite a departure from the warm-white wedding (decor) glow during COVID-19.‚Äù  WEDDING DRESSES: SIMPLE WITH DISCREET EMBELLISHMENTS  While wedding decors are getting more extravagant, wedding dresses are becoming simpler.  ‚ÄúAfter the pandemic, everyone prefers a simpler outfit while still maintaining their signature (fashion) style,‚Äù bridal designer Hian Tjen said when interviewed at the launch of a new jewellery collection by Adelle Jewellery x Hian Tjen at Bridestory Market at the Indonesia Convention Exhibition (ICE) in BSD city, Tangerang.  ‚ÄúThus, many brides now favour flowy, loose-fitted wedding gowns with discreet beadings and embroideries.‚Äù  Bridal designer Petrick Sutrisno confirmed this new, more straightforward trend of wedding dresses.  ‚ÄúFull-blown (wedding) gowns are so last year,‚Äù Petrick said. ‚ÄúCustomers prefer simpler, lighter wedding dresses that allow them to move freely and dance.‚Äù  During the IDWF 2023, Petrick showcased two structured semi-ball gowns made of crinoline and silk. While plunging necklines is still preferred in wedding dresses, many now request to have them covered with semi-transparent panels.  ‚ÄúThe semi-transparent panels, subtly adorned with sequins, add more class and decorum to the dress,‚Äù Petrick, who is based in Pluit, Karang Barat, North Jakarta, said.  WEDDING SUITS: SLIM, DOUBLE-BREASTED, CONVERTIBLE TUXES  Many men still prefer to play it safe regarding wedding attire.  ‚ÄúThe classic black tuxedo is still the main choice of our clients for their weddings,‚Äù Tika, representative of Wong Hang Distinguished Tailor, said at the Bridestory Market at ICE BSD, Tangerang.  The renowned bespoke tailor also offers tuxedos fitted with detachable satin lapels and pockets.  ‚ÄúBy taking out (the detachable parts), they can convert the tux into a formal jacket and wear it to many other occasions,‚Äù Tika added.  Besides the classic tux, slim-fit, double-breasted jackets are becoming popular as men‚Äôs wedding attire. ‚ÄúMany of my customers now prefer Italian-style (double-breasted) jackets with relaxed shoulders,‚Äù Henri Winata said at the Bridestory Market at ICE BSD, Tangerang. Wedding suits, made of patterned wool materials, are also becoming a favourite.  ‚ÄúAmong the preferred patterns (for wedding suits) are Prince-of-Wales, Puppytooth and Herringbone,‚Äù the designer (Henri Winata), who studied at Savile Row Academy in London, said.  ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre classics and yet show more character.‚Äù  WEDDING RINGS: TRILOGY AND DIAMOND-LACED  Rings are small yet essential items that bind these once-and-forever love affairs. In this matter, men also opt for the more classic styles.  ‚Äú(Men‚Äôs) wedding bands are usually plain and embellished with a combination of glossy and matte finishing,‚Äù Mondial sales representative Andre said at the IDWF 2023.  Trilogy, a new style of wedding ring featuring a string of three medium-sized diamonds, is very popular among Gen Zs and millennials.  ‚ÄúThe three diamonds (in the Trilogy rings) represent the past, the present and the future,‚Äù Andre said. Besides the Trilogy, diamond-laced wedding bands, known as Tennis Rings, are becoming a favourite among many Indonesian brides.  ‚ÄúThe slim (Tennis) ring, adorned with small, symmetrical diamonds all around, looks very sweet and adorable on women‚Äôs hands,‚Äù Michael Surya, CEO of the local jewellery brand Adelle Jewellery, said at the Bridestory Market at ICE BSD, Tangerang.  During the interview, Michael also shared some tips for choosing the perfect wedding ring for you and your spouse.  ‚ÄúFirst of all, determine a style that you both like and will like for a long time,‚Äù Michael said.  With style in mind, you and your spouse can now visit jewellery houses and see if they have anything suitable to your liking.  Alternatively, you can design your own and make them with a jeweller.  ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôd like to order a specific pair of rings, don‚Äôt forget to allow some time to have it made,‚Äù Michael said. ‚ÄúA jeweller usually takes three to six months to produce them.‚Äù  Last but not least, you should always choose to purchase your wedding rings from a reputable jeweller.  ‚ÄúThere should be no regrets in these precious, once-in-a-lifetime items,‚Äù Michael concluded.

Bride faces criticism after accusing sister of stealing the spotlight with pregnancy (Stock Image)  A woman has been branded extremely self-centred after accusing her own sister of intentionally getting pregnant to draw attention away from her own wedding day. The woman, whose identity was kept private, expressed her worries on Facebook but eventually took the post down.  She sought validation by questioning whether her reaction was exaggerated when she refused to change the wedding date upon learning that her sister, who also held the role of maid of honour, was expecting a child.    When the post was uploaded on Reddit in a thread titled "Wedding Shaming," where users criticise brides, guests, and wedding party members, it attracted a lot of attention. The bride's charges against her sister, alleging that the pregnancy was an intentional attempt to sabotage her special day, sparked a great deal of resentment among the internet community. The debate was further fueled by the fact that her mother and fianc√© agreed with the decision to postpone the ceremony. JUST IN: Jill Barclay‚Äôs horrific murder shows fear of male violence ‚Äòever present‚Äô, say campaigners  Bride's refusal to accommodate sister's pregnancy announcement stirs debate.  In the post, she wrote: "My maid of honour has just announced that she is pregnant. And she is due around my wedding day (October 26, 2023). "She and her husband have been trying for a while, and I would like to feel happy for her, but I'm seriously considering kicking her out of the wedding. The unnamed bride-to-be continued by claiming that her sister purposefully got pregnant in order to draw attention away from her. She said: "I feel she has deliberately done this to take the attention away from me. The only problem is that she is my sister, and my parents are telling me to postpone the wedding for her."  Wedding parties lose hotel rooms to migrants  The woman refused to change the wedding date despite her family's objections because she thought it would negatively impact their plans and result in the loss of non-refundable deposits. She expressed displeasure since she was called "dramatic" in reaction to her viewpoint by both her partner and her parents. The bride emphasised that the location had been reserved since November 2022, but she didn't feel like her fiance was standing by her. She said: "I am not postponing my day as we have had the venue booked since November 2022. Even my fianc√©e is taking her side." And ended the post by asking: "Am I being dramatic?" US First Lady Jill Biden will attend the Royal wedding of the Jordanian Crown Prince Prince Hussein and Rajwa Al Saif, as part of a trip to the Middle East and North Africa, AP reported on Saturday.  It will be Biden's first visit to the Middle East as first lady.  She is scheduled to start her six-day trip on Wednesday. And, she will visit Egypt, Morocco and Portugal.  Biden's Spokesperson Vanessa Valdivia said: ‚ÄúThe first lady believes that supporting youth across the world is critical to our common future, with education, health and empowerment at the heart of it.‚Äù  She added: ‚ÄúWith her visit to the Middle East and North Africa, the first lady will continue to build on her work to empower young people, and reaffirm our commitment to strengthen our partnerships and advance our shared priorities in the region."

A WOMAN revealed that her ex boyfriend invited her to his wedding as a bridesmaid - and didn't tell the bride.  The woman's dilemma was discussed on the Glaswegian podcast Girls Overheard, where her anonymous message explained how the 'scumbag' asked her to join the bridal party.  1 A woman spilled the beans on how her ex-boyfriend asked her to be a bridesmaid at his wedding without telling his wife Credit: Getty  She had previously dated the man for five years, before they split up when she was 17.  They had a five year age gap, which she labels a 'red flag' due to how young she was when their relationship started.  After they broke up he began dating one of her friends, who she nicknames Betty.  The woman is now happily married to and has two kids with her husband.  But her ex, who she refers to by the fake name Johnny, asked a friend for her number so he could issue the unwanted wedding invitation.  And the reason he gave for wanting her as a bridesmaid to his wife-to-be was shocking.  The podcast hosts gasped in horror when they heard his inappropriate quip.  Podcast host Ash read the anonymous message, where the woman said: "Johnny got my number from a mutual friend and phoned two years ago asking me, I quote, 'Will you be Betty's bridesmaid?'  "Surprised he even had my number I said no to his reply 'I always wanted to see you walk down the aisle to me'.  "I hung up the phone. After multiple failed attempts to contact me, I changed my number.  "I eventually told Betty, and as far as I know, the wedding still went ahead and they are still together.  "Poor girl, he's a scumbag."  The hosts all looked at each other in shock, totally speechless after reading the story.  Outraged fans took to the comments to slam the ex boyfriend for his behaviour, and they were all pointing out the same thing.  One wrote: "Am I the only one that thinks the actual gasp of this story is the fact she was 12 & him 17 when they got together???"  Another added: "So he was 17 and she was 12? What the actual?"  A third said: "Ok but how were they even allowed to date at their age then?"  A fourth commented: "12 and 17, so did her parents not say anything or ring police?"

SISTER Wives' Christine Brown has shown off her cleavage in a plunging top after sharing how much weight she plans to lose before her summer wedding.  The reality star took to her Instagram Stories on Friday to promote products from Dime - a beauty company she endorses.  5 Christine Brown showed off her fit figure in a new video Credit: Instagram/christine_brownsw  5 Christine recently revealed she plans to lose 20 pounds before her summer wedding to her fianc√©, David Woolley Credit: david__woolley/Instagram  In the clip, Christine, 51, sported jeans, a tight, low-cut blue top, and her blonde hair in a half ponytail as she gushed over the items.  She smiled at the camera while holding up the brand's day cream and serum, encouraging her followers to use her special discount code when purchasing.  But the TLC star's appearance might have caught viewers' attention more as she flaunted her slimmer frame.  Christine has been focusing on living a healthier lifestyle since splitting from her ex-husband, Kody, 54, in November 2021.  And although she appears to have already lost a considerable amount of weight, the TV personality plans on shedding more pounds before tying the knot with her fianc√©, David Woolley, 59.  "She works out every day. She's like super dedicated to the 'hot mom' comeback thing," a Sister Wives source told The U.S. Sun.  When asked how much she's looking to lose, the source revealed: "Oh, probably 20 more pounds."  "She's happy with how far she's come and David thinks she's perfect.  "So it's not like she's putting a lot of pressure on herself to lose more weight," the source continued.  "I think it's more about how she wants to look in a wedding dress and, of course, cameras will be around."  WEIGHT LOSS CHALLENGE  The mom of six has made it known that she will soon be starting a six-week challenge with her Plexus followers.  Christine has been promoting the upcoming weight loss challenge on her Instagram, asking her fans to message her if they want to sign up.  She captioned a recent post: "I get asked quite often - how did you lose all your weight? This little drink right here with a few others.  "Google gut health & weight loss - you will see how it's ALL connected. It's pretty fascinating, actually. So I jumped on board and have been consistent since.  "I choose these products because they get to the root of the issue, aka gut health = weight loss and better living."  Christine was referring to the "pink drink" sold by Plexus, which is a dietary supplement that aids with weight loss.  The influencer and her former sister wife Janelle, 53, have gone head-to-head, competing against each other in sales.  While it's unknown how much weight Christine has lost, The U.S. Sun reported Janelle lost over 100 pounds.  WEDDING PLANS  Christine's challenge will be over before she walks down the aisle.  The U.S. Sun reported she's planning on having her dream wedding this summer, "probably in July," before the kids go back to school in the fall.  A source claimed the nuptials would occur in Utah, where the newly engaged couple recently bought a new $770K home.  "It's going to be, from what I hear, really intimate and mostly close family," the source dished.  "She's super close to her mom and obviously her kids will be there and his kids and their families."  Christine has six children with her ex-Kody: Aspyn, 28; Mykelti, 26; Paedon, 25; Gwendlyn, 21; Ysabel, 19; and Truely, 13.  The family insider alleged that Kody would not be invited and that Christine "really just talks to Janelle," so invites to her other ex-sister wives, Meri, 52, and Robyn, 44, are up in the air.  A source told The U.S. Sun that the wedding will be filmed for the family's TLC reality show or a "potential spinoff."  5 Christine has been competing against her former sister wife, Janelle, in sales for their wellness supplements Credit: Instagram/christine_brownsw  5 Christine and David are reportedly planning to have their dream wedding this summer Credit: david__woolley/Instagram

Miss Maine, Juliana Morehouse, will make history as the first married woman to compete in the Miss USA pageant.  Morehouse will represent Maine at this year's Miss USA competition. Sage Media Photography  Morehouse, 23, has been competing in pageants since she was 16. Inspired by her mom ‚Äî a former Miss North Carolina who was second runner-up at Miss USA 1994 ‚Äî Morehouse has dreamed of making it to the Miss USA stage since she was just a girl.  "I decided on my 7th birthday that I wanted a Miss USA-themed birthday," Morehouse told Insider. "I was Miss USA of course, because I was the birthday girl, and we did a little evening gown competition in my foyer at home."

A mum looking forward to her dream wedding has had to scale back her plans after excruciating back pain turned out to be terminal cancer. Sandra Jones, who lives in Wolverhampton, was diagnosed with bone cancer.  In a cruel twist of fate, she was given the news seven years to the day since she was told she had breast cancer. The mum-of-two, originally from the Wirral, found out in April that the disease had returned.  Her spine has been affected by the cancer, which has spread to her pelvis, femur, lungs, liver and lymph nodes. Now the 39-year-old's brother, Neil Jones, is trying to raise money to help Sandra adapt her house to make her as comfortable as possible.  READ MORE: Best flight deals from Birmingham Airport from Jet2, Ryanair, Tui and more  This includes changes to the bathroom as well as a stairlift. Any other money raised will go towards Sandra making happy memories with her partner of 16-years Adam and their two children, Brody, 11, and Beau, nine.  Neil, who lives in Oxfordshire and works for the RAF, told BlackCountryLive: "It's been difficult because I'm not close by to provide support. Her partner has had to reduce his work hours to help out and to spend as much time as possible with her.  "They haven't given her a timeframe but we know it's terminal." The 34-year-old went on: "Sandra is one of the most selfless people you could ever meet, she never puts herself before others and has always found a positive outlook in all that does.  "She tackled cancer the first time around and refused to let it get in the way of raising her family and giving her children the best start in life. Now at just 39, she must get ready for another battle.  "Her positivity is honestly inspirational, to not only deal with cancer once, but to be gearing up for another battle she knows she will ultimately lose." Sandra and Adam had planned to marry in Greece on their anniversary in June.  But they have now arranged a small civil ceremony in the UK instead. Adam proposed to Sandra as a family picture was being taken with their children on holiday.  "They're going to get married on the same day but in a small ceremony at a registry office," Neil said. "It will be their 16-year anniversary. They were supposed to go to Greece but had to cancel that but they still want to get married."  A GoFundMe page set up by Neil has so far raised ¬£6,000 to support the family. He continued: "The priority is to make changes to the house that are needed. They've got a conventional bathroom at the moment and she struggles with the stairs.  "She will get more tired with the treatment so we want to make any necessary changes we can do. Any money that's left over will be used for her to have fun days out with the kids to make memories. It is likely that she'll end up in a wheelchair because she gets so tired."  Speaking about the donations, he added: "It is incredible and I've been so overwhelmed with people's generosity. Some friends are coming up with ideas for fundraising."  Neil added that his nephew Brody and niece Beau are coming to terms with the news. He said: "Brody has asked a lot of questions and they've had to have an honest conversation with him. I think he understands it a lot more than Beau does."  You can visit the GoFundMe page here.  READ NEXT:

The cause of death was smoke inhalation  A 19-year-old woman tragically died in a house fire in US' Wisconsin just hours before she was set to walk down the aisle, the Independent reported. Paige Ruddy was asleep on the second story of a Reedsburg home when it became engulfed in flames on May 23 around 4 am. She suffered a fatal brain haemorrhage caused by smoke inhalation and died in the hospital the next day.  Notably, she had already exchanged vows with her husband-to-be Logan Mitchell-Carter on Monday and was planning a small ceremony with her close friends and family at the Sauk County Courthouse the next day.  However, on Tuesday, her family woke up to the terrible news. Local fire department Chief Craig Douglas said Ms. Ruddy couldn't navigate through the smoke to safety. The house, in which the couple was staying, belonged to the groom's grandparents and reportedly lacked any working smoke detectors.  The Sauk County Coroner's office confirmed to WMTV that its preliminary investigation shows that Ms. Ruddy's cause of death was smoke inhalation. The cause of the fire is under investigation but police suspect no foul play was involved. Three other people were home at the time of the fire and managed to escape before firefighters arrived at the scene around 4 am.  ''She was just a precious human. There was nothing about her that you couldn't like. She was this presence you never knew you needed in your life, but always did,'' Ruddy's aunt told NBC 15.  A funeral will take place next week. Meanwhile, the family has set up a GoFundMe dedicated to covering her medical and funeral expenses.  ''Monday night the Ruddy family in Reedsburg, Wisconsin went to sleep excited to attend Paige Ruddy and Logan Mitchell-Carter's small wedding ceremony. Instead, they were woken by police to be informed that there was a fire. Despite the amazing efforts of those who love her, the Reedsburg police and firefighters, EMTs, med flight, and the amazing staff at UW hospital over two horrible days, Paige could not be saved. She passed surrounded by her family and friends who took up a large waiting room in the hospital,'' a note on the page reads.  ''There are enough good qualities about Paige to fill up a room. Since she was a toddler Paige was full of life, ready to help anyone with anything, and an absolute joy to be around. She was kind, fun, and according to her family had lots of spunk. Paige always worked hard at everything she did,'' it further reads.  Ms. Ruddy's family said she had just graduated from Reedsburg Area High School in June 2022 and planned to enroll in a Vet Tech program at Madison Area Technical College this fall, People reported.

Emma Leanne Smith is a hopeless romantic who believes in happily ever after and this is at the heart of everything she does.  Having been nominated in this year‚Äôs County Brides North West Wedding Awards in two categories - Artificial Florist and Venue Stylist ‚Äì Event Cheshire has made the shortlisted top ten on both counts.  Event Cheshire can dress venues for any special occasion  The North West Wedding Awards received more than 15,000 votes with 2,415 companies being nominated for the awards.  These nominations have been whittled down to 360 finalists who are all in the running to take home a title at the gala event at Mere Golf Resort on Wednesday, June 14, with this year‚Äôs theme being ‚Äòdiamonds are forever‚Äô.  Emma, who lives in Sandymoor, has spent the past four years fine tuning her skills to produce Instagram-worthy and Pintrest-worthy masterpieces for weddings and christenings, parties and festivals up and down the country.  READ MORE:  Romantic floral displays creating the perfect ‚Äòhappily ever after‚Äô  Emma, who last year took home the New Business of the Year Award, said: ‚ÄúTo say that we are over the moon to be a finalist again is an understatement.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a real honour to have got this far.  ‚ÄúOur clients are amazing and we are so grateful for all their support and especially those who have taken the time to vote for us.  ‚ÄúI believe I work in the best industry in the world because I get to create beautiful floral stylings for the most gorgeous clients, who are celebrating their love for each other with their families and friends.  ‚ÄúWhat a complete privilege it is to be part of their love story.  ‚ÄúWe create forever memories and it‚Äôs truly a passion not a job for us at Event Cheshire.‚Äù  Event Cheshire's Emma Leanne Smith  She added: ‚ÄúMaking the finals of both awards is in recognition of the hard work of my whole team and their dedication to creating the most perfect day for our couples.  ‚ÄúThey always go above and beyond for our customers and everyone appreciates those extra special touches.  ‚ÄúWhat a talented team!‚Äù  So what‚Äôs next for Event Cheshire?  It‚Äôs promising to be a busy year with 19 weddings between now and the end of July where they will create floral designs for each one and Emma is looking forward to welcoming the newest member of the team this summer ‚Äì a baby boy.

Danielle Harold will appear in Albert Square for the last time on Wednesday, when Lola sadly loses her brain tumour battle - and she said she wants to take some keepsakes from the set  EastEnders star Danielle Harold plans to pinch her character‚Äôs wedding dress when she leaves ‚Äì in case she never gets married.  The 30-year-old, who plays tragic Lola Pearce in the BBC soap, has told how she has her eye on the outfit, as well as a couple of wedding snaps.  She will appear in Albert Square for the last time on Wednesday, when Lola sadly loses her brain tumour battle. Asked if she plans to take any keepsakes from Walford, Danielle replied: ‚ÄúWhatever I can fit up my jumper! I really want the Queen Vic bust. I‚Äôm going to take Lola‚Äôs wedding dress.  Image: BBC/Jack Barnes/Kieron McCarron) BBC/Jack Barnes/Kieron McCarron)  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got a nice big wedding day picture and I‚Äôm single, so it‚Äôs questionable with it up on the wall. [But] I might not ever have a wedding day!‚Äù Danielle, who has been in EastEnders since 2011, has agreed a marriage pact with co-star Jamie Borthwick, 28, who plays her on-screen hubby Jay Brown.  Jamie said: ‚ÄúWe say, if me and Danielle aren‚Äôt married by the age of 30, we‚Äôre going to get married.‚Äù  Laughing, Danielle chipped in: ‚ÄúWe said 40!‚Äù The pair spoke about the emotional toll Lola‚Äôs final scenes took on the entire soap cast.  Image: Ken McKay/ITV/REX/Shutterstock) Ken McKay/ITV/REX/Shutterstock)  Jamie said: ‚ÄúIt was very tough. It was very respectful on set and we had a lovely crew. There were a lot of tears.‚Äù  And Perry Fenwick, who plays Lola‚Äôs on-screen grandad Billy Mitchell, said tear sticks to make the actors weep were not needed.  He added: ‚ÄúIt was hard not to cry before you‚Äôre meant to cry.‚Äù

Aaron Paul paid a sweet tribute to his wife Lauren Parsekian for their 10th wedding anniversary on Saturday.  '10 years of [marriage] with this goddess of a woman,' the Breaking Bad star began on Instagram, before sharing why he's posted the tribute one day after their actual milestone.  'Day late but I was enjoying my day with her and our two precious little babies yesterday. You are such a light to this world @laurenpaul8,' he wrote.  The Emmett, Idaho native goes on to boast how he and their two children are 'spoiled by your love and kindness constantly.'  He described his wife as an example for others and someone he strives to be like and emulate.  Sweet: Aaron Paul, 43, shared a sweet tribute to his wife Lauren Parsekian, 36, for their 10th wedding anniversary, which was on May 26  'Thank you for showing our own beautiful family (and complete strangers) what it's like to be a decent human and to always think of others before ones self.' he gushed.  'I am constantly learning from you and of course in awe of you every single day. Here's to the 10 years we just blew through and to all of the years beyond these. Happy anniversary you pretty little bird you.  Paul shared the sweet sentiments along with a black-and-white photo of the couple seemingly on their wedding day on May 26, 2013.  The Westworld actor can be seen reaching out to touch his bride decked out in a black tuxedo with a matching bowtie and white shirt, while Parsekian looks lovely in a white shoulder-less gown, and her long blonde locks flowing down over her chest and to about the middle of her back.  The couple first met when they both attended the Coachella Music Festival in Indio, California in April 2010, which was the year that Muse, Gorillaz and Jay-Z were the three headliners for the three day event.  Ahead of the concert weekend, Parsekian had just wrapped on shooting the documentary film Finding Kind, which she directed and released the following May in 2011, according to Us Weekly.  After establishing a solid friendship the two in love about a year later and have not looked back ever since.  They would eventually get married two years later, but waited a few years until they decided to expand their family, that started with the arrival of daughter Story, who's now five-years old.  They became a family of four when Parsekian gave birth to their son Ryden 13-months ago.  In a sign of their mutual respect and love for each other, Paul asked his Breaking Bad co-star, Bryan Cranston, to be his boy's godfather, which he readily accepted.  Paul, who never seems to hold back in his love and respect for his wife, shared some more high praise for her for this past Mother's Day.  'I love you to all the moons and back. You are the greatest person I have ever known and our two precious babies are the luckiest kids on the planet to be able to call you mommy,' he wrote in the cation, alongside a head shot of his ladylove. 'Happy Mother's Day you pretty little bird you. Thanks for loving us the way that you do.'  In late March, Paul took to his Instagram page to confirm his new role in the film Ash.  New Zealand here we come! Excited to announce that I am teaming up with @xyzfilms on yet another beautiful story. Brought to you by the incredible film maker and musical genius @flyinglotus,' he shared on March 28.  'Leading the charge in this story is the one and only @eizagonzalez and she is going to absolutely crush it. I have known this beautiful force of nature for many years now and to be able to tackle something this massive with her is truly a dream come true. Love you girl!' he added.  'Ash is a next level Sci Fi drama that will be mind bending and all around fucked up and Flylo is going to blow all of our minds with this one.'  His light and the world's: The Emmett, Idaho native goes on to boast how he and their two children are 'spoiled by your love and kindness constantly'  Music brought them together; The couple first met at the Coachella Music Festival in Indio, California in April 2010, and by the next year they were deeply in love  Grwoing family: The couple are thew proud parents of daughter Story, now five, and son Ryden, 13 months; the famiy are pictured in October 2019  Mates; In a sign of their mutual respect and love for each other, Paul asked his Breaking Bad co-star, Bryan Cranston, to be his boy's godfather, which he readily accepted; the two friends are also business partners with Dos Hombres Mezcal  The three-time Primetime Emmy Award-winner concluded, 'Thank you Jonni Remmler for writing such a powerful script for us all to dive into. Let's get it!!!'  Ash focuses on a woman (Gonz√°lez), who wakes up on a distant planet to find that everyone on her space station has been hideously murdered. A man (Paul) is sent to rescue her‚Äîbut she must decide if he is her salvation, or her doom.  Lotus ( born Steven D. Bingley-Ellison), 39, who previously directed the surreal body horror film Kuso, dished on the production to Collider before making his way to New Zealand to being the shoot.  'We are building something fresh and unique with Ash and having Eiza and Aaron in this world just makes it flames, he told the publication. 'They are absolute magic makers, brave and equally inspiring. All that to say‚Ä¶We 'bout to kill this s**t.'

Catherine Hodgson, who works in the office at the Ravenglass and Eskdale Railway, married Ian Hodgson from Moor Row, who works as a landscaping supervisor on Sellafield.  The couple, who lives in Seascale with their three children, met while they were working at Muncaster Castle.  Ian was working as part of the forestry team, and Catherine worked in the cafe onsite.  The pair got engaged on the top of Scafell Pike on September 27 2020.  Catherine said: "It wasn't really a surprise, as Ian had joked that would be the only place he would propose to me."  The couple got married in Tipis on Catherine's parent's farm in Waberthwaite on April 15 2023, surrounded by 70 guests during the day and over 100 in the evening.  Catherine said they enjoyed a 'lovely sunny day.'  She said: "We got married under a homemade wooden arch with views of the Eskdale Valley in the background.  "Everyone was sitting on straw bales. The wedding theme was very rustic, and we had tried to make as much as we could ourselves. We had the order of the day written on pallets, my auntie had made hundreds of meters of hessian bunting, and we had lots of jars and bottles with lights dotted around.  "There were lots of garden games out to entertain the kids. We had a traditional wedding breakfast of soup, roast beef and Rhubarb Crumble, which was delicious.  "In the afternoon, we went up to Wasdale with Clare, our photographer, and got some beautiful shots."  Their first dance was to Lover of the Light by Mumford and Sons.  The couple is planning to have a honeymoon abroad, but they will be waiting until next year when their youngest daughter gets older.

The sky's the limit for ABC investigative journalist Grace Tobin.  The notoriously private Four Corners reporter enjoyed a rare moment in the mainstream spotlight this week when her unconventional wedding dress went viral.  As her public profile grows, industry insiders believe the Walkley Award winner will soon move up the ranks at the public broadcaster - which is currently in the midst of a PR disaster following Stan Grant's exit from Q+A, citing relentless abuse on Twitter.  Grace, who tied the knot with her long-time boyfriend Tom in Brisbane last weekend, sparked a fashion frenzy when she walked down the aisle in thigh-skimming frock.  The flirty satin number featured puffy ruffled shoulders, a tasteful neckline that exposed her d√©colletage, and a short A-line skirt that cinched in at the waist.  The sky's the limit for ABC investigative journalist Grace Tobin, who went viral last week for her thigh-skimming wedding dress (pictured) while marrying boyfriend Tom in Brisbane  The investigative journalist (center) is a rising star at ABC and already boasts two Walkley Awards  After Channel Nine presenter Sylvia Jeffreys, who was a guest at the wedding, posted photos of the nuptials on Instagram, fans demanded to know where they could get the dress for themselves.  'Beautiful! Would you mind sharing where your dress is from?' one asked.  'You look absolutely stunning, Grace!' another wrote, while a third fan begged: 'Please let me know where your dress is from!'  'Your dress is stunning, what brand please?!' one commented.  At the wedding, Grace stood alongside Sylvia Jeffreys, and pals Katie Buxton, Charlotte Dunn, and Jill McCormick. All pictured  Before joining the ABC, Grace worked as a crime reporter in Queensland before joining Channel Nine as a producer on 60 Minutes.  In 2017, she won a Walkley Award for the 60 Minutes story on Matthew Leveson's death.  The following year, she published a book about the crime called, 'Deal with the Devil: The death of Matthew Leveson and the ten-year search for the truth'.  Tobin won her second Walkley award in 2019 for an expos√© on Crown Resorts.  Before joining the ABC, Grace worked as a crime reporter in Queensland before joining Channel Nine as a producer on 60 Minutes  The ABC is currently in need of some fresh faces after some of its biggest stars either jumped ship or had their shows cancelled.  Radio personality Fran Kelly's talk show Frankly was just axed after one season, while comedian Shaun Micallef recently walked away from his satirical series Mad As Hell after fifteen seasons.  However, the network's most notable departure - albeit a temporary one - has been Q+A host Stan Grant.  Grant revealed last Friday he was stepping away from hosting the ABC's flagship political panel program after just ten months in the role, citing racial abuse.  The 59-year-old said he was subjected to 'relentless racial filth' and accused the ABC of 'institutional failure' after no one in senior management offered him support.  The glamorous reporter also boasts a Kennedy award  The ABC is currently in need of some fresh faces after some of its biggest stars either jumped ship or had their shows cancelled. (Pictured: ABC headquarters in Ultimo)  RN Breakfast host Patricia Karvelas has been tipped as the frontrunner to be the new host of Q+A as Grant prepares to leave the role.  The sudden exit has left ABC officials scrambling to find an interim host with a week's notice.  As Grant considers his future, it's understood Karvelas could be the initial replacement for a minimum of two episodes from May 29, reports The Australian.  Radio personality Fran Kelly's talk show Frankly was just axed after one season. Fran is pictured  Stan Grant revealed last Friday he was stepping away from hosting the ABC's flagship political panel program after just ten months in the role, citing racial abuse  ABC Radio Melbourne host Virginia Trioli's name has also been thrown around, having previously worked as an interim host in 2021 following Hamish Macdonald's shock switch to Network Ten.  However, Trioli isn't considered a long-term replacement due to ongoing 'family issues', which saw her take time off earlier this year.  Insiders host David Speers is unlikely to be considered, despite being in the role previously as a rotating host.  'The circumstances which saw Grant's Indigenous heritage become part of the online vitriol directed towards him mean that Speers, as a white male, is unlikely to be considered for the role ‚Äì even on an interim basis,' journalist Nick Tabakoff writes.

The 12 - our free newsletter with all the news you need  A groom's vows have been criticised as 'full of red flags' after a video of his 'gross' declarations to his bride went viral. Jonathan Pajak, the wedding videographer and TikToker, captured the husband-to-be's vows in a clip that has been watched by millions of people.  Jonathan shared the video with his 118,000 followers and it has racked up 31 million views. People in the comments were also shocked to find out that the groom made the vows, which focussed on the couple's sex life, in front of his mother who officiated the wedding.  The TikTok started with Jonathan introducing the clip. He said: "When the groom said this earlier on his wedding day..." before cutting to a shot of the groom responding to the question: 'Is there anything you'd like to say to your future bride?'  READ MORE: Victoria's Secret model faces backlash after documenting end of her nan's life as she chooses euthanasia following terminal diagnosis  The husband-to-be said he hoped they will have a lot of intimacy. Jonathan then appeared back on the screen, continuing his thought: "I should have known his vows were going to go like this."  The footage then cut to the groom's vows. He said: "Only two things are required to keep me happy, keep my belly full" and ensure he is 'satisfied' in another way.  He added: "Though you're amazing at half of it, we really need to get you some cooking lessons. Even when my belly isn't full, there's no one I could ever love more in this lifetime - unless I actually get a chance to meet Margot Robbie.  "Since the beginning I was always told 'life gets even better when the kids fall asleep' and you tell me to come to the bedroom." The guests can be heard laughing and his mother then interrupts to exclaim: "Michael!"  The groom's vows ended with: "P.S. since you're so good at making decisions, like marrying me, you can choose [how tonight's going to end]." His mother then said: "Alright, being as I am his mum, I will deal with him later, he is grounded, by all means."  It's no surprise that the clip quickly went viral, with many people shocked that he would say 'gross' vows on his wedding day. One person commented: "That would make me so sad."  The clip was also discussed on the wedding podcast The Unfiltered Bride with Beth and Georgie calling the vows "disgusting". One social media user wrote: "I felt so sorry for his wife!!!"  A second person agreed, writing: "I couldn't watch the video. after 5 seconds had to turn it off." "I would DIE. The biggest ICK," said a third commenter. However, another person disagreed, writing: "If my man don‚Äôt do this I don‚Äôt want him!"  The bride herself even commented on the video. Destiny Lentini wrote: "So I'm the bride an[d] no this isn't a red flag. We have been together for 10 years now and decided to get married right before our 10th year."  What do you think of the vows? Micro weddings grew during COVID. With inflation, are they here to stay?  Homemade pizzas, 15 guests and a small intimate ceremony in their backyard in -35 C weather.  That‚Äôs how Kay and Curtis Ballance celebrated their ‚Äúperfect‚Äù wedding day.  The couple got married at their home in Grand Prairie, Alta., in February this year just seven weeks after giving birth to their first daughter.  Kay Ballance said their preference was to have no guests at all and to just tie the knot at the courthouse, but in Alberta, you are required by law to have a marriage ceremony ‚Äì which is what they ended up doing.  ‚ÄúThe size of our wedding, it actually turned out to be perfect,‚Äù said Curtis Ballance.  ‚ÄúThe very important people in our lives were there and yeah, just the smaller the better. And it was affordable.‚Äù  Kay and Curtis Ballance on their wedding day, Feb. 23, 2023 Mihaela/MR Photography  Curtis‚Äôs dad, who is a chef, made his special cheeseburger pizzas, wings and lasagna, so they didn‚Äôt have to spend on catering.  For decorations they rented a $25 wedding arch and Kay bought flowers from the dollar store to make her own floral arrangements.  The total cost of their wedding was around $1,000, the Ballances said ‚Äì which helped them save for bills, house furnishing and baby toys.  The trend of micro weddings picked up during the COVID-19 pandemic amid limits on large gatherings, forcing couples to go for smaller ceremonies.  But even without the public health restrictions in place, the shift towards less extravagant weddings with a lower price tag amid inflationary pressures has struck a chord with many couples in Canada.  In reaction to the COVID-19 lockdown rules in 2020, Kennedy Event Planning, an Ottawa-based wedding planning agency, launched Petite Weddings, specializing in micro weddings.  Owner Shannon Kennedy said the pandemic has highlighted the charm of smaller weddings.  ‚ÄúI think, through COVID ‚Ä¶ people are understanding that micro weddings and small weddings are just as joyous and just as big of a celebration as their 200-person component on the other end,‚Äù she told Global News.  Bryn Armstrong founded Primp & Pop Event Co., which specializes in pop-up ceremonies, elopements and micro weddings in Muskoka, Toronto and Niagara, Ont., in 2016.  Armstrong said the demand for their services has now petered out a little bit after a surge early on in the pandemic, but she is still seeing a trend toward smaller weddings.  ‚ÄúOne of the positive aspects of the pandemic, I suppose, is that it has opened people‚Äôs eyes to the flexibility around wedding planning and that there are different versions of the wedding outside of doing a big traditional wedding that is potentially six figures or takes a lot of money.‚Äù  As Canadians continue to grapple with high prices, one of the main motivations to opt for smaller weddings is financial reasons, wedding planners say.  Shaving off the guest list automatically helps cut costs.  A big traditional wedding of roughly 100 guests can cost up to $50,000, said Mallory Lauder, owner of Lasting Events, a boutique wedding coordinating company in Ontario‚Äôs Niagara Region.  For the coming summer, Lauder says they are planning weddings of 50 guests or less, with a price tag of roughly $35,000 or under.  ‚ÄúWeddings aren‚Äôt cheap, and given what our economy looks like right now, a lot of people are focusing on trying to save for a home or what the next steps in life are.‚Äù  If you are working with a tight wallet and have financial concerns, Lauder‚Äôs advice to her clients is to start talking budget very early in the wedding planning process so there are no unexpected expenses or surprises later.  Armstrong said their micro weddings of 20 people are priced between $10,000 and $15,000.  Elopements and pop-up weddings ‚Äì an all-inclusive package that relieves clients of all the planning stress with the officiant, flowers, photographer and d√©cor provided at the venue ‚Äì are even cheaper options, costing as little as $5,000.  For some brides and grooms, it‚Äôs about personal preference for what they want their big day to look like and what makes them comfortable.  ‚ÄúSome couples just really don‚Äôt like being in the limelight so the smaller, more intimate wedding is better for them and that is a comfort zone for them,‚Äù said Lauder.  Curtis Ballance said eliminating public speaking in front of a big crowd did take ‚Äúsome pressure off‚Äù on their big day.  A second marriage or a wedding after giving birth to a child are other reasons why couples go for smaller receptions, planners say.  It‚Äôs also about priorities as some would rather put that extra wedding expense toward other life goals, such as buying a new house, starting a family or spending more on their honeymoon, said Armstrong.  Planning big weddings can be stressful, too, which is why couples are tempted to go the simpler, smaller route, Armstrong added.  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs also a stress factor in planning a bigger wedding. We have couples who are ‚Ä¶ really focused on their professional aspect of their lives. They‚Äôre very busy in their family life, so having the added stress of planning a really big event is not what they want.‚Äù  Hosting a micro wedding also comes with the advantage of using alternative venues, such as restaurants, boutique hotels and Airbnbs that would not be able to accommodate large groups, said Kennedy.  Besides a smaller guest list, e-invites instead of mailed printed invitations are another way that couples are saving their dollars.  They also avoid any design costs by turning to companies that offer a wide range of templated invites online, said Lauder.  Decorations can take up a huge chunk of the wedding budget ‚Äì and that is where an increasing number of people are taking a simpler affordable route, she added.  ‚ÄúWe have seen a large trend in people going more minimalist in their decor as well, and that has really reduced a lot of people‚Äôs budgets.‚Äù  Kay Ballance made her own flower arrangements for her wedding Mihaela/MR Photography.  Kennedy said she has also noticed shorter cocktail hours with the bar wrapping up early, which is a great way to save costs on alcohol.  When it comes to outfits for the day, brides typically want to buy their dress instead of renting but selling afterward ‚Äúdefinitely is on the rise,‚Äù said Lauder.  Kay Ballance bought her dress online for a couple of hundred dollars, while her husband Curtis rented his tux.  More and more couples are also choosing to remain in the same clothes throughout the day ‚Äì moving away from multiple wardrobe changes, for instance, for the ceremony, reception and dance party afterward, said Kennedy.  When you host the wedding can also go a long way into stretching your dollars.  Off-peak months between November and April, weekdays and serving lunch or brunch instead of dinner are great ways to reduce wedding costs, said Armstrong.  ‚ÄúThe season makes a big impact. If you‚Äôre planning a summer wedding when a majority of the other weddings are happening in Ontario, (then) the prices escalate.‚Äù  ¬© 2023 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc.

The Ministry of Culture announced a program of events and activities, which will be held Thursday (June 1), in celebration of the Royal Wedding of His Royal Highness Crown Prince Al-Hussein bin Abdullah II and Miss Rajwa Khaled Al-Saif.  The events, which will begin at 5 pm, will be held across the Kingdom and include live broadcasting of the Royal Wedding, in addition to a variety of activities for children such as face painting, giveaways and music.  Events will also feature folklore shows, patriotic music, live musical performances and fireworks. A single mum is forcing the bride (her sister) to pay for her six-year-old's 'expensive' babysitting costs - otherwise, she's refusing to attend the ceremony altogether  While weddings are most commonly attended by a bride and groom's closest friends and family, it's not uncommon that they may enforce a "no children" policy for the special night.  However, this quickly becomes a dilemma for any parents who have to look at expensive childcare methods for their little ones.  After her sister enforced a strict adult-only policy at her wedding, a woman is forcing the bride to pay the babysitting fee for her child otherwise she's refusing to attend.  Taking to popular forum site Reddit, the woman has sparked a huge debate after claiming it's "ridiculous" that the bride won't pay the costs.  She explained: "I want to be there for my sister and obviously, I'd like to see her get married. But the problem is... I'm a single mum. My son is six and when he's not at school I need to be home watching him."  Image: Getty Images/Tetra images RF) Getty Images/Tetra images RF)  The woman went on: "So being out for hours at a time isn't really in the cards for me right now. My sister's wedding is child-free.  "Since it's taking place in her state, I'd need to commute, and I'd probably have to be gone from my house for two full days. I can't have family watch my son since they'll all be at the wedding. And I don't really have friends who will babysit for two days.  "I contacted my sister and asked if she'd be willing to let my son come to the wedding with me, and explained he couldn't be left alone so young and that I didn't have anyone to watch him. She responded by telling me her 'no children' policy was strict and she wouldn't make exceptions.  "I explained my situation again and said I'd need some form of child care or to bring him with me. I then asked her if she would pay me to hire a nanny or babysitter to watch him.  "She got offended, and said 'children and weddings are both parts of life' and I need to 'just figure it out, it's my kid, my problem.' Which sure that's true, but also... her wedding, her making it a problem by not allowing me to bring my kid.  "I told her she could either pay for my child care or I wouldn't be going to her wedding. Which all she did was call me 'ridiculous' and 'entitled'. She said she shouldn't have to pay for my child and that part of being an adult is knowing how to take care of that kind of thing.  "I think that's ridiculous. Money is tight. Child care is expensive. I can't magically afford for someone to watch my six-year-old and most people would just let me bring him to the wedding.  "My sister says she's definitely not paying for child care, and 'I guess you're not going to the wedding then'," she added.  Seeking advice, the woman wrote: "My whole family is mad at me for 'not being there for my sister'. Am I the a**hole?"  Since sharing her concerns online, the Reddit user's post has raked in over 2,000 comments to date - where people slammed her online for being unreasonable.  One person wrote: "You're the a**hole. I get where you're coming from, but you went about this all wrong. 'I'm sorry, but it's not within my budget to travel so far and also arrange to pay for child care when I get there. I send my best'. Don't ask for handouts from a stressed-out bride."  Meanwhile, someone else agreed: "You're the a**hole. It's no one else's responsibility to pay for your childcare. Completely unreasonable ask."  Do you have a story? We want to hear it! Get in touch at grace.hoffman@reachplc.com

Kate Middleton may be looking forward to attending the royal wedding in Jordan as she and husband Prince William are speculated to attend the ceremony.  Royal Families from across the globe will gather in Jordan to celebrate an extravagant royal nuptials which is to take place on June 1st, 2023, at the Zahran Palace in Amman.  It was announced in September that King Abdullah II and Queen Rania‚Äôs eldest son, 28, is set to wed Saudi Arabian-born architect Rajwa, also 28, after an engagement ceremony at the bride-to-be‚Äôs family home in Riyadh.  Snippets from Queen Rania‚Äôs social media showed ‚Äòsome highlights from Rajwa‚Äôs Henna,‚Äô a symbolic celebration that takes place before a wedding and allows a bride to spend quality time with her female friends and family.  It seems that the Princess of Wales may be eager to attend the wedding ceremony after all since it holds a special place in her heart, via Express UK.  During a tour of the Middle East in 2018 Prince William mentioned his wife‚Äôs childhood spent in the country, telling Save the Children‚Äôs chief executive Rania Malki, ‚ÄúShe loved it here, she really did. She is very upset that I am coming here without her.‚Äù  He later told the press that he would come back to the country along with his wife and children which he did in 2021. Moreover, the family used an image for their Christmas card, which was taken during a holiday to Jordan earlier that year.  The two country‚Äôs royal family seemingly share close ties as Queen Rania and King Abdullah attended the Coronation of King Charles.

Nikola Jokic is arguably the most dominant player in the NBA at this moment, yet the Serbian also has a caring side, something he shows by wearing his wedding ring on his shoe every single time he steps onto the court.  Whilst notoriously clear in sport that wearing jewelry isn't necessarily advised, Jokic has found a way around this by tying the ring to his shoes.  The Denver Nuggets will play in the NBA Finals this year, and this is the biggest ever stage that the Joker will be able to showcase his bizarre ritual on.  Videos taken throughout his career in the United States, the center has been seen tying the ring to his shoes, which is meant to symbolize the fact he is carrying his family with him onto the court.  Back in 2020, Jokic married his high school sweetheart Natalija, and the pair have since had a baby daughter.  Jokic's basketball career is intrinsically linked with his family  Whilst we often see athletes equate sporting success with their relationship with faith and religion, Jokic prefers to focus simply on his family ties.  The powerful center is often seen making gestures to his infant daughter during Nuggets games, with the youngster now being a regular spectator.  He cites the presence of his wife and child at games as a fuel for success, and that has certainly been the case in 2023.  There was a heartwarming display after the Nuggets booked their place in the Finals, dispatching the Los Angeles Lakers, when Jokic made a ring gesture around his finger to signify the pursuit of a championship ring.  His young daughter was then caught on camera returning the gesture in kind to her father on the court.
