Here‚Äôs the thing about TV weddings: It‚Äôs seldom easy to say ‚ÄúI do‚Äù without much ado.  In real life, the officiant might get held up by traffic, or weird cousin Otto and his plus-one (who is she again?) might dance a bit inappropriately at the reception. But the drama tends to be ratcheted up way higher for TV nuptials, making it harder to pull off a sweet ceremony worthy of the couple being celebrated.  With the traditionally popular wedding month of June upon us, TVLine decided it was time to revisit our list of TV‚Äôs best weddings, first published way back in the year 2015. A lot of on-screen vows have been exchanged since then, but only a select few unfolded in storybook (or Storybrooke) fashion.  In our list below, the weddings may not have always gone off without a tiny hitch (or, you know, the intrusion of Nazis from an alternate Earth), but they were memorable affairs tailor-made for the two saying ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù  Review our picks below, then weigh in with your own!  Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. : Jemma and Leopold Image Credit: ABC What began as a very bad day ‚Äî Coulson realized he was dying ‚Äî took a decidedly upward turn when Coulson & Co. surprised Fitz (and us!) with a picture-perfect wedding, to Simmons. The beautiful, drama-free ceremony was timed perfectly to the Marvel series‚Äô 100th episode, and among other things it featured the stealth reveal, at least to viewers, that Deke from the future is FitzSimmons‚Äô grandkid! (Watch video above.)  Beverly Hills, 90210 : Donna and David Image Credit: Everett Collection After Donna lost her virginity to David in Season 7, the couple‚Äôs relationship was an on-and-off roller coaster. Thankfully, they got it together in time for the show‚Äôs series finale.  The Big Bang Theory : Bernadette and Howard Image Credit: Everett Collection Despite Leonard, Sheldon and the rest of the gang totally hogging their friends‚Äô spotlight, Howard and Bernadette‚Äôs rooftop ceremony was romantic, succinct and ‚Äî much like the lovebirds themselves ‚Äî thoroughly quirky.  Bones : Booth and Brennan Image Credit: Fox After nine seasons, the couple‚Äôs vows felt so rich and earned, especially Brennan‚Äôs words (read from a note she wrote to Booth while buried alive years earlier): ‚ÄúHow is it possible that simply looking into your fine face gives me so much joy? Why does it make me so happy that every time I try to sneak a peek at you, you‚Äôre already looking at me? Like you, it makes no sense. And like you, it feels right.‚Äù  Boy Meets World : Cory and Topanga Image Credit: Everett Collection Arguably the most satisfying TV wedding of all time ‚Äî seriously, we followed this couple‚Äôs every step, from their first kiss in middle school ‚Äî Cory and Topanga‚Äôs ceremony also served up one of the most emotional episodes of the series‚Ä¶ even if it wasn‚Äôt technically supposed to be their big day. (Congrats, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Peterman!)  The Brady Bunch : Mike and Carol Image Credit: YouTube screenshot With the classic sitcom‚Äôs very first episode, we began the story of a man named Brady (busy with three boys of his own) and his marriage to a lady named Carol (who was bringing up three very lovely girls). The mayhem that ensued when the girls‚Äô cat got chased around the venue by the boys‚Äô dog, culminating in a wedding cake fiasco, loosened up the about-to-be-blended clans and set the tone for the years to come.  Brooklyn Nine-Nine : Jake and Amy Image Credit: Fox Much like Jake Peralta‚Äôs butt, Amy Santiago‚Äôs wedding vows were ‚Äúda bomb.‚Äù But perhaps even better was hearing wedding officiant Captain Holt admit that it‚Äôd been a true pleasure to watch their ‚Äúdistracting, childish rivalry evolve into a distracting, childish courtship.‚Äù  Brothers and Sisters : Kevin and Scotty Image Credit: Hulu screenshot Not even Scotty‚Äôs disapproving parents could stand in the way of the historic union. (It was the first same-sex commitment ceremony between series regulars to be depicted on network TV.)  Charmed : Leo and Piper Image Credit: Prime Video screenshot Besides the fact that Piper and Leo had to literally defy the heavens in order to form their perfect union, we dare you to find another TV wedding officiated by a damn ghost. No, really, take all the time you need.  Chicago Fire : Casey and Dawson Image Credit: NBC The NBC drama has had its fair share of fancy weddings, which makes the casual but meaningful nature of Casey and Dawson‚Äôs impromptu nuptials ‚Äì they got hitched in the courthouse, wearing their uniforms ‚Äì truly stand out. They simply couldn‚Äôt wait another second.  Chuck : Sarah and Chuck Image Credit: Prime Video screenshot ‚ÄúYou can count on me,‚Äù the spy told his bride. You can also count on smiling like a fool throughout the sweet scene, which even got Casey a little verklempt.  Cougar Town : Grayson and Jules Image Credit: Everett Collection After a magical wedding on the beach, the Cul de Sac crew‚Äôs central couple rode off into the sunset on horseback.  A Different World : Dwayne and Whitley Image Credit: Max screenshot Winners: Dwayne, Whitley and the studio audience, which exploded in catcalls when he stopped the love of his life from marrying another man. Losers: Jilted groom Byron, the bridesmaids (those dresses!) and whoever had to catch Whitley‚Äôs mom when she swooned.  Downton Abbey : Matthew and Mary Image Credit: PBS Before he met his demise (sob!), Matthew and Mary had one elegant and unpredictable wedding. He may not have been sure if his future wife was going to show up, but we had no doubt it was meant to be.  ER : Luka and Abby Image Credit: Everett Collection Luka and Abby didn‚Äôt have a fairytale romance, but they did have a fairytale wedding. Not only did Kovac manage to surprise his bride with an intimate ceremony attended only by their closest friends from County General, but an unprepared Lockhart just so happened to have the perfect poem in mind (‚ÄúI carry your heart in my heart‚Ä¶‚Äù) in lieu of traditional vows.  The Flash : Barry and Iris Image Credit: Courtesy of The CW Soooo wonderful was this wedding ‚Äî a stunning bride and a robust, crossover-fueled guest list! Kara sang ‚ÄúRunning Home to You‚Äù! ‚Äî that we‚Äôre letting it claim a spot even though Nazis from another Earth crashed the proceedings. Besides, Barry and Iris (‚Ä¶and Oliver and Felicity, grr) did say ‚ÄúI do‚Äù when all (meaning the ‚ÄúCrisis on Earth-X‚Äù) was said and done.  The Fosters : Lena and Stef Image Credit: Freeform Following the Supreme Court‚Äôs ruling legalizing same-sex marriage, Lena and Stef pledged their love in a touching ceremony officiated by their parents. Not that we needed a wedding to know the couple was committed to each other.  Friends : Phoebe and Mike Image Credit: Everett Collection Monica and Chandler‚Äôs nuptials were great and all, but Phoeb‚Äôs happy ending was a long time coming and even a snowstorm wasn‚Äôt going to get in the way of it.  Full House : Rebecca and Jesse Image Credit: Everett Collection Jesse‚Äôs touching nuptials were capped off by a romantic performance of The Beach Boys‚Äô ‚ÄúForever,‚Äù accompanied by a large gospel choir and a cheesy-as-all-heck montage of his time with Rebecca.  Game of Thrones : Margaery and Joffrey Image Credit: HBO It ended with the awful Joffrey‚Äôs death, so that‚Äôs a win in our book.  General Hospital : Luke and Laura Image Credit: Everett Collection The 1981 wedding may only be one of TV‚Äôs best ever, but it‚Äôs inarguably daytime TV‚Äòs best ever. Between the popularity of the couple, the lavishness of the affair and the crashers it attracted (Elizabeth Taylor, for Pete‚Äôs sake!), its no wonder the event was ‚Äî and still is ‚Äî the most-watched hour in soap opera history.  Gilmore Girls : T.J. and Liz Image Credit: The WB The renaissance faire-themed affair just reinforced how perfect these two kooks are for each other. Plus, it gave us Luke waltzing with Lorelai, and for that, it edges out Lane and Zack‚Äôs rockin‚Äô reception.  Glee : Santana and Brittany... and Kurt and Blaine Image Credit: Fox Only the Fox series could pull off a spontaneous, double same-sex wedding without making it seem like too much of a stretch. Plus: a group performance from Gloria Estefan, Jennifer Coolidge and Gina Gershon? This was like the Oscars of gay weddings.  Gossip Girl : Blair and Chuck Image Credit: The CW It might have been rushed ‚Äî you know, to make sure it was over before the cops showed up to arrest both the bride and groom ‚Äî but Chuck and Blair‚Äôs wedding also fit perfectly with the couple‚Äôs tumultuous history. They were too cool to even swap traditional vows, simply ‚Äúthree words, eight letters‚Äù from Chuck and ‚Äúone word, three letters‚Äù from Blair. That‚Äôs love.  Grey‚Äôs Anatomy : Arizona and Callie Image Credit: ABC Before hitting one seriously ugly rough patch and splitting up, the pair tied the knot in the stunning outdoors while Bailey, fittingly, officiated.  Hart of Dixie : Zoe and Wade Image Credit: The CW screenshot Never ones to do things the traditional way, Zoe and Wade exchanged sweet vows in the hospital while she was literally being wheeled away to deliver their baby. Funny, romantic and most definitely memorable!  How I Met Your Mother : Lily and Marshall Image Credit: CBS The twosome‚Äôs low-key and touching ceremony before their ‚Äúofficial‚Äù one only made us love them more. Marshmallow + Lilypad 4ever!  I Dream of Jeannie : Tony and Jeannie Image Credit: Everett Collection Midway through its fifth (and what would be final) season, Major Nelson and Jeannie made their love official, though the ceremony faced one hitch: Genies cannot be photographed! Cue a Jeannie ‚Äúrobot‚Äù that Dr. Bellows walked down the aisle in front of photographers, as a campy, robot-ified version of the classic ‚ÄúHere Comes the Bride‚Äù played.  NCIS: Los Angeles : Kensi and Deeks Image Credit: CBS When a buncha bad guys rudely RSVP‚Äôd for Deeks and Kensi‚Äôs big day, Hetty returned from a disappearing act (Linda Hunt had been recuperating from her July 2018 car accident) to literally ‚Äúcrash‚Äù the wedding by mowing down a goon with her Mini Coop. As an added bonus, she then officiated the ceremony!  Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman : Lois and Clark Image Credit: Everett Collection Sure, Lois and Clark‚Äôs wedding took a few tries ‚Äî including one that resulted in Lois getting electrocuted by, we kid you not, Delta Burke as a villain named Myrtle Beech ‚Äî but their super-ceremony (eventually) went off without a hitch. The episode‚Äôs title (‚ÄúSwear to God, This Time We‚Äôre Not Kidding‚Äù) was merely the icing on the cake.  New Girl : Cece and Schmidt Image Credit: Hulu screenshot After having to FaceTime into the service and reception he so painstakingly planned but then missed (don‚Äôt ask), Schmidt formally weds Cece in a gorgeously intimate ceremony at the apartment. Vows about his mispronunciation of common words? Stomping the douchebag jar instead of a glass? We love a show that revels in long-running, jokey details.  The O.C. : Seth and Summer Image Credit: Max screenshot The brief glimpse of the couple‚Äôs long-awaited big day during a flash forward montage is all that‚Äôs needed to bring on the tears. Thankfully, as if sensing the oncoming waterworks, Summer stuck out her tongue as she walked down the aisle, breaking up the hefty emotions.  The Office : Jim and Pam Image Credit: NBC screenshot It‚Äôs hard to pick a highlight ‚Äî everyone dancing down the aisle? Jim and Pam‚Äôs private kodak moment? Them secretly exchanging vows on the boat? ‚Äî but the look of pure happiness and love on the groom‚Äôs face has to be it.  Once Upon a Time : Emma and Hook Image Credit: ABC In the first, 2015 edition of this list, OUAT was represented by Snow and Charming‚Äôs impromptu ‚ÄúLady of the Lake‚Äù-side ceremony from Season 2 (officiated by Lancelot). But years later, the fantasy drama gave us Emma and Killian‚Äôs wedding, which featured vows that spoke to each character‚Äôs journey-to-date, punctuated by the musical episode‚Äôs final performance ‚Äî the duet-turned-all Storybrooke singalong, ‚ÄúHappy Beginning.‚Äù  One Tree Hill : Haley and Nathan Image Credit: The CW Despite getting hitched while still in high school, these lovebirds beat the odds. They even made it to a vow renewal ceremony ‚Äî all before graduation!  The Originals : Jackson and Hayley Image Credit: The CW If you didn‚Äôt swoon when Jackson took Hayley‚Äôs hand and walked her down the aisle ‚Äî a nice change of ritual ‚Äî then you may need to get your heart checked.  Outlander : Jamie and Claire Image Credit: Starz Despite the fact that Claire was marrying Jamie just to save herself from Black Jack, the vows managed to be heartfelt and emotional. And they were followed by an even more memorable wedding night.  Parenthood : Sarah and Hank Image Credit: NBC screenshot Any occasion that gets the entire Braverman clan in one place (and gives an ailing Zeek the chance to walk his daughter down the aisle) is a welcome one. And even though many a Parenthood fan is still mourning the loss of Sarah‚Äôs relationship with Mark, Hank had proven himself more than worthy of his lady‚Äôs love.  Parks and Recreation : Ben and Leslie Image Credit: NBC From the handcrafted dress to their vows ‚Äî ‚ÄúI love you, and I like you‚Äù ‚Äî to Ron walking Leslie down the aisle, it was all absolute perfection.  Pose : Angel and Lil Papi Image Credit: FX Angel and Lil Papi‚Äôs sweet nuptials delivered everything we‚Äôd come to expect from the FX drama: heartfelt emotion, fabulous fashion (even the ring bearer looked like an A-lister!) and a little music, courtesy of Papi‚Äôs surprise performance of All-4-One‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Swear.‚Äù  Rookie Blue : Andy and Sam Image Credit: ABC After six seasons, Andy and Sam finally got their happy ending in the show‚Äôs series finale ‚Äì and it was worth the wait! From the way he called her McNally in his vows to a tearful Andy saying that while she won‚Äôt obey him, she will always hear him, it was so perfectly them.  Saved by the Bell : Zack and Kelly Image Credit: Everett Collection The couple was so iconic, they got their own TV movie, in which the longtime high school sweethearts decided to elope in Vegas before getting a proper ceremony (and a last-minute visit from Jessie!).  Schitt's Creek : Patrick and David Image Credit: Courtesy of Pop TV David and Patrick‚Äôs sweet nuptials were memorable for a multitude of reasons ‚Äî including the fact that it served as the show‚Äôs swan song ‚Äî but Moira taking her role as officiant above and beyond? Absolutely priceless.  Sex and the City : Charlotte and Harry Image Credit: HBO Everything went wrong on the day of Charlotte‚Äôs second wedding, and somehow, it was still perfect. Plus, there has never been a more stunning bride.  Smallville: Clark and Lois Image Credit: The CW Before Clark supersuited up at the close of the two-part series finale, he donned a tux to make Lois his bride ‚Äî meeting her at the start of the aisle to calm some last-minute jitters, and even passing by the spectre of his late father, Jonathan, as they marched to the altar. ‚ÄúEverything OK, Smallville?‚Äù asked Lois. ‚ÄúEverything‚Äôs perfect,‚Äù Clark replied‚Ä¶ albeit prematurely, seeing as his Darkseid-possessed best man, Oliver, would soon waylay things with a gold kryptonite wedding band! What are YOUR favorite TV weddings of all time? Share your picks below!

Grace Kelly's wedding dress took 36 seamstresses three weeks to make  Queen Victoria was buried with her veil that she wore when she married Albert  From Queen Victoria and Albert, Diana and Charles to Meghan Markle and Prince Harry, we've compiled a timeline of Royal Wedding portraits from around the world.  Some of the most notable include the 1840 marriage of Queen Victoria and Albert, who had a wedding cake measuring nine feet tall by 16 inches wide, according to author and historian Kate Williams.  Queen Elizabeth's wedding to Prince Philip was held on on November 20, 1947 at Westminster Abbey in front of 2,000 guests - and they went on to have one of the longest royal marriages of all.  Then came one of the most glamorous weddings of all time - between American actress Grace Kelly and Prince Rainier III of Monaco.  Princess Grace's veil was made up of 90 yards of tulle and had been crafted to ensure that her face would not be obscured from cameras. Her shoes and Juliet cap were decorated with pearls.  Her wedding dress was so exquisite that it took 36 seamstresses three weeks to make, and so beautiful that guests gasped out loud.  1840  Queen Victoria and Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha  An artist's representation of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert on their wedding day in 1840  The couple had a grand wedding, which included a wedding cake measuring nine feet tall by 16 inches wide  1858  Princess Victoria, Princess Royal and Frederick III, German Emperor  A watercolour which shows the wedding ceremony of Princess Victoria, Princess Royal, and Frederick III, German Emperor which took place on 25 January 1858  1862  Princess Alice and Prince Louis of Hesse  Princess Alice was the third child of Victoria and Albert, and she married Prince Louis of Hesse on 1 July 1862. It has been said that the wedding took part in private as it was less than six months after the death of Albert, her father  1863  Alexandra, Princess of Denmark and Edward VII, Prince of Wales  Alexandra, Princess of Denmark with her husband Edward VII, Prince of Wales in 1863  Alexandra (left) is pictured with her new husband Edward VII, Prince of Wales and Queen Victoria (bottom right). Distraught Queen Victoria was still in mourning for Prince Albert and appeared utterly miserable garbed in swathes of matte black  1866  Princess Helena and Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein  Queen Victoria's third daughter Princess Helena married Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein on 5 July 1866 and remained in the UK as Queen Victoria liked to have her daughters nearby  Alexander III of Russia and Maria Feodorovna  Alexander III married Maria Feodorovna (also known as Princess Dagmar of Denmark) on the 9 November 1866 in the Grand Church of the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg, Russia  1871  Princess Louise and John Campbell, Marquess of Lorne  Princess Louise and John Campbell, Marquess of Lorne married on the 21 March 1871 at St George's Chapel  The newlyweds were reportedly happy at first but Queen Victoria's demands on Louise grew as she was secretary, and the couple had several childless years  1874  Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh and The Grand Duchess Marie Alexandrovna of Russia  An artist drawing shows the wedding between Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh and The Grand Duchess Marie Alexandrovna of Russia on the 23 January 1874, they had five children together: Alfred, Marie, Victoria Melita, Alexandra, and Beatrice  1879  Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn and Princess Louise Margaret of Prussia  A drawing of the bridal procession arriving for the wedding between Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn and Princess Louise Margaret of Prussia, March 13, 1879  A drawing of the couple saying their vows before a priest, gathered by their family and friends  1882  Prince Leopold, Duke of Albany and Princess Helen of Waldeck and Pyrmont  The wedding of Prince Leopold, Duke of Albany and Princess Helen of Waldeck and Pyrmont, which took place on 27 April 1882 in St George's Chapel  1885  Princess Beatrice and Prince Henry of Battenberg  The front page of an old newspaper showing Princess Beatrice and Prince Henry of Battenberg walking down the aisle on their wedding day which was on the 12 July 1885  1889  The Duke of Fife and Princess Louise  The Duke and Duchess of Fife at their royal wedding at Buckingham Palace in London in 1889  1893  King George V on his wedding day with his bride Princess Mary of Teck  King George V on his wedding day with his bride Princess Mary of Teck in December of 1893  1895  Tsar Nicholas II of Russia and Alexandra Feodorovna  Tsar Nicholas II of Russia married Alexandra Feodorovna on the 26 November 1895. How Queen Elizabeth eased Camilla‚Äôs fears on her wedding day two decades ago  Camilla was seemingly so overcome with wedding jitters that she fell ill before her wedding to long-time love and the then-Prince of Wales, Charles III almost two decades ago.  Royal author Penny Junor‚Äôs book The Untold Story shed light on the wedding jitter Camilla experienced as her sister Annabel Elliot threatened to wear the wedding dress for her if she refused to get out of bed, via Express UK.  However, the Queen had some kind words to offer which eased some of the fears she had of being unwelcome in the family.  ‚ÄúThey have overcome Becher‚Äôs Brook and The Chair [referencing the Grand National fences at Aintree racecourse] and all kinds of other terrible obstacles. They have come through and I‚Äôm very proud and wish them well. My son is home and dry with the woman he loves,‚Äù the late monarch had said.  In the week leading up to her wedding, Camilla had been run down with a friend, Lucia Santa Cruz, noting that she was not in the best state when the day dawned.  Camilla had four people in her bedroom, including her sister Annabel and daughter Laura, trying to help her get ready and persuade her to leave her bed.  In the moment, Annabel told Camilla, ‚ÄúOK, that‚Äôs all right. I‚Äôm going to do it for you. I‚Äôm going to get into your clothes.‚Äù  At the time, Charles‚Äô two sons, William and Harry, apparently also gave their seal of approval as they were ‚Äú100 percent‚Äù behind their father and stepmother, wishing them ‚Äúall the luck in the world.‚Äù  However, contrary to Prince Harry‚Äôs memoir, Spare, the royal claimed that he and his older brother had begged their father not to marry Camilla.

Both on and off screen the Modern Family cast really is a family, and their real-life love for each other was on full display at Sarah Hyland‚Äôs wedding to Wells Adams last summer. While Hyland and Adams‚Äô wedding had many alums from the ABC comedy on the guest list, one person who had a really big job at the ceremony was Jesse Tyler Ferguson , who officiated for the couple. However, that was a last-minute decision after Ty Burrell had to step down, and the Mitchell actor joked that he ‚Äúcouldn‚Äôt get out of it.‚Äù  For some background, Sarah Hyland‚Äôs wedding was basically a Modern Family reunion , as Jesse Tyler Ferguson, Julie Bowen, Sofia Vergara, Nolan Gould and Ariel Winter were all in attendance. After working together for 11 years the crew grew very close, and are still very tight. One person who wasn‚Äôt there, but was supposed to be, was Hyland‚Äôs TV dad Ty Burell, who had a family emergency, and couldn‚Äôt make it. He was supposed to officiate the wedding, but when he wasn't able to Jesse Tyler Ferguson stepped up to the plate to help out, and he explained what went down on that day on the Jennifer Hudson Show , saying:  Ty Burrell was meant to officiate. I will let people know that. He had a family emergency, so I was his understudy. It came down like, 10 days before the wedding. I did not have any notice. And you can't say ‚Äòno.‚Äô She already knew I was going to the wedding, so it‚Äôs like it‚Äôd be like, ‚ÄòOh, I‚Äôm busy that weekend. I couldn‚Äôt get out of it.‚Äô I adore Sarah, so I was like, ‚ÄòThis means a lot that she‚Äôs asking me to do this, but it‚Äôs a lot of pressure.‚Äô  Considering both the popularity of Modern Family and Sarah Hyland, plus the public‚Äôs love for her and her now-husband Wells Adams, who is the beloved bartender on Bachelor in Paradise, there were a lot of people who were excited to see all the photos, posts and videos from the ceremony. So, I understand why Ferguson may have wanted to jokingly get out of it at first, it‚Äôs a high-stakes event. However, he did officiate, and he did a great job.  He continued to talk to Jennifer Hudson about the ceremony, which also featured A-list guests including Shaun White, Nina Dobrev , Debby Ryan and more, noting how high profile the wedding was. Ferguson said:  It‚Äôs not just like a regular wedding, it‚Äôs a wedding that‚Äôs like, has paparazzi, helicopters flying above us. It‚Äôs going to be in Vogue magazine. I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòJeez, can I start with maybe a low-profile one? No! Right to the top!‚Äô I‚Äôm very good now, so if anyone needs anything.  It was so adorable seeing Wells Adams well up as his ‚Äúperfect person‚Äù walked down the aisle and Jesse Tyler Ferguson beamed in the background. Overall, it seemed like a beautiful ceremony, and to have Hyland‚Äôs beloved co-star officiate the wedding must have made it extra special. Plus, as the actor noted, now he can help out anytime since his first time officiating a wedding was at a pretty big one.

Chris and Diana Mills on their wedding day in 1963 and on their 60th wedding anniversary on Thursday (Image: Sue John)  An Isle of Wight couple celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary on Thursday (May 25) with a surprise party attended by friends and family.  Chris and Diana Mills, from Shanklin, met at the dances held at the Trouville Hotel in Sandown and were married at Yaverland Church in 1963.  Scroll to continue with content Ad ADVERTISEMENT  After a honeymoon in Oxford, the couple spent some of their early married life in Germany with the army.  Chris was a trooper in the 10th Royal Hussars before working various jobs, including as a bakery delivery driver and flat roofer.  Isle of Wight County Press: Married 60 years: Diana and Chris Mills from Shanklin  Married 60 years: Diana and Chris Mills from Shanklin (Image: Sue John)  Diana was a shop assistant and worked as a home help and cook at a residential home in later years.  They have three children, Sue, Dawn and Allan, as well as six grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren and a little dog called Willow.  Family is a very important part of Chris and Diana‚Äôs day-to-day life.  When the family was younger, the couple enjoyed trips away at holiday camps, but in later years have travelled abroad to destinations including Kenya, Gambia, Dominican Republic, Cuba, Spain, France and Greece ‚Äì as well as the occasional cruise and coach holiday.  Chris and Diana celebrated their special day with a surprise party in Sue‚Äôs garden with 48 friends and family, some of whom travelled from the mainland and others who the pair had not seen in a long time.

Luxury Ingredients Don't Belong In A Wedding Menu's Main Course  Planning a wedding is stressful for a multitude of reasons, not the least of which, for many people, is managing expenses. Visions of the picture-perfect day often conflict with the cost of adding luxe details that make an event feel special. Those of us who love food naturally want the meal to be one of the day's highlights, and for this we've got a newsflash: That doesn't mean you have to splurge on spendy ingredients for your main course. Why?  A number of luxury ingredients can leave guests feeling alienated. If guest enjoyment matters at all, including foods that the majority of wedding guests might not like can end up being a waste of money. Luxuries like fresh truffles, caviar, escargot, and foie gras are delectable treats for some, but there are plenty of people who won't eat them. This may be because they don't care for the strong flavor in the case of truffles, they're put off by an ick factor (Hello, caviar and snails), or perhaps they object to the way a food is produced. (Yes, we're looking at you, controversial foie gras.) At the end of the day, spending big bucks on luxuries like these could mean lots of very expensive wasted food.

Lorry Myers  I cried at the wedding. The words were beautiful, just like the bride, and now here I was at the reception, my toes tapping underneath the table.  The bride and my bridesmaid daughter Mariah are childhood friends, so the evening was full of young people loving each other and living their best life. The first dance was over, and now the DJ was luring everyone to the dance floor.  Everyone but me.  Even after two years, I am still learning the ways of widowhood, how to navigate all the ‚Äúfirsts‚Äù that come after the ‚Äúlasts.‚Äù This was the first time I RSVP‚Äôd for one, my first wedding that I had no arm to take and, now, my first dance where I had no one to dance with. Wedding dance music is predictable, thank goodness, because I want to hear all those familiar tunes I have danced to countless times before.  That night, I was content to tap my toes.  The DJ was on it and a mob of young women took over the floor, celebrating their friend and their night out. After that, dads danced with their daughters and little boys practiced their breakdance moves. The line dancers lined up and the two-steppers stepped out.  Then the music shifted to something slow and smooth, and couples automatically floated to the floor and into each other‚Äôs arms. Until that moment, I had not thought about a dance without a dance partner or my past years of slow dancing.  My toes suddenly stopped tapping.  Looking around, the tables were mostly empty as the dancers paired up. There were established couples practiced in their moves from years of dancing together. There were young couples, still new to each other and trying to find their own moves. Then there were a few couples who spent the dance talking to each other.  A slow dance is different with different partners.  When I danced with my dad, I learned that he had a little dip instead of a fourth step. That‚Äôs the way he danced with my mother, so I learned that move too.  My husband Randy liked to turn after every fourth count and took a step back after every third step forward. One hand rested on my lower back pulling me close, and his other hand held mine across his chest.  Those were the days.  My husband preferred slow dancing over fast dancing and waited for a song he knew, something predictable, before he asked. Every song Randy chose to slow dance with me was the same.  They were all love songs.  I was at my table when the DJ played one of those songs. It was the classic about ‚Äúlonely rivers flowing to the sea,‚Äù and suddenly I felt all those things. I looked around and noticed I was the only one sitting ‚Äî everyone else had someone else.  I was by myself.  I saw him out of the corner of my eye; it was Joel, the matron of honor‚Äôs husband and my family‚Äôs friend. Joel is a quiet guy, steady and strong and sure. But that night, he seemed uncertain as he offered me his hand.  ‚ÄúWould you like to dance?‚Äù Joel asked. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt find my wife.‚Äù  With that, I took Joel‚Äôs hand and we danced. The whole time, I smiled, remembering the last time I danced and how safe and protected I felt in this, my first dance. I don‚Äôt know if Joel understood, but when he reached out his hand, I grabbed it like it was a lifeline to the rest of my life.  I don‚Äôt think he will ever know what asking me to dance meant. It was a reminder that life goes on, that people are good, and I am never by myself. That night, Joel saw that my toes had stopped tapping and held out his hand.  That, or his wife was missing and he just wanted to dance.  You can reach Lorry at lorrysstorys@gmail.com.

Rosie Joyce and her husband Justin swapped their wedding outfits on their recovery day.  It was a surprise for Rosie's parents, who actually did the same thing at their own wedding.  Rosie shared the photos and clips of her and her husband recreating the tradition in a viral TikTok.  Top editors give you the stories you want ‚Äî delivered right to your inbox each weekday. Loading Something is loading. Thanks for signing up! Access your favorite topics in a personalized feed while you're on the go. download the app Email address By clicking ‚ÄòSign up‚Äô, you agree to receive marketing emails from Insider as well as other partner offers and accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy  A bride surprised her parents by following in their footsteps and swapping wedding outfits with her husband, and documented the special moment in a viral TikTok.  Rosie Joyce said she and her husband Justin decided to surprise everyone ‚Äì her parents included ‚Äì on the recovery day after their wedding by reversing their wedding outfits. Posted on May 19, the clip already has 10.4 million views, with most users on the platform sharing love for the playful family tradition started by Rosie's parents.  The TikTok, set to Natalie Cole's "This Will Be," begins with several photos of her parents swapping outfits on the recovery day of their wedding. The images show Rosie's mom wearing an oversized black tuxedo and her dad in a white wedding gown, topped off with a veil. The dress featured a sweetheart neckline, puffy sleeves, and a thigh-high slit.  "I grew up obsessed with these photos!" Rosie wrote in the caption of the TikTok.  Later in the clip, she showed videos of how she and her husband swapped their own wedding outfits on the recovery day of their wedding, surprising all of their guests.  Rosie is wearing a black tuxedo decorated with a boutonniere, which is her husband's, who himself appears to be wearing her strapless wedding dress, unbuttoned.  "How did we do? My poor dress," Rosie also wrote in the caption of the clip.  The TikTok goes on to show photos of the couple embracing in their playful outfits and another image of Rosie standing next to her mother. "They were so proud," she added next to a photo of her and her mother.  Fellow TikTokers put their stamp of approval on the wedding outfit surprise. One wrote: "This is such a cool tradition to carry on!! absolutely love this."  "ur mum looked GOOD in that suit it was made for her not ur dad it's decided," another wrote.  One user complimented Rosie rocking her husband's suit, writing that they even had "a sneaking suspicion" she wore it better than him.  "The fact that your new hubby loved the idea shows you found the one," one TikToker wrote. Rosie responded: "Definitely."  Rosie Joyce did not immediately respond to Insider's request for comment.

A change in plans. Clare Crawley and her husband, Ryan Dawkins, planned to hold two wedding ceremonies but several factors got in the way.  ‚ÄúI wanted to get married in Mexico. We both found this spot in Mexico. We were like, ‚ÄòThis is our spot. We‚Äôre going to have this big celebration,‚Äô‚Äù the former Bachelorette, 42, recalled during an appearance on ‚ÄúMost Dramatic Podcast Ever With Chris Harrison‚Äù on Thursday, May 25, episode. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd been waiting forever to get married.‚Äù  She added: ‚ÄúI always wanted to get married on June 21. It‚Äôs [the] summer solstice. I was like, ‚ÄòWhat if she doesn‚Äôt make it to June 21?‚Äô She ended up getting really sick [in the] end of January. And so I said, ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs have a mini little wedding because she won‚Äôt be able to make it to Mexico anyway. A little mini wedding just for her. A special little one for us, for her.‚Äô‚Äù  Crawley‚Äôs mother, Lilia, had previously been diagnosed with dementia, which took a turn for the worse amid her wedding plans. As a result, the couple decided to hold an intimate ceremony with just her mother and Dawkins‚Äô two daughters from a previous relationship as witnesses.  ‚ÄúWe wanted to make it tiny. Everybody [else] was going to come to the big wedding,‚Äù the hairstylist emotionally recalled to host Chris Harrison. ‚ÄúBut my mom ended up getting really, really sick the day before. She wasn‚Äôt able to make it. She‚Äôs OK still, but she was just really sick at the time and couldn‚Äôt leave the nursing home.‚Äù  The couple ultimately decided to go ahead with their scheduled plans, tying the knot in February.  In order to view the video, please allow Manage Cookies  ‚ÄúRyan, by nature, is an event planner, so he planned the whole wedding. I was kind of frozen with, ‚ÄòWhat do we do?‚Äô It was very last-minute stuff and I was so worried about my mom,‚Äù Crawley added on Thursday. ‚ÄúBut he took the reins, he planned everything.‚Äù  She continued: ‚ÄúWe had a little ceremony. We had the best vows to each other, super personal. It was in the spot [where] we had our first kiss. It was just the greatest little spot.‚Äù  The twosome, who got engaged at the RISE Festival in October 2022, confirmed one month earlier that they had started first connected in 2021.  ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt ready to date again,‚Äù The Bachelor Winter Games alum exclusively told Us Weekly in October 2022 of meeting her now-spouse. ‚ÄúThe second that I was single he was like, ‚ÄòLet me take you out.‚Äô And he knew that I was in such a low point and I told him I wasn‚Äôt even ready to go out to dinner.‚Äù  She added at the time: ‚ÄúI needed to take the space to have time to myself to heal. I didn‚Äôt want him to be a rebound.‚Äù  Prior to falling in love with the Mascot Sports CEO, Crawley was briefly engaged to Benoit Beaus√©jour-Savard after meeting on Winter Games in 2018. After the relationship fizzled, she led The Bachelorette season 16 and instantly hit it off with Dale Moss. The former football player, 34, proposed after just 12 days and they left the show early. The now-exes were together on and off until splitting for good in September 2021.

Some young couples are now using TikTok to help plan their weddings and find original ideas.  Traditions like the bouquet toss, favors, and matching bridesmaid dresses are out.  The wedding industry is beginning to see the fallout of this shift away from tradition.  Top editors give you the stories you want ‚Äî delivered right to your inbox each weekday. Loading Something is loading. Thanks for signing up! Access your favorite topics in a personalized feed while you're on the go. download the app Email address By clicking ‚ÄòSign up‚Äô, you agree to receive marketing emails from Insider as well as other partner offers and accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy  Ashley Klimper has been spending a couple hours a week on TikTok to help plan her wedding.  She wanted to keep her costs under $10,000, so an event planner wasn't in her budget. That meant "wedding TikTok" ‚Äî with its dancing groomsmen and videographers turned influencers ‚Äî was the next best thing.  "We can't afford all those special vendors but since they're giving away their secrets, I write them down," said the 25-year-old, who's getting married in June. "Really, everything's on TikTok."  In this tears-of-joy-drenched corner of the internet, business owners, planners, and fellow brides share their tips. Klimper found ideas for meticulous day-of schedules, entrance and recessional songs, signs she could design on Canva, and Jimmy Choo-inspired, DIY pearl-encrusted platform heels. What more could she need?  Not much, it seems. Though Klimper is getting married on rolling farmland, you won't find any burlap decor or Mason jars. "That's a big no-no," she said. "I hate rustic weddings."  Instead, she's aiming for an "elegant secret garden" vibe, she said. There are peonies and rosebushes on the property and she'll place vintage, floral-embroidered handkerchiefs on each seat for the ceremony.  Klimper hopes to make her wedding unique, with touches that bring her and her fianc√©'s personalities to life. "We're very fun and a little quirky," she said.  Brides and grooms have always wanted to personalize their weddings, but now they're getting their inspiration from TikTok. To make their nuptials memorable, couples are going after viral ‚Äî and sometimes cringey ‚Äî moments like couples dapping at the altar or turning their first kiss into a skit, this generation's version of flash-mob dances down the aisle.  That quest for originality is proving difficult for the old guards of establishment weddings: The companies that sell pulled-from-a-catalog formalwear and traditional jewelry are falling behind in a TikTok world. David's Bridal ‚Äî once the go-to for affordable bridal and bridesmaid dresses ‚Äî filed for bankruptcy in April after struggling to appeal to modern brides. And Signet Jewelers, the country's largest jeweler, has seen ring sales slump alongside a drop in engagements.  Businesses that want to survive the social reboot of weddings will have to adapt or risk becoming ‚Äî like leg-of-mutton sleeves ‚Äî a faded nuptial fad.  Redefining the 'perfect day'  Weddings also look different for what they're omitting. For example: The bouquet toss is dead.  "I think it's really mean to put all women in a room and fight for who's gonna get married next," one creator said in a TikTok.  In its place, couples are throwing T-shirts to their guests or gifting the bouquet to the couple who's been married longest. All this change comes as the definition of a wedding ‚Äî and who gets to have one ‚Äî has evolved in just the past decade. Ceremonies are changing, too, as religious practices become less common. Couples are asking friends to officiate, using gender-neutral scripts, having a flower man instead of a flower girl, and doing group vows. Even the towering, tiered cakes are being replaced with dessert boards or ice cream.  "Couples are now seeking the freedom to celebrate their weddings the way that feels most authentic to them," said Vishal Joshi, the cofounder and CEO of the wedding-planning platform Joy.  "Many don't want to be defined by the overly romanticized, traditional, and costly expectations of their wedding," he continued. "So it is time for us in the wedding industry to expand the definition of what a perfect day means."  While planning her May wedding, Melanie Breault, 34, found herself trying to pull off a delicate balance between her family's expectations and the creativity she desired. "There was no way that my family was going to be OK with us not doing printed invitations," she said.  But she was able to subvert tradition in other ways. Instead of a veil, she wore a cape. For favors, the couple gave their guests scratch-off tickets.  Klimper plans to do favors her own way, too. She's asked an artist friend to paint watercolor portraits of guests during cocktail hour.  "They'll have this little cute picture of what they're wearing for the day and they'll have it forever," she said. "Favors are kind of going out of style. They're just not needed."  Many couples have eliminated favors altogether because they don't feel obligated to fork over even more money.  "We're just calling the alcohol that we're giving everybody our favor," said Stephanie Kirk, 30, who is getting married in July. "We're giving guests something that they're actually wanting, which is probably a free glass of wine."  Some couples have decided to forgo a formal wedding party as well. Klimper designated her "bridal besties" and her fianc√© has a "groom's crew," but they won't stand with the couple during the ceremony or wear matching outfits. Instead, they've asked all 40 of their guests to wear shades of blue, which is the couple's wedding color palette.  Grace Lee, the founder and CEO of the bridal brand Birdy Grey, is seeing a shift toward unconventional wedding-party looks. Instead of matching pastel chiffon dresses, more brides are going maximalist and mixing fabrics, styles, colors, and patterns. That's why Birdy Grey is introducing a collection of prints next year.  "Gone are the days of the same bridesmaid dress in the same color, in the same silhouette, having six women wear the same thing," Lee said. "People are just getting a little more creative."  Companies are using TikTok to stay relevant  David's Bridal's bankruptcy is showing other companies in the wedding industry that those who don't adapt to modern couples could follow a similar fate.  "Historically, the wedding industry has held tight to tradition without fully acknowledging the change in times and we are seeing it finally catch up to them," Joshi, the founder of Joy, said.  Adrienna McDermott spent nine years in the wedding industry before starting a marketing agency for wedding professionals called Ava and the Bee. She's found that young millennials and Gen Zers want to feel connected to the vendors they book for their weddings.  "A decade ago, when I was first starting out in the industry, they were relying more on wedding expos or The Knot and WeddingWire," she said. "But we're seeing a lot of them are turning to social platforms and websites to really get a closer understanding of their vendors."  If a company like David's Bridal can't keep up with the modern bride, there are other brands that are happy to grab the business.  When news of the bankruptcy broke, Lee said Birdy Grey's website traffic spiked. "The lead time for a bride to decide to buy a bridesmaid dress from us is pretty long, so we're just starting to see the effects," she said. "But if you just look at pure site traffic, we've definitely seen a huge bump." Birdy Grey declined to share traffic figures with Insider.  When she launched her company in 2017, Lee said it was "the epitome of an Instagram brand," and she was spending $10 a day on Facebook and Instagram ads. "We were able to drive $2 million revenue in our first year," she said.  Today, Birdy Grey's digital-marketing strategy is a combination of paid search and paid social. But as the company builds brand awareness, more customers are coming through word of mouth.  And then there's TikTok.  "We've gone viral a couple times, and let me tell you, TikTok works," she laughed. "You'll see it reflected in site traffic and sales that same day."  While the brand creates its own content, customer tutorials and testimonies perform the best. One video in particular ‚Äî of a customer picking bridesmaid dresses ‚Äî went viral and led to more fabric-swatch sales.  "It really opened up my eyes for the power of TikTok," Lee said. "The marrying generation is now Gen Z so I feel like there's a subset of people who are completely skipping Instagram and going to TikTok to plan their weddings."

Wedding Venue In Houston, The Bell Tower on 34th, Launches Inclusive Packages  The Bell Tower on 34th, a luxury wedding venue in Houston, near The Woodlands, has announced their new customizable packages for large wedding parties.  Houston, Texas--(Newsfile Corp. - May 27, 2023) - The Bell Tower on 34th announced that they now offer event packages for wedding parties of over 175 guests, allowing clients to benefit from the private use of a large-capacity venue with different spaces for the ceremony, post-ceremony canapes and cocktails, and reception.  More information is available at https://thebelltoweron34th.com  Wedding Venue In Houston, The Bell Tower on 34th, Launches Inclusive Packages  To view an enhanced version of this graphic, please visit:  https://images.newsfilecorp.com/files/8814/167656_98e1178114d74af8_001full.jpg  The Bell Tower on 34th explains that the new customizable wedding packages were introduced in response to the increasing popularity of large wedding parties. The historic Mediterranean hacienda-style wedding venue offers couples their choice of indoor and outdoor spaces, depending on their personal preferences, the number of guests, and the style of their wedding.  For those brides who want a ceremony with a view, they recommend their outdoor venues with a garden setting that can also be used for post-ceremony bridal photos. Then, The Bell Tower on 34th recommends large parties make use of their spacious master ballroom. The venue's interiors with vintage-style marble floors, high ceilings, and grand staircases can also be used for the newlyweds' photo session, as well as group photographs.  With their new wedding packages for large parties, The Bell Tower on 34th can offer brides an executive chef and catering team and an event planner and coordinator who can design the event including d√©cor, florals, music, lighting, and more. Added package features for large weddings include valet parking and additional rooms for the bride to get ready in before the wedding.  Angela Nicholson Igo, the property's VP/Director of Marketing and Advertising said, "The Bell Tower on 34th has the perfect space for stylish weddings and we now have plenty of room to accommodate those classic Texas-sized grand extravaganzas."  More details can be found at https://thebelltoweron34th.com/wedding-venues-in-houston.  Contact Info:  Name: Roger Igo  Email: roger@bell34.com  Organization: The Bell Tower on 34th  Address: 901 West 34th Street, Houston, TX 77018, United States  Website: https://thebelltoweron34th.com  To view the source version of this press release, please visit https://www.newsfilecorp.com/release/167656

A mom has been criticized for wearing a $5,215 white wedding dress to her daughter‚Äôs big day.  The Norma and Lily Couture gown was listed for sale on the Facebook marketplace after the wedding, labeled an ‚Äúevening mother of the bride dress‚Äù.  The mom was also seen with her daughter in a white gown in the photos.  The photos were reposted on a ‚Äúwedding shaming‚Äù Facebook group with the caption ‚Äú$8,000 [$5,215 USD] mother of the bride dress ‚Ä¶ Ma‚Äôam, that is a wedding dress.‚Äù  Many users were stunned by the frock and couldn‚Äôt believe the price.  ‚ÄúOh god, it has a train as well,‚Äù one wrote.  ‚ÄúDefinitely thought this was a wedding dress. Yikes!‚Äù another said.  ‚Äú$8,000 [$5,215 USD]?! Oh, did all the audacity cost extra?‚Äù a third person wrote.  ‚Äò‚ÄôYou just know she was bridal dress shopping with her daughter and saw this dress, and immediately bought it before anyone could stop her,‚Äù a fourth person said.  Commenters were swift to put the woman in her place. via News.com.au  One person commented, ‚ÄúShe wouldn‚Äôt be allowed at my wedding, I don‚Äôt care who she is.‚Äù  ‚ÄúMy daughter would have killed me if I bought that for her wedding,‚Äù one mom wrote.  Others defended the mother of the bride, explaining a little-known cultural tradition.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs quite common for Lebanese mothers to wear white dresses like this to their daughter‚Äôs weddings,‚Äù one woman said.  ‚ÄúNorma and Lily are one of the top Lebanese designers in the industry ‚Äì I‚Äôm surprised she only paid $8000 [$5,215 USD] for this.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThis is a cultural thing in Lebanon. I‚Äôve only ever attended one Lebanese wedding and I was shocked when I saw the mother of the bride in a white dress,‚Äù a second person revealed.  ‚ÄúWhere I‚Äôm from, that‚Äôs asking for a strategic red wine spill from a bridesmaid.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the same with Thai weddings,‚Äù another shared.  ‚ÄúI was horrified when my stepmother wore white ‚Äì until I realized the mother of the groom followed a similar custom.‚Äù

CLEVELAND, Ohio ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd end up doing a few columns on weddings, but it‚Äôs a topic that connects with readers. In the near future, I will use some of the responses from my previous column about the price of weddings ‚Äì and also having the courage to break off an engagement, regardless of how it looks to others.  But I love this from Ann Heyward:  ‚ÄúA wedding is often the first real exercise in making decisions together as a couple. Don‚Äôt follow the expectations of others, especially from social media. Think about how to have the day reflect your values as a couple.‚Äù  Maybe it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm male and dense about these things, but it never occurred to me that the wedding ‚Äúis the first exercise in making decisions as a couple.‚Äù But it is, at least in terms of being the first major decision after you agree to marry each other.  You can either plan your wedding, or let others impose their will on you.  A warning sign is if one person wants a huge, elaborate and expensive wedding, and the other wants to keep it small, simple and yes ‚Äì to be kind ‚Äì frugal.  If this can‚Äôt be resolved without one party feeling trampled, look out.  Or if both parties agree on the type of wedding, but they can‚Äôt withstand the pressure from other family members to do it their way ‚Äì trouble will probably follow.  Here‚Äôs the disclaimer: Suppose both parties want a big wedding but also want the parents to pay for it. Suppose the parents can‚Äôt or won‚Äôt do it ‚Äì that‚Äôs something the couple needs to resolve. Too many young couples expect someone else to take on the cost of an expensive wedding.  The average wedding costs $30,000. One man wrote me that he paid for two weddings, combined cost was $90,000. If people want to and can afford it ‚Äì wonderful. But the marriage has to be about so much more than the wedding day.  ONCE UPON A TIME  Roberta and I knew each other nearly four years before we were married. We met in German class during my freshman year at Hiram College. A year later, my father was laid off. I transferred to Cleveland State to live at home. The idea was to save tuition costs and work while getting my degree in secondary education with a social studies major and English minor.  Roberta is two years older. We stayed in touch after she graduated with a biology degree and worked as a laboratory technician at Metro General Hospital in Cleveland.  After graduating from CSU, I sent out at least 50 resumes with copies of stories that I wrote while working part-time at the old Cleveland Press. I also sold three stories to the old Plain Dealer Sunday Magazine while in college.  This was in the typewriter days. And who typed out all those cover letters and resumes?  One guess.  The same woman who has lived with me for the last 45 years, serving as the first edit on my books and many of my stories.  We were sort of unofficially engaged. When I received a job offer from the Greensboro (N.C.) News-Record, I moved south. Within a few weeks, I knew we needed to get married.  But I also became fearful. My parents had a stormy marriage. My mother knew Roberta well and loved her, but she also remembered being an 18-year-old bride who married quickly to my father as World War II broke out.  She wanted me to wait. Roberta and I knew each other far better than my parents did when they were married. Finally, Roberta pushed me over the finish line: Get married, or we‚Äôre done.  PLANNING THE WEDDING  I don‚Äôt recall a long discussion about our wedding. I wanted three things:  Keep it small. Get married in a church. Have a chocolate wedding cake.  Roberta was on board for that. We were married in St. Clement‚Äôs Episicol Church, her home church in Greenville, Pa. Her mother, Elizabeth Monroe, took over the wedding. Roberta is a no-frills person. To her, smaller is better.  The guest list was about 20. Her mom made Roberta‚Äôs dress. Her veil was handed down from several generations of women in her mother‚Äôs family.  I was married in what now looks like an awful gaudy 1970s style green sportcoat. Roberta mentioned we had to find a green pair of pants to match that dreadful coat‚Ä¶which she did. YIKES!  No members of our wedding party were told to wear anything except what they wanted. Even in our early 20s, we knew the wedding was about making a commitment to each other ‚Äì not a style statement to impress others.  My mother-in-law secured the church and had a small reception at the Greenville Country Club.  That was it. My guess is the cost could not have been much more than $1,500.  And yes, we had chocolate cake!  ‚ÄúThe color may have faded from the Plutos‚Äô wedding photo (thankfully, for Terry‚Äôs sake?) but their love for each other remains as vibrant as that day in 1977. Courtesy, Terry Pluto  YES, 45 YEARS!  I received this email from Gwen Smith, who also was married in 1977 ‚Äì the same year that I married Roberta.  ‚ÄúWe paid for most of the wedding...parents contributed what they could. We had a Christmas wedding (Dec. 30) and saved on church flowers.  ‚ÄúMy bridesmaids made their gowns and capes. I made and decorated their fur muffs. Groomsmen wore boutonnieres of holly my husband got from his boss‚Äôs holly farm. I made a large silk rose and pearl rosary to wrap around Mother Mary‚Äôs hands at the Pieta statue.  ‚ÄúOur invitations were printed on Christmas cards. We came down the aisle to ‚ÄòOh Come All Ye Faithful,‚Äô and ‚ÄòOh Come, Oh Come Emmanuel‚Äô was the Communion hymn. Because Elvis Presley died that year, music before the ceremony included ‚ÄòI Can‚Äôt Help Falling in Love With You.‚Äô Barbra Streisand‚Äôs ‚ÄòEvergreen‚Äô was the reflection hymn.  ‚ÄúI wore my mother‚Äôs dress and my Communion veil ..both a little altered. People were amazed at the beauty of it all. It is a night we reminisce about often after 45 years....magical!‚Äù  Maybe these stories sound like they come from another era, but I present them not to tell you what to do. Rather, to present an alternative to the wedding industrial complex that sends many couples and their parents into major debt even before anyone says ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù

Sign up for our Daily Newsletter for the latest local news straight to your inbox  The schools which will receive government money for building improvements over the next year have been named - and you can search to see which ones in your area will benefit. The government announced on Monday that 859 schools will be receiving the latest round of funding to improve the condition of their buildings.  A total of ¬£456m will be spent on over 1,000 separate projects across England between 2023 and 2024. The Condition Improvement Fund is awarded annually to academies, sixth-form colleges and voluntary-aided schools to ensure that their buildings are safe and in good working order.  The projects include works such as roof repairs, fire safety enhancements, new boilers, and rewiring. You can search to see which schools in your area will be affected and what work they will receive, using our interactive map.  Simply type in your postcode to zoom into your area where all of the schools appear as a pin.  Eligible academies, sixth-form colleges and voluntary-aided (VA) schools can apply for capital funding from the Condition Improvement Fund (CIF) in an annual bidding round. The Department for Education says the schemes are chosen on the basis of address significant condition needs.  This means keeping education providers‚Äô buildings safe and in good working order. This includes funding projects that address health and safety issues, building compliance and buildings in poor condition. The fund also supports a small number of expansion projects. These are for academies, sixth-form colleges and VA schools rated good or outstanding by Ofsted that can demonstrate a need to expand.

Mismatched Bridesmaid Dress Trend Promotes Sustainability (A Little Individuality Doesn't Hurt Either)  It's exciting to work closely with your friend, the bride-to-be, on helping them decide on their special dress, their romantic wedding hairstyle, and the perfect bridesmaid gown for yourself and the whole crew ‚Äî especially when you share a similar enough taste in color and design. Often, though, it can be a challenge choosing one single dress design and color, as everyone's body shape and tastes are different. This is partly the reason why so many brides are now opting for mismatched dresses.  Mismatched bridesmaid dresses are a raging hot trend and allow everyone's individuality to shine ‚Äî and depending on the style or color, it may be easier to visualize individual gowns as having a second life beyond the wedding. They can look more ready-to-wear than traditional gowns, especially if they're a midi length, although floor-length gowns can easily be repurposed as well. Best of all, the mismatched trend may prevent you from having to speak up about a wedding party outfit you hate.  Traditionally, bridesmaids pay for their own dresses. The Knot says the average dress costs $130, though it can be higher based on where you live and the formal or casual nature of the wedding. Add alterations from $30 to $100, and the cost of shoes, accessories, hair, and makeup all add up to a significant investment. This is why it's ideal to invest in a dress you can wear again or repurpose somehow. And besides, no one wants to thoughtlessly toss more clothes into a landfill.

A bride got a surprise of a lifetime during her wedding when she was able to dance with not just her husband, but her bias as well.  This newlywed's photo during their first dance went viral for all the cute reasons‚Äîthe groom, Anton surprised his wife, Pat during their first dance by seemingly impersonating her K-pop bias, Jeonghan of Seventeen, who is also wearing a suit, as seen in a cutout photo.  Anton and Pat del Rosario shared to PhilSTAR L!fe that they are both fans of Seventeen since 2021. The latter shared that Jeonghan is her ultimate bias because of his visuals and personality.  ‚ÄúI find Jeonghan's visuals insane, especially after seeing him live when they held concerts here in the Philippines. I also love his personality!‚Äù she told L!fe. ‚ÄúI [also] enjoy watching their variety shows.‚Äù  Looking back to their special moment, Pat couldn‚Äôt help but laugh at her husband‚Äôs gimmick.  ‚ÄúI literally knelt down on the floor laughing. I was laughing so hard the entire time,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut of course, we still had our special moment after he placed down the Jeonghan hanger,‚Äù she added.  She also shared how supportive her husband is to her fangirling life ever since.  ‚ÄúHe doesn't mind me fangirling or buying K-pop merch as long as it will not take up too much of my time and that I don't forget my other priorities,‚Äù she said.

Jennifer Lopez in "Selena." Warner Bros  Jennifer Lopez's career is filled with impressive performances.  From "Selena" to her "The Wedding Planner," we highlighted her 11 best performances and ranked them.  Her performance in "Hustlers" is her best performance to date.  11. Lopez plays documentary filmmaker Terri Flores, who gets more than she bargains for when shooting in the Amazon rain forest in "Anaconda."  Scroll to continue with content Ad ADVERTISEMENT  Jennifer Lopez in "Anaconda." Columbia Pictures  Lopez is front and center in this cult classic, playing a filmmaker who finds herself going up against a giant anaconda with her crew (Ice Cube, Owen Wilson, Eric Stoltz) and a creepy snake hunter (Jon Voight).  Despite the silly premise, Lopez completely leans into the lead role, which marked one of the first in her career.  10. She plays superstar Kat Valdez who falls for a regular guy in "Marry Me."  Owen Wilson and Jennifer Lopez in "Marry Me." Universal  In one of her most recent rom-coms, Lopez plays a pop star who dumps her celeb boyfriend after being embarrassed in front of millions. She then decides to start a relationship with a regular guy, played by Owen Wilson.  Lopez doesn't hold back in showcasing how her Kat character has to navigate the toils of celebrity, which oftentimes mirrors scenarios Lopez herself has dealt with in her real life.  9. Lopez plays no-nonsense dance instructor Paulina in "Shall We Dance?"  Jennifer Lopez in "Shall We Dance?" Miramax Films  Though the movie was a box-office disappointment, the Paulina role showcased not just Lopez's growing comedic talents but her dramatic chops as she holds her own opposite Richard Gere and Susan Sarandon.  8. As Mary Fiore, Lopez shines in the rom-com ‚ÄúThe Wedding Planner.‚Äù  Matthew McConaughey and Jennifer Lopez in "The Wedding Planner." Archive Photos / Getty Images  Playing San Francisco's best wedding planner, Lopez's Mary Fiore character is similar to many of the characters she was playing in the early 2000s ‚Äî someone dedicated to her job, but who is also a sucker for love.  Starring opposite Matthew McConaughey, the pair serve up one of her best performances in the genre.  7. Lopez plays Charlie, who is up against a mean soon-to-be mother-in-law played by Jane Fonda in "Monster-in-Law."  (L-R) Jane Fonda and Jennifer Lopez in "Monster-in-Law." Monster in Law/New Line Cinema  Here's another one where the movie may not be the best, but Lopez's performance is one that can't be ignored in her filmography.  Once again playing love-sick in a rom-com, the nice twist in this one is the biting comedy she has opposite Fonda.  6. She plays Slim Hiller, who is an abused wife who fights back in the thriller "Enough."  Michael Apted's "Enough." Columbia Pictures  Known best at the time for her romantic comedies, Lopez changed things up in a major way when she played Slim, a woman on the run from her abusive husband (Billy Campbell).  Things are really turned up a notch when she finally fights back against him.  5. Playing psychologist Catherine Deane in "The Cell," Lopez delivers one of the most underappreciated performances of her career.  Jennifer Lopez in "The Cell." New Line Cinema  In this trippy thriller, Lopez plays a child psychologist who has to team with an FBI agent, played by Vince Vaughn, as they use VR to go into the mind of a serial killer.  The movie is known for its amazing production and costume design, but it also features a fantastic performance by Lopez that rarely gets recognized.  4. As Marisa Ventura in "Maid in Manhattan," Lopez gives her best performance in a rom-com.  Story continues  Jenifer Lopez and Ralph Fiennes in "Maid in Manhattan." Columbia Pictures  While working as a maid in a swanky New York City hotel, a single mother (Lopez) falls for a guest at the hotel (Ralph Fiennes).  Lopez delivers with both comedy and emotion.  This is definitely her best performance to date out of all her romantic comedies.  3. She is fantastic as U.S. Marshal Karen Sisco in "Out of Sight."  Jennifer Lopez in "Out of Sight." Universal Pictures  From the red-hot connection she has with costar George Clooney, to the perfect delivery playing a character created by crime-fiction icon Elmore Leonard, Lopez is perfect in the Karen Sisco role in this caper movie directed by Steven Soderbergh.  2. Playing musician Selena Quintanilla-P√©rez in "Selena," Lopez found her breakout role.  Jennifer Lopez in "Selena." Warner Bros.  In chronicling the rise and tragic death of Selena Quintanilla-P√©rez, who was known as the queen of Tejano music, Lopez showcases everything that would turn her into a global sensation herself, from her acting abilities to her dancing and singing.  The performance would earn her a Golden Globes nomination, but more importantly, catapult her to stardom.  1. Lopez's performance as Ramona Vegas in "Hustlers" is a tour-de-force.  Jennifer Lopez stars in "Hustlers." STX Entertainment  In this movie that chronicles how a group of strippers in the early 2000s stole money from their rich Wall Street customers by drugging them, Lopez delivers the best performance of her career to date.  As the leader of the group, Ramona Vegas, Lopez commands the screen as she formulates her mini criminal empire, leading to a lavish lifestyle that ends as quickly as it began.  Lopez's amazing confidence in her performance makes this movie so fun to watch.  It led to Lopez earning another Golden Globes nomination (her first since "Selena") and an unfathomable Oscar nomination snub that still puzzles us to this day.  Read the original article on Insider

KOURTNEY Kardashian and Kim Kardashian have posed together for a rare pic amid their bitter feud.  Kourtney, 44, recently attended one of her husband Travis Barker's, concerts as he is in the midst of touring with his band, Blink-182.  4 Kourtney Kardashian posed with her sister Kim for a rare pic Credit: Instagram/kourtneykardash  4 On Saturday, Kourtney shared a variety of photos on Instagram Credit: Instagram/kourtneykardash  In a new carousel of photos posted on Saturday, the mother-of-three shared pics of her sightseeing while in Washington D.C, kissing Travis onstage, and even a selfie with her sister, Kim, 42.  In the pic, the sisters were spotted making kissy faces while backstage.  In a sneak peek of the upcoming season of The Kardashians, they teased a possible feud between Kim and Kourtney.  Even though season three just premiered last Thursday, the family drama is only getting started.  In clips released by Hulu, Kim and Kourtney appeared to be feuding.  In one sneak peek, sister Kendall Jenner asked Kim if she talked to Kourtney about Milan.  Kourtney angrily accused Kim of using her wedding as a "business opportunity."  Kim asked, "She's mad at me?"  In a confessional interview, sister Khloe said Kourtney was "livid."  "She felt like her wedding vibes were, like, stripped from her," Kendall said during a conversation between her and younger sibling Kylie.  "I'm really confused how this narrative came into her head," Kim explained at the time.  "I couldn't have been more mindful," Kim admitted to Khloe in another clip.  "I said 'Don't do anything that Kourtney wore to her wedding,'" Kim explained.  "I see both sides," Kendall admitted and Kylie agreed.  "People think it's a misunderstanding. It's not," Kourtney said.  "It's who she is to her core," Kourtney admitted in a clip.  ADDRESSING THE DRAMA  Earlier this month, Kim was a special guest on the Today Show to discuss the newest season.  Host Savannah Guthrie asked: "After all these years, are you ever like, 'I think I'm done with showing everyone this part of my life.'"  The reality TV star replied: "When we signed up for this we wanted to always be super open and honest and there's obviously different seasons where some people feel like they just have some boundaries and want to protect some things and then other people want to open up and share way more.  "I'm so blessed that there's so many of us that we can always respect each other's space."  Kim confessed: "This season was probably one of my - out of filming Keeping Up With the Kardashians or The Kardashians - this season was probably my most emotional and frustrating internally with family, that I haven't really seen or experienced before."  The Today personality asked: "Why is that? They talk about some tension between you and your sister Kourtney over her wedding. Is that the source of it?"  "Yeah - and we've been there before and we'll always be okay. We're always family, that's how we were raised. But I'm also proud that everyone's really vulnerable because I'm sure so many other families have gone through similar things.  "Maybe on different levels or experiences but I'm proud that we're still so open and still driven to show and share so much," Kim admitted.  Savannah then asked Kim if there's an "aftermath" when she has arguments with her family once the episodes finally air.  "Yeah there's different cycles, you know you film it and we think we're good, and we make up and then you edit it and I'm seeing all the things she's saying about me behind my back and she's seeing all the things I'm saying about her behind her back.  "The tension rises all over again, and then you have to wait more months for the audience to see it and get everyone else's opinions. So it is a cycle, I think I like to look at it as therapy.  "But it gets really tricky and really emotional. But at the end of the day, we really love sharing our life and I don't see that changing anytime soon," she closed.  4 During many teasers for The Kardashians, Kourtney was 'livid' at Kim for using her wedding as a 'business opportunity' Credit: Getty

Tamannaah Bhatia and Vijay Varma‚Äôs relationship rumours have been making headlines for a long time now. While the two actors have not confirmed or denied their dating reports as of now, there have been several instances when the Darlings actor has been asked about his link-up. Vijay Varma has flown to Abu Dhabi for IIFA. At one of the event‚Äôs red carpets, when a reporter asked him if he was going to break any good news, Vijay Varma had an interesting response.  In a clip that is doing the rounds of social media, a reporter can be heard asking the actor, ‚ÄúKya andar aap koi khushkhabri sunane waale ho?(Are you going to share any good news at the event?)'". Vijay Varma promptly replied with a blushing face, ‚ÄúHaan mein pet se hu dosto. Aur haan I am going to deliver a beautiful project very soon."  Last month, Tamannaah and Vijay were spotted out on a date night in Mumbai, and they were seen exiting the venue in the same vehicle. Vijay Varma was driving the car, while Tamannaah was sitting beside him. Tamannaah wore a white tank top with two-tone grey pants and matching shoes. She kept her hair open and chose to go with a sans-makeup look. In contrast, the Mirzapur 2 actor donned a grey checkered shirt with a black T-shirt. As they departed in the car, the two even waved to the photographers present.  Previously, Tamannaah was questioned about the speculation concerning her rumoured relationship with Vijay. While speaking with Hindustan Times, the Baahubali actress stated, ‚ÄúWe have done a film together. Such rumours keep going around. Clarifying all of them is just not necessary. I have nothing more to say about it.‚Äù  Rumours about Vijay and Tamannaah‚Äôs dating life began circulating when they were reportedly seen celebrating the New Year together. Earlier, they have been seen together on multiple occasions, such as Diljit Dosanjh‚Äôs concert in October and a fashion event in November of last year.  Meanwhile, Vijay Varma‚Äôs new web series titled Dahaad has released. It has been created by well-known filmmakers Zoya Akhtar and Reema Kagti. The 8-episode series, directed by Reema Kagti and Ruchika Oberoi, boasts of an impressive cast featuring Sonakshi Sinha, Gulshan Devaiah, Sohum Shah, Manyuu Doshi, and others in significant roles. The series is streaming on Prime Video.
