Share your email to get soaps interviews, spoilers from the Star  Coronation Street are known for their impressive weddings and grand gestures on the ITV Cobbles.  And fans are in a treat next week as Gemma Winter prepares to walk down the aisle in style to tie the knot to her childhood sweetheart Chesney Brown.  Viewers know little about the plans for the happy couple‚Äôs big day, but they fan-favourite character has already been dropping hints that it is going to be an unmissable event.  READ MORE: Corrie's Chris Fountain supported by co-stars as he issues health update after stroke  But she‚Äôs not the only bride set to go down in ITV history, with other memorable weddings on the cobbles including Les Battersby and Cilla Brown dramatic nuptials, Steve McDonald‚Äôs impressive seven marriages and not forgetting Deirdre and Ken‚Äôs heartbreaking wedding day.  As the fiery redhead puts the final finishing touches on her impressive gown, Daily Star has taken a deep dive inside some of the wildest engagements and dramatic weddings in the history of the long-running soap.  Sally pops the question to Tim  (Image: ITV)  One memorable proposal which must make the list is fan-favourite couple Sally and Tim Metcalfe and the countless times they did it.  When Sally and Tim first clocked eyes on one another back in 2013, not even Barlow‚Äôs Bookies would have put odds on the couple making a go of it.  Yet 10 years later not only are they still together, but they are one of Coronation Street‚Äôs most popular couples.  (Image: ITV)  The couple first got engaged by accident when Sophie‚Äôs girlfriend Maddie spotted Tim coming out of the jewellers and got the wrong end of the stick.  Months later, Tim did it again when he cheekily got down on one knee in the middle of the street and proposed not to get married when they both felt their relationship was moving too quickly.  Luckily, the blonde bombshell managed to change his mind when she returned the favour and got on bended knee in the middle of the street in a last-ditch effort to make things official.  (Image: ITV)  After breaking the builder‚Äôs heart when she drunkenly kissed Kevin Webster, Sally recruited the help of Craig Tinker and his impressive artistic skills to help make the best proposal possible.  The loveable policeman created two beautiful murals on Egyptian cotton bed sheets, one which had the phrase ‚ÄòTim marry me‚Äô on it and the other with a beautiful picture of Sally.  Luckily, after much persuasion, Tim managed to put her drunken night of passion behind them and tied the knot during a romantic ceremony back in 2020.  Tyrone proposes to Maria in Blackpool  (Image: ITV)  One proposal which has gone down in the Coronation Street history books is Tyrone Hobbs‚Äô first proposal on the street to childhood sweetheart Maria Connor.  The brunette beauty first joined the show back in 2000 as a kennel maid with the TV hunk, and it didn‚Äôt take long before their romance took off with a series of romantic dates.  And Tyrone made sure to pick the perfect place to pop the question to his beautiful bride to be, as he plucked up the courage to ask his girlfriend to become his wife on top of the Blackpool Tower.  (Image: ITV/REX/Shutterstock)  Everything seemed to be going swimmingly, with the happy couple sharing their exciting news with their loved ones and planning for their big day.  But after 12 months of planning, the TV heartthrob‚Äôs eyes started to wander over to fiery redhead Fiz Brown.  It‚Äôs fair to say when Maria found out Tyrone had been locking lips with another woman that Tyrone was in trouble with the fuming fianc√©e immediately calling off the wedding.  But it all worked out in the end, with Maria going on to find the love of her life with Liam Connor and tying the knot with him in 2008.  Steve‚Äôs wedding fever  (Image: ITV)  We couldn't share this list without giving an honourable mention to fan-favourite star Steve McDonald, who has been consistently unlucky in love during his time on the soap.  The loveable character - played by Simon Gregson - has been part of the furniture since he joined the long-running show back in 1989.  It's fair to say the soap star has been quite the womaniser on the show, after tying the knot throughout his 34-year reign.  (Image: ITV)  Bride number one was Vicky Arden, the granddaughter of Rovers landlord Alec Gilroy.  But it wasn't meant to be after the pair called time on their marriage two years later after he fell into the arms of hairdresser Fiona Middleton.  Steve later tied the knot to Karen Phillips who he walked down the aisle with not once but twice, with both weddings ended in tears.  (Image: PD UNKNOWN)  In 2001, the couple exchanged vows for the first time for a bet, but they soon realised they loved each other and got divorced so they could tie the knot properly in 2004.  However, their ceremony was interrupted by Tracy Barlow who revealed that she had a one night stand with the groom himself.  Despite the heartbreaking news, Karen tied the knot anyway but their marriage broke down just months later.  (Image: ITV)  Next up to wear the white gown was Rovers barmaid Michelle Connor, but he then cheated on Michelle with Becky Granger who he also married in 2009.  Sadly, their wedding bliss wasn't made to last, with Steve later returning to his former flame Tracy Barlow.  It didn't take long before the brunette beauty fell pregnant with twins, and being the gentleman he is, Steve decided to do the right thing and put a ring on her finger.  (Image: ITV)  But when he found out she had been lying about Becky causing her to miscarry her unborn twins, which she actually lost through natural causes, it was all over.  Following their divorce in 2015, Steve rekindled his relationship with Michelle who he tied the knot with later that year.  But after an argument, Steve slept with Leanne Battersby who later fell pregnant with his son Oliver.  (Image: ITV)  It's fair to say when Michelle found out about his infidelity, she threw him out the house and swiftly divorced him.  But that didn't stop the TV veteran from finding love again, after he rekindled his relationship with Tracy Barlow once again.  The happy couple later tied the knot in 2018, but that didn't mean their wedding went off without a hitch after she discovered that Steve had slept with her once again.  Luckily, Steve managed to get back in Tracy's good books and (for now) the happy couple have been going strong.  Les and Cilla‚Äôs star-studded wedding  (Image: ITV)  Another match made in heaven (or hell) has to be the Cilla Brown and Les Battersby who made sure their wedding went off with a bang.  In 2005, the happy couple decided to tie the knot largely so they could treat themselves to countless wedding presents from their friends and family.  But arguably the person who was most pleased by their nuptials was Chesney who was over the moon to be part of a real family for once.  (Image: Chris Neill)  However, their day certainly didn't go to plan after bride-to-be Cilla was pampered by best friend Yana who carefully styled her auburn locks into three sixes.  But the madness didn't end there after Les got caught up in a pre-wedding bust-up with one of the band member of Status Quo.  And the trouble didn't end there after Francis Rossi and Rick Parfitt locked horns just moments before he was duo to walk down the aisle.  (Image: Unknown)  Last time the star managed to escape the drunken brawl without so much as a scratch, but this time the TV legend was forced to wear a neck brace on his big day.  Luckily, the groom managed to patch things up with the band, and they even played at the happy couple's reception.  Ken and Deirdre‚Äôs heartbreaking reception  (Image: ITV)  They weren't the only happy couple to tie the knot that year, as legendary couple Deirdre and Ken remarried later that year.  Unfortunately, they day was set to end in tragedy when Deirdre's ex-husband Ray Langton died at the reception.  Ray made his return to Weatherfield when Tracy's father discovered he had stomach cancer.  (Image: ITV)  After learning about the devastating diagnosis, Tracy's dad managed to convince him to to return to the Cobbles to make amends with his daughter before it was too late.  Luckily he didn't have to look too hard to find his long-lost family, after he accidentally hit baby Amy Barlow's pram at the hospital.  It was at this point that he realised the tot was his granddaughter as he reconnected with his daughter Tracy.  (Image: ITV)  For more of the latest showbiz and TV news from the Daily Star, make sure you sign up to one of our newsletters here.  After he revealed that he had terminal stomach cancer, the family unit attended Ken and Deirdre's wedding to wish the happy couple well on their big day.  But during the reception which was held at the Rovers Return, Ray passed away much to Tracy's distress.  READ NEXT:

Wedding photos of minor daughters of TN Chidambaram temple priests surface  The development comes a day after NCPCR member Dr RG Anand claimed that the priests‚Äô daughters were not subjected to child marriage and that the children were forced to say they were.  news News  Photographs from the marriage ceremonies of the minor daughters of priests at the Chidambaram Natarajar temple in Tamil Nadu have surfaced on the internet. The development comes a day after Dr RG Anand, member of the National Commission for Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR), claimed in a press conference that the Dhikshitars‚Äô (priests) underage daughters were not subjected to child marriage and that the children were forced to say they were. Dr Anand‚Äôs claims were in line with the allegations made by Governor RN Ravi.  At least three child brides can be spotted in the photographs that are now circulating the internet. A state government official confirmed to TNM that the photos were indeed captured during the wedding ceremony of the priests‚Äô daughters. Family members of the children are also identifiable in the images. As per media reports, the images were procured from the cell phones of the Dhikshitars themselves.  ‚ÄúThe Department of Social Welfare has submitted evidence to the police including photos from the weddings, receipts from the halls where the child marriages took place, wedding invitations, and the thamboolam bags (yellow bags carrying the names of the bride and groom presented to those attending the weddings). Hence, no one can claim that child marriages never took place,‚Äù said a source from the state government. The source confirmed that the grooms were also minors in some of these cases.  Vasuki Umanath, national vice president of the All India Democratic Women‚Äôs Association (AIDWA), said it was deplorable that this child marriage took place and the Governor is denying it. ‚ÄúIt appears as though [the Governor] is supporting child marriages, which is prohibited by law. He is crossing the constitutional line. The Sangh ideology is being increasingly imposed and even the NCPCR member [Anand] seems to have been pressured to comply,‚Äù she said.  Devaneyan, a child rights activist from Tamil Nadu, told TNM that he is saddened to see the state‚Äôs superior authorities functioning against the best interests of the children. ‚ÄúThe question that has arised is whether the NCPCR is functioning in the best interests of the children or the Governor. It is clear that the NCPCR is favouring the latter because they have even denied the evidence that had already been processed by authorities,‚Äù he said.  Sources from the Police Department said they suspect 52 child marriages to have taken place in Chidambaram since 2021. At present, they are gathering strong evidence to book six more child marriage cases, they said.  The All Women‚Äôs Police Station in Chidambaram have already booked four cases under Section 366(a) (procuration of minor girl) of the Indian Penal Code and the 9th and 10th sections of the Prevention of Child Marriage Act, which are to be heard in court soon. Eight men and three women were arrested in this regard between September and October 2022. ‚ÄúWe are discussing if the cases must be heard in Chidambaram‚Äôs special court for the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO),‚Äù a source said.  In an interview with the Times of India published on May 4, Governor RN Ravi had alleged that the Social Welfare Department officials lodged ‚Äúfalse complaints‚Äù of child marriage against two priests of the Natarajar temple out of ‚Äúvengeance‚Äù, he had claimed. After media reports highlighted the Governor‚Äôs allegations, the NCPCR took suo motu cognisance to investigate the incident and declared that the governor‚Äôs allegations were ‚Äú100% true.‚Äù  On May 26, Dr Anand also strengthened the governor‚Äôs claim alleging that the two-finger virginity tests were carried out on the victims of child marriage cases and added that the NCPCR holds the evidence to prove it. However, the state officials denied the claim. Incidentally, media reports from May 25 had quoted Dr Anand as saying that there was no evidence the two-finger test was performed on the minors. Although spring doesn't end for another few weeks, Dr. Nicole Martin is already in summer mode.  How to Watch Catch up on The Real Housewives of Miami on Peacock or the Bravo App.  The Real Housewives of Miami mom returned to Instagram on May 26 to share several photos of her family's St. Barths getaway. The certified anesthesiologist posted pictures of scenic cliffs and crystal-clear water; however, it was her stunning swimsuit that received the most compliments.  The carousel began with a photo of Nicole posing with her back toward the camera while rocking a teeny string bikini. The cheeky green design was created by Naomi Newirth's ACACIA, an eco-conscious label that specializes in sophisticated swimwear and women‚Äôs ready-to-wear garments. Nicole‚Äôs swimsuit featured a tonal horizontal pattern, a triangle top with adjustable straps, as well as side string ties with tassels on the end. The mother-of-one finished the look with a pair of black sneakers, a few gold bracelets, and some brown Oliver Peoples shades.  As shown on her Instagram, Nicole enjoyed the St. Barths outing with a couple of friends and her longtime partner, Anthony Lopez, with whom she shares a 4-year-old son.  ‚ÄúHappy [Memorial Day weekend],‚Äù she captioned the post. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve officially reached the start of summer!! Looking forward to our upcoming trips.‚Äù  Several Bravolebrities hopped in the comments section to provide a few flattering words for Nicole.  ‚ÄúLil hottie with bodyody!‚Äù wrote Southern Charm and Southern Hospitality‚Äôs Leva Bonaparte.  ‚ÄúBaby got back,‚Äù added RHOM‚Äôs Adriana de Moura.  This isn‚Äôt the first time Nicole has delivered a sizzling swimsuit look. The University of Miami alumna has slayed in a black two-piece design with gold accents, a playful denim bikini top with ruffles, and a striking leopard print swimsuit with knot details.  Related  Nicole and Anthony are no strangers to the jet-set lifestyle. The couple frequently takes to social media to document their travels, which have included stops in Aspen, Paris, Capri, and the Bahamas. The Miami mom spoke about her wanderlust during RHOM Season 5, when she had her castmates flew to the Caribbean for a girls‚Äô trip.  ‚ÄúI love to travel,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúLike, I am the first one to jump on a plane and go anywhere for any amount of time...‚Äù  Photo: Nicole Martin/Instagram  So, what's Nicole‚Äôs next adventure? It may be her wedding with Anthony. The two got engaged on New Year‚Äôs Eve 2021, after several years of dating. Though the couple has not formally announced a wedding date, Nicole told People magazine she and her fianc√© were eyeing a destination ceremony.  ‚ÄúI just love the idea of the destination wedding vibe,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIn Miami, you get married, you‚Äôve got four hours, and the party‚Äôs over. But when you travel, you‚Äôve got a welcome night, then you have a day party, then the night party, and it‚Äôs four or five days where you really get to enjoy your people.‚Äù

The Mayor of Amman, Yousef Al-Shawarbeh, took to Twitter on Saturday to announce that citizens will enjoy free rides on the Amman bus and Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system on June 1.  This initiative aligns with the wedding ceremony of His Highness Prince Hussein bin Abdullah II, the Crown Prince.  Shawarbeh also extended his congratulations to His Majesty King Abdullah II and Queen Rania Al Abdullah on this joyous occasion.  Jordanians are eagerly anticipating the wedding festivities, with preparations for various celebratory activities underway across all governorates.

A person who has read my columns weekly and knows of my connection with Sri Lanka contacted me asking for information about her visiting Sri Lanka to see the Asian elephants. She has travel around Africa and saw plenty of African elephants and is curious to see Asian elephants and the Sri Lankan people.  My info on the national parks where the Sri Lanka elephants roam is a bit outdated, so I sent out messages to trusted Sri Lanka friends to learn how the situation is now.  Each response back was something similar to this: ‚ÄúPlease let me know when your friend is coming. Will help her along. Do give her my number, it‚Äôs always good to have a local contact.‚Äù And, ‚ÄúLet me know if you need me to help, if you need me to get your friend tour assistance.‚Äù And, ‚ÄúPlease contact me and Mr. H. so we can both help your friend. Thanks.‚Äù  My friends have been so helpful and so willing to give my ‚Äúnew‚Äù friend help with whatever she may need. It made me tear up. Made me miss them and wonder if I‚Äôll ever get back there to see them.  They also gave me information on where best to see elephants in the wild. One place that I really loved was the elephants in Udawalawe National Park. Our guide there was respectful of the magnificent animals who came close to our Jeep. It was the first time I heard them rumble. I thought it was them warning us, but then I realized it was their way of communicating to each other. It was friendly. I have been forever since protective of them and in love with them.  As my wedding photography in Sri Lanka grew, my photo partner and I decided to never take photos of couples wanting to use elephants in their wedding pictures. One wedding brought the couple on the back of an elephant handled by a mahout (elephant handler) who was drunk and the elephant was in chains. I could barely photograph them because I was crying. That was the end of us taking photos of elephants in chains.  Over time elephants have been used and abused in all countries for labor and tourism. Just being one person, I can‚Äôt cure the situation, but I could stop promoting using elephants for wedding photos and didn‚Äôt care if we lost business because of it.  I now daily follow and promote the amazing work of Sheldrick Wildlife Trust (https://www.sheldrickwildlifetrust.org/), a nonprofit organization who are pioneers in the rescue and raising of orphaned elephants and rhinos in Kenya. Their work certainly lifts my spirits, and to watch the baby elephants and their antics is just the best!  On my latest visit to Santa Rosa for another (and hopefully final) procedure on my back, my friend Mabel drove me, as usual. When arriving at the surgery center we drove up a long hill and saw a woman struggling to walk the steep grade. Mabel left me in the car and walked down to assist the woman. Turns out the woman was severely disorientated and couldn‚Äôt find her car. She didn‚Äôt know what brand her car was. She‚Äôd been walking up and down streets trying to find it. It was 2:30 p.m. and hot. Mabel saw from her car keys the car was a Toyota. The woman said it was white. She had dropped off a friend and couldn‚Äôt remember where or who. Mabel walked with her and eventually found her car and her friend.  The woman asked Mabel, ‚ÄúWhy are you doing this?‚Äù  ‚ÄúBecause you looked like you could use some help,‚Äù said Mabel.  Helping others without any reason and giving without the expectation of receiving anything in return is what Mabel is all about. I never asked her to help me when my back became unbearable, she just helped. She has been there for me, along with her husband Bart and the friends I‚Äôve made along my journey.  What‚Äôs a girl to do?‚Ä¶pay kindness forward. Always.  Lucy Llewellyn Byard is currently a columnist for the Record-Bee. To contact her, email lucywgtd@gmail.com

If you've already got your prom dress sussed but have no idea how to style your hair to compliment it, these are the best prom hairstyles for 2023, handpicked by the experts.  While bob hairstyles and brunette balayage (like Kendall Jenner's new blonde hair) continue to dominate our Insta feeds, occasion-ready hair, or more specifically prom hair, is a whole different ball game. Your chosen hair look needs to work with both your dress and prom makeup, making it one hell of a big decision.  Do you go for a classy up-do or a Hollywood-esque blowout? The choices are truly endless but thankfully, the experts have supplied us with all the intel on the trendiest look for prom 2023...  What are the best prom hairstyles 2023?  From a wispy fringe hairstyle to a slicked back, Clean-Girl-esque bun, we've rounded up all the chicest (and celebrity-approved!) hair looks that are guaranteed to make you the belle of the ball.  1. Sofia Richie's wedding-inspired hair  A post shared by Vogue Weddings (@vogueweddings) A photo posted by on  According to Miffy G, senior stylist at HARI's salon, Sofia Richie's wedding hair will be one of the hottest prom hairstyles this year.  Sofia wore her hair in a soft, low bun, with a middle parting and not one hair out of place. It was giving major old-money vibes, so for anyone wanting to channel a similar 'Quiet Luxury' aesthetic with their prom look, this could be the hairstyle to opt for!  Luckily for any fans of this classic look, it's actually quite easy to recreate and yes, Miffy has indeed shared some pointers!  To start, Miffy says to: "Begin by prepping the hair with Chiffon mousse by R+Co (available at Amazon) on dry hair and smoothing with a dryer and brush. This is the first step in helping you control the movement of the hair when slicking it back."  She then says to section your hair into two, "from behind one ear diagonally upwards towards the crown, before coming diagonally downwards behind the other ear," Miffy explains that separating your hair in two sections allows for more control‚Äîespecially if you have thicker hair‚Äîyou should then secure the hair at the nape of your neck with an elastic.  Be sure to keep your center parting clean before securing your hair into the ponytail, Miffy notes: "If the hairline is prone to frizz, wrap neck tape around the hairline to help lay the edges down."  Then get your curling one out and curl the hair in some directions, this will make it easier to twist and wrap into your low bun. Miffy then instructs to: "split ponytail in two. Twist hair, pinch the ends and back team using your fingers, creating volume in the twist. Wrap hair around the base of the ponytail. Repeat the same with the remaining hair."  Lastly for that photo-ready shine, Miffy says to use R+Co Two Way Mirror Smoothing Oil (available at Amazon) and then finish off with a few spritzes of hair spray. Here's a step-by-step breakdown of the look, for you to screenshot...  Prep Hair: use a mousse on dry hair and smooth with a hairdryer and brush Section hair: split your hair into two sections, "from behind one ear diagonally upwards towards the crown, before coming diagonally downwards behind the other ear." Secure hair: tie your two sections of hair at the nape with a bungee or elastic. Curl: Tong your hair in some direction making it easier to twist, wrap and pin hair into the bun. Volume: split the ponytail into two sections, then: "Twist hair, pinch the ends and back team using your fingers, creating volume in the twist." Create the bun: "Wrap hair around the base of the ponytail." Finish: complete the look with a shine-boosting product and hair stray  A post shared by Sophie Habboo (@sophiehabboo) A photo posted by on  Miffy also notes that this look should be adapted depending on your face shape, "A center part low bun may look quite severe on longer face shapes. Changing the parting to the side to give the illusion of width." She suggests also perhaps "leaving some hair out around the face to soften the look."  You can also opt for some more volume or texture at the crown, but not too much, as "relaxed and undone is the general vibe of formal hair requests‚Äîa modern hair up."  2. Hollywood waves  A post shared by Gigi Hadid (@gigihadid) A photo posted by on  Celebrity hair stylist and R+Co Creative Ambassador, Steven Beaver, says that if you have hair past the collarbone, the celebrity-approved textured wave is the perfect look for prom.  He says: "Deep side parts with natural texture recreating the iconic Jerry Hall look is very in for 2023 when it comes to occasion hair."  For this look, simply curl your hair loosely either with a wand or the Dyson Airwrap and use a texturizing spray, to create that beachy, mermaid-esque wave.  3. The tousled bob  A post shared by Hailey Rhode Baldwin Bieber (@haileybieber) A photo posted by on  If you've been influenced by Hailey Bieber's recent hair chop and now find yourself with an Italian-esque bob, a tousled look would be perfect for prom.  This look will work with any length of hair on or above the shoulder. Plus, if you have naturally straight hair, this is a fun way to change up the look of your new bob!  If you are planning to rock this look, we'd recommend keeping your makeup more on the natural side, as the waves and short crop will around bring the focus to your face.  4. The curly updo  A post shared by Maya Jama (@mayajama) A photo posted by on  If you've got a curly hair type, a look similar to Maya Jama's curly updo would be perfect, we especially love the face-framing tendrils!  Her look is very effortless glam and would look incredible when paired with a maxi dress.  5. The slick bun  A post shared by Lori Harvey (@loriharvey) A photo posted by on  Alternatively, if you were wanting a more sleek look, a slicked-back bun is so on-trend right now. This hair-up moment from Lori Harvey would make a truly timeless prom hairstyle, especially with the two face-framing sections.  We'd recommend using a hair wax stick like the TikTok-popular Tigi Bed Head stick available at Amazon‚Äîit's also small enough to fit in your prom bag for any emergency flyaway-touch-ups!  6. The voluminous bob  A post shared by Zendaya (@zendaya) A photo posted by on  Zendaya's blown-out, bouncy bob definitely fulfills the prom hairstyle assignment. This look is chic and sophisticated and ideal if your hair is at that in-between bob and shoulder-length stage.  As Zendaya's outfit proves, this look was made for a formal occasion!  7. The sleek, behind the ears look  A post shared by Simone Ashley (@simoneashley) A photo posted by on  If you have long hair, this 'behind the ears' hairstyle is perfectly elegant and so low-maintained! Simply straighten your hair, before tucking the front sections behind your ears and securing with some pins. Then let the rest of your hair fall behind your shoulders, covering the pinned back sections‚Äîto make it look as though you've literally just tucked your hair behind your ears.  Alternatively, you can also tie the two front sections together, behind the nape of your neck, instead of pining them. This will also help to create some volume for the rest of your hair.  8.The 90s updo  A post shared by Sydney Sweeney (@sydney_sweeney) A photo posted by on  Reminiscent of Pamela Anderson's iconic curly updo, this look from Sydney Sweeney is also another option for prom, especially if you have curtain bangs!  If you don't have a fringe however (and have no intention of getting one before prom), this curly 90s look also works with a sleek middle parting, as we see here on Hailee Steinfeld...  A post shared by Laura Polko (@laurapolko) A photo posted by on  9. Half up, half down  A post shared by Stella McCartney (@stellamccartney) A photo posted by on  A half up, half down prom hairstyle will never go amiss! This wavy, hair twist moment from Madelyn Cline is would compliment any prom dress and will not cause you too much hassle!

Post by ANI on Sunday, May 28, 2023  A soulful Kashmiri song titled 'Kya Karie Korimol' has taken the internet by storm. It's a heartwarming tribute to the bond that father and daughter share on a wedding day.  The song depicts a journey through the emotions of a bride on her wedding day. The song released by Coke Studio India has garnered 1 million views, capturing the hearts of people not only in Kashmir but also across the globe.  The track beautifully encapsulates the profound love, protection, and compassion that envelops a father-daughter relationship, showcasing its unwavering strength as it evolves over time. The emotional journey of a bride and her father as they prepare for her wedding feast is artfully portrayed through poignant and melancholic lyrics.  The song features Alif, an acclaimed poet, singer, and songwriter, who previously won the prestigious IRAA Award for his single 'Like A Sufi.' Known for his deeply introspective lyrical compositions, Alif weaves colloquial references to society into his work, captivating listeners with his unique storytelling.  Playback singer and actor Aashima Mahajan added a soulful touch to the composition. Additionally, Noor Mohammad, a traditional Sufi music performer and songwriter hailing from Handwara in North Kashmir, brought his expertise and enriches the song with his contributions.  The collaboration of trio- Alif, Aashima Mahajan, and Noor Mohammad resulted in a harmonious blend of talent, skill, and heartfelt emotions, leaving listeners spellbound.  The enchanting melody resonates not only with Kashmiris but also with people worldwide who appreciate and cherish the beauty of Kashmiri culture.  Talking about the success of the song, Creative Producer Ankur Tewari expressed his delight, said "We are thrilled to witness the overwhelming response to 'Kyakariekorimol.' This song truly captures the essence of the father-daughter bond, and we are grateful to Alif, Aashima Mahajan, and Noor Mohammad for their exceptional artistry."  The song composed and written by Alif. Aman Moroney, ALIF, and Ashish Manchanda produced the song, ensuring its flawless execution.  Alif's mesmerizing vocals and acoustic guitars create an unforgettable musical experience, while the Wanwun Vocals by Zartasha Zainab, Shivani Matyal, Samhita Shiledar, Samiyah Nabi, and Rumuz-e-Bekhudi add depth and richness to the composition.  The 'Wanvun' couplets compiled by Rumuz Bekhudi and Alif, serve as a poignant addition to the song.  Not only that, Rumuz has also efficiently translated the whole song, as given in the video captions, making it accessible and palatable to non-kashmiri readers across the globe.  As the world continues to embrace the magical harmonies of "Kyakariekorimol," it becomes evident that this extraordinary father-daughter saga has struck a universal chord, uniting people through the power of music and love.  For enamoured listeners, "This song is a masterpiece that beautifully portrays the unbreakable bond between a father and daughter. It truly touches the soul and leaves an everlasting impact."(ANI)

Wedding horror as bride's mum unveils plans to wear long 'champagne' coloured gown  The bride-to-be took to Reddit to share her wedding dilemma after she found out what her mother had planned to wear to the ceremony. Writing on the Am I the a******" forum, the woman asked whether she was overreacting about the dress being a "champagne colour". While it wasn't exactly white, she explained that the gown style meant it "looked too much like a wedding dress" and was even less gold than she thought. After seeing an image of the dress the daughter revealed that she felt disrespected by her parent and didn't want her to wear it. And she garnered plenty of support from fellow forum users who agreed that the colour of the outfit is widely known to be "off-limits" for weddings. READ MORE: Airplane passenger horror after parents change baby's nappy on seat tray table  The dress as pictured is elegant and bright like a wedding gown  In the post, the bride wrote: "My wedding colours are navy, dusty blue, sage green, and silver. "My mother wants to wear a champagne, one-shoulder, long dress to my wedding as mother of the bride‚Ä¶ "It looks too much like a wedding dress to me and the colour doesn‚Äôt look gold in pictures. I honestly don‚Äôt know what to do because it‚Äôs upsetting to me she doesn‚Äôt want to respect my wishes by getting a different dress. "I‚Äôm trying to let it go and let her wear it but it‚Äôs screaming 'I want to be the centre of attention' to me."  Fellow Reddit users argued that champagne is worn by many brides and is 'off limits' to guests  While the daughter was upset about the dress itself, she added that "the principle of it" goes deeper into her relationship with her mother. The Reddit poster explained: "My mother has tried to upstage me my entire life and she constantly makes jabs about my weight and how I would be a prettier bride if I lost weight. (We look identical I‚Äôm just chubbier). "This is a continual struggle of her not caring about my opinion or requests. So it‚Äôs not just a dress, it‚Äôs the principle of it." And the bride wasn't alone in thinking that her mother's dress was inappropriate for a wedding. One person took to the tread to comment: "Loads of people wear champagne wedding dresses because it is close enough to white. In any case, it‚Äôs more of a good tint which is outside of your wedding colours and as the mother of the bride should lean into your chosen colours more."  Trending

Put it in the baby books.  Fans on Cameo have requested that legendary Mets radio broadcaster Howie Rose reveal whether they are having a boy or a girl.  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of ‚ÄòHere‚Äôs our gender reveal, would you announce to everybody what we‚Äôre having,'‚Äù Rose told The Post of his account on Cameo, where a celebrity records personalized video messages for a fee. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fun.‚Äù  Other requests have included ‚Äúintroducing the bride and groom at their wedding or a bar mitzvah or something like that,‚Äù said Rose, 69, whose talking bobblehead is being handed out at CitiField on May 31.  Perfect timing, because on June 3 Rose will join players Howard Johnson and Al Leiter and fellow broadcaster Gary Cohen in being inducted into the Mets Hall of Fame at Citi Field.  Twitter users have called for Rose to be honored with the polyresin replica for years.  ‚ÄúBy popular demand, absolutely. They‚Äôre banging down the doors to get a Howie Rose bobblehead,‚Äù Rose said of the doll, which utters his famous catchphrase ‚ÄúPut it in the books.‚Äù  Rose‚Äôs bobblehead utters his famous catchphrase, ‚ÄúPut it in the books.‚Äù Noah K. Murray-NY Post  Rose was initially opposed to joining social media, and didn‚Äôt create a Twitter account until 2020.  ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt trust myself because I know me and I figure I‚Äôll have dinner and ‚Ä¶ maybe a couple of glasses of wine, and then I‚Äôll think, ‚ÄòYou know what? Yeah, I could say this.‚Äô‚Äù  However, once the pandemic hit, he felt disconnected from his listeners and decided to post his first tweet ‚Äî not realizing he did it on the same date, April 11, that the Mets played their first game.  ‚ÄúIt was pure irony ‚Ä¶ I just realized it later that night and said, ‚ÄòOh, this is spooky,'‚Äù he remembered.  The Brooklyn native who grew up in Bayside, Queens, remembers when he would attend baseball games at Shea Stadium when general admission was just $1.30 and the bus ride there 15 or 20 cents.  ‚ÄúIf I could scrounge two bucks off of my parents, which was a challenge ‚Ä¶ I still had money left over to buy a scorecard and maybe a hot dog,‚Äù he recalled.  The Brooklyn native, who grew up in Queens, recalled attending Mets games at Shea Stadium for $1.30. Sam Valorose  Now, his stadium food of choice is sushi from Daruma of Tokyo.  ‚ÄúTo me, sushi is the new pizza,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd whenever I get a chance, I try to have that before a game.‚Äù  He admitted to shedding a tear on air, when the team won the National League pennant in 2015.  ‚ÄúAs I was finishing my final call, if you listen very carefully ‚Ä¶ I said, ‚ÄòThey‚Äôre going to the World Series‚Äô and you could hear my voice crack just a little bit,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúBecause it was sort of your whole career, your ambitions and your dreams being crystallized in that moment.‚Äù  Fans on Cameo requested that legendary Mets radio broadcaster Howie Rose reveal their baby‚Äôs sex. Courtesy Howie Rose  Earlier this year, he revealed his battle with bladder cancer, and has received an outpouring of support.  ‚ÄúSince then, I‚Äôve had a number of people get in touch with me whom I‚Äôve had conversations, trying to help them through something similar that they‚Äôre going through ‚Ä¶ And it‚Äôs been somewhat cathartic,‚Äù he said.  Rose has no plans of retiring anytime soon and is hoping he can one day announce a World Series win for his beloved team.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping that happens this year,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd if not, next year and God willing and health willing, I‚Äôll hang on as long as I can to have a chance to make that call.‚Äù

The Yorkshire victims of a cruel wedding scammer have spoken of their heartbreak at finding they had been fleeced out of thousands only three days before they were due to tie the knot.  Nicky and Jason Asquith-Thorpe from Harrogate were conned by swindler Dana Twidale, a wedding planner from Hull. The couple discovered they had been fleeced out of ¬£3,500, paid to Twidale to organise their big day, just three days before the ceremony itself.  The pair will speak about their horrific experience in new TV documentary 'The Big Swindle' due to air this evening (Saturday, May 27) on Quest Red. Twidale was sentenced to five years in prison in 2021 after admitting 26 counts of fraud, reports Hull Live.  Read More: Woman's frustration as taxi firm stops her from pre-booking a cab because of her wheelchair  In the new documentary, The Big Swindle: The Wedding Planner Scammer, Nicky and Jason tell how their dreams turned to dust when Twidale ‚Äì whom they considered a friend ‚Äì failed to meet them at the venue as planned days before the wedding. Nicky said: ‚ÄúWe all went to the venue together ‚Ä¶ so my mum, my auntie, myself, Jason, my children. We were hoping that Dana would already be there with her van putting the marquee up ‚Ä¶ and the chairs and the tables.‚Äù  When they arrived, Dana was nowhere to be seen. Jason said: ‚ÄúThere was no van, there was no marquee, no nothing. There was a car parked with a couple sat in it that we‚Äôd never seen before, we assumed that one of them was Dana. They were the people that she‚Äôd hired to come and fill the marquee ‚Äì to make it really special for us. And they were still none the wiser, they assumed she was going to turn up as well.‚Äù  Shockingly, rather than come clean, Twidale had strung the couple along up to the very last minute. Nicky added: ‚ÄúThis is the worst bit ‚Äì Dana had messaged me saying ‚Äòwe‚Äôre running late, don‚Äôt worry, we‚Äôll be there.‚Äô And that was the last message I received from her.‚Äù  In the documentary, which is due to air tonight (Saturday May 27) at 10pm on Quest Red, the couple explain how Twidale failed to answer their increasingly desperate calls. ‚ÄúBy lunchtime she hadn‚Äôt turned up. We kept ringing and it‚Äôd just ring through," said Jason.  "So then we thought it might be a problem with the phones, so then I rang, then someone else rang. The couple that were there to put the marquee together rang, there was just no answer. We didn‚Äôt know what happened we didn‚Äôt know if something was wrong with her.‚Äù  The offences happened between 2017 and 2019. When her betrayal of trust was publicised in July 2019, she fled the UK and was pictured sunning it up in Benidorm on her ill-gotten gains.  Among Twidale's other victims was a man she met on Tinder. She lied to him, claiming she was the victim of domestic violence, and begged him for money to pay for her mum‚Äôs funeral ‚Äì despite her mother being alive and well. He paid her more than ¬£42,000, leaving him ‚Äúan emotional and financial wreck‚Äù.  At a later Proceeds of Crime hearing, it was revealed that Twidale's crimes had netted her ¬£60,263, but her remaining assets were valued at a only ¬£600, enough to reimburse one of the victims just ¬£1.74.  The Big Swindle, a series on Quest Red, tells the stories of the most brazen and ruthless con artists and the victims they preyed on. Focusing on one story of devestating deceit each episode, those affected reveal the shocking details of what happened and a forensic psychiatrist helps unpack the mindset of the swindlers, as well as social media posts, emails and text messages, to reveal how and why these complicated cons were executed.  The Wedding Planner Scammer is episode three of the series. It can be viewed at 10pm on Saturday May 27. Quest Red is on Freeview, channel 40.  Read Next:
Ruffled Saree  Ruffle sarees are all the craze in the fashion market and you too can drape one to look stylish and elegant at a wedding.

Hans Eggstein was feeling out of place. As ‚Äúthe only white boy at the wedding,‚Äù as he described it, the restaurant manager was nervous.  He wondered if he‚Äôd made a mistake taking time off from his job at Philly‚Äôs famed Le Bec-Fin to accept a waiter‚Äôs invitation to a wedding in Casablanca, especially after a back-firing car sent him diving to the ground in a crowded bazaar shortly following his arrival. Then he saw Samira Mountassir.  ‚ÄúShe was so beautiful in her kaftan and jewelry,‚Äù Eggstein told Billy Penn. ‚ÄúShe looked like a princess.‚Äù  Mountassir (now Eggstein) recalls being similarly struck. ‚ÄúI felt comfortable right away around him,‚Äù she said of their brief interaction at the wedding. ‚ÄúI even held his hand on our first date,‚Äù in defiance of her conservative upbringing.  Fast forward 17 years, and the duo are now proprietors of Chez Hansi on the 1600 block of South Street.  The spot underwent a few changes since opening last April before settling into a quaint BYO with 24 seats across a main floor and lower level. Dishes include spaetzle-and-mushroom covered schnitzels, fragrant couscous-based tajines, and plenty of pastries, both savory and sweet.  It‚Äôs a harmonious blend of the couple‚Äôs respective European and North African backgrounds, and a realization of a plan set in motion during their earliest conversations.  Chez Hansi‚Äôs vegetable tajine, a bright rendition of the classic Moroccan dish. (Kimberly Paynter/WHYY)  Obstacles along the way  Wanting to respect local customs, then 55-year-old Hans approached Samira‚Äôs family the day after the wedding in Morocco to seek out her mother‚Äôs approval for a date, which was promptly denied. Undeterred, he returned two days later, and then two days after that. The third time proved to be the charm.  Together at last, the two discovered a language barrier, with Samira speaking only a little English and Hans even less French.  ‚ÄúI remember we were talking about preparing couscous, and I was [struggling] to explain,‚Äù Samira said of their first date. ‚ÄúBut we got there, no problem. We made it.‚Äù  They quickly bonded over their shared culinary interests and backgrounds. Samira, who had honed her baking skills in her uncle‚Äôs bakery, had grown up with a passion for cooking; experimenting in the kitchen from an early age and by high school regularly preparing meals for her mother and five siblings. She had settled on an accounting diploma after narrowly missing the application deadline for restaurant school.  Hans had grown up in his parents‚Äô traditional German pub in Stuttgart, where he later went to restaurant school before moving to Philadelphia in 1974 and eventually becoming a manager at Georges Perrier‚Äôs Center City fine dining gem.  Over the next few days, Samira guided Hans across Casablanca, exploring the cafes and restaurants on Boulevard d‚ÄôAnfa and the local bazaars. They served as inspiration for the pair‚Äôs future cafe, which even by that early point had become a shared assumption.  With his time in Casablanca coming to an end and the two realizing how difficult it was to say goodbye ‚Äì ‚ÄúI think I cried in the airport,‚Äù said Samira ‚Äì they made plans for Hans to return several times over the next few months.  Chez Hansi‚Äôs cr√®me br√ªl√©e. (Kimberly Paynter/WHYY)  A little over a year after first meeting, the Eggsteins were married in Casablanca in 2007, with a plan to move to Germany once Samira‚Äôs paperwork was processed.  But the German bureaucratic system was ‚Äúoverwhelming‚Äù, Hans said, proving ‚Äútoo long and with too many steps.‚Äù He demoted himself to waiter to make it easier to continue seeing Samira. ‚ÄúBeing a manager was too much work to step away from,‚Äù Hans explained. ‚ÄúSo, I stepped down.‚Äù  ‚ÄúFor three years he was coming to visit me in Casablanca,‚Äù said Samira. ‚ÄúBut it wasn‚Äôt enough.‚Äù  Frustrated by the lack of progress, the Eggsteins changed their plans and decided to move to the U.S. They applied for Samira‚Äôs green card and, within three months, had settled in Philadelphia, where Hans found her a job as a runner at Le Bec-Fin.  ‚ÄúIt was like restaurant school,‚Äù Samira said of the experience. ‚ÄúI learned how to set up the table, how to serve, how to clean up. I loved it.‚Äù  ‚ÄòA rollercoaster ride‚Äô  Samira moved on to other establishments, working at the Water Works, Chestnut Hill Hotel, White Dog Caf√©, and Germantown‚Äôs Paris Bistro, where she went from waitressing to becoming assistant manager. Throughout, the couple kept the vision of opening their own cafe.  ‚ÄúWe had no money, but the dream was there,‚Äù said Hans. ‚ÄúSo, we started very slowly, doing catering on our days off.‚Äù  Tarte au citron at Chez Hansi on a table outside the South Street West BYOB. (Kimberly Paynter/WHYY)  They set up Anfa Catering in 2016, working out of a commissary in University City on a menu of sauerkraut, veggie burgers, and salads. The service ran for a year and made no profit.  Hans was forced to retire from his day job due to health reasons. Samira went back to waitressing at Bistro la Baia on Lombard. On his way to pick Samira up one evening, Hans noticed a ‚Äúfor rent‚Äù sign in the window of 1610 South St., a small storefront that was previously home to Pumpkin Market.  Samira agreed the space was ‚Äúvery cute,‚Äù and right in line with their vision of a neighborhood caf√© specializing in coffee, baguettes, and pastries.  Chez Hansi opened quietly in April of 2022 ‚Äî ‚ÄúI have no money for advertising,‚Äù said Hans. It was a rocky start, the Eggsteins struggling to secure the regular clientele that their idea of an early morning cafe depended on.  Samira found herself overworked, baking at night, setting up at Hansi in the morning before rushing off to her waitressing job, while Hans lamented the effort and trays of baked goods going to waste daily. Realizing the concept wasn‚Äôt working, the couple called an emergency meeting one late summer evening.  ‚ÄúWe just closed the [restaurant] doors and had a brainstorm,‚Äù Samira said of the night a new menu was created and the decision taken to run Chez Hansi as a dinner spot, with dishes inspired by German and Moroccan cuisine, or as Hans describes it, ‚Äúgood home cooking.‚Äù  Eight months in, the reinvention seems to be working.  The labor is evenly split ‚Äî the two shop daily for ingredients together, Samira bakes and serves customers while Hans cooks, and join forces for cleaning duties at the end of the night. The menu rotates weekly according to marketplace availability and Hans‚Äô mood, with some staple dishes like the jaegerschnitzel, and a tajine that alternates between vegetarian and slow-braised lamb. Entrees hover between $20 and $30.  Samira also makes weekly additions to the pastry menu, like a black forest cake she added to the usual lineup of lemon tart, chocolate mousse, tiramisu, and cr√®me brul√©e, alongside the savory poultry-nut-and-berries bastillas. ‚ÄúSamira‚Äôs pastries are unbelievable,‚Äù beamed Hans.  Now settling into a routine, the Eggsteins are hoping to establish more of a presence in the community. They‚Äôre considering live jazz nights and a special cake promotion for Bastille Day.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still a rollercoaster ride. One day you think ‚ÄúI made it‚Äù because it was busy, and then the next no business,‚Äù said Hans. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm really happy with what we‚Äôre doing here.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt took too long,‚Äù Samira said, ‚ÄúBut it makes you happy when people come and enjoy themselves and leave with a smile. It‚Äôs worth it.‚Äù  1611 South Street | 5 to 9 p.m. Tuesday-Saturday (closed Tuesday May 30) | (267) 455-0670

Onagh O‚ÄôDriscoll and Paul Chira knew it was meant to be when they first locked eyes on one another back in 2019 and the pair have been together ever since  THE HAPPY COUPLE  Onagh O‚ÄôDriscoll, Wicklow and Paul Chira, Romania.  THE FIRST GLANCE  We met in Twenty Twos on south Anne street back in 2019. Paulie walked past to go to the bathroom, we locked eyes, he asked me if I wanted a drink and the rest is history as they say!  We were inseparable the moment we met. As cringey as it sounds it was definitely love at first sight.  THE PROPOSAL  Paul proposed during Covid when we were on the way back from a family weekend in Cork.  Read more: Wexford bride weds in vintage wedding in breathtaking black dress  We had all of our friends and family organised to be in the apartment when we got back. It was decorated with ‚ÄòWill you marry me balloons‚Äô and flowers everywhere and he got down on one knee.  I was speechless. I wasn't expecting it at all. Paul designed the ring himself with Voltaire diamonds and it was so special, I‚Äôm obsessed with my ring.  THE RECEPTION  We got married in Farnham estate in Cavan. It was the perfect venue for our big day. Farnham was the first place that Paulie brought me when we were dating for a weekend away so it has always had a special significance to us.  THE DATE  Our original wedding date was the 29th of July however my Mam was critically ill around that time so we pushed it to the 3rd of December 2022. We aimed to get married outside in the fabulous pergola style outdoor area but unfortunately the December weather didn‚Äôt give us that option!  After the change of date we opted to get married on the grounds of the hotel indoors.  THE WEATHER  The weather was dry but it was cold so the outdoor photos were a challenge. I was freezing but we were just happy it stayed dry. We had the child of Prague out the night before with the hope of some sun!  THE DRESS  I got my wedding dress at ‚ÄòBridal by Tamem Michael‚Äô in Ballymount. I altered the neckline, added a jewelled belt and had over 15 fittings but it was worth it!  Read more:Belfast bride enjoys stunning Cavan wedding after nearly missing her own proposal  Read more: Meath bride's breathtaking wedding after she proposed to her husband  I tried on over 20 wedding dresses and the minute I tried this one on I fell in love. I lost four stone between buying my dress and the wedding day so needless to say I had a lot of fittings and alterations but Paula and the girls had the dress absolutely perfect on the day.  I loved it so much, I wish I could wear it again. I recommend any bride to go to Tamem Michael. They were amazing.  THE PHOTOGRAPHER  Babs Daly was our photographer, we were so at ease with Babs as she made the whole process super enjoyable.  We also had the Fennels as our videographers who captured the day so perfectly. We watched the wedding video numerous times, it‚Äôs so special watching your big day in a venue filled with all the people you love.  THE BAND  We had Spring Break and they were incredible. They had everyone up on their feet all night. I don't think anyone in the room was sitting down once they came on, they were electric!  We also had Karen Byrne and Maurizio Benenato perform a dance to kick off the night time part of the evening, they were spectacular.  THE FIRST DANCE  Our first dance was ‚ÄòPower of love‚Äô by Celine Dion. I love Celine Dion, she‚Äôs my favourite artist and Paul loves that song too. We always said that would be an ideal song for our first dance so we went with it.  THE HIGHLIGHTS  Walking down the aisle for me was really special. Paul was crying his eyes out and it was really emotional. We loved the speeches and of course we loved the night time element, we all danced the night away.  THE STRESS FACTOR  It was super stressful, trying to coordinate all the details from the wedding suppliers, entertainment and transport.  As we had to change the date so it felt like it was being planned all over again but as it got closer all the jobs were done so we really enjoyed the run up to the big day.  I planned the wedding myself and I really enjoyed it so when it was over I didn‚Äôt know what to do with myself!  THE HONEYMOON  We went to Dubai in January and it was just gorgeous. We stayed in the stunning Rixos Hotel. The weather was great and so was the food, the views, everything was incredible.  Read more:Dublin bride's gorgeous city wedding after romantic family proposal  Read more: Cork bride says Covid delays meant her children could be part of their dream wedding  We‚Äôre also going to Stella Island in Greece in August too so we‚Äôre really looking forward to that too.  THE ADVICE  I made a big mistake and I‚Äôd love to prevent any other couple from doing the same; I got our wedding date printed on absolutely everything; the invites, the fans, favours, bathroom bits, bridesmaid presents, grooms crew presents, parents presents, basically anything that could be personalised had the date and then we ended up changing it!  It took a good bit of time to redo everything, not to mention the expense of it so when you‚Äôre ordering, I would recommend leaving the date off of everything and just keep the other details that won‚Äôt change on it instead. You never know what could happen.  We never thought when we booked our wedding two years in advance that we‚Äôd be pushing it out. I hope that helps at least one couple like us, who love everything personalised.  Would you like to have your wedding featured in RSVP Magazine and on our website RSVP Live? Get in touch with kathy.prendeville@reachplc.com

Sign up to our newsletter for daily updates and breaking news delivered direct to your inbox  Plans have been submitted to convert a historic manor house near Slough into a hotel and wedding venue. The proposed conversion of Ditton Manor House would see the main building, chapel and granary adapted into the flexible venue, along with the north, east and south gatehouses.  The brief proposal visible on Slough Council's planning portal show developers plan to build a bar, restaurant and spa. The Local Democracy Service reported earlier this month the manor house itself would be a 33-bed hotel, while a two-storey block adjacent would facilitate an extra 99 rooms.  Ditton Park belonged to the crown under the reign on Elizabeth I, before being passed on to Ralph Montagu, 1st Duke of Montagu. The previous house on the site was taken down after being damaged by a fire in 1812, which eventually led to the construction of the house on show today.  READ MORE: Interactive map shows the Berkshire banks set to close in 2023  Built in a romantic and gothic architectural style, it features turrets and crenelations which provide it a stark identity. For much of the 19th century it was home to the Duchess of Buccleuch who was a very close friend to Queen Victoria.  Since then, more outbuildings were constructed and the land was used for a variety of purposes including radar research and a compass observatory.  The estate owners say they have to change tactics as the site was mainly used for 8-hour conferences, but has seen small demand ever since the Covid-19 pandemic.  The planning statement reads: ‚ÄúThe result of the pandemic and changing work styles has increased the demand for 24-hour conferencing which is not currently possible at the site as there are no bedroom facilities. To meet this demand, significant refurbishment and additional development is required to provide a product geared to market demand; hotel bedrooms, leisure facilities, restaurant and bar, conferencing, and weddings.‚Äù  Planning officers are yet to decide on the application. We want to pay for it out of pocket and have our debt paid off by November.‚Äù  Recently engaged, Cara and Will have two financial goals in 2023: to pay off their debt and start saving for their wedding.  Most of the couple‚Äôs $160,000 income is going toward repaying their sizable debt, which stems from hefty vet bills when their dog was a puppy, the purchase of an engagement ring and overspending. Cara is paying $1,500 a month toward a student loan, credit card debt and a line of credit. She is prioritizing the credit card payments, which have the highest interest. Will is on the hook for $500 a month with credit card debt and a line of credit.  Their wedding, which will take place next May at a golf course, will cost them $11,500. ‚ÄúThe wedding is about 50 people. There is no honeymoon planned,‚Äù she said.  In a province with Canada‚Äôs priciest housing, the couple is paying just $1,780 a month to rent their Langley, B.C., apartment. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre renting a two-bedroom apartment that‚Äôs 1,100 square feet. It‚Äôs a steal of a deal for the size,‚Äù says Cara.  And they aren‚Äôt fazed by their lack of savings; they have just $346 in a savings account, $352 in a TFSA and $311 in RRSPs.  Neither Cara nor Will had financial support from their parents for their postsecondary studies. Cara, who worked three jobs while in school, graduated from Kwantlen Polytechnic University with a degree in geography and $30,000 in debt. She has since whittled that down to $6,442.  ‚ÄúMy parents both worked and had six kids ‚Äì they basically did everything so we could have a better life than they did,‚Äù she says.  Cara admits that she and Will lived beyond their means as students. These days, they prepare meals for the week ahead, go only on mini-vacations and limit their spending on clothing. Their dog, a one-and-a-half-year-old dachshund, is one of their larger expenses, as are two gym memberships, which set them back $105 a month.  Another significant expense they hope will lead to some side gigs is the rental of two workshops and tools, which cost the couple $683 a month. Cara uses the space to create jewellery and paintings she aims to sell while Will makes pocket knives and cutting boards.  As for the future, Cara wants to continue renting and to buy a cottage, but Will would prefer to buy a townhome.  Neither option is cheap: Townhomes in the area sell for $650,000 while cottages start at $400,000.  ‚ÄúI personally feel like we‚Äôll be shut out,‚Äù Cara says about home ownership. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking at other provinces versus staying in B.C.‚Äù  Their typical monthly expenses:  Investment and savings: $200  $200 to TFSA. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs with a credit union.‚Äù  $0 to RRSP. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm contributing nothing to my retirement right now. [Sebastian Staacks] built a video booth for his wedding, and the setup was so popular with family, that it was only fitting to do one better and make some improvements to the setup, Matrix-style. The ‚Äúbullet time‚Äù video effect was introduced by the classic movie franchise and makes for a splendid video transition effect for video montages.  Hardware-wise, the effect is pretty expensive, requiring many cameras at various angles to be simultaneously triggered, in order to capture the subject in a fixed pose with a rotating camera. Essentially you need as many cameras as frames in the sequence, so even at 24 frames per second (FPS), that‚Äôs a lot of hardware. [Sebastian] cheated a bit, and used a single front-facing camera for the bulk of the video recording, and twelve individual DSLRs covering approximately 90 degrees of rotation for the transition. More than that is likely impractical (not to mention rather expensive) for an automated setup used in as chaotic an environment as a wedding reception! So, the video effect is quite the same as in the movies, as this is a fixed pose, but it still looks pretty good.  [Sebastian] did consider going down the Raspberry Pi plus Pi-cam route, but once you add in a lens and the hassle of the casing and mounting hardware, not to mention availability and cost, snagging a pile of old DLSRs looks quite attractive. Connectivity to the camera is a simple 3.5 mm jack for the focus and trigger inputs, with frames read out via a USB connection.  For practical deployment, the camera batteries were replaced with battery eliminator adapters which step-up the 5 V from the USB connection to the 7.4 V the cameras need, but the current spike produced by the coordinated trigger of all twelve cameras overwhelmed any power supply available. The solution, to be practical, and not at all elegant, is to just have lots of power supplies hidden in a box. Sometimes you‚Äôve just got a job to do.  Reproducing this at home might be a bit awkward unless you have exactly the same hardware to hand, but the principles are sound, and there are a few interesting details to dig into, if you were so inclined.  We‚Äôve seen a few takes on the bullet-time effect over the years. We featured a Raspberry Pi-based hack, a couple of years back, and earlier still, someone even built a rig to take bullet-time videos of Tesla coil discharges, because why not?

A mum looking forward to her dream wedding has had to scale back her plans after excruciating back pain turned out to be terminal cancer. Sandra Jones, who lives in Wolverhampton, was diagnosed with bone cancer.  In a cruel twist of fate, she was given the news seven years to the day since she was told she had breast cancer. The mum-of-two, originally from the Wirral, found out in April that the disease had returned.  Her spine has been affected by the cancer, which has spread to her pelvis, femur, lungs, liver and lymph nodes. Now the 39-year-old's brother, Neil Jones, is trying to raise money to help Sandra adapt her house to make her as comfortable as possible.  READ MORE: Best flight deals from Birmingham Airport from Jet2, Ryanair, Tui and more  This includes changes to the bathroom as well as a stairlift. Any other money raised will go towards Sandra making happy memories with her partner of 16-years Adam and their two children, Brody, 11, and Beau, nine.  Neil, who lives in Oxfordshire and works for the RAF, told BlackCountryLive: "It's been difficult because I'm not close by to provide support. Her partner has had to reduce his work hours to help out and to spend as much time as possible with her.  "They haven't given her a timeframe but we know it's terminal." The 34-year-old went on: "Sandra is one of the most selfless people you could ever meet, she never puts herself before others and has always found a positive outlook in all that does.  "She tackled cancer the first time around and refused to let it get in the way of raising her family and giving her children the best start in life. Now at just 39, she must get ready for another battle.  "Her positivity is honestly inspirational, to not only deal with cancer once, but to be gearing up for another battle she knows she will ultimately lose." Sandra and Adam had planned to marry in Greece on their anniversary in June.  But they have now arranged a small civil ceremony in the UK instead. Adam proposed to Sandra as a family picture was being taken with their children on holiday.  "They're going to get married on the same day but in a small ceremony at a registry office," Neil said. "It will be their 16-year anniversary. They were supposed to go to Greece but had to cancel that but they still want to get married."  A GoFundMe page set up by Neil has so far raised ¬£6,000 to support the family. He continued: "The priority is to make changes to the house that are needed. They've got a conventional bathroom at the moment and she struggles with the stairs.  "She will get more tired with the treatment so we want to make any necessary changes we can do. Any money that's left over will be used for her to have fun days out with the kids to make memories. It is likely that she'll end up in a wheelchair because she gets so tired."  Speaking about the donations, he added: "It is incredible and I've been so overwhelmed with people's generosity. Some friends are coming up with ideas for fundraising."  Neil added that his nephew Brody and niece Beau are coming to terms with the news. He said: "Brody has asked a lot of questions and they've had to have an honest conversation with him. I think he understands it a lot more than Beau does."  You can visit the GoFundMe page here.  READ NEXT:

Warm weather, a glass of something fizzy and full on glam ‚Äì that's right, it's wedding season. But while the gorgeous photos from Jamie Laing and Sophie Habboo's Spanish nuptials nuptials last weekend gave us feel good vibes, planning such a monumental life event can be seriously stressful.  That's something you might know only too well if it's your best mate getting ready to say 'I do'. Worries about dress dramas, guest lists and hair disasters are enough to turn any beautiful bride into a seething hot mess, venting at her friends as she struggles to keep in control!  It‚Äôs every bridesmaid‚Äôs worst nightmare - dealing with the Bridezilla. Because regardless of how well you think you know your closest mate, you can never predict how the pressure of the fast-approaching nuptials will make her feel and act.  If you're a bridesmaid, or even just as a member of her support squad, your role isn‚Äôt simply to plan her the best hen party of all time. You‚Äôre there for her during every step of the way and of course, walk beside them (in person and/or emotionally) on their big day. So, how do you deal with a bride-to-be who‚Äôs letting the prospect of what should be the happiest day of their life transform them from super chill to a seething ball of stress?  (Image: Nearly Weds Podcast/Instagram)  Lisa Forde, wedding expert and founder of leading stationery company Tree of Hearts, is on hand with her top tips.  ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs your sister or childhood BF, you want what‚Äôs best for your bride-to-be, but it can often be really tricky knowing how to do this sensitively,‚Äù Lisa explains. ‚ÄúYou have your own life, which understandably doesn‚Äôt revolve around this upcoming wedding. But you‚Äôve been given and accepted a very important role and need to act accordingly to prevent any major friendship fallouts.‚Äù  RULE 1: Keep calm and carry on  ‚ÄúIn true British style, you need to stay calm and carry on. Be patient with your bride - even if you want to strangle her - and try to give her the benefit of the doubt when she‚Äôs having a Bridezilla moment.‚Äù  (Image: Getty Images)  RULE 2: Don‚Äôt take it personally  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not you - it‚Äôs her! Sometimes wedding planning brings out the worst in people, the bride may snap and bark orders, and it‚Äôs easy to get offended and wonder if you‚Äôve done something wrong. Try not to get upset about it, it‚Äôs almost certainly not your fault, It's probably not you the bride-to-be is mad at.‚Äù  RULE 3: Talk to her  ‚ÄúWedding planning is an incredibly stressful time, and stress can make people behave in ways they normally wouldn‚Äôt. If your bestie strays toward the Bridezilla territory, maybe consider letting her know, she may not even realise that she‚Äôs turning nasty.‚Äù  (Image: Getty Images)  RULE 4: Plan something away from wedding prep  Maybe it‚Äôs worth planning a day out to distract the bride-to-be from her wedding planning duties and remind you of the bestie she once was. Maybe invite the rest of the bridal party but explain it is a wedding-planning free zone. Let her take her hair down and relax.  RULE 5: Step away‚Ä¶  ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs all getting too much and impacting your own life and mental health, don‚Äôt be afraid to remove yourself from the situation. You need to give your reasons and be clear so they are able to understand. It might be an emotional conversation, but try to remain confident in your decision and remember why you have made it.‚Äù  READ MORE:

US First Lady Jill Biden will attend the Royal wedding of the Jordanian Crown Prince Prince Hussein and Rajwa Al Saif, as part of a trip to the Middle East and North Africa, AP reported on Saturday.  It will be Biden's first visit to the Middle East as first lady.  She is scheduled to start her six-day trip on Wednesday. And, she will visit Egypt, Morocco and Portugal.  Biden's Spokesperson Vanessa Valdivia said: ‚ÄúThe first lady believes that supporting youth across the world is critical to our common future, with education, health and empowerment at the heart of it.‚Äù  She added: ‚ÄúWith her visit to the Middle East and North Africa, the first lady will continue to build on her work to empower young people, and reaffirm our commitment to strengthen our partnerships and advance our shared priorities in the region."

Wedding forces Ruturaj Gaikwad to miss WTC Final 2023, Yashasvi Jaiswal to join squad as STANDBY opener  Ruturaj Gaikwad will not make the trip to London for the World Test Championship. The CSK star is set to get married‚Ä¶  Ruturaj Gaikwad will not make the trip to London for the World Test Championship. The CSK star is set to get married next month, ruling him out of action. In his absence, Yashasvi Jaiswal will travel as one of the reserves. Follow Indian Premier League LIVE updates on Insidesport.IN  ‚ÄúHe (Jaiswal) will be joining the Indian team as Gaikwad has informed us that he won‚Äôt be able to fly due to his marriage. He would be able to join the team post-June 5. (But) Coach Rahul Dravid took a call, asking the selectors to pick a replacement. So, Jaiswal will now fly to London soon,‚Äù a BCCI official told The Indian Express.  Gaikwad was initially added by the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) as a backup opener for the WTC Final, in which India would play Australia at The Oval on June 7. When Gaikwad told the BCCI he could join the team after June 5, Rahul Dravid immediately started looking for a substitute. The cricket board was told of Ruturaj Gaikwad‚Äôs impending wedding on June 3‚Äì4.  According to The Indian Express, Jaiswal will be travelling to London in a few days because the team management has asked him to start exercising with the red ball and he already has a UK visa. This season, Jaiswal has been in excellent shape. He amassed 625 runs while representing Rajasthan Royals in the IPL over the course of 14 games, and 404 runs over the course of five games in the Ranji Trophy.  Ishan Kishan and Rohit Sharma, the captain of India, will fly to London on May 28. Suryakumar Yadav and Mohammed Shami, Shubman Gill, and Ravindra Jadeja, who will play in the IPL final on Sunday, will leave on May 30. Sylviana Hamdani  ANN/THE JAKARTA POST ‚Äì Designers and experts in the industry talk about emerging wedding trends in Indonesia after the pandemic. Indonesia‚Äôs penchant for big weddings, which often host thousands of guests in luxurious settings, is likely to return now that the COVID-19 pandemic is ending.  As seen in a string of wedding expos in Jakarta since the end of last year, beaming brides-and-grooms-to-be have thronging vendors‚Äô booths as they plan for their perfect day.  ‚ÄúThe industry‚Äôs been steadily looking up since 2022,‚Äù Indonesian wedding community Weddingku chief executive officer Tono Raharja said when interviewed by The Jakarta Post at the Indonesia Dream Wedding Festival 2023 (IDWF 2023) at the Jakarta Convention Centre.  Prior to the pandemic, Indonesia was known to be among a few countries that maintains the tradition of celebrating weddings with large-scale parties.  ‚ÄúI think Indonesia has the largest (scale) of wedding parties in Asia, after India and Thailand,‚Äù Tono added. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm optimistic that these (large-scale) weddings will return as soon as the pandemic ends.‚Äù  Here are some new trends the pandemic has brought into weddings:  HOTEL BALLROOMS WITH A DREAMY DECOR  ‚ÄúBusiness is going back to normal now,‚Äù Priyanto, representative of the wedding organiser Anastasia Project, said at the IDWF 2023. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre handling weddings with 400 to 1,000 invitees every week.‚Äù  While outdoor parties were the preference at the height of the pandemic, many brides and grooms choose to host their weddings in hotel ballrooms again these days.  ‚Äú(Having weddings in hotel‚Äôs ballrooms) has always been the main preference of many Indonesians before the pandemic,‚Äù Priyanto added. ‚ÄúIt seems that the trend‚Äôs returning now.‚Äù  Michelle Paris Decorations representative Mey Lie agreed.  ‚ÄúHotels have (all the facilities) that clients need for a big wedding,‚Äù Mey Lie said. ‚ÄúPlus, (hosting weddings in a hotel ballroom) is weather-safe.‚Äù Ayana Midplaza Jakarta has seen the number of wedding reservations almost return to normal.  ‚Äú(The number of reservations) are getting almost normal,‚Äù senior sales manager of Ayana Midplaza Jakarta Silva Rosalia said at the IDWF 2023.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been seeing an 85 per cent increase in ballroom bookings for weddings (since the pandemic)‚Äù, But there is a slight change in behaviour among customers due to COVID-19.  ‚ÄúBefore the pandemic, customers usually made their (ballroom) bookings at least a year before the planned event,‚Äù Silva said.  ‚ÄúBut these days, they book the venue just three or six months beforehand as many of them are still worried that (the infection rate of COVID-19 will rise again.‚Äù  Aston Sentul Lake Resort and Conference Centre has also received many ballroom wedding bookings these days.  ‚ÄúOur clients are excited that there are no more social restrictions,‚Äù sales executive of the hotel Novita Sari said.  ‚ÄúMany of them now request for (weddings with) a full decor, which includes lots of flowers and (indoor) pergolas.‚Äù  Mey Lie of Michelle Paris Decorations greatly enjoys the hike of exciting new client demands.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been so long since we‚Äôve created such exciting wedding decors,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd now, our artistic brains are exploding with new ideas.‚Äù  During the IDWF 2023, the decorator presented a platform designed like a storybook page, embellished with carved wooden horses and lighted wire butterflies. A mix of blue and magenta ambient lighting creates a dreamy feel about the decor.  ‚Äú(The blue, magenta ambient lighting) is trending now in Jakarta,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs quite a departure from the warm-white wedding (decor) glow during COVID-19.‚Äù  WEDDING DRESSES: SIMPLE WITH DISCREET EMBELLISHMENTS  While wedding decors are getting more extravagant, wedding dresses are becoming simpler.  ‚ÄúAfter the pandemic, everyone prefers a simpler outfit while still maintaining their signature (fashion) style,‚Äù bridal designer Hian Tjen said when interviewed at the launch of a new jewellery collection by Adelle Jewellery x Hian Tjen at Bridestory Market at the Indonesia Convention Exhibition (ICE) in BSD city, Tangerang.  ‚ÄúThus, many brides now favour flowy, loose-fitted wedding gowns with discreet beadings and embroideries.‚Äù  Bridal designer Petrick Sutrisno confirmed this new, more straightforward trend of wedding dresses.  ‚ÄúFull-blown (wedding) gowns are so last year,‚Äù Petrick said. ‚ÄúCustomers prefer simpler, lighter wedding dresses that allow them to move freely and dance.‚Äù  During the IDWF 2023, Petrick showcased two structured semi-ball gowns made of crinoline and silk. While plunging necklines is still preferred in wedding dresses, many now request to have them covered with semi-transparent panels.  ‚ÄúThe semi-transparent panels, subtly adorned with sequins, add more class and decorum to the dress,‚Äù Petrick, who is based in Pluit, Karang Barat, North Jakarta, said.  WEDDING SUITS: SLIM, DOUBLE-BREASTED, CONVERTIBLE TUXES  Many men still prefer to play it safe regarding wedding attire.  ‚ÄúThe classic black tuxedo is still the main choice of our clients for their weddings,‚Äù Tika, representative of Wong Hang Distinguished Tailor, said at the Bridestory Market at ICE BSD, Tangerang.  The renowned bespoke tailor also offers tuxedos fitted with detachable satin lapels and pockets.  ‚ÄúBy taking out (the detachable parts), they can convert the tux into a formal jacket and wear it to many other occasions,‚Äù Tika added.  Besides the classic tux, slim-fit, double-breasted jackets are becoming popular as men‚Äôs wedding attire. ‚ÄúMany of my customers now prefer Italian-style (double-breasted) jackets with relaxed shoulders,‚Äù Henri Winata said at the Bridestory Market at ICE BSD, Tangerang. Wedding suits, made of patterned wool materials, are also becoming a favourite.  ‚ÄúAmong the preferred patterns (for wedding suits) are Prince-of-Wales, Puppytooth and Herringbone,‚Äù the designer (Henri Winata), who studied at Savile Row Academy in London, said.  ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre classics and yet show more character.‚Äù  WEDDING RINGS: TRILOGY AND DIAMOND-LACED  Rings are small yet essential items that bind these once-and-forever love affairs. In this matter, men also opt for the more classic styles.  ‚Äú(Men‚Äôs) wedding bands are usually plain and embellished with a combination of glossy and matte finishing,‚Äù Mondial sales representative Andre said at the IDWF 2023.  Trilogy, a new style of wedding ring featuring a string of three medium-sized diamonds, is very popular among Gen Zs and millennials.  ‚ÄúThe three diamonds (in the Trilogy rings) represent the past, the present and the future,‚Äù Andre said. Besides the Trilogy, diamond-laced wedding bands, known as Tennis Rings, are becoming a favourite among many Indonesian brides.  ‚ÄúThe slim (Tennis) ring, adorned with small, symmetrical diamonds all around, looks very sweet and adorable on women‚Äôs hands,‚Äù Michael Surya, CEO of the local jewellery brand Adelle Jewellery, said at the Bridestory Market at ICE BSD, Tangerang.  During the interview, Michael also shared some tips for choosing the perfect wedding ring for you and your spouse.  ‚ÄúFirst of all, determine a style that you both like and will like for a long time,‚Äù Michael said.  With style in mind, you and your spouse can now visit jewellery houses and see if they have anything suitable to your liking.  Alternatively, you can design your own and make them with a jeweller.  ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôd like to order a specific pair of rings, don‚Äôt forget to allow some time to have it made,‚Äù Michael said. ‚ÄúA jeweller usually takes three to six months to produce them.‚Äù  Last but not least, you should always choose to purchase your wedding rings from a reputable jeweller.  ‚ÄúThere should be no regrets in these precious, once-in-a-lifetime items,‚Äù Michael concluded.
