Lorry Myers  I cried at the wedding. The words were beautiful, just like the bride, and now here I was at the reception, my toes tapping underneath the table.  The bride and my bridesmaid daughter Mariah are childhood friends, so the evening was full of young people loving each other and living their best life. The first dance was over, and now the DJ was luring everyone to the dance floor.  Everyone but me.  Even after two years, I am still learning the ways of widowhood, how to navigate all the ‚Äúfirsts‚Äù that come after the ‚Äúlasts.‚Äù This was the first time I RSVP‚Äôd for one, my first wedding that I had no arm to take and, now, my first dance where I had no one to dance with. Wedding dance music is predictable, thank goodness, because I want to hear all those familiar tunes I have danced to countless times before.  That night, I was content to tap my toes.  The DJ was on it and a mob of young women took over the floor, celebrating their friend and their night out. After that, dads danced with their daughters and little boys practiced their breakdance moves. The line dancers lined up and the two-steppers stepped out.  Then the music shifted to something slow and smooth, and couples automatically floated to the floor and into each other‚Äôs arms. Until that moment, I had not thought about a dance without a dance partner or my past years of slow dancing.  My toes suddenly stopped tapping.  Looking around, the tables were mostly empty as the dancers paired up. There were established couples practiced in their moves from years of dancing together. There were young couples, still new to each other and trying to find their own moves. Then there were a few couples who spent the dance talking to each other.  A slow dance is different with different partners.  When I danced with my dad, I learned that he had a little dip instead of a fourth step. That‚Äôs the way he danced with my mother, so I learned that move too.  My husband Randy liked to turn after every fourth count and took a step back after every third step forward. One hand rested on my lower back pulling me close, and his other hand held mine across his chest.  Those were the days.  My husband preferred slow dancing over fast dancing and waited for a song he knew, something predictable, before he asked. Every song Randy chose to slow dance with me was the same.  They were all love songs.  I was at my table when the DJ played one of those songs. It was the classic about ‚Äúlonely rivers flowing to the sea,‚Äù and suddenly I felt all those things. I looked around and noticed I was the only one sitting ‚Äî everyone else had someone else.  I was by myself.  I saw him out of the corner of my eye; it was Joel, the matron of honor‚Äôs husband and my family‚Äôs friend. Joel is a quiet guy, steady and strong and sure. But that night, he seemed uncertain as he offered me his hand.  ‚ÄúWould you like to dance?‚Äù Joel asked. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt find my wife.‚Äù  With that, I took Joel‚Äôs hand and we danced. The whole time, I smiled, remembering the last time I danced and how safe and protected I felt in this, my first dance. I don‚Äôt know if Joel understood, but when he reached out his hand, I grabbed it like it was a lifeline to the rest of my life.  I don‚Äôt think he will ever know what asking me to dance meant. It was a reminder that life goes on, that people are good, and I am never by myself. That night, Joel saw that my toes had stopped tapping and held out his hand.  That, or his wife was missing and he just wanted to dance.  You can reach Lorry at lorrysstorys@gmail.com.

A mom has been criticized for wearing a $5,215 white wedding dress to her daughter‚Äôs big day.  The Norma and Lily Couture gown was listed for sale on the Facebook marketplace after the wedding, labeled an ‚Äúevening mother of the bride dress‚Äù.  The mom was also seen with her daughter in a white gown in the photos.  The photos were reposted on a ‚Äúwedding shaming‚Äù Facebook group with the caption ‚Äú$8,000 [$5,215 USD] mother of the bride dress ‚Ä¶ Ma‚Äôam, that is a wedding dress.‚Äù  Many users were stunned by the frock and couldn‚Äôt believe the price.  ‚ÄúOh god, it has a train as well,‚Äù one wrote.  ‚ÄúDefinitely thought this was a wedding dress. Yikes!‚Äù another said.  ‚Äú$8,000 [$5,215 USD]?! Oh, did all the audacity cost extra?‚Äù a third person wrote.  ‚Äò‚ÄôYou just know she was bridal dress shopping with her daughter and saw this dress, and immediately bought it before anyone could stop her,‚Äù a fourth person said.  Commenters were swift to put the woman in her place. via News.com.au  One person commented, ‚ÄúShe wouldn‚Äôt be allowed at my wedding, I don‚Äôt care who she is.‚Äù  ‚ÄúMy daughter would have killed me if I bought that for her wedding,‚Äù one mom wrote.  Others defended the mother of the bride, explaining a little-known cultural tradition.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs quite common for Lebanese mothers to wear white dresses like this to their daughter‚Äôs weddings,‚Äù one woman said.  ‚ÄúNorma and Lily are one of the top Lebanese designers in the industry ‚Äì I‚Äôm surprised she only paid $8000 [$5,215 USD] for this.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThis is a cultural thing in Lebanon. I‚Äôve only ever attended one Lebanese wedding and I was shocked when I saw the mother of the bride in a white dress,‚Äù a second person revealed.  ‚ÄúWhere I‚Äôm from, that‚Äôs asking for a strategic red wine spill from a bridesmaid.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the same with Thai weddings,‚Äù another shared.  ‚ÄúI was horrified when my stepmother wore white ‚Äì until I realized the mother of the groom followed a similar custom.‚Äù

CLEVELAND, Ohio ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd end up doing a few columns on weddings, but it‚Äôs a topic that connects with readers. In the near future, I will use some of the responses from my previous column about the price of weddings ‚Äì and also having the courage to break off an engagement, regardless of how it looks to others.  But I love this from Ann Heyward:  ‚ÄúA wedding is often the first real exercise in making decisions together as a couple. Don‚Äôt follow the expectations of others, especially from social media. Think about how to have the day reflect your values as a couple.‚Äù  Maybe it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm male and dense about these things, but it never occurred to me that the wedding ‚Äúis the first exercise in making decisions as a couple.‚Äù But it is, at least in terms of being the first major decision after you agree to marry each other.  You can either plan your wedding, or let others impose their will on you.  A warning sign is if one person wants a huge, elaborate and expensive wedding, and the other wants to keep it small, simple and yes ‚Äì to be kind ‚Äì frugal.  If this can‚Äôt be resolved without one party feeling trampled, look out.  Or if both parties agree on the type of wedding, but they can‚Äôt withstand the pressure from other family members to do it their way ‚Äì trouble will probably follow.  Here‚Äôs the disclaimer: Suppose both parties want a big wedding but also want the parents to pay for it. Suppose the parents can‚Äôt or won‚Äôt do it ‚Äì that‚Äôs something the couple needs to resolve. Too many young couples expect someone else to take on the cost of an expensive wedding.  The average wedding costs $30,000. One man wrote me that he paid for two weddings, combined cost was $90,000. If people want to and can afford it ‚Äì wonderful. But the marriage has to be about so much more than the wedding day.  ONCE UPON A TIME  Roberta and I knew each other nearly four years before we were married. We met in German class during my freshman year at Hiram College. A year later, my father was laid off. I transferred to Cleveland State to live at home. The idea was to save tuition costs and work while getting my degree in secondary education with a social studies major and English minor.  Roberta is two years older. We stayed in touch after she graduated with a biology degree and worked as a laboratory technician at Metro General Hospital in Cleveland.  After graduating from CSU, I sent out at least 50 resumes with copies of stories that I wrote while working part-time at the old Cleveland Press. I also sold three stories to the old Plain Dealer Sunday Magazine while in college.  This was in the typewriter days. And who typed out all those cover letters and resumes?  One guess.  The same woman who has lived with me for the last 45 years, serving as the first edit on my books and many of my stories.  We were sort of unofficially engaged. When I received a job offer from the Greensboro (N.C.) News-Record, I moved south. Within a few weeks, I knew we needed to get married.  But I also became fearful. My parents had a stormy marriage. My mother knew Roberta well and loved her, but she also remembered being an 18-year-old bride who married quickly to my father as World War II broke out.  She wanted me to wait. Roberta and I knew each other far better than my parents did when they were married. Finally, Roberta pushed me over the finish line: Get married, or we‚Äôre done.  PLANNING THE WEDDING  I don‚Äôt recall a long discussion about our wedding. I wanted three things:  Keep it small. Get married in a church. Have a chocolate wedding cake.  Roberta was on board for that. We were married in St. Clement‚Äôs Episicol Church, her home church in Greenville, Pa. Her mother, Elizabeth Monroe, took over the wedding. Roberta is a no-frills person. To her, smaller is better.  The guest list was about 20. Her mom made Roberta‚Äôs dress. Her veil was handed down from several generations of women in her mother‚Äôs family.  I was married in what now looks like an awful gaudy 1970s style green sportcoat. Roberta mentioned we had to find a green pair of pants to match that dreadful coat‚Ä¶which she did. YIKES!  No members of our wedding party were told to wear anything except what they wanted. Even in our early 20s, we knew the wedding was about making a commitment to each other ‚Äì not a style statement to impress others.  My mother-in-law secured the church and had a small reception at the Greenville Country Club.  That was it. My guess is the cost could not have been much more than $1,500.  And yes, we had chocolate cake!  ‚ÄúThe color may have faded from the Plutos‚Äô wedding photo (thankfully, for Terry‚Äôs sake?) but their love for each other remains as vibrant as that day in 1977. Courtesy, Terry Pluto  YES, 45 YEARS!  I received this email from Gwen Smith, who also was married in 1977 ‚Äì the same year that I married Roberta.  ‚ÄúWe paid for most of the wedding...parents contributed what they could. We had a Christmas wedding (Dec. 30) and saved on church flowers.  ‚ÄúMy bridesmaids made their gowns and capes. I made and decorated their fur muffs. Groomsmen wore boutonnieres of holly my husband got from his boss‚Äôs holly farm. I made a large silk rose and pearl rosary to wrap around Mother Mary‚Äôs hands at the Pieta statue.  ‚ÄúOur invitations were printed on Christmas cards. We came down the aisle to ‚ÄòOh Come All Ye Faithful,‚Äô and ‚ÄòOh Come, Oh Come Emmanuel‚Äô was the Communion hymn. Because Elvis Presley died that year, music before the ceremony included ‚ÄòI Can‚Äôt Help Falling in Love With You.‚Äô Barbra Streisand‚Äôs ‚ÄòEvergreen‚Äô was the reflection hymn.  ‚ÄúI wore my mother‚Äôs dress and my Communion veil ..both a little altered. People were amazed at the beauty of it all. It is a night we reminisce about often after 45 years....magical!‚Äù  Maybe these stories sound like they come from another era, but I present them not to tell you what to do. Rather, to present an alternative to the wedding industrial complex that sends many couples and their parents into major debt even before anyone says ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù

By India Today City Desk: A fight broke out during a wedding celebration between two groups of political rivals in Moth area of Jhansi district in Uttar Pradesh.  The dispute started when the song 'Baap to baap hota hai' was played by the DJ which didn't sit well with the guest party. It was also revealed that there was tension between the two Muslim parties because of Uttar Pradesh's Municipal Elections.  advertisement  The altercation escalated to the point where stones were thrown and bottles were hurled at each other, resulting in multiple injuries. The situation quickly spiralled into a state of chaos.  As soon as the information reached the authorities, police forces including high-ranking officials from various police stations rushed to the scene to bring the situation under control.  Gopi Nath, the Rural Police Superintendent, said that the fight broke out because of the song that ignited tension between both parties.  (With inputs from Pramod Gautam)

Marriage is considered a special union for the bride and the groom. It is not only special for the couple but also for their families. In India, weddings are a splendorous affair involving two families exchanging their cultures and traditions with each other. While some are arranged marriages, there are some who tie the knot with their childhood sweethearts. The day marks the beginning of a new life with their significant other. Recently, a video went viral on social media where a groom was seen dancing his heart out on his wedding day.  A hilarious video was shared on Twitter by an account named @HasnaZarooriHai who captioned the video, ‚ÄúIn today‚Äôs time, the groom‚Äôs dancing skills fail everyone in dancing." In the viral video, the groom is seen capturing the attention of the guests by showcasing his exceptional dancing skills. He is wearing a cream-coloured sherwani with a red turban in the video.  Initially, he is seen dancing alone, but later he involves his friends as well. Seeing him happily dance, many people said that he seems like a Zumba instructor or a choreographer, as he is able to make others follow his steps as well.  One of the users wrote, ‚ÄúHe is dancing like a Zumba instructor at his wedding". Another user commented, ‚ÄúThere is so much flexibility in the sherwani". So far, the viral video has received 60,000 views and 1,000 likes on social media.  top videos  Recently, another wedding video went viral on the internet, in which the couple were seen getting married in the rain. Aja Dang-Puspos arrived to champagne and strawberries at her bachelorette celebration in July 2022 at the Civana Wellness Resort and Spa in Carefree, Ariz. Her meticulously planned itinerary for the week included spa treatments, healing work featuring a sound bath and reiki, and plenty of resort activities, such as water aerobics and pickleball.  Ms. Dang-Puspos, 36, a small-business owner and YouTube content creator based in Los Angeles, was excited about having a week of rest, self-care and indulgence. She had everything she wanted for her bachelorette, but it was missing one common element: guests. It was a solo bachelorette party.  ‚ÄúIt was the most stress-free process,‚Äù Ms. Dang-Puspos said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want anyone to ask me questions about what to do, where to eat, where to go. I just wanted to be pampered.‚Äù  Ms. Dang-Puspos‚Äôs party is a departure from the stereotypical, more popular type of bachelorette celebrations ‚Äî where groups of women wear matching T-shirts and go bar hopping through a city such as Nashville, for instance, or rent houses filled with party d√©cor and animal-shaped pool floats in Scottsdale, Ariz. Nearly 80 percent of couples reported having a bachelorette party in 2022, according to The Knot, and the average number of attendees was 10 people; only 11 percent of people hosted a party with one to five guests.

Whether you're getting ready to tie the knot with your partner or you've been asked to officiate a family member or friend's wedding, you probably have some questions about the legalities of the whole process. Before you do anything‚Äîand no matter who you choose to officiate your wedding‚Äîit's essential that you first check the laws in your local county (or the county in which you are getting married!) to ensure your chosen officiant fits the bill from a legal standpoint. Why? Marriage laws and regulations vary from state to state and even county to county, so there are a lot of nuances to account for, and some states don't allow certain officiant types to perform legal marriages. In general, you'll find that the person who can legally perform the marriage is one of several types of officiants: Civil, professional, ordained, or religious.  When it comes to choosing the right person, this is something you, as partners, should discuss carefully before you begin planning the wedding. "Regardless of whether couples choose a friend or family member, or a professional, their celebrant needs to listen and hold space for them, both during the planning and writing phases, and then during the ceremony itself," says Lewis King, the executive director of American Marriage Ministries. "In practice, this means finding someone who can build that bridge between what makes the couple unique, and what is universal and accessible to their guests."  Below, we outline the difference between each kind of wedding officiant, with input from an expert, so that you can make the best‚Äîand legal‚Äîdecision for your big day.  Meet the Expert Lewis King is the executive director of American Marriage Ministries.  What Is a Civil Officiant?  A civil officiant is a person who has gone through a formal, legal process to become recognized as an officiant. An example of a civil officiant is a justice of the peace or a magistrate, but anyone can become a civil officiant. If you are planning a civil ceremony‚Äîwhich is a non-religious, legal marriage ceremony‚Äîa civil officiant will perform the marriage.  What Is an Ordained Officiant?  If a couple would like a close friend or family member to officiate their wedding, that person can receive the legal ability to be an officiant through non-denominational churches, nonprofit organizations, and online services that offer the ability to get legally recognized as an officiant. Note that state laws vary, and many will require the marriage officiant to also be registered with the state where the marriage ceremony is taking place ahead of the wedding.  What Is a Professional Officiant  There are many non-religious and non-civil officiants, also called celebrants, who offer marriage officiant services as well as guidance for writing vows and planning a wedding ceremony (this may include non-denominational ceremonies, interfaith ceremonies, and spiritual ceremonies). These professionals are licensed officiants who have lots of experience officiating weddings. If you're not sure that you want a civil or religious officiant, and you don't have a friend or family member performing the ceremony, a celebrant is a great option.  "Couples should look for a professional officiant with similar qualities, with whom they feel a connection and shared vision for the ceremony," advises King. "Since [the couple] is probably hiring someone off the internet, it's important to read reviews and to find someone who specializes in the kind of ceremony they have in mind."  What Is a Religious Officiant?  A religious officiant is someone who is ordained by a specific religious denomination as a member of the clergy and is typically a leader within their faith, like a minister, priest, imam, or rabbi, who performs marriage ceremonies at their place of worship. Take note that while many people can become religiously ordained to perform a marriage, some states have limits to who they consider a religious officiant.

NFL player Camryn Bynum is married!  The Minnesota Vikings safety, 24, said "I do" to Lalaine Bynum in an romantic wedding celebration off the coast of the Philippines on March 2.  "We envisioned a beautiful private and intimate beach wedding with our closest family and friends," the bride told PEOPLE of the couple's special day. "Our goal was to make it a party to celebrate love and two families coming together."  For their nuptials, the groom walked down the aisle to a "Still Dre" and "Tadow" mashup by Masego, while Lalaine, in a beautiful white sheer fabric gown by Viktoria MNL made her entrance to "Back at One" by Brian McKnight.  "We wanted guests to be fully present at the ceremony as we exchanged vows, so we requested that all cell phones and cameras be turned off and not used," Camryn explains. "We also had an intimate time of prayer and live worship songs together."  Courtesy of Kay Jewelers  RELATED: All the Celebrity Weddings of 2023  The couple, who chose rose pink decor with accents of ivory and gold, opted to write their own handwritten vows from the heart.  During the reception, the pair kicked off their marriage with a first dance to Deborah Cox's "Nobody's Supposed to Be Here."  Guests dined on a buffet style dinner with several filipino delicacies and a three tiered wedding cake with fresh flowers that included carrot, red velvet and strawberry flavors.  RELATED: Couple Gets Married at Oscar Mayer 'Wienermobile of Love' Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas: See the Photos!  Camryn adds that his bride caught his attention from first moment he saw her during a chance encounter in Dubai. The pro football player was on a family vacation when he spotted Lalaine dancing at a hotel they visited.  "My eyes immediately focused on her because of her infectious smile and her energy that lit up the stage. My family urged me to meet her and they introduced us. I knew that there was instant chemistry and the rest is history," he says.  The pair began dating and later got engaged in February when Camryn popped the question.  Courtesy of Kay Jewelers  "What I love most about Lalaine is that she simply enjoys life, just like me, she doesn't take many things too seriously," says Camryn who chose a custom wedding band from Kay Jewelers. "She is always in the mood to joke around. We are both selfless people, so serving each other comes easy."  When it came to choosing their jewelry for their big day, the pair decided to go all out.  "Shining and flawless!," says Camryn. "Neither of us have even been flashy but on this special day we embraced the opportunity to select jewelry that reflects the biggest, most profound day of our lives together."  Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from juicy celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.  As for what comes next, the newlyweds are dedicated to growing Camryn's Bynum Faith Foundation, which helps to provide weekly feeding operations in Tondo, Philippines. Camryn and Lalaine add that they are passionate about providing outreach and resources to those in need.  "Our love for one another and shared desire to help others is actively seen in our relief efforts," says Camryn. The time spent together in doing so positively impacts us both as we serve and bless others."

Celebrity chef and best-selling author Sandra Lee, 56, is loving life ‚Äî and her fiance. With a wedding on the horizon, it‚Äôs no wonder the breast cancer survivor is thriving after overcoming her disease.  Lee, the ex-girlfriend of former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, was diagnosed with breast cancer in early 2015. A successful double mastectomy ‚Äì the removal of all breast tissue ‚Äì led to a remission she‚Äôs still enjoying today.  But her health issues didn‚Äôt stop there. During a routine gynecology appointment, her doctor found ‚Äú a change in some of [her] cells. ‚Äù A second and third opinion came to the same conclusion, so she eventually underwent a preventative hysterectomy ‚Äì the surgical removal of the uterus and, usually, the cervix ‚Äì after putting off the procedure for a few years. Hysterectomy patients may also have surrounding organs and tissues removed depending on the reason for the surgery, but it‚Äôs unclear exactly what Lee had removed.  ‚ÄúHopefully this will encourage anyone who needs to get a concerning procedure done to take the opportunity now so you can live as happy and healthy as possible,‚Äù she wrote around the time of her surgery in March 2022. ‚ÄúWe must all live our best lives every day and in every way.‚Äù  Thankfully, Lee is well past her active and preventative cancer treatments and living life to the fullest. Her Instagram is full of love and light with plenty of smiling snaps featuring her fianc√©, Ben Youcef, 44.  View this post on Instagram A post shared by Sandra Lee (@sandraleeonline)  Lee and Youcef began dating in 2021 after reportedly meeting at a restaurant in Santa Monica, California, and the couple got engaged in August of the same year.  It‚Äôs unclear when Lee and Youcef will officially tie the knot, but a source recently told Page Six the two are ‚Äúdefinitely in the midst of planning their wedding‚Äù and ‚Äúlooking at places in New York and the Hamptons.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre soulmates and head over heels in love,‚Äù another source said after their engagement.  Thriving After Cancer Like Sandra Lee  Life on the other side of a cancer battle can bring a whole new host of anxieties. And you might even need further treatment ‚Äì like in the case of Sandra Lee ‚Äì to reduce your risk of developing cancer again.  Genetic Testing: What Is It and Why Is It Important? An Interview with Breast Cancer Previvor Erika Stallings  It‚Äôs important to know, however, that your feelings after cancer treatment are valid, and many other survivors struggle after overcoming the disease.  ‚ÄúIn life after cancer, I experienced an entirely new level of anxiety that I didn‚Äôt know existed,‚Äù Hodgkin lymphoma survivor CC Webster told SurvivorNet.  ‚ÄúEarth-shattering anxiety that makes you sweat, and makes your heart race.‚Äù  After learning how ‚Äúto process the trauma that [she] had just been through,‚Äù Webster was able to get back to living life on her own terms.  Follow That Fire: Life After Cancer Will be Different, That Doesn‚Äôt Have to be a Bad Thing  ‚ÄúThe thing that helped me the most in managing myself is to allow yourself to process the worry,‚Äù she said.  ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre brave enough to look fear, or worry, or anxiety in the face, it goes away.  ‚ÄúThe whole process of being sick, especially at a young age, gives you more perspective on yourself and on the life that you want, because we‚Äôve gotten the second chance. And if you can be bad ass enough to follow that fire, it is an amazing thing. It will take you places where you didn‚Äôt even know existed.‚Äù  Webster and Lee, like so many cancer survivors, learned how to process the emotional toll of their diseases and move forward with strength. And survivors like Marecya Burton even find new passions after their battles.  Former College Cheerleader Reinvents Herself After Surviving Ovarian Cancer  Following her ovarian cancer diagnosis at just 20 years old, Burton realized she would no longer be able to pursue a law degree right after graduation.  ‚ÄúI really had to, in a sense, put my life on hold,‚Äù she told SurvivorNet. ‚ÄúSometimes I look at where I am, and I can‚Äôt help but wonder, would I be further had I not had my diagnosis?‚Äù  But instead of going to law school, Burton found a love for education. She became a high school teacher in Baltimore, Maryland, and she‚Äôs since embraced her new direction in life.  ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt change my career for the world,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so fulfilling.‚Äù  Learn more about SurvivorNet's rigorous medical review process.
2.  This maid of honor who backed out of the wedding because the bride's fianc√© got into a car accident and let the maid of honor's husband take the blame to commit insurance fraud:

The brother was killed in an accident while carrying the greeting cards and wedding photo of his only sister‚Äôs wedding with the groom‚Äôs father. The groom‚Äôs father was seriously injured in the accident.  The deceased has been identified as Bimsara Prabod Ranasinghe (15) of Kotigala, Hadapangoda.  The wedding was held yesterday (25) with the participation of both parties and after the bride left the groom‚Äôs house, the groom‚Äôs father and the bride‚Äôs brother were coming on the Kurana road by motorcycle with printed wedding photo cards. Lew and Doreen Day with a picture of Queen Camilla and King Charles, who will soon be sending a letter to Lew for his 100th birthday. Photo / Paul Taylor  Lew and Doreen Day with a picture of Queen Camilla and King Charles, who will soon be sending a letter to Lew for his 100th birthday. Photo / Paul Taylor  Doreen Day speaks with pride sitting alongside her husband Lew as she fondly remembers some of the highlights of their incredibly long married life together.  It would be difficult to find a more high-flying couple than Lew, 99, and Doreen, 93, who are both qualified pilots and celebrated their 76th wedding anniversary this week.  Lew, turning 100 on July 17, was living in Napier when he enlisted in the RNZAF in 1942 and flew Sunderland flying boat patrol bombers during WWII.  They met not long after his return to New Zealand, while Lew‚Äôs brother was dating Doreen‚Äôs sister, and the new couple dated for a few months before marrying.  ‚ÄúI had to move quickly, otherwise she would have said no,‚Äù Lew said.  The pair were married in Pukekohe on May 24, 1947. Their ‚Äòhoneymoon‚Äô was a seven-week trip on a boat transporting frozen goods in stormy weather, to move to the UK.  Lew took a commission in the RAF with whom he flew in the Malayan Emergency and the Korean War. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for gallantry.  While Lew flew for the RAF, Doreen raised their three sons in the UK and Singapore before they eventually moved back to Aotearoa.  Their son Brian joked that the secret to the longevity of his parents‚Äô marriage was the time they spent apart while Lew worked as a pilot. Doreen said the reality was they simply had a ‚Äúfabulous life‚Äù together.  A young Lew and Doreen Day, who were married in Pukekohe on May 24, 1947. Photo / Day Family  She describes the moment when Lew was awarded a decoration from Queen Elizabeth II and the Queen asked him what his other ribbons were for.  ‚ÄúThe lady next to me said, ‚ÄòWho is that? Who is she talking to?‚Äô and I said, ‚ÄòMy husband‚Äô,‚Äù Doreen laughed.  Lew was an instructor at the Central Flying School at Cranwell, UK, before they returned to New Zealand in 1962 where he worked as a flight instructor, then a corporate pilot and went on to fly air ambulances.  Dorren said Lew taught Laura Margaret Grenfell, the wife of Sir Bernard Fergusson, who was New Zealand‚Äôs governor-general at the time, how to pilot an aircraft.  ‚ÄúThat was marvellous. We were invited to their place for garden parties and they would send a car for us,‚Äù she said.  Doreen obtained her own pilot‚Äôs licence when they resided in Gore. Photo / Day Family  Doreen got her own pilot‚Äôs licence when they lived in Gore. She said the pair would travel together when Lew went to aerodromes across the country.  Lew said he and Doreen even flew a job together delivering an aircraft to Fiji for the Fijian Minister of Finance at the time, Charles Stinson.  ‚ÄúIt was a few days before Christmas and I thought I would have to rush there and get back in time but they said, ‚ÄòNo no, you can stay over there.‚Äô Doreen was qualified as a pilot and therefore quite entitled to sit there and be the second pilot of the aeroplane,‚Äù Lew said.  The couple moved to Hawke‚Äôs Bay last year to be closer to their family. Photo / Day Family  During their travels, the couple photographed the space shuttle Challenger disaster from their hotel in the US, with Lew describing how staff at the photo shop didn‚Äôt believe it when he printed out his pictures. It was before the story had hit the news.  Lew was made a Member of the NZ Order of Merit (MNZM) in 1997 for his services to aviation and eventually retired after 57 years of flying, aged 77.  The couple moved to Hawke‚Äôs Bay last year to be closer to their family after living in Papakura since 1965.

Johnny and Rey have been a couple since 2018. After a split, they revived their romance in 2021.  Finally, the Ingham family will close of their summer of love with Katie's wedding in Tuscany, Italy.  She will tie the knot with her beau Ali Rosenberg.

Jamie Lee Komoroski is accused of crashing a rented Toyota car into a golf cart containing newlyweds Samantha Hutchinson and Aric Hutchinson on April 28 in Charleston County, South Carolina  Dad of drink driver who 'killed bride on wedding night' gives her five words of advice  The dad of a drink-driver who allegedly hit and killed a bride on her wedding night gave his daughter five words of advice after releasing she was likely to go to jail.  Suspect Jamie Lee Komoroski, 25, is accused of crashing a rented Toyota car into a golf cart containing newlyweds Samantha Hutchinson, 34, and Aric Hutchinson, 36, following their wedding reception on April 28.  Cops said she had been going 65mph in a 25mph speed limit zone and was allegedly three time the legal limit after her blood alcohol content was 26.  She was arrested and placed in Charleston County, South Carolina, US, when bemoaning to her parents how her life was going to change during recorded conversations.  Ms Komoroski said: "I can‚Äôt believe this is my life ‚Ä¶ and my whole life is going to be over. Oh my God. I just can‚Äôt believe this happened to me. ‚Ä¶ Why me? ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm going to be here for years and years and years and years."  Image: Jamie Komoroski/Instagram) Jamie Komoroski/Instagram) Image: Folly Beach Police) Folly Beach Police)  However, her dad then issued a blunt response with five words to his daughter as he told her to "suck it up" and "get tough" during the phone call.  In another recorded conversation, the dad told his daughter "you don't need to be sorry" and "we're going to take care of you."  "You don‚Äôt need to be sorry, Jamie, this is what happened and we‚Äôre going to take care of it. There‚Äôs no being sorry about it,‚Äù her father said during one call. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt care about what happened. We don‚Äôt care. We care only about you.‚Äù  Image: GoFundMe/Folly Beach Police/MEGA) GoFundMe/Folly Beach Police/MEGA)  Ms Komoroski claimed the fatal crash was just a "freak accident" and believed she wouldn't serve any jail time - despite facing three charges of felony driving under the influence resulting in great bodily injury or death and a count of reckless homicide.  Heartbroken husband Mr Hutchinson, who was seriously injured in the crash, had two broken legs, one which had to be surgically repaired.  He also had broken bones in his face which also had to be surgically repaired along with broken vertebrae‚Äôs in his back, brain bleeds, and numerous cuts with stitches.  Image: WCIV) WCIV)  The husband has since filed a civil lawsuit against Ms Komoroski and the bars that served her.  The suspect is accused of drunkenly crashing her rented Toyota Camry into the golf cart carrying Samantha's new husband, Aric Hutchinson, and two other passengers.  During a phone call with her boyfriend on May 2, the suspect is said to have expressed remorse and claimed she was worried people would think she's a bad person.

Real, Housewives of New Jersey star Teresa Giudice is known for her dramatic, statement style, but her wedding hair from last year divided the internet, as well as her family.  Teresa Giudice's August 2022 nuptials to Luis Ruelas finally aired on Tuesday night's episode of The Real Housewives of New Jersey, and fans finally got to see her infamous wedding hair that set the internet alight at the time.  During her big day in East Brunswick, New Jersey, in August, the 51 year old sported a half-down half-up voluminous hairstyle with towering tight curls at the top, all held in place with a sparkling silver crown.  And while the hairdo didn't go down too well on social media, it was clear that it wasn't a hit with Teresa's nearest and dearest either.  During the episode, the reality star asked her daughters about her hair, and they did not hold back.  "You literally look like a rat's nest," 19 year old Gabriella told her mother.  Read More  Image: Instagram/mrsjillzarin) Instagram/mrsjillzarin)  Gia, 22, added: "Obviously, it's big. Queen Elizabeth probably has a crown like that."  Later, in one of her confessional interviews on the show, Teresa said she stuck by her choice of hairstyle as she loved "statement pieces" that were "dramatic."  On her wedding day, viewers also saw Teresa admitting that the hairstyle and crown combination, which was put in place by her hairdresser Lucia Casazza, made her head feel heavy, but it didn't matter as she "loved the height of it!"  Teresa's unique and dramatic hairstyle went viral on social media at the time, with her castmate Jennifer Aydin revealing at a BravoCon panel in October that wedding guests "gasped" when she walked down the aisle during her big day.  Image: NBCU Photo Bank via Getty Images) NBCU Photo Bank via Getty Images)  Meanwhile, in an interview shortly after their wedding, Teresa and her husband, Luis, admitted that they romped up to five times a day when they first got married.  Later, she said she stood by her stance of having sex multiple times per day in order to keep the romance alive.  Talking to PEOPLE, Teresa explained: "That was on our honeymoon. You figure morning, afternoon, night time and in between. But I mean, listen, my point is, if you don't do that, then that's not normal. That means you love the person you're with and want to be with ... I mean if not, then why be with that person? It's a normal thing when you love someone."  Louie chipped in: "During the honeymoon, I'm like, 'I'm going home with a lot of clean clothes,' 'cause we stayed naked a lot of the time, but it was like... I'm attentive to her needs."  He added: "We live on six acres, big house, a lot of work that goes on. We'll fly past each other like ships in the night and be like, 'I'll see you tonight, I'm going to see all of you tonight. I'll meet up with you, I'll meet you later on.' The kids know we're in love. In the house, they're like, 'Mom, please no P.D.A. right now'."  The couple met and began dating in 2020 and got engaged in October 2021.  We're testing a new site: This content is coming soon
The 19-year-old‚Äôs family explained Ruddy died of a brain hemorrhage Wednesday afternoon as a result from smoke inhalation on Tuesday.

Beloved pets, much-needed medication and even a wedding dress were saved by firefighters and police officers from unit blocks after a huge fire tore through a nearby building.  Residents living in surrounding apartments of a seven-storey heritage-listed building on the corner of Randle St and Elizabeth Street in Surry Hills, near Sydney's Central Station, were evacuated on Thursday afternoon after it went up in flames.  The building burst into flames about 4pm and much of it, including the roof, had collapsed by 6pm.  With nearby apartment blocks under threat, residents had to flee their homes as more than 100 firefighters worked to get the blaze under control at the 111-year-old former hat factory, which had been left derelict and unoccupied.  Fire and Rescue NSW Acting Commissioner Jeremy Fewtrell said a number of pets including cats, dogs and rabbits were rescued.  One resident who lived in a unit block near the building that caught on fire in Surry Hills thanked emergency services for rescuing his cat  The building near Sydney's Central Station burst into flames about 4pm and much of it, including the roof, had collapsed by 6pm  'As people were evacuated last night we did start to get information from people who needed medication, who needed pets and so forth to be retrieved,' he said.  'We even had one lady who was due to have a wedding in Hobart and firefighters were able to go retrieve her wedding dress.  'So that's a very happy bride, I would imagine.'  One owner is seen clinging onto her cat after they were evacuated from their unit block  Bunnies and cats were rescued from unit blocks after a fire ripped through a nearby building  One man who lived in a nearby apartment had his beloved cat rescued after the blaze took hold.  He'd been teaching at Sydney University when he saw the news and raced home.  'The guy who went in is a very good man,' the resident told 10 News First outside his unit block on Thursday night while cuddling his pet who was visibly distressed by the ordeal.  'We've been here for a few hours now and we're happy to be going somewhere else.  Commuters and workers are seen watching on in horror as a fire tore through the unoccupied building in Surry Hills  'He's a bit terrified of the noise I think, but he's going to be OK.'  Many of the residents evacuated have been offered temporary accommodation or are staying with friends and family.  It comes as police confirmed two 13-year-old boys handed themselves in on Thursday evening.  NSW Police Acting Assistant Commissioner Paul Dunstan confirmed on Friday the two 13-year-olds had been inside the building at the time.  They have spoken with police after turning up separately at Paddington and Kings Cross police stations and are assisting with inquiries.  Charges have not been laid and the arson squad are leading the investigation.  Officers are also wanting to speak to three or four more children of a similar age who were also at the building at the time the fire ignited.  'We ask them to come forward with their parents and put their side of the story forward,' Mr Dunstan told reporters.  Mr Dunstan also confirmed up to 15 people were sleeping rough in the building the night before the fire took hold, with 13 of those accounted for.  Police are working with government agencies to try and locate the other two people.

Marriage celebrant and mum of two Suzanne Panter has a home on the KƒÅpiti Coast that looks relatively normal from the outside. But once you step inside and open the door to a spare room off her hallway, an array of flowing fabric, glistening beads and intricately patterned lace greets you. Hanging in rows are more than 100 beautiful wedding gowns that've been carefully cleaned and labelled, beside delicate veils and signage that reads "Eco Bride". The collection of gowns for sale and hire include one-off styles that've only ever been worn on the catwalk. But there's a catch to Suzanne's small passion-filled business ‚Äì Eco Bride only stocks preloved wedding dresses, which are sold and rented  out at a fraction of their original prices. "My wedding dresses are filled with love when I get them as they've already been someone's dream dress," enthuses Suzanne, 57, who started working as a celebrant in 2017. "We just keep the love going. "Hiring or purchasing a pre-loved wedding dress is far more eco-friendly and affordable in the current climate. Not every bride  has thousands of dollars." Thanks to Suzanne, budding brides on budgets can pay as little as $195 to hire their dream dress, or between $395 and $595 to purchase one.  Suzanne officiating at a wedding.  "Wedding dresses can cost anywhere from $5000 to $10,000 new and are only worn once," says the mum of sons Chris, 33, and Daniel, 27. "As a celebrant, I've seen a lot of wedding dresses come and go, and some of them are beautiful, like works of art.  It was a shame to think they were boxed up, never to be seen again." After marrying her husband Scott, 57, in Manchester, UK, in 1987, Suzanne donated her own beloved wedding gown. "My dress was a couple of hundred pounds, which doesn't sound a lot now, but in those days, it was quite a lot of money," recalls Suzanne, who stocks wedding dresses in sizes six to 22. "It was very '80s, with a high collar and long sleeves, although at the moment, the trend is a lot of dresses with long sleeves." The grandmother of one recycled her dress after having her sons, dropping it to the British charity Oxfam, which would've sold it on at a low cost. "Technically, I'd already done what I'm doing now, without even thinking about it!" laughs Suzanne, who moved to New Zealand in 2008. "It was quite by accident."  Happy customer Emma Johnston took her dress all the way to the UK to marry Robert.  She was sitting down with Scott during the first Covid lockdown when she asked him what he thought about the idea of preloved wedding dresses. With his support and the help of their youngest son's marketing and photography skills, Suzanne's dream business came to life. In keeping with her sustainability theme, Suzanne decided to donate to Trees That Count, a native tree planting organisation, each time a dress is hired or purchased. Just 24 hours after launching, she received her first inquiry call and almost a year on, the bookings haven't stopped. "I started off with a few dresses I got from brides and other people reaching out when they heard what I was doing," explains Suzanne. "Now I have over 100 and it's ongoing because unlike sample dresses, once they're gone, they're gone, so I need to keep replacing them. It has gone far better than I ever anticipated!" People have travelled hours to visit Suzanne's at-home boutique, which includes a separate consultation room that's decorated with accessories like tiaras and wedding-themed d√©cor. The room, which is next to a separate changing space with candles and white robes, is where Suzanne chats to brides about their big days. "The girls and I have had lots of laughter and tears because it's quite emotional when they do find that dress," she says, suddenly wiping tears. "Everyone deserves to feel special and I'm so proud of what we do." Suzanne also offers a buy-back service that allows brides to sell their frocks back to her for $100 up to six months from their wedding if they don't want to store it, keeping the recycling going. "A dress may only be a few hundred dollars, but that's a lot of money to some people and it's great to be able to say to girls, 'No pressure, let's do this.' Then if they sell it back to us, we can redo the fun all over again!"

She may have not found love on season seven of Married At First Sight, but it led KC Osborne one step closer to finding her soul mate Blake Spriggs - and now they are set to get married.  After watching KC tie the knot with her TV husband Drew Brauer on the Channel Nine show, Blake started following the bride on social media.  While he didn't initially slide into her DMs, he made his move when she became single and they went on their first date in January 2022.  Things moved very fast for the happy couple as they welcomed their first baby - a boy called Brooklyn last October - and they got engaged two months prior.  Speaking to Daily Mail Australia, the new mother said she wants to keep the details of their wedding private, but it will be an intimate affair.  She may have not found love on season seven of Married At First Sight, but it led KC Osborne (pictured) one step closer to finding her soul mate Blake Spriggs, and now they are set to get married  'We want a really nice private, small, intimate wedding,' she said.  'But it's going to be a destination wedding as well. So we only want like 30 to 40 guests.  'We also want to have little Brooklyn be able to walk down the aisle, so we're going to wait about a year and it'll be a nice tropical destination wedding and definitely in a church.'  While he didn't initially slide into her DM's, Blake made his move on KC when she became single, and they went on their first date in January 2022 (both pictured)  They welcomed their first baby, a boy called Brooklyn, last October, and they got engaged two months prior  The former professional dancer said she always dreamed of having a big wedding, but after having such a big affair for her Married At First Sight ceremony, she has now decided to opt for something more low-key.  'I always imagined a really big wedding, but then I had the MAFS wedding and I know that wasn't real, but it kind of felt like a real wedding,' she explained.  'As far as the guests being there and having all eyes on me, I guess that stuff doesn't matter as much to me now.  'So I really just want my nearest and dearest there I don't really care for all the attention.'  KC has enjoyed many opportunities from appearing on the hit Australian reality show.  She went on to star on MTV's UK show Ex On The Beach, where she was surprised by her fellow season seven MAFS contestant Michael Goonan, who she dated for five months after her series ended.  KC and Blake got engaged last August and the new mother said she wants to keep the details of their wedding private, but it will be an intimate affair (both pictured)  KC was matched with Drew Brauer on season seven of MAFS (both pictured)  Despite this, the mother-of-one insists she did go on the show to find love, and she won't be watching next year's season as it's clear many of the contestants only go on it to become influencers.  'I think now that it's gone to the UK as well people are seeing how many followers they're getting and they're just thinking "Oh, I'll get followers and I can quit my job and become an influencer, or go on Only Fans,"' she said.  'They're kind of looking at it as like a opportunity, rather then really wanting to meet someone.  'I think a lot of people are going on it to kind of get famous and I feel like the show in that sense is losing its way a bit.  'If you're single and you want to live that influencer life that's totally fine. But if you're gonna go on a show like that be genuine and be open to finding love as well, and then whatever comes from, if that is brand deals and stuff, amazing, but like go on it to truly find someone.  'Because otherwise it's s**t watching and people can tell when they're not there for the right reason.'  The mother-of-one said she did go on the show to find love, and she won't be watching next years season as it's clear many of the contestants only go on it to become influencers  KC dated her fellow season seven MAFS contestant Michael Goonan who she dated for five months after her series ended (both pictured)  While KC said her main priority is being a new mother, she would love to feature on more reality shows.  'I love being in front of the camera. I think I'm made for being on TV if I'm being completely honest,' she said.  'I just love entertaining, so obviously it won't be a love reality show, but, there's so many reality shows out there. I'll definitely try and find the right fit for me.'  Before appearing on MAFS, KC lived in LA for 11 years where she worked as a professional dancer and rubbed shoulder with some of Hollywood's biggest stars.  She said she was asked to go on I'm A Celebrity... Get Me Out Of Here! and talk about her glamorous LA days with the stars, but she turned it down because she didn't want to publicly air these stories and is terrified of snakes.  She also appeared on MTV's Ex On The Beach where she was reunited with Michael  'Not a lot of people know about my LA days, I could write a book on my experiences with the different celebrities I was around and friends,' she said.  'There is a whole part that's so interesting and there's moments of that I'd probably share, but for the most part I'm pretty private about it.  'I honestly don't think I could do that show because I'm petrified of snakes. I did say to Blake "Would I do it for a million dollars?"  'I'm not a big enough celebrity for a million dollars, so they're not going to pay that, but I don't even know if I could do it for that price.'

IMAGE: Just after she got married, Krishna Rajput rushed to do this. Photograph: ANI  Why we should all be proud of Krishna Rajput.  The Top Videos of the Week, listed by Shailajanand Mishra. IAF Showcases Its Might  Location: Greece, France  Watch the IAF at INIOCHOS, hosted by the Hellenic Air Force at the Andravida Air Base in Greece.  And at Orion 2023, yet another multilateral exercise held at Mont-de-Marsan, a base used by the French Air and Space Force.  How fantastic is our air force!  All Videos: ANI  Bhubaneswar's Child-Friendly Police Station  Location: Bhubaneswar  Even adults face a sense of unease when it comes to visiting a police station; imagine, then, how children must feel.  In an applause-worthy move -- and we hope many other police stations will be inspired to do the same -- here's what the Nayapalli police have done to make the experience easier for young children who, for whatever reason, have to visit their station.  Acid Attack Survivor's Amazing Achievement!  Location: Chandigarh  She suffered the trauma of an acid attack at the tender age of three.  Her entire face was burnt.  She lost her sight but not her indomitable spirit.  Beating all odds, 15-year-old Kafi -- whose father works as a peon -- has scored 95.02 per cent in the Class 10 CBSE board exams. Why This Bus Is A Mobile School  Location: Surat  Their classroom has benches, rugs, a television, lights, a fan and Internet connectivity.  And it can move from place to place.  Classes are held for three hours and 32 children can study here.  For the children living in the slums and footpaths of Surat, Vidyakunj-Vidyapeeth Group's mobile classroom has come as a blessing.  Why Ram Singh Collects Radio Sets  Location: Amroha  He has over 1,100 of them.  Some are over a hundred years old.  Ram Singh, a retired government employee, believes no one in the world has a radio collection like his.  And here's what inspired him to take up this rather unusual hobby.  Just After Her Wedding, She Did This  Location: Jhansi  "My wedding is important," says Krishna Rajput.  But something else was just as important.  Kudos, Krishna! Niamh Cullen has lifted the lid on her wedding plans as she prepares to marry her longtime love Jamie Gill.  The influencer and her beau got engaged last December while they were doing some early Christmas shopping.  The couple met at a Bingo Loco event five years ago, and became friends before they started dating.  Speaking on Louise Cooney‚Äôs Open Book podcast, Niamh admitted: ‚ÄúI actually kind of knew [the proposal] was going to happen because he was actually acting a little bit funny that week, what he was doing as well wouldn‚Äôt really be like Jamie.‚Äù  ‚ÄúHe was kind of encouraging me to go on Instagram, he was like ‚Äòyou should go on Instagram and address a few things, tell people why you‚Äôve been upset and sad‚Äô.‚Äù  ‚ÄúHe wanted a clean slate so when we woke [the day after the proposal], he was so cute, he booked The Shelbourne for us, and we woke up the next day and he was just like ‚Äòare you getting loads of lovely messages?‚Äô and I was like ‚ÄòYeah‚Äô.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI said to him,‚Äôiit‚Äôs so nice, I‚Äôm getting people who are still commenting on how I shared about my mental health‚Äô and he was like ‚Äòyeah that‚Äôs why I was encouraging you, I really wanted you to have such a clean slate‚Äô and I was like ‚Äòthat‚Äôs just so cute of you to think that‚Äô.‚Äù  Lifting the lid on wedding plans, Niamh said: ‚ÄúI feel like we‚Äôre definitely going to get married abroad, hopefully, maybe the end of next year, we‚Äôll see how finances are ‚Äì I also want to get a house, I‚Äôm wanting it all, so we‚Äôre just going to have to see, who knows.‚Äù  Recalling a conversation in Jamie‚Äôs parents‚Äô house, Niamh explained she was surprised when Jamie told them they‚Äôd be getting married in a church.  ‚ÄúI looked at him and I was like ‚Äòwhat? Jamie I‚Äôm not getting married in a church‚Äô. I‚Äôm not a practising Catholic, I‚Äôm sorry, like all my friends got married in churches, I‚Äôm all for it but [it‚Äôs not] for me.‚Äù  ‚ÄúJamie‚Äôs dad‚Äôs looking at me from the corner of his eye and he‚Äôs like shoock at me and I was like ‚ÄòI‚Äôll burn up in flames in that church, if I‚Äôm at the altar I‚Äôll catch smoke!‚Äô So if I‚Äôm getting married in a church you‚Äôre going to have a bucket of water ready.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI would love to go off to the likes of Ibiza or something fun [for my hen] but if we‚Äôre asking people to travel I won‚Äôt do that, we‚Äôll probably have something like my 30th, have a big whopper party.‚Äù  In February, Niamh and Jamie held their engagement party in The StoryTeller Pub in Dublin.  The couple got Chained welded forever bracelets to mark their special occasion.

Idris Elba shocked fans by revealing he was asked to DJ at Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's private wedding reception in May 2018, but perhaps even more surprising was his choice of outfit.  While the Duchess of Sussex looked gorgeous in her second wedding dress ‚Äì a halterneck Stella McCartney gown ‚Äì and Prince Harry chose a classic black suit to party with friends and family, Idris was pictured in a very casual ensemble.  WATCH: Idris Elba looking dapper as he arrived for the royal wedding  He was spotted leaning over the raised platform to chat with Harry, shaking his hand in the process. The Luther actor wore a maroon polo top with a gold watch and headphones perched on his head. Idris had clearly changed for the reception, as he was previously spotted at the ceremony at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle with his wife Sabrina wearing a black suit, white shirt and tie.  Idris has made a few rare comments about the royal wedding, including admitting Meghan's unexpected song request. During an appearance co-hosting BBC Radio 1Xtra‚Äôs Rap Show with Tiffany Calver, he was asked songs the guests were dancing to, to which he replied: ‚ÄúStill DRE by Dr Dre went off! It was Meghan‚Äôs choice."  ¬© Netflix Idris was spotted in a casual polo top as he DJ'd at the wedding  Opening up about performing at the evening celebrations, he said on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon that the royal couple are "good friends and I wanted to make sure they had a good time, so there was a lot of pressure".  He added that it was the "most stressful" gig he's done, explaining: "This wasn‚Äôt like my cousin‚Äôs wedding. This was like, you know, this wasn‚Äôt at the community hall, the reception. This was a big deal."  ¬© Getty Idris Elba was one of many celebrity guests at the royal wedding  However, he clearly enjoyed the experience as he described it as "one of the highlights of my life". Speaking to The Observer, the star said: "Harry's a friend of mine," before joking that he knows him "just from round the way, haha! He's a neighborhood lad!"  He added: "I try not to talk too much about it, because it was a private day, but it remains one of the highlights of my life, for sure. It was a beautiful experience."  ¬© Getty George Clooney, Serena Williams and Idris Elba were pictured inside St George's Chapel  Many royal fans had previously assumed it was the bride who had invited him to the royal wedding, especially considering his kind words for the Duchess.  Idris discussed his admiration for her as a member of the royal family. "Meghan Markle, as a person, regardless of colour, is a role model," he explained to Sky News. "Of course, our society is one of mixed heritage and it's great to see Meghan within the royal family. It's great. And of course, she's going to be a beacon and of course she's going to be someone that people look towards." Getty Images  Whether he‚Äôs dancing with the stars, dancing with his fianc√©, or dancing with himself ‚Äì it‚Äôs rare to find a moment where Derek Hough is sitting still. However, the dancing pro did miss a step when his longtime friend and colleague, Len Goodman, passed away suddenly last month. Derek got emotional when speaking with ‚ÄúExtra‚Äôs‚Äù Billy Bush about what Len meant to him.  ‚ÄúHe was just pure joy. He really was. I mean, what he represented and what he did for that show, for television, for all of us,‚Äù said Derek, whose memories with Len go all the way back to childhood.  ‚ÄúI lived in London when I was 12 years old. And I remember him MCing a dance competition, so I've known him for so many years and then to be able to work alongside him for over 16 years; just being able to judge alongside him these past couple years, and especially last season, I really remember just savoring every moment with him. And I'm so grateful for that.‚Äù  Goodman, who passed away from bone cancer, was a head judge on the BBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúStrictly Come Dancing‚Äù from 2004 until 2016. He was a judge on ‚ÄúDancing with the Stars‚Äù for 15 years until his retirement in November 2022.  Derek says he and his ‚ÄúDancing with the Stars‚Äù family weren‚Äôt aware of just how sick his friend had been.  ‚ÄúWe sensed his fragility, but we had no idea the extent of it. This was a huge shock for all of us,‚Äù Derek told Billy.  ‚ÄúHe's a special guy's, just a special guy. We definitely lost somebody really special.‚Äù  Derek will no doubt have Len on his mind when he returns to the ballroom.  ‚ÄúI want to do something just to honor him and continue to in the future.‚Äù  ‚ÄúDancing with the Stars‚Äù is set to return in the fall and bring back a familiar face: Julianne Hough will rejoin the dance competition as a co-host for its 32nd season.‚Äù  ‚ÄúShe is back in the family,‚Äù said Derek, on Julianne, who previously had been both a pro-dancer and a judge on the show. ‚ÄúI was like, oh, yeah, that makes perfect sense. What a great return.‚Äù  Derek, himself, will return to touring around the country as Derek Hough Symphony of Dance kicks off September 28.  ‚ÄúThis one is really special,‚Äù said Derek, who put together this tour, which will be his third.  ‚ÄúI have a team. We really create this beautiful symphony. And what's really special about this tour as well, is that my fianc√©, Hayley‚Äôs [Erbert] gonna be on the road with me as well, dancing, performing.‚Äù  Derek, who popped the question to Hayley in June of 2022, let it slip that the tour isn‚Äôt the only big thing he has planned for this year.  The wedding is also this fall. August,‚Äù said Derek. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the first time I‚Äôve said that actually, so I probably get in trouble from the wife.‚Äù  Asked if friend Mark Ballas will be the best man? Derek says there‚Äôs a possibility.

Planning a wedding is a big deal ‚Äî cue Jennifer Lopez in The Wedding Planner. From the flowers and colours, to the food and cake, it feels like the decision-making will never end. And let‚Äôs not forget the most important one you‚Äôll have to make: the venue. Whether you‚Äôre a traditional couple looking for a modern twist or a couple who wants to break all the rules and go completely off the beaten path, Toronto has a plethora of extraordinary wedding venues to choose from.  From stunning estates to charming historic districts, we‚Äôve scoured the city to bring you the top five most out-of-the-box wedding venues that are worth considering for your special day.  High Park Brewery  While trends come and go, the rustic wedding is probably one that is here to stay. If you‚Äôre looking for one that embodies comfort and charm, High Park Brewery offers a unique and memorable wedding experience for couples looking for a welcoming atmosphere. The space‚Äôs open-concept design ‚Äî with its expansive windows and string lighting‚Äî is sure to create a magical ambiance for up to 150 guests. And with a selection of craft beers brewed in-house, your guests are sure to enjoy a one-of-a-kind, local wedding celebration.  The Guild Inn Estate  Get ready to be transported into a fairy tale at The Guild Inn Estate. Set on 88 acres of land in Scarborough, the estate features a variety of event spaces, including a beautiful outdoor chapel, a grand ballroom and a charming garden terrace. Whether you‚Äôre planning a small and intimate ceremony or a grand reception, the Guild Inn Estate can accommodate weddings of all sizes. And with so many photographic spots on-site, you‚Äôre sure to capture any and every ‚Äúhappily ever after‚Äù moment.  The Hockey Hall of Fame  Now that the Leafs have broken the round one playoff curse, why not make your wedding day a real game-changer and celebrate at the Hockey Hall of Fame? Imagine saying ‚ÄúI do‚Äù surrounded by the Stanley Cup and historic hockey memorabilia. The venue features a variety of spaces to host weddings of all sizes, including a stunning ballroom and a historic bank vault. If you‚Äôre looking to score big with a one-of-a-kind wedding celebration, the Hockey Hall of Fame is the perfect place to make your dreams come true.  Storm Crow Manor  If you‚Äôre looking for a wedding venue that‚Äôs as quirky and unique as you are, look no further than Storm Crow Manor. This venue is a haven for all things bold, with eccentric themes ‚Äîlike a mad scientist bar or a nautical-themed room ‚Äî and an abundance of spooky decor, making it the perfect place to host a fun and unforgettable wedding reception. Depending on the room you book, the venue can accommodate up to 100 guests, with a variety of menu options to suit everyone‚Äôs tastes and dietary needs.  The Stirling Room  Transport yourself to the 19th century Victorian era with this historic venue choice. With its exposed bricks and dark lighting, you‚Äôll find yourself enjoying this bespoke lounge that merges contemporary design and antique architecture. It‚Äôs a wedding experience your guest won‚Äôt forget. Located in one of Toronto‚Äôs most iconic neighbourhoods ‚Äî the Distillery District ‚Äî the Stirling Room also offers ample opportunity for exploration before and after the wedding.

By Medha Chawla: Glitzy Indian weddings are back to their pre-pandemic glory. From the intimate at-home celebrations, the Band Baaja Baraat has once again returned to grand wedding venues. Tarun Tahiliani, in collaboration with Catering Collective, has now forayed into the luxury wedding space with Araya Bagh, a conceptual venue in New Delhi.  An amalgamation of a lot of distinctive design sensibilities ‚Äì timeless beauty and modern elegance, indoor halls and lush lawns, minimalism and regalia ‚Äì Araya Bagh is a depiction of the couturier‚Äôs ‚ÄòIndia Modern‚Äô philosophy which, of course, also reflects in his ethereal sartorial creations. An outside view of Araya Bagh.  advertisement  Located on MG Road, the venue spread across 2.5 acres is an unconventional take on wedding spaces comprising two lawns, two indoor spaces and a central concourse.  The design boasts of extensive use of intricate jaalis ‚Äì a signature element also pervasive in his newly-opened first menswear design studio in Mumbai designed by the couturier himself - coupled with intricate patterns in the form of stone mosaics, inlay technique, and antique mirrors, along with an understated tone-on-tone colour palette. A section of an indoor hall features a glass ceiling to ensure beautiful natural light illuminates it. A section of an indoor hall features a glass ceiling to ensure beautiful natural light illuminates it.  Tarun Tahiliani brings his 'India Modern' vision to luxury wedding venue in New Delhi  "Design is an ongoing process ‚Äì viscerally churned from education, exposure, experience, and one‚Äôs own trial and error to evolve a signature, a philosophy, a unique language. To this, we hope to bring our brand of India modern comfort, fineness, and longevity and create a harmony to make the experience of space blissful in every way,‚Äù designer Tarun Tahiliani said on conceptualising Araya Bagh.  The interiors and overall appearance of Araya Bagh is a refreshing take on wedding spaces with no extravagant use of a gleaming golden palette and flashy lights. ‚ÄúAt Araya Bagh, we have turned away from the prevalent culture of making wedding banquets a flashy piece of work, which is essentially just a bright box of glitter. Our space boasts of a kind of beauty rooted in Indianness, that, even when it is not decked up for an event, has an innate elegance,‚Äù said Bindu Vadera, Head of Interiors, Tahiliani Design Studio.  What do you think about it?

2. Generative AI and augmented reality loom large as Marks and Spencer hosts seventh hackathon  Marks and Spencer hosted its seventh hackathon event last week, with generative AI playing a key role.  In a LinkedIn post, Jeremy Pee, Chief Digital and Technology Officer at Marks and Spencer, said: ‚ÄúYesterday (18th May) we witnessed an incredible display of innovation, collaboration, and sheer talent as we hosted our 7th Hackathon.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWith over 200 participants and 16 teams across all areas of M&S, it was a remarkable event that was high energy and truly inspiring!‚Äù  He added: ‚ÄúCongratulations to all the teams who participated and pushed the boundaries of creativity.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWe were blown away by the abundance of groundbreaking from automation and chatbots to augmented reality and generative AI, the range of projects showcased the depth of talent within our team.‚Äù  Pee gave a special shout-out to Team Magrathea, who ‚Äúwowed us with their innovative approach to generative AI, focusing on recommending outfits through chat and enhancing access to our company's treasure trove of data through conversation. Well done, Team Magrathea!‚Äù  3. Walmart opens first Market Fulfilment Centre in Arkansas, powered by Alphabot system  Walmart has opened a Market Fulfilment Centre (MFC) in Arkansas at Store 100 located at 406 S Walton Blvd in Bentonville.  This is built within the store and is powered by a proprietary storage and retrieval system, named Alphabot.  Walmart says that fulfilment through digitisation and connecting its store and supply chain assets end to end will ‚Äútransform fulfilment. And along with it, customer satisfaction and associate opportunity‚Äù.  ‚ÄúThis new order fulfilment system is truly game changing,‚Äù says Ryan Simpson, the store manager at Store 100.  ‚ÄúNot only does it enhance the customer experience through quicker, more accurate online order fulfilment, it also provides us the runway to continue growing our business now and in the future.‚Äù

Happily married to Anna Hansen in August 2022, cycling legend Lance Armstrong is over the moon. Supporting each other for more than 10 years, the couple has shared their joys and sorrows, making their bond stronger. Recently, Armstrong celebrated his wife‚Äôs contribution to his life on her special day.  The retired cycling athlete shared a heartwarming Instagram post on his wife‚Äôs birthday on 24th May 2023. This post was a reflection of how Hansen had an important place in his life. Giving stability to Armstrong‚Äôs kids Grace, Isabella, Luke, Max, and Olivia, she became an inseparable part of Armstrong‚Äôs life. Expressing his fondness for his wife, Armstrong hinted at his enthusiasm for an exciting event with his wife.  Lance Armstrong‚Äôs heartfelt message on his wife‚Äôs birthday  On his Instagram retired cyclist shared a picture of him with his wife and wrote, ‚ÄúHappy birthday @annahansenarmstrong.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúI love you babe, and can‚Äôt wait for our lunch date.‚Äù  With this, Armstrong also displayed adorable pictures with his wife. Dressed in a black T-shirt and grey pants, the couple posed against a background of trees and mountains. Tremendously happy, the couple were all smiles, enjoying themselves in a beautiful location.  These amazing pictures were taken by Elizabeth Kreutz, a popular photographer.  View this post on Instagram A post shared by Lance Armstrong (@lancearmstrong)  Armstrong and Hansen have known other since 2008. The two have always stood by each other.  Here is a glimpse of how the two lovebirds met and their unforgettable wedding celebrations.  Lance Armstrong and Anna Hansen‚Äôs story  The couple met in 2008 during Armstrong‚Äôs charity initiatives and began dating. In 2009, Anna gave birth to Armstrong‚Äôs son, Max, and in 2010, she birthed Olivia. Their relationship remained strong despite the fact that the United States Anti-Doping Agency found him guilty of doping in 2012.  Ten years later, on 9th August 2022, Armstrong got married to Anna and their children were also a part of this wedding in France.  The retired cyclist penned an emotional message, ‚ÄúBest.Day.Ever‚Äù, on Instagram, exhilarated to start a new beginning with his wife Anna Hansen. Further, he shared, ‚ÄúI am so proud of the couple we have become- It took us doing the work, the really hard work, and I am glad that we did.‚Äù  Armstrong‚Äôs birthday wishes for his wife are a testament to his immense affection and respect for his wife. The cyclist‚Äôs update will definitely make fans curious about the bond they share and hope for more such updates.

With FRIENDS dominating the TV screens during the 1990s, Jennifer Aniston and the rest became household names, gaining a plethora of fans. The show‚Äôs success was also a result of the close relationship the cast shared behind the scenes. Even after the end of the television blockbuster, they can often be spotted together.  However, there is one instance that caught the interest of many fans, making them doubt whether the FRIENDS cast are really friends in real life or not. What made fans doubt them was when Jennifer Aniston did not invite her co-star, Matt LeBlanc to her second wedding after he flunked out of her first.  Also Read: ‚ÄúI heard this yelling‚Äù: Jennifer Aniston Freaked Out Brad Pitt in Her Sleep With Her Rare Medical Condition  How Matt LeBlanc Betrayed Jennifer Aniston  Also Read: ‚ÄúRemember how that s*cked?‚Äù: Jennifer Aniston Became Emotional and Walked Out of FRIENDS Set Many Times After Reunion With Her Co-stars  The FRIENDS cast reunited in 2021 for FRIENDS: The Reunion. They reminisced about the time they spent together and how close they have become since then. However, fans were quick to point out that they weren‚Äôt as close since Jennifer Aniston did not invite her co-stars to her second wedding in 2015. While we don‚Äôt know the real reason, it might have been related to what went down during Jennifer Aniston‚Äôs first wedding with Brad Pitt. LeBlanc revealed in an interview that Aniston wasn‚Äôt pleased when he declined the invite.  ‚ÄúI missed when she married Brad. I was in Austria working. She called me, and she was like, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre really not coming to my wedding?‚Äô And I was like, ‚ÄòI asked them if they could change the schedule. I would fly and clap and fly out.‚Äô And they said, ‚ÄòWe can‚Äôt do it. It‚Äôs too tight.‚Äô It was a small-budget movie in Austria you‚Äôve never heard of. Probably should have left anyway, but s‚Äî happens. What are you going to do?‚Äù  Aniston Did Not Invite LeBlanc To Her Second Wedding After His Betrayal  Many were shocked when Jennifer Anniston chose not to invite Matt LeBlanc and the rest of her FRIENDS male co-stars to her second wedding with Justin Theroux. The two had a very intimate wedding attended by Courteney Cox and Lisa Kudrow, her two other co-stars from FRIENDS.  Although LeBlanc did not get an invite, he was very happy for the newlyweds.  ‚ÄúI think they‚Äôre a great couple. I think she‚Äôs happy. And that‚Äôs all I care about is that Jen‚Äôs happy. If she wanted me there, I would have been there. Jen‚Äôs like my little sister, Courteney, and Lisa are like my big sisters, but Jen‚Äôs like my little sister. Matthew‚Äôs like my little brother and David‚Äôs like my big brother. That‚Äôs how it all broke down. And it‚Äôs literally just like chronological.‚Äù  Similar sentiments were expressed by Matthew Perry who was also snubbed from the wedding along with LeBlanc and David Schwimmer.  Jennifer Aniston and Justin Theroux divorced back in 2018. While Jennifer Aniston is still single today, who knows if she might get a third one in, and invite the whole FRIENDS cast for it. Vicmar Carolina Flores Hidalgo and Cullen Joseph Heater first crossed paths at a hostel in Panama City in late 2017. Mr. Heater, a Peace Corps volunteer from Milton, Mass., was recuperating there after ankle surgery. Ms. Flores, who moved to Panama from her native Venezuela a year earlier, was teaching yoga at the hostel.  They caught glimpses of each other, but didn‚Äôt speak until the end of Mr. Heater‚Äôs monthlong convalescence, when they learned they would both be attending a concert of a mutual friend.  After a night of communal drinking and dancing, they decided to stay in touch, despite the difficulties posed by Mr. Heater‚Äôs return to his Peace Corps community. He lived in Boca de Cuiria, a remote village without electricity, in the province of Cocl√©, about six hours and two river crossings away from Panama City.  The two made plans to meet in January 2018, and at a friend‚Äôs suggestion visited Isla Taboga, in the Gulf of Panama.

The FBI Chicago is still searching for a man accused of stabbing his wife to death in 2012, less than 24 hours after getting married.  On May 12, 2012, Arnoldo Jimenez allegedly stabbed his wife to death in his black, four-door Maserati before dragging her body into the bathroom tub of her apartment in Burbank.  The murder occurred less than 24 hours after they got married, and the victim was still wearing her wedding dress.  Jimenez was charged with first-degree murder and a state warrant was issued for his arrest on May 15, 2012.  A federal arrest warrant was then issued on May 17, 2012, after Jimenez was charged federally with unlawful flight to avoid prosecution.  Jimenez became the 522nd fugitive named to the FBI's Top Ten Most Wanted in May 2019.  SUBSCRIBE TO FOX 32 ON YOUTUBE  The reward for information has been increased from $100,000 to $250,000. The increase is part of an across-the-board increase in the Top 10 Fugitive List rewards nationwide, the FBI said.  Jimenez is believed to have ties to Durango, Mexico, specifically Santiago Papasquiaro. He may also frequent Reynosa, Tamaulipas, Mexico, the FBI said.  Jimenez also uses the aliases Arnoldo Gimenez and Arnoldo Rochel Jimenz.  The public can report tips, even anonymously, at 1-800-CALL-FBI or tips.fbi.gov.
