Some women are celebrating their single to married status by chopping their locks. Then again it's not news that hairstyles have been used throughout life to recognize major milestones. But the New York Times reports a mid-wedding chop is the latest trend in a lifetime of momentous haircuts. Buzz60‚Äôs Maria Mercedes Galuppo has the story.

Fabian Koenig ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Maximilian Scheuplein  Fabian Koenig ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Maximilian ‚ÄúMaxi‚Äù Scheuplein‚Äôs wedding has been nine years and thousands of miles in the making.  In the summer of 2014, the two met in their hometown of Frankfurt, Germany through a website for gay teenagers. Fabian was about to start high school; Maxi had just graduated high school and was about to start his bachelor‚Äôs. They stayed up until 5 a.m. messaging each other that first day, then exchanged texts and hours-long voice recordings constantly over the next several weeks.  ‚ÄúI feel like we were best friends from the first message,‚Äù Fabian says. He came out to his mom two days after meeting Maxi in person for the first time.  Fabian Koenig ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Maximilian Scheuplein are engaged to be married in July 2023. By Courtesy of Fabian Koenig and Maximilian Scheuplein  In 2017, when Fabian graduated from high school and Maxi graduated from university, they transitioned to a whirlwind long-distance relationship. Fabian traveled the world during a gap year, then came to Harvard for college, while Maxi got a master‚Äôs at University College London, worked at Oxford and New York University, and ended up in the Netherlands for a Ph.D. in cognitive neuroscience.  Around two years ago, when they started talking about getting engaged, they made it a tradition to window-shop for rings in each new city they visited together, enjoying the free samples of champagne at fancy jewelry stores.  They eventually settled on a custom-ordered ring from Amsterdam. However, the proposal itself still came as a surprise.  On a trip to San Francisco last December, they hiked up a hill overlooking the ocean at sunset. When they reached the top, Maxi set up a tripod under the guise of doing a photoshoot. The two had gotten manicures for the first time a couple days prior, so Fabian joked, ‚ÄúMy finger is ready; you can put it on!‚Äù He thought it was funny when Maxi got down on one knee ‚Äî ‚Äúand then he pulled out the box, and I was like, ‚ÄòOh, wait! This is for real.‚Äô‚Äù  ‚ÄúI forgot everything I wanted to say,‚Äù Maxi laughs. ‚ÄúWhen you listen to the video now, the only thing I‚Äôm asking is, ‚ÄòYes? You sure?‚Äô‚Äù  Advertisement  He was. The couple is planning a courthouse wedding in Frankfurt this July, followed by a small celebration with their families. In the fall, Fabian will move to Los Angeles to work in consulting, and Maxi will return to the Netherlands for the last year of his doctorate. Afterward, they hope to reunite and finally close the long-distance chapter of their relationship.  In hindsight, though, both agree that the challenge of growing up and changing alongside each other ‚Äî developing their own interests and pursuing their own educations while remaining committed to a partner ‚Äî made their relationship stronger.  ‚ÄúHaving to overcome all these hurdles that come with long-distance relationships really made me feel this is definitely the right person to spend the rest of my life with,‚Äù Maxi says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the way you have to communicate with each other, the way you have to know each other in order to make this work across the Atlantic.‚Äù  Lindsey B. Bouldin ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Evan T. Anderson  Lindsey B. Bouldin ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Evan T. Anderson‚Äôs relationship was long-distance ‚Äúfrom the get-go,‚Äù Lindsey says. Even though they‚Äôd attended the same high school in central Tennessee, they only began dating in 2020 when they were both in college ‚Äî Lindsey at Harvard, Evan at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville.  In March 2020, halfway through her gap semester, Lindsey flew to Knoxville to visit Evan, ‚Äúthe day that the first confirmed case of Covid was in Tennessee.‚Äù Unable to fly back to Boston, Lindsey‚Äôs intended two-week visit home turned into a year-and-a-half stay. The change of plans, though unexpected, granted the couple valuable time in person together. Lindsey rented an apartment a five-minute drive away from Evan‚Äôs dorm, enabling them to spend weekends exploring Knoxville and camping in the Smoky Mountains.  But in the fall of 2021, when Lindsey returned to Harvard‚Äôs campus, the pair had to switch back into long-distance mode. ‚ÄúIt was definitely an adjustment,‚Äù Lindsey says. But the duo has figured out a good system: they schedule virtual date nights every weekend, prioritize visiting each other during school breaks, and text every day. ‚ÄúI feel like we‚Äôre both really good texters,‚Äù she says.  Lindsey B. Bouldin ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Evan T. Anderson are engaged to be married in May 2024. By Courtesy of Lindsey B. Bouldin and Evan T. Anderson  Marriage had been on Lindsey‚Äôs mind since a year into their relationship, but her convictions solidified the summer before senior year, when she started picturing her life after graduation. ‚ÄúI knew whatever I do in my life, I'd want to do it with Evan,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWhy delay the inevitable, you know?‚Äù  Evan was more hesitant. ‚ÄúI just wasn‚Äôt sure if I was ready for it,‚Äù he says. But in the last year, he‚Äôs become interested in Catholicism, and his religious commitment has inspired a newfound appreciation for marriage. ‚ÄúThat has really cast marriage in a new light for me, and made me realize that it was something that I really wanted, and something that I really wanted with Lindsey.‚Äù  Advertisement  Lindsey, who grew up as a Jehovah‚Äôs Witness, says she‚Äôs still learning about Catholicism. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more of a slower path that I‚Äôm going on, but I think it‚Äôs the path to the same destination,‚Äù she says. The two are planning to convert to Catholicism together through the Rite of Christian Initiation for Adults program.  This past January, during a trip to the Virgin Islands, Evan proposed. ‚ÄúIt just felt like the first step in something really great and really beautiful,‚Äù he says.  The couple are currently planning their wedding, which is slated for next May. In the meantime, they will both move to Knoxville following their respective graduations, after which Evan will pursue a master‚Äôs degree. They are already planning their honeymoon: a road trip to the Grand Canyon, Yellowstone, the Badlands, and other national parks.  Most of all, the two are excited just to be together in person again and experience ‚Äúthe little moments that you don‚Äôt really get when you‚Äôre long distance,‚Äù like cooking and drinking coffee together ‚Äî or as Lindsey calls it, ‚Äúthe boring life stuff that‚Äôs kind of boring when you‚Äôre alone, but is more meaningful and special when you‚Äôre with another person.‚Äù  Christian J. Rodriguez ‚Äô23 and Nyckole L√°zaro Quintero ‚Äô24  It all started when Nyckole L√°zaro Quintero ‚Äô24 spotted two anime keychains hanging off Christian J. Rodriguez‚Äôs ‚Äô23 backpack. It was a Friday night in the spring of 2022, and Nyckole was outside Fong Auditorium stringing up lights for Harvard College Faith and Action‚Äôs weekly ‚ÄúDOXA‚Äù worship meeting. ‚ÄúHey,‚Äù she recalls saying to him, ‚ÄúI like your keychains.‚Äù  Christian, a long-time HCFA member, turned around with a ‚Äúhuge smile,‚Äù pleasantly surprised to meet ‚Äúanother anime connoisseur who also liked Jesus,‚Äù he remembers. ‚ÄúThat was pretty cool for me.‚Äù After the event, the pair continued their conversation in Ticknor Lounge, where they talked about everything from anime to their spiritual beliefs.  For the rest of that semester, they frequented cafes in Harvard Square and ‚Äúwould occasionally flirt, but no one did anything,‚Äù Nyckole says. Because both had recently exited relationships the previous semester, they were reluctant to rush into anything, even though they knew they both liked each other.  They texted only sporadically throughout that summer but reconnected on Nyckole‚Äôs Minecraft server and then in person at an HCFA retreat the week before school began. On the first day of school, they got bubble tea and had a conversation that would prove decisive, about how they had each grown in their faith over the summer. ‚ÄúIt was really important for me to hear that God was working in [Nyckole‚Äôs] life as an individual, and not just because I was there or when I was talking to her about what I believe,‚Äù Christian says.  Their last stop that night was the Quincy Grille, where they sat in a booth together, finally confessed their feelings for each other, and officially started dating.  Advertisement  Christian J. Rodriguez ‚Äô23 and Nyckole L√°zaro Quintero ‚Äô24 are engaged to be married in summer 2024. By Courtesy of Christian J. Rodriguez and Nyckole L√°zaro Quintero  From there, it wasn‚Äôt a long journey to engagement. Though originally Nyckole had imagined dating for longer before engagement, her ideal timeline ‚Äúcompletely changed‚Äù when she saw how much her family ‚Äúadored‚Äù Christian. Just four months into their relationship, the couple was already talking about potential timelines for engagement. Over winter break, they planned out their ‚Äúentire hypothetical future together,‚Äù Christian says. ‚ÄúThings just clicked.‚Äù  On April 29, following their eight-month anniversary meal at Spring Shabu Shabu, Christian told Nyckole that a mutual friend needed help taking headshots for an internship. Halfway through the photo session on Weeks Bridge, the friend volunteered to take some photos of the couple, too. Christian moved behind Nyckole as if to pose high-school-prom-style, then got down on one knee instead. Overcome by laughter, and later by tears, she turned around and said yes.  The couple is planning to tie the knot next summer. In the meantime, Christian will be teaching at the middle school he attended in Lawrence, Massachusetts, while Nyckole finishes her senior year at Harvard. Eventually, Christian hopes to become a dentist, while Nyckole wants to become a math teacher.  Both of them emphasize how lucky they feel to have found a life partner in each other. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to have to build my own foundation and then add someone to it; I want to build that foundation with someone from the beginning,‚Äù Christian says. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm glad I found someone like Nyckole who I‚Äôm ready to do that with.‚Äù  Nyckole agrees: ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt want to go through daily life with someone else.‚Äù  Carter J. Martindale ‚Äô23 and Elise L. Fischer  Carter J. Martindale ‚Äô23 and Elise L. Fischer wouldn‚Äôt have met if not for the pandemic.  After Harvard went virtual in spring of 2020, Carter came across a group of Harvard students looking to fill a room in their Utah apartment. Carter made the move to Provo, where he ended up meeting Elise.  One night, Carter and Elise, then a student at Brigham Young University, both attended a mutual friend‚Äôs gathering and got to chatting in the hot tub. Carter mentioned his interest in Taylor Swift‚Äôs ‚ÄúEvermore‚Äù album, which was also one of Elise‚Äôs favorites. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt let this one go,‚Äù Elise recalls thinking.  Advertisement  Shortly thereafter, the pair went on their first official date: ‚Äúhammocking‚Äù in a local park. They found ample common ground, from their similar taste in memes to their shared love of thrillers and mysteries to their compatible religious beliefs ‚Äî both are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.  They had only planned to hang out for a couple hours but ended up staying for nine. ‚ÄúWe just kept talking for, like, forever,‚Äù Carter says.  For the rest of that spring, the duo went on dates either every day or every other day. Carter had an internship in Palo Alto that summer, so the pair went long-distance, and they stayed in that mode when he returned to Cambridge for his junior year. They reunited last summer, when Carter took an internship in Utah.  The lead-up to the engagement wasn‚Äôt a surprise; the pair had been talking about engagement for a while and even went ring shopping together. (‚ÄúI was not about to just buy a random ring without her having looked at it!‚Äù) But when it came to the moment itself, Carter kept it hush-hush.  On a morning in July, he found a hiking trail with a secluded clearing and enlisted a couple friends to set up a blanket with rose petals and pictures of the couple. Then he drove back down and picked up Elise, who expected a routine hike. Ten feet into the trail, he led her into the clearing and proposed. ‚ÄúIt definitely caught me off guard, especially because I really thought we were doing this hike,‚Äù Elise says. ‚ÄúHe did a really good job.‚Äù  They didn‚Äôt finish the rest of the hike; they left and got Korean barbecue instead.  They got married in December in a small ceremony in Elise‚Äôs hometown. This semester, Elise elected to finish her BYU graduation requirements online, enabling the couple to move into an off-campus apartment near Fresh Pond. They settled into a routine ‚Äî Elise would often drive Carter to campus in the mornings, and the two would sometimes work in Quincy House together or hang out with Carter‚Äôs blockmates.  After their respective graduations, they will move to Austin, Texas, where Carter will work for a legal tech company and Elise will attend nursing school.  The pair still marvels that the pandemic precipitated the start of their relationship. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs worked out to be where we are now,‚Äù Carter says. ‚ÄúSo yeah, it was like a miracle.‚Äù  Advertisement  Cameron M. Stone ‚Äô23 and Savannah J. Stone (n√©e Fisher)  Cameron M. Stone ‚Äô23 calls his first date with his now-wife ‚Äúkind of unorthodox‚Äù: After a mutual friend introduced him to Savannah J. Stone (n√©e Fisher), they went on a group date shooting guns in the Utah desert, followed by dinner.  ‚ÄúReally safe first date when you don‚Äôt know someone, going out into the wilderness with guns,‚Äù Savannah says with a laugh. But after getting to know Cameron, she was immediately ‚Äúsmitten.‚Äù She remembers telling her mom over the phone late that night: ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs not this boy, I don‚Äôt want any other boy.‚Äù  The two began dating in January 2021, while Cameron was taking Harvard classes remotely from Utah and Savannah was attending Brigham Young University. That August, the weekend before he was set to return to Harvard to resume in-person classes, Cameron proposed.  ‚ÄúSavannah always joked with me that she would marry me even if I wrapped a blade of grass around her finger instead of a real diamond ring,‚Äù he says. So he had a florist make a custom engagement ring out of grass, and he surprised her with it on a picnic date.  ‚ÄúAnd she kept her word,‚Äù he smiles.  Cameron and Savannah maintained a long-distance engagement throughout the fall semester, then reunited in Utah for their wedding on January 7, 2022 ‚Äî coincidentally one year to the day after their first date. Both members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, they were married in Mount Timpanogos Temple, against a backdrop of snow-capped mountains and surrounded by 500 friends and family members from across the country.  ‚ÄúAs part of our faith, the wedding ceremony, in the prayer that they give, they replace words like ‚Äòuntil death do you part‚Äô with ‚Äòfor time and all eternity,‚Äô‚Äù Cameron says. ‚ÄúSo we have a belief that we‚Äôre married for this life and the next, which was pretty special and meaningful for us.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt was so exciting to see so many people being absolutely supportive and taking a chance on two kids getting married and coming all the way to Utah to celebrate with us,‚Äù Savannah says.  Advertisement  Savannah transferred to the University of Massachusetts Boston, and the newlyweds now live together in an apartment in Cambridge. They enjoy hanging out with Cameron‚Äôs friends in Mather House, trying new restaurants, and staying active by lifting, practicing yoga, and playing tennis and pickleball.  After they both graduate this May, they plan to relocate to London, where Cameron will work as a software engineer, and explore Europe while Savannah takes a gap year before starting dental school. They hope to eventually settle down in the Bay Area to stay close to their families in California. ‚ÄúA really cool aspect of getting married young is us being able to make these really big, game-time life decisions that usually people are making alone, together,‚Äù Savannah says.  Indeed, when asked what married life is like, they answer in unison: ‚ÄúThe best!‚Äù  Kat S. Boit ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Ben B. Hebert  Kat S. Boit ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Ben B. Hebert describe their relationship as a ‚Äúslow burn.‚Äù  They first met on the robotics team at their high school in Granby, Connecticut, and although Kat developed a bit of a crush, they stayed just friends for a couple years. ‚ÄúI just thought he was so out of my league,‚Äù Kat says.  Their romance didn‚Äôt begin until 2017, Kat‚Äôs junior year of high school, when Ben had already gone off to college at the Rochester Institute of Technology. The two kept in touch through a larger group chat, which turned into one-on-one phone calls, which eventually led to Kat inviting Ben to a party when he came home for spring break ‚Äî a set crew party for their high school‚Äôs production of ‚ÄúCinderella.‚Äù They made it official a month later.  Kat S. Boit ‚Äô22-‚Äô23 and Ben B. Hebert are engaged to be married in July 2023. By Courtesy of Kat S. Boit and Ben B. Hebert  For the next few years, the couple braved long-distance. Ben would make the six- to seven-hour drive down from Rochester every couple months to spend a weekend at Harvard. In the interim, Kat says, ‚Äúwe Skyped each other pretty much every day.‚Äù  The pandemic would prove pivotal for the pair. After being kicked off campus in March 2020, it took Kat only two weeks at home to decide to move in with Ben in Rochester. ‚ÄúMy parents thought I was crazy!‚Äù  Advertisement  But as Kat tells it, their decision to move in together was a very thoughtful one. ‚ÄúI honestly felt like Ben was the person for me after probably a year into our relationship,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúBut I was very insistent on, like, I really need to be able to live with you first. I need to make sure that we‚Äôre compatible, and also we just need to grow up a little more.‚Äù  The two shared a 90-square-foot bedroom for the next year and a half (Kat took a year off school), and the tight quarters only brought them closer. ‚ÄúWe definitely handled it a lot better than I would have thought,‚Äù Ben says. ‚ÄúThat really cemented the idea that, like, we‚Äôre definitely it.‚Äù  When Ben graduated in spring 2021, he found an engineering job in Massachusetts, and the two moved into an apartment in Boston where they‚Äôre been living together since, along with their cat, Maisy. They cook together nearly every night, and unwind with yoga or games ‚Äî Myst and Dungeons & Dragons are favorites.  Kat expected Ben to propose ‚Äî they‚Äôd been talking about marriage ‚Äúfor a long time,‚Äù Ben says ‚Äî but she was still surprised when it happened. After securing Kat‚Äôs parents‚Äô blessing, Ben planned a trip to Cape Cod in June of 2022, framed as a long-overdue anniversary present. When he took her on a walk to the beach, Kat had her suspicions ‚Äî the day was almost too sunny, the beach too empty ‚Äî but she dismissed them when she couldn‚Äôt spot any ring-box-shaped objects in Ben‚Äôs pockets.  On a secluded stretch of shoreline, Ben brought out the ring he had hidden behind his car keys and proposed. ‚ÄúIt just felt right,‚Äù he says.  The couple will be married in July, in a small ceremony in Brookline. After tying the knot, they‚Äôll move to New Haven, where Kat will pursue a Ph.D. in Biology at Yale.  Polina Galouchko ‚Äô23 and Benjamin J. Porteous ‚Äô22  ‚ÄúWe just talk, talk, talk, talk,‚Äù Benjamin J. Porteous ‚Äô22 says of his relationship with Polina Galouchko ‚Äô23. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs probably our favorite hobby.‚Äù  The pair began talking ‚Äî quite literally ‚Äî on Valentine‚Äôs Day last year, when a mutual friend invited them both to a group dinner in Dunster House dining hall. They quickly bonded over ‚Äúan incredibly interesting conversation‚Äù about literature and philosophy, Polina says.  ‚ÄúI remember her as a lively conversationalist, just really interesting and thoughtful,‚Äù Benjamin agrees.  Advertisement  Although they bumped into each other a couple more times afterward, they didn‚Äôt really reconnect until the end of the school year. Polina, then a junior, was staying on campus to work at Senior Week and Commencement events, while Benjamin was preparing to deliver the Latin Salutatory at his own graduation ceremony. They found themselves spending more and more time together that May, until they finally made it official the night before Commencement ‚Äî mere hours before Benjamin was set to appear onstage.  ‚ÄúWe were just walking around the Quad and talking and talking, and I felt this guilt because he had to get up at 5 a.m. the next morning,‚Äù Polina recalls. ‚ÄúAnd right around midnight, he said, ‚ÄòWould you consider dating me?‚Äô‚Äù  ‚ÄúScrap the Latin oration ‚Äî there was more important stuff going on!‚Äù Benjamin says.  A year later, the duo can even finish each other‚Äôs sentences. When asked to describe their shared interests, Benjamin starts: ‚ÄúClassical music‚Ä¶‚Äù  ‚ÄúOpera,‚Äù Polina adds.  ‚ÄúVisiting historic churches of all kinds.‚Äù  ‚ÄúTraveling.‚Äù  ‚ÄúAh, and this is my new fun fact for Zoom meetings ‚Äî‚Äù  ‚ÄúSoviet comedies!‚Äù  Polina Galouchko ‚Äô23 and Benjamin J. Porteous ‚Äô22 are engaged to be married in June 2023. By Courtesy of Polina Galouchko and Benjamin J. Porteous  Advertisement  They come from ‚Äúdifferent and yet very analogous‚Äù cultures, Benjamin says ‚Äî although he attends an Anglo-Catholic church and she a Russian Orthodox one, they both love elaborate ‚Äúhigh church‚Äù traditions, such as incense, beautiful vestments, and music.  Their academic pursuits are analogous, too: Polina will start a master‚Äôs in political science at Harvard‚Äôs Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies this fall, and Benjamin is currently enrolled in the equivalent master‚Äôs program studying China.  In fact, Benjamin‚Äôs knowledge of Communist China has helped him bond with Polina‚Äôs parents, who grew up in the Soviet Union. This past winter break, when the couple traveled to Europe to visit Polina‚Äôs family, Benjamin showed up at their home wearing a fluffy winter hat with ear flaps which a Chinese friend had gifted him.  ‚ÄúIt looked like their Soviet comrade had just arrived,‚Äù Polina chuckles. (‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt wear it with any ulterior motives,‚Äù Benjamin swears.)  With her parents‚Äô blessing obtained, Benjamin proposed during that trip, on Polina‚Äôs birthday, in a Baroque church in Croatia overlooking the Adriatic Sea. They‚Äôll be getting married this June on Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire, where Benjamin went to summer camp and where his parents were married.  Now, their conversations have turned to the seating charts for the wedding reception as they figure out how to arrange guests ‚Äúfrom all walks of life.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThere should be some really interesting conversations at the wedding,‚Äù Benjamin says.  ‚ÄúAnd good music,‚Äù Polina adds.

Thornbridge Hill Estate balances rustic and elegant. Image: Courtesy of Costa Christ  After last week‚Äôs modern hideaway listing, we‚Äôre in a country state of mind. An 1800s-era property in Whitesboro, Texas, Thornbridge Hill Estate comes complete with a 3,782-square-foot main residence and 56 acres, as well as a few potential income streams. These include nine acres of hay-producing pastures, facilities for cows and horses, and a renowned wedding venue with a chapel, reception hall, and a three-bedroom, two-bathroom guesthouse.  The current owners, Jennifer and Glen Horowitz, designed and built many of the homestead‚Äôs buildings, starting in 2017 with the main residence. The goal was to create a traditional farmhouse that effortlessly balances the rustic with the elegant. Think relaxed luxury, or as the owner summed it up, a place to wear jeans and boots, and drink from a crystal glass.  A pool and 56 acres of land will delight anyone who loves the outdoors. Image: Courtesy of Costa Christ  The exterior of the main house veers classic, with stone and wood cladding, and those country necessities: covered front and back porches, the latter with a fireplace and close to the lap pool. Inside, there‚Äôs more classic detailing, like a double-height formal foyer with a curved staircase and custom millwork, which segues into an open great room with vaulted ceilings. Wood beams line the ceiling, and the walls are filled with windows overlooking the property.  The state-of-the-art kitchen features quartz counters and a La Cornue range. Image: Courtesy of Costa Christ  A soaring limestone chimney anchors the living room at one end of the main space, while at the other, a 10-foot-long island with quartz counters protects the kitchen. A statement, custom-designed hood vent hovers over the La Cornue range; other appliances are hidden behind custom cabinetry for a clean look. A nearby walk-in pantry also conceals clutter. There‚Äôs a formal dining room, as well as a cozy breakfast nook tucked into a windowed alcove, with a second fireplace.  The layout includes delightful surprises, like the double-height library with a spiral staircase, and modern conveniences like a laundry room with space for two sets of washers and dryers and built-in kennels.  A spiral staircase is a nice touch in the double-height library. Image: Courtesy of Costa Christ  The primary suite is on the main floor, with another fireplace in the bedroom and a metal-covered cast-iron soaking tub in the marble bathroom. Upstairs, find three more bedrooms, one serving multipurpose function with four custom bunk beds‚Äîeach has a light, outlet, and USB port‚Äîand living space.  In the past, the property had a church on it, with baptisms performed in the spring-fed creek running through the acreage. In honor of that history, the couple built a new chapel on the same site, with crisp white siding, oversize windows, and 100-year-old pews inside. There‚Äôs also the inky-toned Osage Hall, the reception venue also affectionately referred to as the ‚Äúparty barn.‚Äù It has plenty of dance space, as well as a custom stone fireplace and 15-foot mantel fashioned from an Osage tree.  The estate features a newly built chapel that can be rented out for wedding ceremonies. Image: Courtesy of Costa Christ  Once the venue opened, the owners put it on Instagram and garnered a thousands-strong following, becoming popular for private events among influencers, celebrities, and athletes‚Äîthere‚Äôs even a helipad‚Äîrented for photo and film shoots, and featured in national magazines. With all that acreage, it would be easy enough for a prospective buyer to continue what‚Äôs been started, or dream up something entirely new.  Listing Fast Facts:  Address: 608 Old Center Church Rd, Whitesboro, TX 76273  Size: 5,980 square feet/7 bedroom/5.5 bath  List Date: 2/28/2023  List Price: $5,599,000  Listing Agent: Tracy Tutor and Breah Brown, Douglas Elliman Realty

Jordan‚Äôs royal family has reportedly caused an uproar on the Italian island of Sardinia, where alleged plans for a secret wedding bash to celebrate Crown Prince Hussein bin Abdullah tying the knot include a ‚Äúmonster‚Äù marquee that locals just don‚Äôt want to see.  The 28-year-old crown prince is officially due to wed his bride-to-be, Rajwa Khaled Al Saif, at what the family bills as a ‚Äúhighly anticipated royal wedding‚Äù in Amman on June 1. But Italian media reports say the pair will also celebrate their nuptials at a party in Sardinia on June 10.  A ‚Äúgigantic tubular steel gazebo‚Äù that clocks in at over 10 meters high and at least 50 long has been erected on the shoreline of Tavolara Island, according to Il Messaggero, describing the structure as an ‚Äúeco-monster.‚Äù  The gazebo is said to have been set up on the Villa Joy estate, which was rented out for the Jordanian royal family‚Äôs big event. La Nuova reports that 450 guests are expected to attend, including some unspecified heads of state.  Environmentalists have reportedly sounded the alarm over the party set-up, appealing to prosecutors and local police to look into whether organizers cut any corners by setting up the massive display on protected land.  ‚ÄúWe want to understand if the necessary environmental checks have been carried out,‚Äù a spokesperson for the Legal Intervention Group said in comments to local media.  ‚ÄúLaws in force establish a landscape constraint and a specific integral conservation constraint to protect the 300-meter strip from the seashore,‚Äù the group said.  The local mayor, Francesco Lai, has assured locals that an inspection had been carried out in the area and they are ‚Äúnow awaiting the results of the investigations.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI can certainly say that we will be compliant so that the structure is removed immediately after the event,‚Äù he was quoted saying.  Jordan‚Äôs royal family, for their part, deny that they have any plans to host a ‚Äúceremony‚Äù in Sardinia, stressing that the wedding itself, featuring ‚Äúnumerous VIP guests from around the world,‚Äù will take place in the country‚Äôs capital.  Meanwhile, Queen Rania has already been hyping up the wedding on social media, posting a flurry of photos and videos of the bride-to-be on Instagram as she attended a henna party to honor the big day.  ‚ÄúNo celebration would be complete without our Jordanian family. Celebrating our beautiful Rajwa,‚Äù she captioned one photo on Tuesday.

Family Medicine  This post was written by Ashley M. Bojrab, DPM, FACFAS, ABPM, CWS, PPG ‚Äì Podiatry.  Wedding season is upon us, which means good reasons to dress up and celebrate love with friends and family. As a podiatrist, whenever I‚Äôm lucky enough to attend a ceremony like this, I can‚Äôt help but scan the guests‚Äô footwear selections. (Call it occupational curiosity.) In this post, I‚Äôll share some of my recommendations for making the long day on your feet more comfortable, as well as the trends I‚Äôve noticed that I really want you to avoid.    Wedding day do‚Äôs and don‚Äôts  Practice makes perfect.  If you purchased new dress shoes to accessorize your outfit, you should consider breaking them in prior to the event. Wear them around the house or out and about. Not only will this make them less stiff, it will also help you get accustomed to how the shoes wear and gauge whether or not they‚Äôre comfortable. This goes for men‚Äôs shoes, too! Between the ceremony and reception, weddings can make for a marathon day on your feet‚Äìwaiting for seating, visiting with others, dancing‚Äìso it‚Äôs important to feel good.  Think about a thicker heel or even a wedge.  Ladies, if you‚Äôre opting for heels, consider a wider style. Keep in mind that, the thicker the heel, the more balance and stability the shoe provides. A wedge heel can also be a sturdier option if balance is a concern. If you are looking for height, try a platform shoe. This style offers better height distribution, so the angle of the foot isn't as sharp and the fit is more comfortable.  Don‚Äôt leave home without ‚Ä¶  Take adhesive bandages! BAND-AIDS¬Æ can be your best friend on a busy day in new shoes. When you are breaking in your shoes or on the day of the ceremony, if you notice an area is rubbing, place an adhesive bandage there to create a barrier to protect the skin. This can help prevent calluses and blisters from forming and keep you out on the dance floor. Don't forget to take a few extra just in case they fall off (or a fellow well-wisher needs some coverage).  Avoid the temptation to go barefoot!  It never fails ‚Ä¶ As the dinners are cleared and the dancing picks up, I see so many people shed their shoes to get more comfortable. My mind immediately jumps to all of the things that could go wrong. Your feet could get stepped on. You could pick up warts or athlete's feet from bacteria on the ground. Or worse, you could step on something that might require stitches or even surgery! Please, do me a favor, and bring a slipper or flat dress shoe in your bag. Flip flops work as well. Changing into a more comfortable shoe rather than going barefoot will keep your feet safe, and my mind at ease.  I hope the months ahead bring you many moments of joy and celebration. Remember, the best outfit is one that looks good and feels good, so plan ahead and enjoy the party.

Cassius Life Featured Video CLOSE  Apparently, it‚Äôs not a massive bag that gets Childish Gambino to perform; you‚Äôve just got to be a part of his team.  Donald Glover lent his performing chops to serenade his manager Chad Taylor and his wife at the newlyweds‚Äô first dance.  In a clip from TikTok, Gambino performs his song ‚Äú24.19‚Äù from his 2020 album 3.15.20.  The couple dances outside while Gambino can be seen in the background singing the bars, ‚ÄúSometimes I wonder why you love me, But you love me, I always make you cry no matter how I try, Sometimes I wonder why, Why would you ever want to love me? Must you love me?‚Äù  While they may certainly not be the most positive lyrics, the vibes at the wedding seemed immaculate.  The TikTok isn‚Äôt long, but it‚Äôs a welcomed treat for Gambino fans who haven‚Äôt seen him perform since he was the headliner at Texas‚Äô Austin City Limits in 2019.  Since then, he‚Äôs been consumed with wrapping up his FX show Atlanta‚Äôs fourth season and producing the satirical comedy horror thriller short series Swarm where Dominique Fishback stars as a crazed fan of a pop star that‚Äôs eerily reminiscent of Beyonc√©. Glover, however, confirmed at the 2023 Golden Globes ‚Äî where he was nominated for Best Performance by an Actor in a Television Series for his work in Atlanta‚Äìthat he‚Äôs still got a passion for music and the Gambino moniker will continue to crank out songs.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm making music right now. I love it. I‚Äôm actually in the studio. I‚Äôve been bringing people in, like secret people, working on little things. I‚Äôve been just making it for fun right now. But soon, something will happen. I promise,‚Äù he said before addressing the retirement whispers. ‚ÄúThat was out in the ethos. You don‚Äôt have to worry about that. He‚Äôll be back. He‚Äôs here right now.‚Äù  Peep the wedding performance above as we await new tracks from Childish Gambino.

Are you wondering what your wedding budget has to do with your studying abroad, especially if you‚Äôre an intending couple who want to travel and would love to relocate with your spouse, or you know a couple who are currently on this route? If this is you, then you need to read this.  It is no news how expensive Nigerian weddings can be irrespective of the region, which at times could be a factor of individual mindset or a cultural thing. You may have to prioritize your future by downsizing a lot of things that are talk of the town, yet in essence wouldn‚Äôt make you miss your fun on that big day. It is a labyrinth where many intending couples spend their fortunes on this memorable single day, and while this is good‚Äîthe glamour, the moments‚Äîit is really advisable to save if one desires to relocate.  Imagine getting married and relocating with your partner to a desired country a few weeks after your wedding. Nothing beats such a happy beginning.  Deciding to have an expensive wedding, due to the pressure, could in fact hamper your study abroad plans, especially if you have to borrow or expend your savings for this big day. It would be unfortunate to have a big wedding and then apply to study abroad without any savings to fund this dream.  Perhaps the story of a past student at Vantage Migration, Nancy, who relocated to the UK with her husband three months after her wedding, might give you a clue to this prudence. Her wedding was simple and beautiful; she cut down on her wedding budget so she could secure her relocation dream.  You can have a great wedding on a budget, so you can live the life you deserve with your spouse after the wedding. Take a lesson from Nancy: don‚Äôt spend money on things that will not really matter in the future. Discipline yourself and exercise delayed gratification.  So, if you are planning to get married and relocate abroad, these tips will help you budget and focus on your main goal:  1. Agree with your partner: This is so important; make sure you and your future spouse are on the same page. When you agree, then you can work together to fulfil your dreams. Even when you are tempted to overspend, one person would advise the other because of the vision ahead.  2. Explain your decision to your parents: Some parents are difficult and want a big wedding for the sake of their friends. However, you must not allow your parents and family members to decide what your wedding should be like; instead, communicate the goal to them and make them understand your plans. You need to be firm so you are not pressured to go beyond your budget  3. Have a wedding gift registry. Let your friends and loved ones know what you would like as your wedding gift. It is wise to let them know you would appreciate financial contributions, especially as you plan to relocate. However, not everyone needs to know about your plans, but it is okay to communicate your desired gifts and preferred support to friends and family.  4. Have your vision in front of you. Constantly remind yourself of the future you are pursuing. Have a vision board, look at it frequently, stay focused, and do not get distracted or discouraged on your journey. If Nancy could do it, then you can do it too.  Studying abroad can be daunting, but with the right tools and support, the relocation process can be seamless. To begin your journey with your future spouse, attend our free webinar, you can also share the link to someone who would be interested in following this route.

It‚Äôs up in the air whether Robyn and Meri will get invites.  ‚ÄúTheir family is broken at this point ‚Äì that‚Äôs very clear.‚Äù  Indeed, Christine herself has admitted that things are quite awkward between the Sister Wives at the moment. We can‚Äôt say for certain whether Christine‚Äôs wedding will be featured this year or next year‚Ä¶ but The Sun concludes by writing about it:  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be, from what I hear, really intimate and mostly close family.  ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs super close to her mom and obviously her kids will be there and his kids and their families.‚Äù

The last year hasn't been the easiest for Niamh Cullen and the influencer has been very open about her mental health.  Yet at last things seem to be looking up for the 30-year-old as she opened up to Louise Cooney on her podcast Open Book about all things wedding planning and burning in churches - yes, you read that right.  Today's top videos  As it turns out, Niamh had a notion that her other half Jamie Gill was going to pop the question telling her host that the proposal 'pulled her out' of a 'rotten year'.  'I actually kind of knew it [the proposal] was going to happen because he was actually acting a little bit funny that week, what he was doing as well wouldn't really be like Jamie,' Niamh said teasing how Jamie asked her to be his wife.  Niamh and Jamie Pic: Niamh Cullen/Instagram  'He was kind of encouraging me to go on Instagram, he was like "you should go on Instagram and address a few things, tell people why you've been upset and sad". He wanted a clean slate so when we woke [the day after the proposal], he was so cute, he booked the Shelbourne for us, and we woke up the next day and he was just like "are you getting loads of lovely messages?" and I was like "Yeah".'  Niamh continued: 'I said to him, "it's so nice, I'm getting people who are still commenting on how I shared about my mental health" and he was like "yeah that's why I was encouraging you, I really wanted you to have such a clean slate" and I was like "that's just so cute of you to think that".'  Now she's knee-deep in wedding planning and it seems that maybe she and her other half needed to talk about the perspective location for their nuptials before they made a trip to Jamie's parents' house.  'I feel like we're definitely going to get married abroad, hopefully, maybe the end of next year, we'll see how finances are, I also want to get a house, I'm wanting it all, so we're just going to have to see, who knows,' she said.  Niamh and Jamie Pic: Niamh Cullen/Instagram  Recalling a conversation at her new in-laws' home, Niamh told how when Jamie told his parents they'd be getting married in a church she was very surprised.  'I looked at him and I was like "what? Jamie I'm not getting married in a church". I'm not a practising Catholic, I'm sorry, like all my friends got married in churches, I'm all for it but [it's not] for me,' she said.  This didn't seem to go down to well as she explained: 'Jamie's dad's looking at me from the corner of his eye and he's like shoock at me and I was like "I'll burn up in flames in that church, if I'm at the altar I'll catch smoke!" So if I'm getting married in a church you're going to have a bucket of water ready.'  As it turns out Jamie was hoping the couple would get married in a church abroad but Niamh was not for the idea, however they've reached a comprise and are planning to have a traditional wedding at home first with close friends then jet off.  Instagram Niamh Cullen engagement  The blonde beauty has other big ideas floating around her head before she says 'I do' including an all-out bash for her hen night - and she's taking a rather untraditional route by planning it herself!  Traditionally, the maid of honour pulls together a big night or weekend celebration for the bride-to-be but Niamh is more than happy to come up with her own hen plans.  You Might Also Like 'Channelling my inner Carrie Bradshaw' influencer Niamh Cullen celebrates engagement  'I would love to go off to the likes of Ibiza or something fun but if we're asking people to travel I won't do that, we'll probably have something like my 30th, have a big whopper party,' she said with a laugh.  Though many things aren't set in stone right now for the couple, Niamh has one very important thing sorted and it was all thanks to a Pinterest search the day after they got engaged - her dress!  'There could be a deposit down,' she told Louise, 'Jamie's like "come on we haven't even got an official date yet" and I'm like "so? This is my priority!'  We love the organisation, Niamh!

Coronation Street's Paul has huge row with Gemma ahead of her wedding  Coronation Street spoilers follow.  Paul Foreman has had a huge row with sister Gemma Winter ahead of her wedding in Coronation Street.  Paul's partner Billy and family have no idea that he has been diagnosed with motor neurone disease, a life-shortening condition that can explain the chronic pain in his hand and now right foot.  In Wednesday's (May 24) episode, Paul was desperate to hide the pain in his foot ahead of his sister's wedding to Chesney Brown later in the week.  ITV  Related: Coronation Street star Dolly-Rose Campbell teases huge wedding story for Gemma Winter  After Jenny noticed Paul was having difficulty walking, Paul snuck off to his hospital appointment with confidant Dee Dee Bailey. There, he begged his doctor to consider him for a life-lengthening treatment used for MND and the similar condition ALS muscular dystrophy.  "It's not a cure, Paul," the nurse explained.  The nurse insisted "only a tiny percent of people" qualify for this treatment, but Paul said he wanted to move forward with the process.  "I need to get better," he insisted.  Later, Paul tried to put off Billy when the vicar explained that he'd spoken to Toyah about the adoption process. Paul tried to keep focus on the hen do, but he was understandably uncomfortable and in pain at the party.  ITV  Related: Coronation Street star Sam Aston on Chesney Brown's wedding day secret  Billy eventually left due to Paul's surly attitude, leading to an awkward situation where Paul refused his sister Gemma's request to dance together.  As Paul stormed out, Gemma chased after him to try to see what was wrong. Paul made it seem like he was sick and tired of all the wedding preparations, leaving Gemma feeling hurt.  "I don't care. I don't want anything more to do with it," he angrily demanded. "I'll tell you, find yourself someone else to walk down the aisle!"  Gemma finally snapped back at her brother: "If you really couldn't care less, don't even bother coming to the wedding at all!"  Can Paul make things right with Gemma before her big day?  Coronation Street airs on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays at 8pm on ITV1 and streams on ITVX.  Read more Coronation Street spoilers on our dedicated homepage  You Might Also Like

How Mashed Potatoes In Martini Glasses Became A Thing At Weddings  A loaded mashed potato bar might sound like something befitting for a Fourth of July backyard barbecue or a potluck party. Instead, the build-your-own model has become a popular wedding appetizer, often served alongside cocktail hours during wedding receptions. And, to make the dish a little fancier and suitable for a wedding celebration, many couples started having the potatoes served inside martini glasses.  According to an Eater article, the trend may have newfound fame thanks to social media, but it has existed since the '90s. "The mashed potato martini bar was a staple food experience for a long time," said John D'Arcangelo, managing director of the Abigail Kirsch catering company, "...because it brings together elements of surprise, glamour, and guest interaction."  The appetizer's popularity may be thanks to the fact that it allows guests to start with a simple base and add as many toppings as they want ‚Äî keeping guests entertained and fed while waiting for the main course. This is a great way to allow guests to interact with their food while waiting for the rest of the festivities.  And it seems that wedding planners took note. While this may have previously been a novelty appetizer at a select few weddings, mashed potatoes served in martini glasses are now offered through plenty of catering companies.

A couple gets married on Mount Diablo by Contra Costa County Deputy Commissioner of Marriages. Photo: CoCoCo Clerk-Recorder  By Dawn Kruger, Civic Outreach and Engagement Specialist, Contra Costa Clerk-Recorder‚Äôs Office  The Contra Costa Clerk-Recorder‚Äôs Office, in partnership with the California Department of State Parks, will be offering ‚ÄúDestination Weddings‚Äù on top of Mount Diablo on Friday May 26, 2023. Sixteen marriage ceremonies will be performed at the summit by Clerk staff between 10:00 am and 3:00 pm. Couples may have up to 30 guests, but there is limited seating available during the ceremony (16 chairs).  ‚ÄúDestination Weddings on Mount Diablo is always a favorite location for our customers,‚Äù Clerk-Recorder Registrar of Voters, Kristin Connelly said. ‚ÄúWe are excited to be able to offer couples this accessible opportunity for a unique day to remember at the summit of a Bay Area jewel.‚Äù  Mount Diablo State Park is a Contra Costa County landmark. On a clear day visitors have views westward beyond the Golden Gate Bridge to the Farallon Islands; South to Mount Hamilton and the Santa Cruz Mountains, North to Mount Saint Helena; and East over the Delta waterways. The stunning views provide a special backdrop for wedding ceremonies.  Because of the event‚Äôs popularity, all ceremony appointments for this Destination Weddings event have been booked, and no unscheduled appointments will be accommodated.  A marriage license must be obtained before a ceremony can be performed. Couples must purchase a license before their ceremony appointment at the County Clerk-Recorder‚Äôs office in Martinez. The fee for a public marriage license is $86, while a confidential license is $90. The civil marriage ceremony fee is $60.  For information about marriage license and ceremony services, go to www.contracostacore.us or call the office at 925-335-7900 Monday through Friday between the hours of 8:00 am and 4:30 pm. A BRIDE-TO-BE has been branded a "spoiled brat" after trying to ban her own sister from getting married the same year as her.  The woman, from Scotland, was fuming when her newly engaged sibling announced plans to tie the knot in 2024 just like her.  1 A bride has told her sister she can't get married the same year as her (stock image) Credit: Getty - Contributor  Writing in to the Girls Overheard podcast, she said she wanted the year to be "all about her" and now fears her sister will steal the spotlight.  She said: "Me and my partner were getting married in July this year but due to unforeseen circumstances we‚Äôve had to postpone until next July.  "So we‚Äôve got most of our planning done, venue booked etc.  "About a month ago or so my mum mentioned that my sister, who is also engaged, was thinking of having her wedding next year also.  "This really upset me as she‚Äôs a lot older than me, had been married previously and to also mention every big event in my life has been diminished by my sister.  "The one thing I thought could be about me would now be turning into us or more realistically, all about her.  "I told my mum and my sister my concerns. My mum‚Äôs initial response was ‚Äòit‚Äôs not her fault your unforeseen circumstances cropped up and that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre not getting married this year.‚Äô  "Is it still wrong of me to say I still don‚Äôt want her getting married the same year as me?"  The video has racked up more than 32,000 views, with social media users divided.  Some have insisted the bride-to-be is being a "diva" and can't block off a whole year.  One said: "A wedding is one day, I don‚Äôt think you can claim the whole year as your own."  Another wrote: "Yip unacceptable, sounds like she‚Äôs a diva."  A third added: "What a spoiled brat, life‚Äôs too short for this s***."  And a fourth agreed: "So unreasonable, especially if your sister is older. She will probably want to settle and have a family so she can‚Äôt be expected to push back."  But some have agreed with the woman that she should have her time to shine.  One said: "I would be fuming if my sister got married within a few months of me because the build up with the hen etc is fun."  Meanwhile, another added: "Absolutely not. I have a sister who would ruin all I would do, I feel you."

Heroic bridegroom halts wedding to save life of a man at another wedding reception  A bridegroom has been hailed a hero after he put his wedding on hold to save the life of a guest at another wedding reception.  The Chinese groom, who works as a nurse, was just about to make a speech at his wedding when he heard a call if there was a doctor or nurse in the room. A man had collapsed and fallen unconscious in a neighbouring banquet hall.  The incident took place on May 7 in Huai‚Äôan City, in the eastern province of Jiangsu, reported the South China Morning Post. Feng Luokun, an emergency nurse at a local hospital, swiftly responded to the call. His bride, who also heard the plea, encouraged her husband without hesitation. She said‚Ä¶  ‚ÄúGo save a life first. I will wait for you.‚Äù  Upon arriving at the scene, Feng discovered that the victim was having a seizure and losing consciousness. He suspected that the man was experiencing an epileptic episode. A video clip circulating online shows Feng asking wedding guests to call an ambulance before carefully placing a cloth in the patient‚Äôs mouth to prevent them from accidentally biting their tongue.  Some of Feng‚Äôs nurse colleagues who were attending the wedding joined him. Within 10 minutes an ambulance arrived to transport the patient to a hospital.  Local media reports disclosed that the patient, a relative of another wedding party in the nearby banquet hall, had a history of epilepsy but had not experienced a seizure for more than a decade.  Following treatment at the hospital, the patient regained consciousness, and his grateful family extended thanks to Feng.  Feng told Huaian TV‚Ä¶  ‚ÄúAs a medical worker, I think I should do my job in such a situation.‚Äù  The moment went viral on Weibo last week, attracting over two million views from various media platforms. One netizen commented‚Ä¶  ‚ÄúThe groom is so kind to save someone‚Äôs life on his own wedding day. I wish them happiness in marriage and a hundred years of good life together.‚Äù  Follow us on :              Another online observer said‚Ä¶  ‚ÄúThis kind of good man is worth marrying. Not only is he kind, but he also respects his bride. So, ladies, keep your eyes peeled for a good husband.‚Äù

by Charley Ross |  After tying the knot in Chelsea, Jamie Laing and Sophie Habboo have had a second wedding ceremony out in Marbella ‚Äì and they‚Äôve released a podcast episode centred around the day.  The wedding ‚Äì which was attended by the couple‚Äôs closest family and friends ‚Äì took place in a private villa called Sotogrande, and the bride wore two gorgeous dresses, one Emma Beamount lace bridal gown for the ceremony and a satin halter neck number for the evening reception.  Jamie also posted an adorable video to Instagram, commemorating the events of the Marbella wedding with the cute caption: ‚ÄòIt happened‚Ä¶.. ‚ÄúTo find true Love you must first find a true Friend‚Äù‚Äô.  Here are the top takeaways from part one of the NearlyWeds podcast‚Äôs ‚ÄòThe Wedding‚Äô episode.  Jamie was unlikely to be wearing open-toed shoes to the wedding  Sophie revealed that Jamie‚Äôs toenail fell off shortly after he arrived in Marbella, which she described as ‚Äòthe cherry on top of the tree‚Äô, a hilarious mix of metaphors that her fianc√© found hilarious. Let‚Äôs hope he wasn‚Äôt planning to wear flip flops or sandals to the ceremony.  An A-list nail technician ditched the Biebers to do Sophie‚Äôs nails for the big day  Sophie couldn‚Äôt wait to share that a special guest offered to add to her pre-wedding beauty routine.  ‚ÄòHarriet Westmoreland, who I have followed for 3 years, who was meant to be doing Hailey and Justin Bieber‚Äôs nails in England today, asked to fly out to do my nails instead,‚Äô she said. ‚ÄòDoes that mean I‚Äôve made it? I think so.‚Äô  Clearly waving her newly-done nails around behind the podcast mic, she added: 'Take these in, suckers!‚Äô  And a true bonus ‚Äì Sophie decided to invite Harriet to the wedding ‚Äòbecause she‚Äôs a vibe‚Äô.  Sophie‚Äôs snoring proved a problem in the run up to the wedding  Jamie was quick to point out that Sophie her snoring ‚Äòwasn‚Äôt too good‚Äô.  ‚ÄòI have to put it out there,' he said, adding that it‚Äôs due to the fact she has allergies in her nose.  Sophie explained that she had stuffed tissue up her nose to try stop herself from snoring, with Jamie describing the sounds to be ‚Äòlike a walrus‚Äô.  Their marriage has been agreed to last ‚Äòat least a year‚Äô  Sophie dished the dirt on comments Jamie has made about having to make it to the year marker of marriage.  She said: ‚ÄôOnce he said during an argument, ‚Äúurgh I've got to stay married to you for at least a year‚Äù. I was like, ‚Äúf * * k you!‚Äù‚Äô  Jamie admitted that this was true: ‚ÄòIf it was before a year, everyone would be like "well that was short‚Äù. But a year, then you're like ‚Äúthat's alright.‚Äù‚Äô  Let‚Äôs see how these lovebirds go!  Spencer Matthews had his own special role on the day  The podcast episode includes a brief chat with Spencer on the wedding day. He generously describes the event itself as ‚Äòquite a lot cooler than I thought it would be‚Äô.  When asked if he was happy to be invited, Spencer responded: ‚Äòeven though I won‚Äôt be officiating, I‚Äôm happy with my role‚Äù. He was due to MC, according to Jamie, who wanted him to dress up as Mr Tumnus from the Chronicles of Narnia.  Alas, Spencer confirmed he was wearing a ‚Äòlovely new tux‚Äô instead.  Sam Thompson talks about his failed plan to ‚Äòmug off‚Äô Jamie during the ceremony  Jamie‚Äôs ex-Made In Chelsea co-star, ex-PA at Candy Kittens and self-proclaimed ‚Äòbrother in arms‚Äô described the ceremony as ‚Äòthe sweetest thing I‚Äôve ever seen in my life‚Äô.  He described reacting differently to he thought he would when he saw his pal crying at the end of the aisle when he saw his bride: ‚ÄòI thought I was going to mug Jamie off when he cried, then I went ‚Äúf * * k I‚Äôm crying!‚Äô  The incredible booze at the Marbella wedding was also mentioned:‚ÄúYou‚Äôre never gonna find a free bar with this kind of ros√© anywhere else.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe dream was to do anything art-related, be financially stable, and to get eight hours of sleep daily,‚Äù Sophia Ng quipped during our interview.  As one of the pioneering artists to bring live wedding paintings to Malaysia, it‚Äôs safe to say that she‚Äôs fulfilled her first two wishes.  Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio  When the pandemic hit, the art studio Sophia was principal at couldn‚Äôt host classes anymore. So she decided to sign up for the Youth Art Entrepreneur Programme by the National Art Gallery.  There, she learnt the basics of running an art business over the course‚Äôs four months.  After completing it, she realised that she needed an art-related business model that would bring in constant flow of income.  That‚Äôs when she came across a viral TikTok video of a live wedding painter in the US, and experienced a lightbulb moment.  ‚ÄúI saw the potential in the business model and made it a mission to figure out how it could be done,‚Äù Sophia said.  Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio  Months were spent to work out the painting process, develop the equipment list, and build a portfolio to suit the local market.  To be more inclusive of different cultures, Sophia‚Äôs portfolio includes various samples to help clients of different backgrounds visualise the final painting.  ‚ÄúMost importantly, I had to practise again and again to ensure that I can complete the painting to a certain detail within a time frame. Because I can‚Äôt risk not finishing a live painting.‚Äù  Sophia also began documenting her journey on social media to gauge the local response to her business, and this became another form of market research. It even led to her first few bookings for live wedding paintings.  Setting her mind at ease(l)  Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio  At the start of every live painting session, artists would typically paint the background. This could be the actual wedding setting or another backdrop that was agreed upon.  Sophia does this before guests arrive, which helps to ensure that nobody is blocking the view. It also puts her in the zone.  ‚ÄúIt gives me a tunnel vision of the painting. I will remain focused on it until it‚Äôs complete despite the distractions,‚Äù she explained. Her past experiences as a teacher meant that she‚Äôs learnt to focus in any environment.  Then all that‚Äôs left to do is to wait for ‚Äúthe moment‚Äù that her clients have chosen to memorialise based on previous discussions.  This could be the march in, the vow exchange, the first dance, a cultural practice (like the tying of the mangalsutra, a pendant necklace, at Hindu weddings), or anything else the bride and groom favour.  Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio  The whole process takes around five to six hours and is presented to the happy couple before the end of the event.  ‚ÄúThe gist of a live painting is that it captures a moment or an impression of the event as it happens. It seals a memory,‚Äù Sophia described.  ‚ÄúThe focus of a regular portrait is the portrait itself, [and] the person painted is the main subject. Whereas in a live wedding painting, the moment is the main subject.‚Äù  This probably also explains why Sophia‚Äôs art style doesn‚Äôt really approach realism. Instead, it‚Äôs more impressionistic.  The painting will then be displayed for the rest of the event before being taken back to the studio for final touch ups, varnishing, and wiring. It‚Äôll be ready for its new home within two weeks after the wedding event.  Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio  All that and ‚Äúpen‚Äù some  Clients can also request to add family members who are no longer around into the painting, so that it‚Äôs as if they were actually present at the ceremony. All they have to do is provide photos for reference.  One of the most memorable sessions Sophia has had was to include a bride‚Äôs late mother, grandmother, and her two dogs who have passed.  ‚ÄúIt was very moving for me as I understood the bride‚Äôs emotions. I was cared for by my grandmother in my early years and wasn‚Äôt able to have her on my wedding day. I also have six dogs that I love dearly.‚Äù  Overall, the addition of these family members took her around 10 hours to complete the painting.  Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio  Sophia‚Äôs live wedding painting service ranges from RM1,850 to RM2,850 depending on the portrait‚Äôs size.  Out of curiosity, we wondered if she‚Äôd faced any naysayers who questioned why they‚Äôd opt for a live painting over a wedding photographer, and Sophia said no.  She doesn‚Äôt think that the goal of live painters is to push out photographers either.  ‚ÄúI think we should co-exist. Live painting is a about capturing a moment, it‚Äôs also a form of live performance and an added element to the wedding event.‚Äù  Off to a flying (st)art  Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio  Sophia is currently based in KL, but her business can take her anywhere across the globe. Besides Malaysia, she‚Äôs also painted at wedding ceremonies in Thailand, Indonesia, and Singapore.  If she‚Äôs travelling to other Malaysian states or overseas though, she charges an additional travel fee.  As one of the first few (if not only) live wedding painting artists in Malaysia, her main goal is to continue bringing awareness to the art‚Äôs existence.  On top of sharing information online, she‚Äôs partnered with local wedding vendors like weddingsmalaysia, Bridepay, and Elysium Weddings. She also attends wedding industry related events, like exhibitions.  Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio  Based on the current global trend, the hype for live wedding paintings doesn‚Äôt seem to be dying down anytime soon.  But live wedding paintings have actually been around for centuries. They were quite popular at royal weddings, such as Queen Victoria‚Äôs.  With social media and wedding sites playing a helping hand in promoting the art as avant-garde, though, more everyday people will be able to enjoy this novel service on their special day.  So it seems that Sophia might just achieve what she‚Äôs wishing for.  Learn more about Sophia Ng Studio here.  Read other articles we‚Äôve written about Malaysian startups here.  Featured Image Credit: Sophia Ng Studio

It‚Äôs wedding season! Local vendor Kelsey Butler Harrison, CEO of Pop & Drop, has recently been honored in The Knot‚Äôs ‚ÄúOnes To Watch List,‚Äù in the ‚ÄúInnovator‚Äù category! The Knot is a wedding planning site and vendor marketplace. Kelsey visited with Studio 512 about what sets her business apart.  Kelsey has five tips for couples who are wedding planning, from a vendor‚Äôs perspective. She‚Äôs got a great blog post covering this information. Check out the highlights below:  Hire your vendors ASAP. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt speak for every vendor, but we love at least a four to six-month notice before your wedding. Vendors are busy and need adequate time to fully prepare for your big day. Contacting them early alleviates stress, spreads out your planning, and gives everyone plenty of time to bring their A-game to your wedding.‚Äù Get a wedding planner. ‚ÄúA wedding planner becomes the liaison between the couple and the wedding vendors, which takes a ton of communication responsibilities off your plate. If juggling emails, arrival times, and last-minute needs stress you out, hire a planner to do those logistics for you. Trust us, vendors love having a planner to go to with any questions or concerns instead of bothering the couple on their day!‚Äù Incorporate interactive reception elements. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre throwing a big wedding, you want to give your guests plenty to do and make it an even more memorable affair. Interactive elements are unique, showcase your personality as a couple, and keep your guests entertained all night. Plus, for your guests who aren‚Äôt big dancers, it‚Äôs great to give them more to do.‚Äù Get creative. ‚ÄúFrom the decor standpoint, we love sprucing up ceremony sites with streamer fringe and balloon garlands! Your ceremony site can be as beautiful as the reception space, and since it‚Äôs usually where you end up taking a lot of group photos, you want it to match the rest of your wedding.‚Äù Do what you want ‚Äì and communicate it with your vendors. ‚ÄúAs vendors, the most important thing is that our couple is happy and has an amazing day. We love getting creative with your vision to bring your dream wedding to life. Don‚Äôt be shy about bringing an out-of-the-box idea to your vendors. If they haven‚Äôt made it happen before, chances are they‚Äôd love to try it and expand their offerings!‚Äù  Kelsey also has a sister business, a photo booth company called Oh Happy Day. Learn more about it at OhHappyDayBooth.com, and connect with Kelsey about her services at Pop & Drop at PopAndDropTX.com.

Michelle Keegan and Mark Wright tend to keep their relationship under wraps, but the Heart Radio star previously made a rare comment about a behind-the-scenes wedding mishap.  The couple, who are celebrating eight years of marriage, exchanged vows on 24 May 2015 at St Mary's Church in Bury St Edmonds, which was decorated with 12-foot trees. While the Ten Pound Poms actress looked stunning in her French lace fishtail wedding dress with a deep-V back and the former TOWIE star looked suave in his tux, Michelle's father Mike suffered a last-minute mishap with his outfit.  WATCH: Inside Mark Wright and Michelle Keegan's love story  DJ Mark recalled the funny story on his Heart Radio show, telling listeners: "On the wedding day right, my father-in-law is panicking about his speech. All I wanted was for things to go smoothly for him.  "To make matters worse, Michelle‚Äôs step-father‚Äôs there as well, we‚Äôre getting on our suits, looking slick as you come, black tie, tuxedo. But I look around and my father-in-law Mike is sat there in just a shirt, bow tie and rainbow-coloured boxers." He continued: "They were horrendous by the way, Mike, if you‚Äôve got them, please throw them away right now."  The couple shared their wedding photos with HELLO!  The mishap was only temporary, and Mike located his trousers in time to walk his daughter down the aisle.  Mark and Michelle shared their wedding album exclusively with HELLO!, and although Michelle looked stunning in her bespoke Galia Lahav gown, she revealed it wasn't her original wedding dress. "I had ordered another dress back in August but when I tried it again three months ago I didn't like it," Michelle told HELLO!. "It wasn't the dress for me.  "I was struggling with what to wear, what designer to go with, I was Googling and Instagramming all day and came across Galia, an Israeli designer not based in London. But then I saw that they were doing a trunk show in London on a weekend at Browns. They had clients booked all day but I managed to go in very early."  So clearly it was meant to be! The Our Girl star asked for some final tweaks to make it her dream dress, which she teamed with a "dramatic" Italian veil from Peter Langner. "I asked for the shape of the neck to be changed and I had more lace details around the deep V back," said Michelle.  ¬© Getty The couple made their red carpet debut at the British Soap Awards in 2013  Her finished gown impressed both her wedding guests and her groom, who admitted he got emotional when he caught sight of Michelle for the first time. Reliving the moment, Michelle said: "I will never get that again, it was the best feeling ever," while Mark agreed: "That's the same for me. It was like being in a dream. Every time I looked back at Michelle, I went to cry.  ¬© Getty Michelle Keegan flashed her engagement ring in October 2013  "I didn't know if I'd be able to keep looking at her. But then I thought, 'You know what? I'm not going to miss this', so I turned back and watched her as she walked towards me."  PHOTOS: 11 Coronation Street stars with jaw-dropping engagement rings  Planning your wedding? Sign up to HELLO!‚Äôs Bride Guide newsletter for expert advice, budget help, wedding inspiration and real life stories delivered straight to your inbox.

Neither Nathan Cole nor Andy Moller is from London, but the city has been central to their love story from the start. Their paths first crossed during London Fashion Week in 2013, where Derbyshire-born Nathan was working for the BFC, and Andy, who grew up in Australia, was producing fashion shows. They had their first date at the Royal Oak pub on Columbia Road, home to the city‚Äôs famous flower market. And a decade on, they exchanged vows in a grand 19th-century members‚Äô club on Pall Mall, wearing matching white tie and tails made bespoke by the same Savile Row tailor behind the ceremonial robes seen at King Charles‚Äôs Coronation.  ‚ÄúWe wanted to look classic and elegant for the formal ceremony and dinner,‚Äù says Nathan, a brand marketing consultant and co-founder of luxury wrapping service Colford, explaining how the couple settled on their made-to-measure evening suits by Ede & Ravenscroft. ‚ÄúThe suits were identical but we chose different personal touches like shirt studs, cufflinks and dress shoes to complete our looks.‚Äù  After the candlelit wedding feast of seared scallops and slow-cooked Hereford beef ‚Äì served in the opulent dining room as the sun went down ‚Äì the grooms swapped their formal tails for a pair of bespoke pale gold tuxedos by the Savile Row tailor Richard James, a close friend, as the party truly got underway. Both chose custom shirts by Emma Willis of Jermyn Street (chocolate silk satin for Andy and an ivory sand-washed silk for Nathan), and Manolo Blahnik loafers. Antique citrine brooches and silk Prada pocket squares served as the finishing touches.  Besides their carefully chosen wedding looks, the couple planned every aspect of the celebrations themselves, enlisting the team at Studio Boum ‚Äì the event design and production studio where Andy is creative director ‚Äì to help them bring their vision to life. ‚ÄúWe brought together an ambitious but ultimately magical moment seamlessly,‚Äù Nathan says now. ‚ÄúWe shared responsibilities, each taking the lead on different creative elements, from floral design to food and cocktail curation to entertainment.‚Äù  That last element proved particularly memorable. After guests ‚Äì fuelled by espresso martinis, negronis and Tommy‚Äôs margaritas ‚Äì were lured onto the dance floor by resident Dalston Superstore DJ Chris Cuff, a Halpern-clad Heather Small, lead singer of M People, performed a surprise live set of ‚Äô90s anthems including ‚ÄúOne Night in Heaven‚Äù and ‚ÄúSearch for the Hero‚Äù for the thrilled crowd, culminating in a particularly euphoric moment care of a confetti drop. The grooms‚Äô friends, DJs Mariam Gedovani and Rohan Bell-Towers, then took over the decks until the small hours.  ‚ÄúAll we wanted to do was bring together all of our favourite people and really celebrate,‚Äù says Nathan now. ‚ÄúWe think we achieved that, so we are very happy. These are memories that we will cherish forever.‚Äù
