While wedding dresses often make a big impression during a couple‚Äôs nuptials, brides usually wear the gown once and then let it take up space in their closet. In an attempt to solve this problem, Zena Holloway creates biodegradable wedding dresses, The Guardian reports. The ocean photographer and bio-designer debuted one of her gowns, a tea-length getup adorned with a substance that looks like coral, at the Chelsea Flower Show on May 22, 2023. ‚ÄúThe concept for this dress is a sustainable wedding dress,‚Äù she notes. ‚ÄúIf they got married by the ocean, for example, she could sustainably trash the dress and get in the water and all the fish would just eat it, and it would just become part of the ocean.‚Äù  According to The Guardian, these special gowns are made with roots of wheatgrass. The designer of the dresses created the sustainable material after coming across plastic pollution while taking photos in the ocean. ‚ÄúI saw the growing amount of plastic in the ocean over the years and became upset about the materials we were using,‚Äù she explains to the outlet.  Then, after the designer grew mushrooms in her basement, she soon became interested in the mycelium, which is the root-like structure of a fungus, because it seemed to form a new material. ‚ÄúAnd then I was in the river doing a river cleanup with my camera, and through the lens, I saw bright red willow roots that were growing in the water,‚Äù she continues. ‚ÄúAnd because my head was in that place, thinking about the binding property of roots or binding of mycelium, the penny dropped.‚Äù  Once she developed the concept, Holloway started growing roots at home to understand how they might mesh together, the publication reports. Holloway experiments with growing wheatgrass over different kinds of materials, such as corals and beeswax, so it takes on those shapes, according to The Guardian. When enough roots have sprouted, the creative uses beeswax to naturally strengthen the material. The final product is a twisting product that‚Äôs reminiscent of coral.  With these biodegradable dresses, Holloway hopes that her designs inspire others to use more sustainable materials in their attire. According to the World Resources Institute, the fashion industry emits two to eight percent of the world‚Äôs greenhouse gasses, and that number is only growing. Even though the sector has committed to decreasing their total emissions, the institute predicts that the fashion industry‚Äôs carbon footprint will rise by 60 percent by 2030. Holloway‚Äôs eco-friendly wedding dresses are one way to curb greenhouse gas emissions.

Rosie Joyce, a newlywed who shares lifestyle and fashion content, posted an adorable throwback TikTok that showed how her own parents had swapped outfits on their wedding day (and completely rocked it, by the way). So, Rosie and her new husband decided to do the same.  ‚ÄúI grew up obsessed with these photos! How did we do?‚Äù Rosie wrote in her video. ‚ÄúWe wanted to recreate the photos and surprise everyone on our recovery day.‚Äù  And surprise everyone they did. Her husband strolled out in a lovely and pristine white gown with his toned arms on display, holding a beer wrapped snugly in a koozie. He may have had a little trouble zipping his dress, but who among us hasn‚Äôt rocked an unzipped outfit occasionally?  You could say the big reveal went well: ‚ÄúOBSESSED,‚Äù commented one TikToker, praising the couple.  While her new husband said yes to her dress, Rosie completely stole the show in his tuxedo, which she topped off with a pair of bright white Gucci clogs. She also accessorized with a fruity White Claw and drop earrings.  ‚ÄúYou absolutely ate it up in that suit, my god,‚Äù wrote one commenter.  The couple then posed for a series of loved-up photos, including one stunning shot edited in black and white and an ending pose with the OG, Rosie‚Äôs mother.  But many commenters pointed out that as darling as Rosie and her hubby looked, the real stars of this TikTok show were her parents.  ‚ÄúYour parents hair?? The drinks?? The cig?? Perfection‚Äù wrote one.  ‚ÄúDad looks like Neil Diamond in his early years,‚Äù pointed out another.  And still, others spotted the uncanny resemblance Rosie‚Äôs dad bore to Dennis Quaid, which, ironically, was a nod to the Parent Trap audio Rosie chose for the TikTok. ‚ÄúI thought it was a deleted scene from Parent Trap,‚Äù laughed another commenter in agreement.  The post is a nod to a recent wedding trend that‚Äôs seen couples incorporate trends and traditions from their own parents‚Äô nuptials, including this bride that transformed her mother‚Äôs wedding gown into her rehearsal dinner dress.  And in the spirit of ‚Äúsomething old and something new,‚Äù a few other TikTokers were curious about the concept of a ‚Äúwedding recovery day,‚Äù which Rosie hashtagged in her video.  A wedding recovery day is exactly what it sounds like ‚Äî the day after a wedding day that a couple takes to recover from the sometimes stressful and exhausting walk to the aisle. Some couples may choose to take a day to themselves to indulge in some low-key fun, like lounging on the beach or hitting up brunch, while others host or attend a casual gathering with friends and families over a few drinks like Rosie and her husband did.  Whether couples choose to rock a wedding outfit swap as this pair did or just take some time for themselves, it‚Äôs safe to say that the trend of a wedding recovery day might just be the next big thing ‚Äî along with this bride‚Äôs parents‚Äô incredible rizz, of course. Barb Bierman Batie Barb is a freelance journalist who grew up near Battle Creek, Nebraska, and now farms row crops with her Platte Valley Farmer, Don Batie, northeast of Lexington. She can be reached at editorial@midwestmessenger.com. Follow Barb Bierman Batie Close Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily! Your notification has been saved. There was a problem saving your notification. {{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items. Save Manage followed notifications Close Followed notifications Please log in to use this feature Log In Don't have an account? Sign Up Today  Just a tad over two weeks ago we took off for Utah to attend the wedding of one of Cicely‚Äôs best buds from high school. Hailey Mandelko was to marry Daniel ‚ÄúDanny‚Äù Ferry, and they were using the hashtag "#ferrytale.‚Äù It truly turned out to be a ‚Äúferrytale.‚Äù  Yes, it was in the middle of spring planting, but from the time we got the ‚ÄúSave the Date‚Äù card last winter there was no question we were going to make attending that event work. Not only was Cicely a bridesmaid, but the bride, her parents and family had been friends since the girls were in pre-school.  Ever since my car accident two years ago and the sudden deaths of some dear, close friends this past year, we have made attending special occasions a priority whenever we can. It has been impressed upon us all too often that life is too short to miss them.  We took off for Colorado after parking the planter about 6 p.m. and drove as far as Fort Morgan, putting us just one hour away from the Denver airport where we had an 11:30 p.m. flight. God smiled on many of us in dry country as we drove through showers for part of the evening and learned the next morning that the showers had reached home as well. While things would get stormy Friday night most of the area got over an inch of much needed rain while we were gone.  We were able to meet up with Cicely at our gate just before boarding. She had flown to Denver from Omaha. The flight went well, and we were pleasantly surprised at how easy it is to navigate the Salt Lake City airport.  Our destination was Spanish Fork, about an hour south of Salt Lake City. While Hubby and I had both been to Salt Lake City before, we had not ventured south and the stunning views of the mountains in spring had us mesmerized. No wonder the bride and groom had chosen this location for their big day.  The next morning, we met the rest of the Lexington contingent at breakfast. It was then we learned Johnson Lake had been hit by a tornado on Friday night. Several of the couples live at the lake, and the bride‚Äôs parents are building a new home there, but only one family sustained major damage and that was loss of a storage shed. While not exactly the start we wanted to the weekend, by mid-morning it was clear that things were being handled by family and friends at home and we proceeded with the festivities.  Cicely and the bridesmaids were to report to the wedding venue by 10 a.m. for hair and makeup with a rehearsal set for 2 p.m. We arrived just ahead of the bride‚Äôs parents and when they pulled in with two full loads of decorations, we did the Nebraska thing and just started carrying in boxes, and boxes, and boxes.  The venue was all self-contained with an outdoor garden for the ceremony, a reception hall, catering kitchen and dressing rooms for the bridal party on the second floor. It certainly was a plus to have everything in one spot.  It became clear that this was going to be an all-hands-on deck affair and while the bride‚Äôs Aunt Jane supervised the decorations, Hubby and I got put in charge of preparing the favors. These were engraved mugs that were to be filled with candy. The bride is an assistant women‚Äôs basketball coach at Southern Utah University in Cedar City, Utah, and the groom is in charge of basketball operations there, which is how they met. So, among the goodies were basketball wrapped mints.  My foresight in bringing a travel sewing kit along paid off. The bride‚Äôs something old were appliques cut from her mother and grandmother‚Äôs wedding dresses. Cicely whip-stitched those in place. The kit‚Äôs safety pins also came in handy when a misstep by a wedding guest pulled the hooks off the bustled wedding gown train and they were used to keep it in place.  After a late lunch we returned to find the catering staff had worked their table setting magic and the venue sparkled with excitement. The ceremony went off splendidly, with the flower girls and ring bearer pulled in a cart stealing the show. The bride‚Äôs dog, Zion, also happily romped down the aisle to greet his mistress and was then leashed and led away while barking the song of his people, as most golden retrievers do.  The rest of the evening we enjoyed a wonderful meal, meeting some of the groom‚Äôs family, visiting with the current Southern Utah basketball team, their head coach and other assistant coaches, and other guests. No strangers left when we left.  Capping the night was a fun popper and bubble send-off. A memo to the bride‚Äôs sister who is getting married in September, remember to check with the venue about send-off regulations. Yes, it was a #ferrytale wedding to remember.

Weddings can be expensive, especially when it comes to paying per person for food and beverages. But one savvy bride on TikTok shared her version of hacking the system ‚Äî by ordering takeout from popular fast-casual chain Chili's ‚Äî and it saved her a ton of money.  The Internet, however, has mixed reactions.  In the video, which has been viewed over 2 million times, bride Madison Mulkey explains how she ordered food for the big day, which came to a meager $1,950 for 99 guests total ‚Äî roughly $19.69 per person.  "It's insane that we only spent that much money for our wedding food," she told viewers.  Instead of having the food delivered for the 6 p.m. reception, Mulkey picked it up at 11 a.m. to avoid delivery fees, but that also meant that the servers hired for her wedding were tasked with other jobs like figuring out how to keep the food fresh.  "My coordinator kind of had to show them what to do and take on a role that she wasn't really supposed to do and they weren't supposed to do either," Mulvey explained, adding that the couple chose easy-to-eat items like chips and salsa and egg rolls. "It was the perfect meal for our wedding. I'm so happy we chose Chili's. So happy we did this!"  The main concern among viewers seemed to be whether or not Mulkey tipped the staff and prepared them for the extra tasks in advance.  "As a wedding planner that is so unfair to the planner and servers," one person wrote. "If ppl do this, hire a delivery pick-up driver and a specific food prep cook."  "All I can think abt is how stressful this must have been for the staff," another said.  In a follow-up video, Mulkey explained that she did tip generously.  "We tipped everyone ‚Äî we tipped the Chili's kitchen staff $300, we tipped the Chili's manager who worked specifically with us to make sure this was even possible $100," she said, as well as noting they tipped the coordinator and servers.  Others, however, were on board with Mulkey's decision.  "I'm not gonna lie, I would've been SO excited for this menu as a guest," one person said.  And as for Chili's opinion on the bride's catering decision?  The restaurant chain commented with one simple word: "Iconic."

CLEVELAND, Ohio ‚Äì I was sitting on my back patio the other day, thinking about how it‚Äôs almost unbelievable that my wedding day is approaching as quickly as it is. So much planning and preparation is done, but there‚Äôs still so much left to do.  A lot of the more last-minute details ‚Äì seating charts, payments due, etc. ‚Äì depend on how many guests will be there on our special day. Which means, naturally, that I have become a hawk when it comes to hunting down RSVPs.  Our invitations, and more importantly, our RSVP cards, went out in the mail not too long ago, so I anticipate folks will send in their responses soon. Or, at least, I hope.  You see, I made a very big mistake when it came to submitting my RSVP on time for a friend‚Äôs wedding last fall, and it nearly ruined what was ultimately a very fun weekend. Let me explain.  A girlfriend from college was getting married in her hometown of San Francisco late last year. I had known about the wedding for a very long time; the couple got engaged during the pandemic, and they chose to wait to celebrate their wedding day until there were fewer COVID-19 cases nationwide and their loved ones felt safe to travel.  I don‚Äôt remember the exact timeline, but I know I received their invitation more than eight weeks before the ceremony. Because I had never been to San Francisco, I had planned to go a few days before the wedding to sight-see and visit with other college friends who would be in town for the wedding. I planned my time off with my manager, and I was excited to go.  One day last September ‚Äì actually, while I was scrambling to leave for another wedding ‚Äì I realized that while the invitation and RSVP details were hanging on my fridge for weeks, I had not yet sent in my answer (yes!) and I was 10 days past the RSVP deadline.  Frantic, I quickly sent my RSVP response through the couple‚Äôs wedding website and texted my friend to apologize for not responding at all, but that yes, we would be there, and we were excited. She responded to me a few hours later, saying her caterer and venue were strict about the RSVP deadline, and it was possible they would not be able to make any edits or exceptions.  To say I was upset was an understatement. I was upset with myself that I procrastinated on responding to an invitation I‚Äôd had for at least a month. I was upset that the catering company could be so immovable that adding two more plates would be impossible. I was upset that a trip that had been planned (but thankfully not yet booked) would come crashing down.  Luckily for me, few days later, my friend texted to say her caterer was willing to make a one-time exception for me and my fianc√©, and our trip to San Francisco was still on.  I traveled to the city a few days before my fianc√© and friends came to town, and I went on a self-guided sight-seeing trip to Alcatraz, the Embarcadero and Ghirardelli Square. We stayed near Chinatown and Nob Hill. We ate delicious dim sum and walked... a lot. As for the wedding itself, their venue was classy and beautiful. The ceremony was elegant, and their reception was a lot of fun. I am grateful I could be there.  Sight-seeing in San Francisco the day after my friend's wedding. I forgot to send my RSVP response in time, so I was fortunate to even be there.  However, my lesson was learned: RSVP dates are not suggestions. They are important for not just the couple but for the applicable vendors on the big day. I no longer procrastinate to respond when I receive an invitation of any kind.  If you have any wedding showers, weddings, baby showers, etc. to attend this summer, don‚Äôt repeat my mistake. Send your answer about whether you‚Äôll attend sooner rather than later. You ‚Äì and the host! ‚Äì will be glad you did.  My fingers are crossed that our guests respond in a timely manner. The invitation went out when they did so that guests would have more than one month to reply.  I also made our RSVP easy to complete by making it primarily online, a trend that I‚Äôve noticed over the past several years among our friends and loved ones. However, we did include an RSVP card along with the invitation that could be mailed back if an online response is not possible, for whatever reason. We wanted to make it easy for our guests!  Ultimately, in the unlikely event that you are both a) reading this and b) invited to our small wedding, I hope to hear from you soon!  This column is part of a series I‚Äôm writing on my wedding planning adventures ahead of my summer 2023 nuptials. If you have a topic that interests you; an anecdote you‚Äôd love for me to read; or thoughtful words of encouragement, you can email me at jmorice@cleveland.com or follow me on Twitter at @janemorice. Planning a summer wedding is the top choice for many couples, and we understand why: Summertime brings longer, brighter days, stunning color palettes, and an abundance of floral choices. This warm and sunny time of year also means access to plenty of delicious seasonal produce.  If you‚Äôre planning a summer wedding, there are a few key considerations to keep in mind while curating the food selections for your menu. To help create the most memorable summer wedding menu, we asked wedding experts for their favorite ideas for this bountiful season. Below, find key tips to keep in mind, ideal seasonal ingredients to incorporate, and ideas for everything from hors d'oeuvres to cocktails and desserts.  Creating a Summer Wedding Menu  Summer brings access to all sorts of fresh produce, and that‚Äôs definitely the star of the show for most summer wedding menus. ‚ÄúSummertime is made to highlight vegetables and fruits,‚Äù says Lynn Easton, founder of Easton Events. ‚ÄúAsk your catering chef what will be in the peak of the season during your wedding month and lean into those delicacies for a more ‚Äòfarm-to-table‚Äô approach.‚Äù  In selecting the perfect menu, Alexandria Hammond, co-founder of GetPlated Catering, says to keep the menu light, refreshing, and fun. ‚ÄúMake sure that menu items are cohesive and include some pops of color,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúCouples might also want to see if it‚Äôs possible to incorporate items that are related to their colors or theme into their food or beverages.‚Äù  Meet the Expert Lynn Easton is the founder of Easton Events, a full-service wedding and event design company in Charleston, South Carolina and Charlottesville, Virginia.  Alexandria Hammond is the co-founder of GetPlated Catering, a husband and wife catering team based in Washington, D.C.  For a summer wedding, Easton says ingredients that are bright and acidic are sure to please. Hammond adds that including seasonal ingredients such as watermelon, mango, pineapple, berries, peaches, tomatoes, corn, and basil are all great highlights. After all, you want to offer something to your guests that will still be enjoyable while it‚Äôs hot outside.

Dagmar Brown and Paul Malle first met at the Los Angeles hotspot Osteria La Buca in 2018 during a dinner hosted by their mutual friend, Olympia Irving. At the time, they were both seeing other people. Three years later, however, they started dating and never looked back‚Äîmoving to Mexico City, where Paul runs Cine Club La Cabra, together just two months into their relationship.  Paul and Dagmar got engaged in March 2022. He proposed with a sixth-century gold Byzantine ring at his aunt‚Äôs home in Puerto Vallarta, which he bought in Paris a mere six months after they became official.  The two wed nearly a year later in Oaxaca, Mexico, where Dagmar grew up. They held an opening party at the Quinta Real Hotel in Oaxaca City, followed by what Dagmar describes as a ‚Äúyouth-only fiesta‚Äù at nearby cultural center Son De Aqui. On March 18, they wed in front of 350 people in the town of San Jer√≥nimo Tlacochahuaya‚Äôs church. Gisele Perez Moreno, whom Dagmar has known since a child, was their wedding planner. ‚ÄúWe both had the most wonderful time through it all,‚Äù she says.  The bride wore a custom Paula Nadal gown with Elizabethan-inspired detailing along with sapphire drop Irene Neuwirth earrings, an emerald and gold lion ring borrowed from her mother-in-law Marie Malle, and Christian Louboutin crystal-encrusted Cinderella slippers. The true statement of her outfit, however? A jeweled diadem with rich origins: ‚ÄúI wore a tiara belonging to my aunt Lisa Margulis which she purchased from a witchy lady in Laguna Beach, California, years ago,‚Äù Dagmar says.  Her brothers, Cosmas and Degenhart, walked her down the aisle. It was an emotional moment for all of them, as their parents, artists Alexandra and James Brown, passed away in 2020. Their absence weighed heavily on Dagmar, who is now executive director of their artistic estate. ‚ÄúPlanning a wedding is really one of those situations where sometimes you just want your parents to deal with it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt can be agonizing, slow, frustrating, disappointing, infuriating, tearful, but it leads to the most magnificent day of your life.‚Äù  For the big day, Paul wore a blue Anderson & Sheppard suit with mother of pearl buttons. Behind him was Father Friedrich Mennekes, modern art consigliere to the Vatican, who married her parents in Paris 36 years before.

This season's hottest wedding trend is a new spin on the "second look."  May is now coming to a close, which means wedding season is creeping up. And with wedding season comes a flurry of new wedding traditions and trends.  One of the hottest events this season is the ‚Äúmid-wedding chop,‚Äù displays of which have gathered over 1.6 million views on TikTok. So what exactly is a mid-wedding chop and why are brides including it as part of their ceremonies? Here is exactly what you need to know about the new trend, as well as how you can pull it off for yourself.  What is the mid-wedding chop?  Marko_Marcello/Getty Images  The mid-wedding chop is a haircut that takes place during a wedding, typically between the ceremony and the reception. Brides are opting to enter the ceremony with long, luscious locks‚Äîoften in an updo‚Äîthen debuting a completely different, shorter, loose hairstyle for the afterparty. Many are doing so as an alternative to, or in addition to, changing from their wedding dress into a reception outfit.  Anyone can perform the mid-wedding chop, though it is typically done by a professional hairstylist. However, according to the New York Times, some brides ask their spouses-to-be to cut their hair for them, as in the wedding of Angela and Chase Gulick. Angela explained, ‚ÄúI surprised him with scissors. He was speechless.‚Äù Angela also opted to donate 11 inches of hair to the organization Wigs for Kids, a positive consequence of the trend.  Why are brides cutting their hair mid-wedding?  Georgi Fadejev/Getty Images  Numerous impulses may inspire a bride to make the mid-wedding chop, from the desire to get the best of both worlds in their hairstyling, to enjoying the shock value of a new do, to imparting a symbolic meaning onto the haircut.  One bride, Jamie Littleton, explained that she ‚Äúthought it was a great way to represent letting go of [her] past and embarking on this new exciting chapter of [her] life.‚Äù Hair historian Rachel Gibson concurred, claiming, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a rich history of hair reflecting relationship status.‚Äù She continued, ‚ÄúSome Orthodox Jewish women shave their heads the day after their wedding in keeping with tradition, while in many African cultures, the choice of braiding and styling techniques is used to visually convey marital status.‚Äù In this context, the mid-wedding chop seems like a natural extension of hairstyles marking momentous occasions.  Other brides appreciate the excitement and individuality of the mid-wedding chop, which can feel like a fun ‚Äúwedding rule break.‚Äù Such is the case for Courtney Sneddon and Christopher Laird. Sneddon had grown her hair out for two years before her November 2022 wedding. After the fact, Laird recalled, ‚ÄúThe first thing she did after we cut it was head to the dance floor and headbang. She felt amazing, fierce and really liberated.‚Äù Similarly, self-described ‚Äúshort hair girlie‚Äù Natalie Pizard wanted her hair in a bun for her wedding ceremony but wanted to ‚Äúlook like herself‚Äù while dancing.  How can I do a mid-wedding chop?  BFK92/Getty Images  If you are planning a wedding and intrigued by the proposition of a mid-wedding chop, keep a few key tips in mind.  First, according to celebrity hairstylist Alex Brown, avoid using large quantities of hair product for the reception. The mid-wedding chop is a dry haircut, so globs of product can hinder a sleek result.  Second, plan your reception accordingly. Build time into your wedding schedule for the mid-wedding chop (10 to 20 minutes is standard). Additionally, inform your wedding planner and photographer so they‚Äôre ready for the big reveal. If you‚Äôre worried about entertaining the guests, plan to pass out dessert or drinks while the bride sneaks away.  Finally, manage your expectations. For the best mid-wedding chop possible, hire a hairstylist‚Äîand pay them accordingly! However, note that a dry, speedy haircut may not be as flawless as a usual salon job (especially if your spouse performs it). Still, the excitement of the mid-wedding chop lies in its adrenaline-fueled spontaneity, so lean into the moment! After all, joyous dancing hides any number of uneven hairlines.  And if you‚Äôre attending a wedding this season, be sure to follow these important pieces of wedding etiquette.  Source:  The New York Times: Just Married. Now Pass the Scissors

After a difficult two years of pandemic-enforced social restrictions, followed by an avalanche of long-delayed weddings, the bridalwear market is finally stabilising in 2023.  However the landscape is changing. Prospective brides are now looking for more than a one-occasion gown and are increasingly guided by the ability to rewear their look, opting for multiple options for longer celebrations, or procuring product through non-traditional methods such as rental and resale.  More is more  On many occasions weddings have evolved to multi-day experiences which begin with a rehearsal dinner on the eve of the wedding day, and extend to a post-wedding brunch the following morning.  The trend has made its way to the UK from the US, according to Annelise Sealy, founder of east London-based bridal retailer The Fall, which specialises in stocking contemporary and minimalist bridalwear and jewellery brands including & For Love, Solace and Galvan.  ‚ÄúPost-pandemic, British brides are after more than one bridal look - more in line with US bridal trends,‚Äù Sealy (below) tells Drapers.  Advertisement  This is due to brides choosing nuptials consisting of multiple events, allowing for ‚Äúmore scope than ever before to wear different looks‚Äù, according to founders of bridal brand The Own Studio, Jess Kaye and Rosie Williams:  ‚ÄúFor a lot of our brides, it‚Äôs about finding the ‚Äòmain‚Äô dress along with other pieces for the night before or day after and - of course - the all-important party look,‚Äù adds Kaye.  Megan Ziems, who founded Australian bridalwear label Grace Loves Lace in 2011, also notes consumers are ‚Äúopting for two different [wedding] looks; one for their ceremony that is slightly more traditional, and a second for the reception which is more relaxed and fun but still bridal.‚Äù  The brand has designed different styles to cater with this in mind. Its bestselling style, the 'Goldie', is a minimalist, high-neckline silk gown which resembles the dress worn by the Duchess of Sussex to her wedding afterparty in May 2018.  ‚ÄúThe trends our brides are favouring most are simple fabrics like our crepes and silks, high necklines, paired with a low back moment. [The] Goldie, has made its mark as one of our top-selling gowns due to its silk fabrication, high neckline, and low back detail,‚Äù says Ziems.  Advertisement  The demand for multiple looks is also evident in accessories. Founded in 2015 and specialising in cowboy boots, luxury footwear label Paris Texas recently expanded into bridal footwear with an exclusive collaboration with Browns (below) launched on 10 May.  ‚ÄúWeddings now run over multiple days with night-before dinners, the wedding day itself, followed by brunches the day after - meaning brides need multiple shoe options,‚Äù says Paris Texas founder and creative director Annamaria Brivio, who says brides are ‚Äúsearching for statement shoes with edge‚Äù.  Pre-wedding getaways have also provided an opportunity for businesses to expand into different categories such as bridal-themed swimwear, according to Boux Avenue chief design and product officer Zoe Price-Smith:  ‚ÄúA trend we are seeing more and more on social media with the bride wearing a white bikini or swimsuit, and her hens in either a black or pink swimwear piece, whether that is for a day sailing, or relaxing on the beach,‚Äù she tells Drapers.  A lasting commitment  The heightened demand for multiple wedding looks can be challenging to marry with following sustainable fashion practices and minimising clothing waste. However, this has resulted in a new opportunity for gown rental and re-wear, especially as budgets tighten amid the cost of living crisis:  ‚ÄúPeople are more conscious about their spend so we are seeing a lean into rental when it comes to second outfits,‚Äù says The Own Studio‚Äôs Williams. ‚ÄúBrides are also really keen to know that the pieces they have can be reworn, so for us it‚Äôs about offering luxurious pieces with versatility.‚Äù  This has prompted The Own Studio to offer its dresses through fashion rental mainstays such as Hurr and By Rotation. Others are tapping into the growing bridal rental market by launching wedding-focused platforms, including Something Borrowed and P.S. Bridal.  Launched on 13 April 2023 by former stylists Ella Gaskell and Zoe Graham, London-based P.S. Bridal allows brides to save at least two-thirds of the original wedding dress retail price by renting it for periods of seven, 14 or 30 days. Apart from savings, rental platforms offer shorter lead times while also allowing brides to customise their fit using reversible alterations for hems, waistlines, straps and sleeves. P.S. Bridal sources wedding dresses from brands and consumers alike, allowing brides to earn back the initial investment in their wedding dress purchase, while P.S Bridal takes a 40% commission. Rental pieces range from ¬£24.38 for a week and ¬£30 for a month for an Emmy London bow comb headpiece to ¬£825 per week and ¬£3,000 per month for an Oscar De La Renta floral appliqu√© tulle ball gown.  Dresses can also be resold to new consumers using a consignment service, such as in the case of bridalwear retailer The Fall, which launched its (Re)Cycle scheme in 2020 to offer a new lease of life for the traditionally once-worn garment.  ‚ÄúWe automatically accept back anything purchased originally from The Fall at full price, and we consider any other submissions on a case-by-case basis,‚Äù the brand states on its website. Through the consignment service, the dresses and accessories can be resold for 40-80% of the original retail price, depending on the condition of the item. The Fall then takes a 20% commission, alongside VAT costs and processing fees from the selling price.  However, some brides opt to keep their dress and re-wear it for other occasions ‚Äì with some adjustments:  ‚ÄúMany are opting to dye and tailor their pieces afterwards, so investing in silhouettes and fabrics suitable for dyeing [such as natural fibres: cotton, silk, linen and wool] are increasingly important to brides,‚Äù says The Own Studio‚Äôs Kaye.  Defying tradition  The Own Studio's customer base is also opting for versatile styles that can be reworn, with sales of the brand's wide-leg trousers increasing by 150% in the first five months of 2023. ‚ÄúThis is set to be the year of deconstructed dressing with a huge uplift in requests for cool separates," explains Williams.  "Brides love how separates allow them to change up their look from day to night with minimal effort, not to mention the added eco-benefit of being able to rewear [separates] long after the wedding day,‚Äù she adds.  Another way of minimising clothing waste ‚Äì as well as wedding budget expenditure ‚Äì is to purchase one rewearable gown which can be customised for different parts of the wedding celebrations with the help of removeable overskirts, separate sleeves, belts and bows, says The Fall‚Äôs Sealy. Accessories can also update a minimalist white slip dress to a more fashion-forward, trend-led outfit as brides look to invest in a staple piece.  Grace Loves Lace‚Äôs Ziems says: ‚ÄúOne big shift we‚Äôve noticed since pre-pandemic is a more minimalist style for their bridal look. Pre-Covid, we were still in a more is more era of bridal fashion, today there is a real demand for paired back styling and classic silhouettes.‚Äù  As more nuptials move out of churches and city halls into beaches, gardens and vineyards, defying traditional wedding expectations has become the new post-pandemic norm:  ‚ÄúA lot of the bridal and wedding rule book has been thrown out the window,‚Äù says The Fall‚Äôs Sealy says. ‚ÄúBrides now feel more empowered and less pressured by family members to choose something more traditional. My favourite post-pandemic trend is the number of brides now choosing a mini dress for their main look - pre-pandemic we never saw this."  Ultimately, inflation and weakened consumer confidence has not dampened spirits among brides, who are still investing in new gowns, according to Grace Loves Lace's Ziems:  ‚ÄúOur research tells us that brides will sacrifice on almost every other element of their wedding except the dress,‚Äù she says.  Wedding dresses have long had a reputation for being the epitome of "wear it once" fashion. However, non-traditional post-pandemic trends and the rise of rental and resale solutions offer consumers savvy ways of saving on their big day - even if they do choose to prolong the celebrations.

Please try again later {{ /verifyErrors }}  A woman who felt she was ‚Äútrapped in this really dark world‚Äù due to her anxiety, causing her to have panic attacks, cancel her hen do, and feel she was ‚Äúconstantly on the verge of having a heart attack‚Äù, has said ‚Äútherapy has allowed (her) to feel like (herself)‚Äù again and she has since gone on to marry her best friend who she met at school.  Kirsty McKillop, 34, a strategist who lives in Walthamstow, London, said she had experienced anxiety ‚Äúon and off‚Äù throughout her life, but it became all-consuming during the Covid pandemic ‚Äì particularly after going through a redundancy process at her previous job in PR, which knocked her confidence and made her question her self-worth.  She said she felt trapped in this ‚Äúprison‚Äù that she had created in her mind and started ‚Äúcatastrophising‚Äù ‚Äì she thought she would ‚Äúlose everything in (her) life that she cared about‚Äù.  ‚ÄúI felt like I was basically being crushed by the dark and being suffocated by it and I couldn‚Äôt get out,‚Äù she said.  Kirsty decided to quit her job to look after her mental health, but then ‚Äúeverything went from bad to worse‚Äù as she started to experience debilitating physical symptoms.  She would cry every day, vomit, experience heart palpitations, have panic attacks, feel agitated and extremely restless, and lie awake in bed until the morning.  At her lowest point, Kirsty said she did not believe that she could get better, and she did not engage in ‚Äúanything that might help her‚Äù.  However, with the continued support of her now-husband, Liam, 34, family and friends, she began engaging in therapy from December 2021 ‚Äì and gradually over time she could ‚Äúphysically feel (her anxiety) lifting‚Äù.  She has since gone on to get married ‚Äì something she previously did not think was possible ‚Äì and go on her honeymoon to South Africa, and she now wishes to give the message that ‚Äúlife without anxiety is possible‚Äù.  ‚ÄúNo matter what level of anxiety you‚Äôre feeling, it isn‚Äôt something that you have to accept as part of life,‚Äù she said.  ‚ÄúWhilst it is a natural human response, it‚Äôs not something you have to live with, and, going through therapy, it has just completely freed me from those feelings and I‚Äôm so much happier.‚Äù  According to the charity Mind, anxiety is a natural human response when we feel that we are under threat; it can be experienced through our thoughts, feelings, and physical sensations.  (PA Real Life)  Kirsty had experienced anxiety at varying stages in her life, but during lockdown, when her job was at risk, her mind was ‚Äúswamped‚Äù with negative and ‚Äúobsessive‚Äù thoughts, with everyday places and situations becoming ‚Äúbleak and scary and threatening‚Äù.  While Kirsty did not lose her job, the redundancy process knocked her confidence, and her heightened emotions quickly spiralled into physical symptoms of anxiety.  She felt she was in ‚Äúthis constant state of panic‚Äù and started ‚Äúoverthinking everything‚Äù.  ‚ÄúI had really irrational thoughts that I was going to lose everything in my life that I cared about because I was not able to function day to day,‚Äù she said.  ‚ÄúI think, eventually, it did turn into depression, and then I had quite intrusive thoughts around not wanting to wake up if I did get to sleep.  ‚ÄúNot being able to sleep, not being able to eat, being sick, crying, feeling like I was having a heart attack, and feeling terrified of everything was really scary.‚Äù  Kirsty would lie in bed and try to ‚Äúdisassociate‚Äù from her anxiety, but her intrusive thoughts just kept ‚Äúswirling around in her head‚Äù.  She then decided to quit her job in September 2021 ‚Äúto give her the headspace‚Äù she felt she needed, but the lack of structure and routine in her life only made her anxiety worse.  ‚ÄúIt had taken over my head so much that I could not think rationally ‚Äì everything was like, I‚Äôm worried about holding down a job, therefore, I‚Äôm not going to be able to pay the mortgage, therefore, I‚Äôm going to lose the house, therefore, I‚Äôm going to lose my husband and all my friends, and I‚Äôm going to end up with nothing,‚Äù she explained.  (PA Real Life)  ‚ÄúDespite having incredibly supportive friends who would come and just be with me for hours, I still had that fear.‚Äù  Kirsty remembers a specific conversation where her parents and her then-fiance were discussing the wedding, and she thought: ‚ÄúThis is ridiculous, there‚Äôs no way I‚Äôm going to get married in this state.‚Äù  By this point, she had started losing consciousness during the day and blacking out, and she had to cancel her hen do.  In November 2021, after moving back to her home town in Yorkshire, Kirsty‚Äôs family and friends encouraged her to seek professional support, as she was ‚Äústuck, trapped, in this completely different place‚Äù.  Kirsty‚Äôs loved ones had looked after her throughout this period and previously suggested she seek help, but she was not willing to engage as she thought ‚Äúit‚Äôs not going to make a difference‚Äù.  She then started speaking to a therapist who was right for her in December 2021, and Kirsty said she was ‚Äúpulled out of this horrible world‚Äù.  Through having sessions once or twice a week, and with cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), Kirsty said she felt she was ‚Äúbecoming much more rational‚Äù as she started to ‚Äúchallenge‚Äù her thoughts.  The CBT focused on thinking about the facts, rather than ‚Äúthe feelings and the catastrophising‚Äù she had been experiencing, to try to ‚Äúbreak the cycles of negative thinking‚Äù.  She said: ‚ÄúWhen that feeling starts to lift, you think, I can get better, and I want to get better.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not about fighting those thoughts, but accepting them and recognising they‚Äôre not facts.‚Äù  By February 2022, Kirsty started to feel like herself again ‚Äì she stopped being sick, no longer had panic attacks, and was able to sleep.  In April, she started a new job as a strategist, which she now loves, and in July she married Liam and had ‚Äúan amazing day‚Äù.  Looking back now, Kirsty said she ‚Äúdreads to think where she would have been‚Äù if she did not start having therapy, and she is beyond grateful for the support she has received from her family and friends.  She does not want anyone else to go through the ‚Äúabsolute hell‚Äù she has, and wants to encourage more open dialogue and acceptance around mental health and anxiety, as she believes it ‚Äúshouldn‚Äôt define you‚Äù.  ‚ÄúAnxiety is a natural response, but when it gets to the point where you‚Äôre having intrusive thoughts, or it‚Äôs affecting you physically, or it‚Äôs stopping you from doing things, that‚Äôs when it‚Äôs not normal and you shouldn‚Äôt accept it,‚Äù Kirsty explained.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a state of well or unwell, it‚Äôs a state of always making sure you‚Äôre looking after yourself because life is always going to throw different challenges at you.‚Äù  She added: ‚ÄúI enjoy life so much more without letting anxious thoughts spoil my day-to-day life‚Ä¶ and therapy has just allowed me to feel like myself and enjoy being myself.‚Äù  Kirsty is one of many who have offered quotes to inform and create a striking collection of AI art to shine a light on anxiety symptoms.  The artwork, from the British Association for Counselling and Psychotherapy (BACP), has been installed outside London Waterloo ‚Äì for more information, visit www.bacp.co.uk/anxietyis.

Goalkeeper Bui Tien Dung and his Ukranian wife, model Dianka Zakhidova, enjoyed a dinner at a resort in the coastal city of Vung Tau to celebrate their first wedding anniversary.  On Monday, Dung, 26, and Zakhidova, 23, returned to the Vung Tau resort where they held their wedding reception last year. The couple on their wedding day on May 22, 2022. Photo from Bui Tien Dung‚Äôs Instagram  "One heart for two, one happiness, one love, and now we are a family. Let our relationship grow stronger every year. Happy First Anniversary. Loveyou,"Zakhidova wrote on her Facebook profile on Monday.  Dung gained popularity when he played for the U23 national team at the AFC U23 Championship. He is currently playing for Hanoi Police FC in the top tier of Vietnamese football. Zakhidova is a Ukrainian model active in Vietnam.

Nestled within the serene vistas of the Bellarine Peninsula lies a unique treasure that beckons the hearts of local and international brides-to-be. Its name is The Barn Wallington, a venue synonymous with rustic opulence, offering an unparalleled experience of a barn wedding that feels both distinctively Australian and worldly at the same time.  Glimpses of this wonder are apparent right from the drive through the verdant, rolling hills that make up its 30-acre estate. The beauty of the surrounding Bellarine Peninsula landscape, coupled with the venue's proximity to Geelong and Melbourne, presents a charming paradox ‚Äî an immersion in rural tranquillity that is, intriguingly, just a stone's throw from the urban buzz.  However, what sets this Geelong wedding venue apart isn't just the breathtaking location or the rustic charm of its barn structure. It's also the ethos of its founders, GG and John Hanrahan, that lifts the Wallington experience from the realm of the ordinary into the magical. "The fun aspect is the freedom," says GG. This statement perfectly resonates with their motto, "Your Day, Your Way".  Under the Hanrahans' thoughtful stewardship, The Barn Wallington has been transformed into an ideal blank canvas ‚Äî an amalgamation of rustic grandeur and adaptability ‚Äî allowing each couple to design their celebration in their own distinctive style. This unique blend of freedom and grandeur, encapsulated in a singular location, has led Bridal Musings to laud The Barn Wallington as one of the top 10 barn venues in the world.  Whether you're dreaming of a spectacular destination wedding or planning a versatile corporate event, The Barn Wallington emerges as the place where the exceptional is rendered possible. It offers an opportunity to partake in an extraordinary experience in the heart of the Bellarine Peninsula, and yet, just on the fringe of the thriving city life of Geelong and Melbourne.  Rural or urban, grand or intimate, traditional or unconventional, The Barn Wallington offers a world of possibilities. It's a barn wedding venue that radiates the magic of the Bellarine Peninsula, and like a great love story, it promises to be as enchanting as it is unforgettable. It's your day, your way, and it begins in Wallington.

Last June, Jay Comfort flew to the United States from his home in Switzerland to attend his only daughter‚Äôs wedding. But the week before the ceremony ‚Äî on a Friday evening ‚Äî Comfort said he found himself in ‚Äúexcruciating pain.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI tried to gut it out for three hours because of the insurance situation,‚Äù said Comfort, a retired teacher and American citizen who has Swiss insurance.  When the pain became unbearable, Comfort called his brother, who drove him and his wife, Nazuna, a few miles to the nearest emergency department, at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center‚Äôs hospital in Williamsport, Pennsylvania.  Every bump of the drive was ‚Äúlike someone taking something and just jabbing it into my abdomen,‚Äù he said.  At the hospital, Nazuna Konishi Comfort handed over her husband‚Äôs Swiss insurance card, which confirmed coverage by Groupe Mutuel. Jay recalled the staff making copies of his insurance card and then treating his acute appendicitis. Doctors performed emergency surgery to remove the inflamed appendix.  Diagnostic tests confirmed he had a rare cancer, which doctors in Switzerland later removed with another surgery after he returned home. ‚ÄúIt was a miracle,‚Äù Comfort said, adding that the cancer was completely removed.  After his appendectomy, Comfort recalled vomiting and then waiting in a recovery room. In all, he spent about 14 hours at UPMC Williamsport before being released. He attended his daughter‚Äôs wedding and, eventually, traveled back to Switzerland.  Then the bill came.  The Patient: Leslie ‚ÄúJay‚Äù Comfort, 66, a retired educator who worked in Japan and Switzerland. Comfort pays a monthly fee and deductible for Switzerland‚Äôs mandatory basic health insurance, which he has with the Swiss-based Groupe Mutuel. His benefits ‚Äî and the prices for procedures ‚Äî are defined by the Swiss government.  Medical Service: Emergency laparoscopic appendectomy and diagnostic tests, which showed Comfort had a rare subtype of cancer called goblet cell adenocarcinoma.  Service Provider: University of Pittsburgh Medical Center Williamsport, which is about 3¬Ω hours northeast of Pittsburgh. The UPMC health system is one of the state‚Äôs largest employers, with 40 hospitals.  Total Bill: $42,156.50, covering emergency surgery, scans, laboratory testing, and three hours in a recovery room. His insurer has said it will pay him about $8,184 (7,260.40 in Swiss francs), which is double the procedure‚Äôs price in Switzerland. This left him to cover the remaining roughly $34,000.  What Gives: Although Comfort has health coverage, his Swiss insurance had no contract with the U.S. hospital where he underwent emergency surgery ‚Äî or with any other provider outside Switzerland.  With what is considered an excellent health system, Switzerland has the highest prices for medical care in Europe. As in the U.S., the country relies on private insurers and hospitals. But the cost of care in Switzerland is substantially lower than what is charged in the U.S., so the reimbursement his insurer offered is a fraction of what Comfort owes the U.S. hospital.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to do the right thing and say I‚Äôm willing to pay my responsibility,‚Äù he said.  Groupe Mutuel does not have agreements with foreign providers, such as UPMC, and does not deal with them directly, said Lisa Fl√ºckiger, a spokesperson for Groupe Mutuel. The insurer originally agreed to reimburse Comfort what would have been paid in Switzerland for the same treatment in a public hospital and then double that because it was an emergency in a foreign country ‚Äî a total of 4,838 in Swiss francs, or about $5,460.  While helpful, Comfort said, that amount wouldn‚Äôt pay off the $42,156.50 he owes UPMC.  UPMC has expanded its reach throughout Pennsylvania and is now the largest provider of care in many parts of the state. In 2016, it purchased a smaller health system and now runs two major hospitals, UPMC Williamsport and UPMC Williamsport Divine Providence Campus.  Studies show that in areas where hospital consolidation is high, prices go up. Because there is less competition, hospitals have more power to charge what they want when patients have private insurance or are paying out-of-pocket.  In the U.S., the amounts charged for medical care are ‚Äúall over the map,‚Äù said Johnathan Clarke, vice president of strategy and business development at Penfield Care, a medical cost-containment company in Canada. The company negotiates medical bills on behalf of individuals, including international visitors to the U.S., but is not involved in Comfort‚Äôs case.  Clarke said he would expect an appendectomy to be priced between $6,500 and $18,800, based on his analysis of Medicare payments in the Pittsburgh area. Healthcare Bluebook ‚Äî which evaluates insurers‚Äô claims data to provide cost estimates based on what insurers have paid, rather than what providers charge ‚Äî says a fair price for a laparoscopic appendectomy in Williamsport is about $14,554.  Comfort said a ‚Äúreasonable price estimate‚Äù based on his own internet research would be between $7,500 and $12,000.  Comfort‚Äôs care included an X-ray and an EKG, or electrocardiogram for his heart, because ‚Äúthere was no information relating to past medical/surgical history for this patient,‚Äù wrote Susan Manko, vice president of public relations at UPMC. The staff also conducted pathology work that identified cancer.  But those additional services did not fully explain the gap between cost estimates and what the hospital charged. For instance, UPMC charged $8,357 for Comfort‚Äôs three-hour stay in the recovery room.  Manko said Comfort‚Äôs total bill aligns with UPMC‚Äôs standard charges.  The cost disparities highlight the stark difference in international pricing. Cost estimates last year showed the average amount paid for an appendectomy in the U.S. was ‚Äúnearly exactly double‚Äù that paid in Switzerland, said Christopher Watney, chief executive of the International Federation of Health Plans, an industry association whose members include health insurers on six continents.  Health care in Switzerland, though, is often expensive compared with other European countries, Watney said. The Swiss pay double for an appendectomy compared with Germans, and more than three times that of those in Spain, he said. Across the globe, Watney said, many countries include an overnight stay in the cost of an uncomplicated appendectomy in contrast to Comfort‚Äôs experience, which was billed as outpatient care.  Comfort, who has dual residency in Switzerland and Japan after nearly three decades working abroad, said he worked in the U.S. long enough to qualify for Social Security benefits and Medicare. He said he had previously tried to gain Medicare coverage at one point but still is not enrolled, after being transferred to a couple of offices and ‚Äúplaying phone tag.‚Äù  Still, unlike many patients dealing with a five-figure medical bill, Comfort said he is not concerned about UPMC harming his financial reputation. The health system doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúseem to put bad marks against people‚Äôs credit record ‚Äî and I don‚Äôt have credit in the United States. I‚Äôve been out for 30 years.‚Äù  Manko confirmed that, saying UPMC reviewed and updated its collection policy last year; it states the health system will not engage in ‚Äúextraordinary collection actions‚Äù such as lawsuits, liens on homes, arrests, or reporting to credit agencies.  She said the health system ‚Äî which, as a nonprofit system, is tax-exempt ‚Äî maintains a ‚Äúrobust financial assistance program‚Äù for patients unable to pay. But ‚Äúto our knowledge‚Äù Comfort has not applied for financial assistance, Manko told KFF Health News.  The Resolution: Comfort said he spent months waiting for a bill and finally reached out to UPMC because, if the bill had arrived this year, he would have had to pay his insurance deductible again on top of the charges.  Comfort received a full UPMC bill six months after his surgery. Manko said there was ‚Äúconfusion‚Äù at the time of Comfort‚Äôs ER registration. Comfort‚Äôs wife provided the insurance information, she said, ‚Äúbut there was no documentation in the patients record for address, policy number or policy holder information.‚Äù  Once Comfort received his bill, he realized it was much higher than his Swiss insurance reimbursement and, frustrated, contacted KFF Health News.  Fl√ºckiger said the original payment amount Comfort‚Äôs insurer calculated was by episode and did not include the scan or laboratory costs. After receiving questions from a KFF Health News reporter, Groupe Mutuel ‚Äúrealized that we have not included the laboratory analysis and the CT scan,‚Äù which are not routinely part of an appendectomy, Fl√ºckiger wrote.  After KFF Health News provided a detailed summary of the UPMC bill, the insurer increased the amount it would pay Comfort. In all, the insurer said, Comfort should receive 7,260.40 in Swiss francs, or about $8,184.  Comfort still hopes to negotiate directly with UPMC to reduce what he owes.  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to try to walk away, saying I don‚Äôt owe you anything,‚Äù Comfort said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not right. We‚Äôre moral people, you know. But if you‚Äôre going to try to gouge me and play the power trip and think you‚Äôre going to try to get everything you can out of me, I won‚Äôt play that game.‚Äù  The Takeaway: Though the Affordable Care Act was meant to provide insurance to more Americans and bring down the cost of care, hospital bills remain extraordinarily high and highly variable.  For a nonemergency, Comfort could have tried to compare prices at other hospitals. But most hospitals in the area where he fell ill are owned by UPMC. And an inflamed appendix can‚Äôt wait for comparison shopping.  Clarke, the cost-containment expert, said the ‚Äúonly thing‚Äù Comfort could have done differently was to purchase a travel health insurance policy before leaving Switzerland. While prices for health care in continental Europe are comparable to Switzerland, the high cost of care in the U.S. means Groupe Mutuel insurance is ‚Äúinsufficient.‚Äù  That is especially important for visitors to the U.S. since, as Robin Ingle, CEO of travel insurance company Ingle International, said: U.S. prices are ‚Äúkind of crazy numbers.‚Äù  Bill of the Month is a crowdsourced investigation by KFF Health News and NPR that dissects and explains medical bills. Do you have an interesting medical bill you want to share with us? Tell us about it!  KFF Health News is a national newsroom that produces in-depth journalism about health issues and is one of the core operating programs at KFF‚Äîan independent source of health policy research, polling, and journalism. Learn more about KFF.  USE OUR CONTENT  This story can be republished for free (details).

The groom was eventually found in a bus outside Bareilly.  A bride's wedding day in Uttar Pradesh's Bareilly turned into an unexpected chase for her groom after he developed cold feet and refused to get married. Unable to accept that she had been spurned, the bride, dressed in her wedding finery, embarked on a chase over 20 kilometers to find the man and marry him.  When she was told that her groom, who she had been in a relationship with for two-and-a-half years, was not going to show up as she sat waiting for him at the mandap, she decided to go looking for him herself. Although he told her on a phone call that he had gone to bring his mother to the venue, she didn't believe him.  The groom was eventually found in a bus near a police station outside Bareilly city limits. After dramatic exchanges that lasted two hours, the bride, her family as well as the man's family took him to a temple.  The groom's family consented to the marriage and the two were wed at a temple outside Bareilly city. Videos of the ceremony show the groom in plain clothes go through the motions of the marriage ceremony as their families watched on.  The bride was praised for her "courage to save her marriage" by the families and onlookers who chided the man for "running away from the responsibility of marriage" after promising to marry the girl.

Sarah Ferguson's goddaughter Eliza Dodd-Noble, 35, has tied the knot with food blogger Hannah Crockett, 32, for the second time in Ibiza ‚Äì and didn't they both look sensational?  The couple exchanged vows in a civil ceremony in Los Angeles in March, with photos showing the pair leaning against a vintage cream car as they gazed into each other's eyes. Music producer Eliza wore a long white slip dress with an oversized blazer layered over the top, finishing off her look with elegant pointed-toe heels, while her bride opted for a ruched mini dress with long sleeves and a blue feathered neckline.  They chose very different outfits for their beachside Ibiza wedding, which saw them celebrate with a larger group of friends and family. This time, it was Hannah who opted for a floor-length silky bridal gown with cold shoulder straps, while Eliza chose a jumpsuit with a top overlay and keyhole detailing at the back.  WATCH: The most unconventional celeb wedding dresses of all time  The newlyweds looked so in love as they shared a kiss underneath a white floral arch, before dancing around in the sand at their evening reception.  Their second wedding took place almost two years after they got engaged in July 2021. Eliza proposed to Hannah at the Chateau Marmont hotel with a gorgeous sapphire teardrop engagement ring that was pictured on her hand as they both screamed in excitement against the backdrop of the city.  LOOK: Sarah Ferguson concealed baby bump in striking wedding guest mini dress‚Äã  RELATED NEWS: Prince Ludwig of Bavaria's royal bride faints during wedding ceremony - details  "She said yes," she simply captioned the Instagram post, which was met with an outpouring of love from their followers.  "Omg - massive congratulations," wrote one, and another added: "This is sooooo sweet and exciting!! Congratulations you two." A third remarked: "This is such an adorable picture - great news and huge congrats to you both."  ¬© Getty Sarah Ferguson and her daughters Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie are close friends with Eliza's family  The Duchess of York also shared her delight at the happy news, saying she was "so proud." She told the Daily Mail's Richard Eden: "Nothing gives my heart greater joy than to see young people happy.  "My Eliza is a special and very talented lady and I wish them all the luck in the world. I have already bagged a seat at the wedding!" she joked. However, it has not been confirmed whether Fergie ‚Äì who is close friends with Eliza's father Paddy ‚Äì was on the guest list.  ¬© Instagram / @thelondonchatter Princess Beatrice appeared in the background of a group selfie taken on the wellness retreat  Eliza and her sister Daisy are also friends with Sarah's daughters Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie, who appeared to have missed the wedding. Eugenie is preparing to welcome her second child with Jack Brooksbank, due "by the end of May", Sarah told HELLO!, and so would not be able to fly overseas.  Meanwhile, Beatrice was spotted on a restorative gut-health retreat on the Goodwood Estate in West Sussex alongside close friend Ellie Goulding and royal fashion designer Emelia Wickstead. A couple was found dead hanging, along with the woman‚Äôs three children from her previous marriage, at their Cherupuzha residence in Kerala‚Äôs Kannur district on Wednesday, 24 May.  The deceased have been identified as Shaji (40), Sreeja (38), and her children Sooraj (12), Subin (8), and Surabhi (6).  Preliminary investigation suggested that the couple killed the children before hanging themselves in Sreeja‚Äôs estranged husband Sunil‚Äôs house.  The children were found hanging from a staircase, while the couple was seen hanging from ceiling fans.  Shaji, who had a wife and two children, is said to have married Sreeja on 16 May.  The police said they were unaware of the marriage. ‚ÄúSreeja was living with her lover. Now it is said that they got married but we are unaware of the details. But Sunil, Sreeja‚Äôs husband, said the house belonged to him,‚Äù Cherupuzha Station House Officer (SHO) Shaji MP told South First.  The incident came to light after their neighbours checked on them after the house remained closed on Wednesday. They alerted the police.  The police said the incident occurred on the intervening night of 23 and 24 May.  Family issues suspected  ‚ÄúWe understand there were some family issues. I am now at the Pariyaram Medical College to complete the inquest procedures. We cannot confirm whether the deaths were suicide or not till we get the postmortem reports,‚Äù the SHO said.  The officer further said Sunil had complained on Monday, 22 May, that Sreeja and Shaji were illegally occupying his house. The SHO said the police visited the house and tried to de-escalate the issue.  ‚ÄúWe could not evict the woman and three kids immediately. We asked all the parties concerned to come to the police station this week to resolve the matter,‚Äù the officer added.  Incidentally, Sreeja had told Sunil that she would commit suicide. However, the police came to know of it only after the tragedy.  (With PTI inputs)  (Suicide prevention helplines in Kerala: 1056, 0471-2552056).

Having enjoyed an unconventional hen weekend visiting sacred wells in Cornwall and undertaking activities such as 'mermaid baths' and spiritual bridal blessings, arty photographer Anouska Beckwith continued the bohemian theme at her wedding.  The 36-year-old daughter of former 'It-girl' Tamara Beckwith wore a flower crown as she exchanged vows with breathwork therapist Luke McSwiney, 38, at a chapel in Bath, Somerset. Arty photographer Anouska Beckwith (left) continued the bohemian theme at her wedding  Lefties love nothing more than depicting Britain as a hotbed of xenophobia, but Emily Maitlis suggests our EU neighbours are far less open to different cultures.  'I've lived in France and I love it for, 'This is what we do, as this is the way we do it',' the former Newsnight presenter says. Ellie makes her ¬£700 bra the star at Cannes  Haven't got a stitch to wear? Here's one designer outfit you could make at home.  Ellie Bamber, who starred in the BBC's hit adaptation of Les Miserables, stepped out at the Cannes Film Festival wearing a Miu Miu crochet-knit triangle bra whose price tag could present a knotty problem at ¬£700. Her pleated Batavia skirt, by the same brand, was even more pricey, at ¬£1,650.  The 26-year-old has been cast as Kate Moss in the forthcoming film Moss And Freud, about the supermodel's friendship with painter Lucian Freud, who died in 2011 aged 88.  Moss, now 49, had mentioned Freud as being the person she most wanted to meet. This led him to ask her to be his muse.  She posed for him nude while heavily pregnant with daughter Lila in 2002. The portrait sold for ¬£3.9 million at auction.  Ellie Bamber, who starred in the BBC's hit adaptation of Les Miserables, stepped out at the Cannes Film Festival wearing a Miu Miu crochet-knit triangle bra whose price tag could present a knotty problem at ¬£700  Fay Ripley is taking desperate measures in her quest to become a grandmother.  'I am so broody, and all the time,' admits the Cold Feet star, 57. 'My daughter is actually now 20, and it's not right, but I'm encouraging an early pregnancy. I'm actively hiding contraception.'  The actress, pictured with Parker, gave birth to her daughter at the age of 36 and adds: 'I was an old mum in the first place. I can't hang about. I understand it's your life but what about mine?  'And my 16-year-old son . . . you know, again, I'll give it another year and then I'll start going in there as well, saying, 'Come on, what you got for me?''  Fay Ripley (right) is taking desperate measures in her quest to become a grandmother  Will Jacobi's Bard TV show cause a tempest?  King Charles used to argue with his father every Christmas over whether William Shakespeare actually wrote his plays.  Prince Philip was a so-called anti-Stratfordian, a group who believe Shakespeare's canon was written by others.  The group includes Sir Derek Jacobi, the celebrated actor who, I can reveal, has signed up to a TV series that will question the authenticity of the playwright's work.  A source on the newly announced series, The Rosy Cross: The Rebels Who Wrote Shakespeare, tells me at the Cannes Raindance Filmmakers' party: 'Derek has signed up to join the production and we're discussing what role he'll be playing. Who knows, he might even play the Bard himself.' To be or not to be the Bard . . .  It's a highlight of the BBC's arts coverage, but the Bafta awards are one big bore to newsreader Huw Edwards.  Giving the annual Philip Geddes Memorial Lecture, on the subject of 'What's the point of the BBC' at Oxford's Natural History Museum, Edwards described the Baftas as 'a prolonged three hours of medieval torture'.  The Welshman, 61, was less forthcoming when he touched on the problems he apparently endured during the rehearsals for the Coronation. 'That's one for when I've left the BBC,' he teases.

Emmerdale's big mystery wedding has been revealed as fan-favourite Tracy Metcalfe (Amy Walsh) returns to tie the knot this summer.  Previously, Emmerdale executive producer Jane Hudson teased that a familiar face would return to the village for one of two mystery weddings this summer.  The Sun has since revealed that one of these brides-to-be is Tracy Metcalfe, whose explosive return will see her walk down the aisle in a lavish summer wedding.  Soap star Amy is thought to have filmed her comeback scenes as she prepares to marry a mystery man upon her return to the Dales.  Tracy left the village last year with her baby daughter Frankie following the breakdown of her relationship with fianc√©e Nate Robinson (Jurell Carter) after he cheated on her and lied about it.  They were on the brink of reconciliation until she was offered a job in Nottingham to help other women with post-natal depression, which she also suffered from.  Emmerdale's huge mystery wedding will see Tracy Metcalfe walk down the aisle this summer. (Image credit: ITV)  A source reportedly told The Sun: "Tracy's comeback is set to be explosive. Fans know she's engaged to mystery man Ollie but slept with ex Nate during her brief return last year.  "Will she go through with her wedding or will someone stop her?"  It has also been reported that Jeff Hordley, who plays Cain Dingle, and Natalie J. Robb, who plays Moira Dingle, also filmed scenes for the upcoming wedding.  Tracy briefly returned for Emmerdale's 50th anniversary and hooked up with Nate, before revealing that she was engaged to her boyfriend, Ollie.  Tracy slept with ex Nate Robinson when she made a brief return to the village. (Image credit: ITV)  After having a change of heart, Tracy was hoping to rekindle their relationship. However, she was left disappointed when she realised Nate still liked Naomi Walters (Karene Peter), leading her to leave the village again.  Details of how the wedding will pan out ‚Äî and even who the groom might be ‚Äî are currently being kept under wraps so we'll have to wait and see if Tracy says I do to a future husband.  Emmerdale airs weeknights at 7.30 pm on ITV1, with a hour-long episode on Thursdays ‚Äî see our TV Guide for full listings. You can also catch up on ITVX.

Megan Fox and Machine Gun Kelly attend Universal Music Group‚Äôs 2023 After Party to celebrate the 65th Grammy Awards, Presented by Coke Studio and Merz Aesthetics‚Äô Xperience+ at Milk Studios Los Angeles on February 05, 2023 in Los Angeles, California.  Megan Fox and Machine Gun Kelly may be working on ‚Äúmaking their relationship better,‚Äù but the engaged couple seems to have put the brakes on planning their wedding. A source told People on Monday (May 22) that the couple is ‚Äúback together.‚Äù  The source added, ‚ÄúThey have explored therapy. He is great with her kids and super hands-on. It‚Äôs a work in progress.‚Äù  These Celebrities Share The Same Ex  Hollywood can be a small dating pool. Find the answer at the bottom of the page.  Cash is a common gift in Korea for various celebratory events like a baby's first birthday, Lunar New Year or weddings. For funerals, too, guests prepare cash in a white envelope to give to the grieving family.  However, with surging inflation in recent years, there has been upward pressure on the amount of money given as congratulatory or condolence gifts, leading many Koreans to face a dilemma of how much to spend on such occasions.  The best guideline, according to many Koreans, is the level of your relationship with the person who will receive the gift.  More specific guidelines could be found in the results of a recent online survey which asked 1,177 workers and university students for their opinions on the appropriate amounts for such cash gifts.  If a coworker you're not close with is getting married, the most appropriate amount to pay, 65 percent of the respondents said, is 50,000 won ($37), while 21 percent said 100,000 won would be ideal.  For a colleague with whom you frequently communicate outside office hours, 100,000 won was chosen by about the same percentage of respondents, while 50,000 was picked by slightly more than 20 percent.  The most preferred amount of congratulatory money for a close relative, friend or acquaintance was 100,000 won (36.1 percent).  Another survey, conducted by Job Korea, showed that salaried workers in Korea spend an average of 1.4 million won a year on congratulatory and condolence money.  Answer: c  By Korea Herald ( khnews@heraldcorp.com

SPARTANBURG COUNTY, S.C. (WSPA) ‚Äì Firefighters battled a large structure fire in Spartanburg County Tuesday afternoon.  According to South Spartanburg Fire Department, firefighters were dispatched at 10:40 a.m. to 651 Stewart Road.  Although Lions Gate Manor is located at that address, it said ‚ÄúThe fire was not our property but the adjoining property owned by someone else.‚Äù  Firefighters said there are 20 to 25 trucks on the scene.  They were able to put the fire out around 4 p.m.  One firefighter was taken to Spartanburg Regional with symptoms related to exertion under heat stress.  The fire is being investigated by the Spartanburg County Sheriff‚Äôs Office.

The Aisle Report by Azazie Releases Its Quarterly Consumer Data and Trends  SAN JOSE, Calif., May 23, 2023 /PRNewswire/ -- Azazie , the leading direct-to-consumer bridal and special occasion dress brand, released its Q1 consumer data polling of more than 97,000 customers. The Aisle Report is Azazie's record of consumer information and trends, the latest resource that is released on a quarterly basis.  Azazie unveiled data, collected from January 2023 through March 2023, on brides' preferences, purchasing habits and trends, including the statistics and key highlights revealing:  Multiple Vendor Dependency: 87% of brides indicated that they engaged with more than five vendors throughout the wedding planning process, demonstrating a growing trend towards collaboration.  Rise of Online Planning: With the convenience and accessibility offered by the digital age, 72% of brides-to-be relied on online wedding planning sites to streamline their wedding preparations.  Natural Grown Diamonds Preferred: 57% of future brides expressed a preference for natural grown diamonds as opposed to lab-grown alternatives, reflecting the appreciation for the allure of natural stones.  Departure of Themed Weddings: 67% of bride-to-be's indicated that they were not planning their wedding around a specific theme, showcasing that couples are embracing a more personalized approach.  Rising Age for Marriage: Among the collected data, 31% of individuals getting married were aged 30 and older, suggesting a cultural shift towards later marriages.  Extravagant Wedding Spending: A notable 40% of brides invested $30,000 or more on their wedding celebration.  Eucalyptus, Dusty Blue, and Black emerged as the top three most popular colors for Azazie's bridesmaid dresses. Azazie's research also identified notable bridal trends, such as "Barbiecore", characterized by vibrant and playful colors, "Black Bridal Gowns", as a striking alternative to the traditional white wedding gowns, and "Corset Detailing" were popular in bridesmaid dresses, adding a touch of vintage flair to wedding ensembles.  View and download the full Q1 results on The Aisle Report here .  ABOUT AZAZIE  Azazie is the leading DTC e-tailer for bridal gowns, bridesmaid dresses, special occasion wear and accessories, Azazie offers direct-to-consumer, high-quality, gowns at affordable prices. Based in the tech capital of Silicon Valley, Azazie is disrupting the traditional bridal industry while garnering high ratings from customers and review sites alike. With 200+ bridal gowns and 400+ bridal party dresses in over 80 colors, Azazie is committed to body-positive fashion, offering all dresses from size 0-30, cut and sewn to order like expensive bespoke designs. A young woman accused of driving with a blood alcohol content three times over the limit when she fatally slammed into a vehicle carrying a bride and groom on their wedding night has expressed her remorse from jail.  Jamie Komoroski, 25, reportedly shrieked and moaned in recorded conversations from behind bars, discussing her future after being charged with crashing into the newlyweds as they left their South Carolina wedding reception in a golf cart-style vehicle last month.  Komoroski‚Äôs vehicle was travelling at 104km/h in a 40km/h zone when it struck the golf cart, according to Folly Beach director of public safety Andrew Gilreath  Watch the latest news and stream for free on 7plus >>  Samantha Hutchinson, 34, from North Carolina, died ‚Äî still in her wedding dress ‚Äî from blunt-force injuries sustained in the collision, according to the Charleston County Coroner‚Äôs Office.  Her new husband, now widower, Aric Hutchinson sustained two broken legs and broken facial bones, among other injuries. Two other family members were also injured in the crash.  Komoroski was charged with one count of reckless homicide and three counts of felony DUI resulting in great bodily harm, court records show.  The reality of the charges was hard to swallow for Komoroski, who is reported to be struggling to accept both the devastating incident and the future that likely lies ahead of her.  Accused driver Jamie Komoroski has expressed her remorse in recorded conversations with family and friends from behind bars. Credit: Charleston Sheriff Office via CNN  She is being held in Charleston County jail where several conversations with friends and family were recorded, and later obtained by The Post and Courier through an open records request.  ‚ÄúWhy me?‚Äù Komoroski asked in one recording, before describing the incident as a ‚Äúfreak accident‚Äù in another.  ‚ÄúOh my God. I just can‚Äôt believe this happened to me,‚Äù she was recorded saying.  ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe this is my life ... my whole life is going to be over.  ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt mean it to happen. I just feel like a terrible person, like, I didn‚Äôt mean for any of that to happen.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to be here for years and years and years and years.  ‚ÄúI just pray and hope that the judge understands how regretful and remorseful I am and that I‚Äôm not a bad person and that I‚Äôll never do anything bad again.  ‚ÄúI want it to be over.‚Äù  Komoroski‚Äôs father told her to ‚Äúget tough‚Äù and ‚Äúsuck it up‚Äù in one of the recorded calls.  Aric Hutchinson and Samantha Miller leave their wedding reception, moments before Samantha was killed. Credit: Go Fund Me  Komoroski is not the only one who could be held accountable over the incident.  A wrongful death lawsuit which the groom filed this month claims Komoroski visited the El Gallo Bar and Grill in Charleston before making her way to Folly Beach, where she began bar-hopping at several bars and restaurants.  She was served alcohol at all establishments ‚Äî eventually reaching 0.261 per cent blood alcohol content level, despite responsible service of alcohol licensing restrictions in the state.  Komoroski was a new employee at a local restaurant, Taco Boy, and the lawsuit notes her supervisor is accused of organising and supervising a staff function ‚Äúknowing that excessive amounts of alcoholic beverages would be purchased for, served to, and consumed by the employees attending the function‚Äù.  Taco Boy said no such employee function with a focus on drinking took place: ‚ÄúWe can assure there was no such thing.‚Äù  Aric‚Äôs lawyer Danny Dalton said: ‚ÄúIf this (lawsuit) stops one person from getting in their car while intoxicated, or helps someone have the courage to step up and stop that from happening, or helps an establishment really take a hard stand on over-serving people ‚Äì that‚Äôs something positive that can come out of this.‚Äù  - With CNN and NBC
