Your journey to forever at Grand Hyatt Manila: Introducing all-in-one wedding service  At Grand Hyatt Manila, brides and groom can wed at a 5-star hotel and avail of a complete wedding package with event coordination by an in-house team of specialists.  MANILA, Philippines ‚Äî A wedding officially heralds a couple‚Äôs journey to forever. But getting there is a journey in itself‚Äîlittered with many ups and downs, triumphs and sacrifices.  Perhaps the most stressful of all during the planning stage is the search for suppliers. As told by married couples themselves, they have faced disappointments and worse, last-minute changes and arrangements.  Then comes the event coordination on wedding day itself. This too, can cause anxiety if not perfectly executed.  Grand Hyatt Manila understands all this and aims to provide stress- and worry-free weddings for brides and grooms. Now, they can wed at a 5-star hotel and avail of a complete wedding package with event coordination by an in-house team of specialists.  Introducing Grand Weddings, the hotel‚Äôs signature, all-in-one wedding event service, that promises to remove the burden of searching for suppliers and to provide ease of mind on the wedding day itself.  Exceeding expectations  In the past, hotels usually serve as venues for wedding ceremonies and receptions.  Today, Grand Hyatt Manila is doing something revolutionary in the hospitality industry. Last May 6, it launched Grand Weddings to select guests, which included future husbands and wives themselves.  As part of the package, a couple clientele can have the most stunning and unique wedding venues in Metro Manila, and to be more specific, in the bustling Bonifacio Global City.  Imagine having an outdoor wedding with picturesque skyscrapers in the background at Garden Pavilion, followed by a reception at the Penthouse No. 66. Here, the most breathtaking 360-degree of Metro Manila and even Rizal and Laguna provinces can be seen. In fact, Grand Hyatt Manila is actually the tallest tower in the country.  Both venues are transformed based on three themes: the timeless all-white, charming rustic, or prettiest pastel. Whatever a couple clientele picks, the hotel‚Äôs team of specialists will work closely with them for their personalized styles and desires.  In-house florists also fill the venues with breathtaking arrangements from bouquets to centerpieces and other decorations.  ‚ÄúWith Grand Weddings, the experience guests can expect is entirely different. Not only can they look forward to the hotel‚Äôs remarkable and unique event spaces, gastronomic concepts and exquisite menus created by our culinary team, or enjoy breathtaking views when they say ‚ÄòI do,‚Äô our end-to-end wedding event services aim to eliminate the inconvenience and need for couples to liaise with several suppliers,‚Äù Gottfried Bogensperger, AVP and general manager of Grand Hyatt Manila, said.  Making dream weddings a reality  The curation continues with the gastronomic offerings that are unique to the couple‚Äôs palette. These are served in several courses, paired with an array of premium beverages‚Äîall created by the hotel‚Äôs creative culinary team.  And don‚Äôt forget the exquisite five-tier wedding cake from the hotel‚Äôs pastry kitchen headed by Nicolas Vergnole.  Come wedding day, brides and grooms can go about their personal preparations with complete peace of mind. Grand Hyatt Manila‚Äôs dedicated event specialists ensure that everything will go about smoothly.  The audio-visual requirements are state-of-the-art for the clearest sounds and the most creative lighting options to set the mood.  To complete the momentous day with an exciting reception, live entertainment is also provided, still suited to the couple‚Äôs preference.  After the grand wedding celebration, the now husband and wife can also enjoy a honeymoon experience within the hotel, which includes a special breakfast in bed with a bottle of bubbly, and a calming massage at Illume Spa.  By taking care of conceptualization, curation, planning, styling and coordination, Grand Hyatt Manila is indeed making dreams a reality for couples who will marry at the 5-star hotel.  For inquiries on Grand Weddings, call (63 2) 8838 1234 or email [email protected]. For updates in its latest promotions, follow Grand Hyatt Manila on Instagram @grandhyattmanilaph and Facebook, www.facebook.com/GrandHyattManilaPh.

A Florida groom-to-be was killed during an apparent carjacking attempt outside a fast food restaurant in February ‚Äî and now, three months later, authorities have arrested a suspect approximately 350 miles away from the crime scene, according to multiple news outlets.  Louis Antuwn Redmon, 23, was taken into custody May 17 in Jacksonville on charges of first-degree murder, armed robbery, armed carjacking, and possession of a weapon by a convicted felon in connection with the shooting death of Hershy Schwartz, NBC Miami, WPLG/Local 10 News and News4Jax reports.  Redmon, who was released from prison last September, is being held without bond, NBC Miami reports. It‚Äôs unclear if he has entered a plea or retained an attorney who can comment on his behalf.  Redmon is accused of fatally shooting 39-year-old Schwartz, a well-known member of his Orthodox Jewish community in South Florida, during what North Miami Beach police officials called an ‚Äúarmed carjacking gone wrong,‚Äù on Feb. 19, per the affidavit cited by WPLG.  Schwartz's fianc√©e, Rosie Brustowsky, told NBC Miami she is comforted by news of the arrest, but she added, "That doesn't bring [Schwartz] back."  Schwartz was reportedly a week from exchanging vows with Brutowsky in his home state of New York when he was found shot dead inside his car in the parking lot of a Miami Wendy‚Äôs, according to WPLG.  "Our detectives believe Redmon targeted Mr. Hershy Schwartz to steal his car,‚Äù North Miami Beach Chief of Police Harvette Smith said during a Thursday press conference.  ‚ÄúBut to put it simple, this was an armed carjacking gone wrong and they stole his life," the chief added. "Fingerprint evidence and ballistic evidence is what linked Redmon to this crime. In addition, it was good, old-fashioned detective work."  Want to keep up with the latest crime coverage? Sign up for PEOPLE's free True Crime newsletter for breaking crime news, ongoing trial coverage and details of intriguing unsolved cases.  After the fatal shooting, Redmon allegedly made phone calls and sent text messages to his apparent girlfriend, as well as her son ‚Äî both of whom were jailed at the time ‚Äî using Schwartz‚Äôs cell phone, according to the affidavit obtained by WPLG. The affidavit alleges Redmon told them about the deadly incident.  Following the February tragedy, Schwartz was remembered by friend friend Yehuda Kaploun as someone who ‚Äúbrought a smile‚Äù to everyone‚Äôs face, according to NBC Miami.

(WJW) ‚Äî With the average cost of weddings continuing to break bank accounts across the country, it makes sense people would take note of a bride who found a sneaky way to cut costs on catered food.  Vlogger and TikTok creator Madison Mulkey recently revealed she spent just $1,950 on food for her 99 wedding guests ‚Äî and she did it by getting Chili‚Äôs to cater the dinner.  ‚ÄúWe loved the price point, I mean you really can‚Äôt beat that price point ‚Äî you just can‚Äôt,‚Äù she told her TikTok followers in a viral video posted earlier this month. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs insane that we only spent that much money for our wedding food.‚Äù  The menu, Mulkey said, included chips, salsa, salads, egg rolls, chicken tenders, sliders, Cajun chicken pasta, and even five specialty meals for guests with dietary restrictions.  Mulkey and her family also offset the cost by picking up the food themselves instead of paying for delivery. And since her nuptials took place over a busy St. Patrick‚Äôs Day weekend, Chili‚Äôs could only handle the order at 11 a.m. ‚Äî even through Mulkey‚Äôs guests wouldn‚Äôt be eating it until 6 p.m.  ‚ÄúSo we had some time in there,‚Äù Mulkey explained. ‚ÄúWe had to keep things cold and then we had to have our hired servers ‚Äî who were really supposed to be cleaning, serving, preparing ‚Äî really do a lot of the cooking ‚Ä¶ but everyone made it work, thank goodness.‚Äù  Their efforts paid off in the end, Mulkey claimed.  ‚ÄúThe food was amazing and other people said so, too,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut they could have been lying to us.‚Äù  Mulkey‚Äôs video, which has been viewed over 1 million times on TikTok, has garnered praise from users who loved the idea and commended her creativity. One viewer even claimed she catered her own reception with Chipotle, while another said she was inspired to ‚Äúget Olive Garden‚Äù to provide the dinner for her own wedding.  ‚ÄúNormalize this! Weddings are so out of control. Such a great idea!‚Äù another viewer wrote.  Others, meanwhile, were concerned for the servers who were given the additional task of reheating Chili‚Äôs takeout for 99 guests.  ‚ÄúAll I can think [about] is how stressful this must have been for the staff,‚Äù one commenter wrote, while another said she hoped Mulkey ‚Äúgenerously tipped [the] servers for the extra unplanned work.‚Äù  Even with a generous tip, it‚Äôs likely Mulkey‚Äôs fast-casual feast was much more affordable than the average cost of catering of a wedding. In a 2022 study, The Knot found that couples were paying an average of $75 per person for catered wedding dinners.  When reached for comment, a representative for Chili‚Äôs described Mulkey‚Äôs workaround as ‚Äúiconic.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWhen we saw Madison‚Äôs video on TikTok our first thought was ‚Äòiconic‚Äô and there is truly no better way to describe it,‚Äù a spokesperson for Chili‚Äôs wrote in an emailed statement provided to Nexstar. ‚ÄúChili‚Äôs is grateful to have been part of many wedding celebrations, in big ways and small ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs a party platter of our Crispy Chicken Crispers to even hosting both weddings and receptions in our restaurants (true story), it is an honor to be a part of Madison‚Äôs special day. Raising our (margarita) glass to the newlyweds!‚Äù

SISTER Wives star Christine Brown has been on a weight loss kick ahead of her summer wedding to David Woolley, The U.S. Sun can exclusively reveal.  The Sister Wives star has shared her weight loss journey with her followers since her nasty split from ex Kody Brown.  5 Christine Brown is 'trying to lose 20 more pounds,' a source told The U.S. Sun Credit: Instagram/christine_brownsw  5 The Sister Wives star is shedding for her wedding to David Woolley Credit: david__woolley/Instagram  But now, more than ever, Christine's focusing on shedding more weight for her dream wedding, according to a source.  "She works out every day. She's like super dedicated to the 'hot mom' comeback thing," a Sister Wives source told The U.S. Sun.  When asked how much she's looking to lose, the source revealed: "Oh, probably 20 more pounds."  "She's happy with how far she's come and David thinks she's perfect.  "So it's not like she's putting a lot of pressure on herself to lose more weight," the source continued.  "I think it's more about how she wants to look in a wedding dress and, of course, cameras will be around."  WEIGHT LOSS CONFESSION  The mom of six has made it known that she's soon going to be starting a six-week challenge with her Plexus followers.  She has been promoting the upcoming weight loss challenge on her Instagram, asking her fans to message her if they want to sign up.  She captioned a recent post: "I get asked quite often - how did you lose all your weight? This little drink right here with a few others.  "Google gut health & weight loss - you will see how it's ALL connected. It's pretty fascinating, actually. So I jumped on board and have been consistent since.  "I choose these products because they get to the root of the issue, aka gut health = weight loss and better living."  Christine, 51, is referring to the "pink drink" sold by Plexus, which is a dietary supplement that aids with weight loss.  The TLC star and her bestie Janelle have gone head-to-head, competing against each other in sales.  While it's unknown how much weight Christine has lost, The U.S. Sun reported co-star Janelle lost over 100 pounds.  TIME IS TICKING  The Utah native's upcoming challenge will be over before her summer wedding.  The U.S. Sun reported she's planning on having her dream wedding this summer, "probably in July," before the kids go back to school in the fall.  A source claimed the nuptials will take place in Utah, where the newly engaged couple recently bought a brand-new $770K home.  "It's going to be, from what I hear, really intimate and mostly close family," the source dished.  "She's super close to her mom and obviously her kids will be there and his kids and their families."  Christine has six children with ex Kody: Aspyn, 28, Mykelti, 26, Paedon, 25, Gwendlyn, 21, Ysabel, 19, and Truely, 13.  The family insider alleged that Kody will not be invited and that Christine "really just talks to Janelle," so invites to Meri and Robyn are up in the air.  At the end of the day though, the reality star is a "people pleaser" and she's going to make sure everyone at the romantic ceremony is happy, not just her and David, the source claimed.  Christine got engaged to David in April after a low-key proposal that was filmed for cameras.  A source told The U.S. Sun that the wedding is also going to be filmed for the family's TLC reality show, or for a "potential spinoff."  PUTTING IN THE WORK  Given the newly engaged couple's wedding is a few months away, Christine has been as active as possible - appearing to achieve her daily steps - to get in shape for her wedding.  On May 12, she posted about walking her daughter Truely to school every day.  "Walking Truely to school is one of my favorite things to do. The atmosphere in mornings is just breathtaking," she captioned a selfie.  A few days later, she shared memories from her hiking trip.  "One of the reasons I love David so much! Truely was stuck on a hill and he climbed up to help her then patiently taught her how to climb down by herself," she captioned another post.  Finally, just this past weekend, she experienced Utah's nature even more by RZR riding with pal Janelle, who was in town visiting.  5 Christine and David are set to tie the knot in Utah this summer, a source told The U.S. Sun Credit: Instagram/christine_brownsw  5 Christine informed her fans that she's embarking on a six-week weight loss challenge ahead of her wedding Credit: Instagram/christine_brownsw

Last June, Jay Comfort flew to the United States from his home in Switzerland to attend his only daughter's wedding. But the week before the ceremony ‚Äî on a Friday evening ‚Äî Comfort said he found himself in "excruciating pain."  "I tried to gut it out for three hours because of the insurance situation," said Comfort, a retired teacher and American citizen who has Swiss insurance.  When the pain became unbearable, Comfort called his brother, who drove him and his wife, Nazuna, a few miles to the nearest emergency department, at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center's hospital in Williamsport, Pennsylvania.  Every bump of the drive was "like someone taking something and just jabbing it into my abdomen," he said.  At the hospital, Nazuna Konishi Comfort handed over her husband's Swiss insurance card, which confirmed coverage by Groupe Mutuel. Jay recalled the staff making copies of his insurance card and then treating his acute appendicitis. Doctors performed emergency surgery to remove the inflamed appendix.  Diagnostic tests confirmed he had a rare cancer, which doctors in Switzerland later removed with another surgery after he returned home. "It was a miracle," Comfort said, adding that the cancer was completely removed.  After his appendectomy, Comfort recalled vomiting and then waiting in a recovery room. In all, he spent about 14 hours at UPMC Williamsport before being released. He attended his daughter's wedding and, eventually, traveled back to Switzerland.  Then the bill came.  The patient: Leslie "Jay" Comfort, 66, a retired educator who worked in Japan and Switzerland. Comfort pays a monthly fee and deductible for Switzerland's mandatory basic health insurance, which he has with the Swiss-based Groupe Mutuel. His benefits ‚Äî and the prices for procedures ‚Äî are defined by the Swiss government.  Medical service: Emergency laparoscopic appendectomy and diagnostic tests, which showed Comfort had a rare subtype of cancer called goblet cell adenocarcinoma.  Service provider: University of Pittsburgh Medical Center Williamsport, which is about 3¬Ω hours northeast of Pittsburgh. The UPMC health system is one of the state's largest employers, with 40 hospitals.  Total bill: $42,156.50, covering emergency surgery, scans, laboratory testing, and three hours in a recovery room. His insurer has said it will pay him about $8,184 (7,260.40 in Swiss francs), which is double the procedure's price in Switzerland. This left him to cover the remaining roughly $34,000.  What gives: Although Comfort has health coverage, his Swiss insurance had no contract with the U.S. hospital where he underwent emergency surgery ‚Äî or with any other provider outside Switzerland.  With what is considered an excellent health system, Switzerland has the highest prices for medical care in Europe. As in the U.S., the country relies on private insurers and hospitals. But the cost of care in Switzerland is substantially lower than what is charged in the U.S., so the reimbursement his insurer offered is a fraction of what Comfort owes the U.S. hospital.  "I'm trying to do the right thing and say I'm willing to pay my responsibility," he said.  Groupe Mutuel does not have agreements with foreign providers, such as UPMC, and does not deal with them directly, said Lisa Fl√ºckiger, a spokesperson for Groupe Mutuel. The insurer originally agreed to reimburse Comfort what would have been paid in Switzerland for the same treatment in a public hospital and then double that because it was an emergency in a foreign country ‚Äî a total of 4,838 in Swiss francs, or about $5,460.  While helpful, Comfort said, that amount wouldn't pay off the $42,156.50 he owes UPMC.  UPMC has expanded its reach throughout Pennsylvania and is now the largest provider of care in many parts of the state. In 2016, it purchased a smaller health system and now runs two majors hospitals, UPMC Williamsport and UPMC Williamsport Divine Providence Campus.  Studies show that in areas where hospital consolidation is high, prices go up. Because there is less competition, hospitals have more power to charge what they want when patients have private insurance or are paying out-of-pocket.  In the U.S. the amounts charged for medical care are "all over the map," said Johnathan Clarke, vice president of strategy and business development at Penfield Care, a medical cost-containment company in Canada. The company negotiates medical bills on behalf of individuals, including international visitors to the U.S., but is not involved in Comfort's case.  Clarke said he would expect an appendectomy to be priced between $6,500 to $18,800, based on his analysis of Medicare payments in the Pittsburgh area. Healthcare Bluebook ‚Äî which evaluates insurers' claims data to provide cost estimates based on what insurers have paid, rather than what providers charge ‚Äî says a fair price for a laparoscopic appendectomy in Williamsport is about $14,554.  Comfort said a "reasonable price estimate" based on his own internet research would be between $7,500 and $12,000.  Comfort's care included an X-ray and an EKG, or electrocardiogram for his heart, because "there was no information relating to past medical/surgical history for this patient," wrote Susan Manko, vice president of public relations at UPMC. The staff also conducted pathology work that identified cancer.  But those additional services did not fully explain the gap between cost estimates and what the hospital charged. For instance, UPMC charged $8,357 for Comfort's three-hour stay in the recovery room.  Manko said Comfort's total bill aligns with UPMC's standard charges.  The cost disparities highlight the stark difference in international pricing. Cost estimates last year showed the average amount paid for an appendectomy in the U.S. was "nearly exactly double" that paid in Switzerland, said Christopher Watney, chief executive of the International Federation of Health Plans, an industry association whose members include health insurers on six continents.  Health care in Switzerland, though, is often expensive compared with other European countries, Watney said. The Swiss pay double for an appendectomy compared with Germans, and more than three times that of those in Spain, he said. Across the globe, Watney said, many countries include an overnight stay in the cost of an uncomplicated appendectomy in contrast to Comfort's experience, which was billed as outpatient care.  Comfort, who has dual residency in Switzerland and Japan after nearly three decades working abroad, said he worked in the U.S. long enough to qualify for Social Security benefits and Medicare. He said he had previously tried to gain Medicare coverage at one point but still is not enrolled, after being transferred to a couple of offices and "playing phone tag."  Still, unlike many patients dealing with a five-figure medical bill, Comfort said he is not concerned about UPMC harming his financial reputation. The health system doesn't "seem to put bad marks against people's credit record ‚Äî and I don't have credit in the United States. I've been out for 30 years."  Manko confirmed that, saying UPMC reviewed and updated its collection policy last year; it states the health system will not engage in "extraordinary collection actions" such as lawsuits, liens on homes, arrests, or reporting to credit agencies.  She said the health system ‚Äî which, as a nonprofit system, is tax-exempt ‚Äî maintains a "robust financial assistance program" for patients unable to pay. But "to our knowledge" Comfort has not applied for financial assistance, Manko told KFF Health News.  The resolution: Comfort said he spent months waiting for a bill and finally reached out to UPMC because, if the bill had arrived this year, he would have had to pay his insurance deductible again on top of the charges.  Comfort received a full UPMC bill six months after his surgery. Manko said there was "confusion" at the time of Comfort's ER registration. Comfort's wife provided the insurance information, she said, "but there was no documentation in the patients record for address, policy number or policy holder information."  Once Comfort received his bill, he realized it was much higher than his Swiss insurance reimbursement and, frustrated, contacted KFF Health News.  Fl√ºckiger said the original payment amount Comfort's insurer calculated was specifically for the appendectomy and did not include the scan or laboratory costs. After receiving questions from a KFF Health News reporter, Groupe Mutuel "realized that we have not included the laboratory analysis and the CT scan," which are not routinely part of an appendectomy, Fl√ºckiger wrote.  After KFF Health News provided a detailed summary of the UPMC bill, the insurer increased the amount it would pay Comfort. In all, the insurer said, Comfort should receive 7,260.40 in Swiss francs, or about $8,184.  Comfort still hopes to negotiate directly with UPMC to reduce what he owes.  "I don't want to try to walk away, saying I don't owe you anything," Comfort said. "That's not right. We're moral people, you know. But if you're going to try to gouge me and play the power trip and think you're going to try to get everything you can out of me, I won't play that game."  The takeaway: Though the Affordable Care Act was meant to provide insurance to more Americans and bring down the cost of care, hospital bills remain extraordinarily high and highly variable.  For a nonemergency, Comfort could have tried to compare prices at other hospitals. But most hospitals in the area where he fell ill are owned by UPMC. And an inflamed appendix can't wait for comparison shopping.  Clarke, the cost-containment expert, said the "only thing" Comfort could have done differently was to purchase a travel health insurance policy before leaving Switzerland. While prices for health care in continental Europe are comparable to Switzerland, the high cost of care in the U.S. means Groupe Mutuel insurance is "insufficient."  That is especially important for visitors to the U.S. since, as Robin Ingle, CEO of travel insurance company Ingle International, said: U.S. prices are "kind of crazy numbers."  KFF Health News, formerly known as Kaiser Health News (KHN), is a national newsroom that produces in-depth journalism about health issues and is one of the core operating programs at KFF ‚Äî the independent source for health policy research, polling, and journalism.  Emmarie Huetteman of KFF Health News edited the digital story, and Taunya English of KFF Health News edited the audio story. NPR's Will Stone edited the audio and digital story.  Copyright 2023 KFF Health News. To see more, visit KFF Health News.

(WJW) ‚Äî With the average cost of weddings continuing to break bank accounts across the country, it makes sense people would take note of a bride who found a sneaky way to cut costs on catered food.  Vlogger and TikTok creator Madison Mulkey recently revealed she spent just $1,950 on food for her 99 wedding guests ‚Äî and she did it by getting Chili‚Äôs to cater the dinner.  ‚ÄúWe loved the price point, I mean you really can‚Äôt beat that price point ‚Äî you just can‚Äôt,‚Äù she told her TikTok followers in a viral video posted earlier this month. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs insane that we only spent that much money for our wedding food.‚Äù  The menu, Mulkey said, included chips, salsa, salads, egg rolls, chicken tenders, sliders, Cajun chicken pasta, and even five specialty meals for guests with dietary restrictions.  Mulkey and her family also offset the cost by picking up the food themselves instead of paying for delivery. And since her nuptials took place over a busy St. Patrick‚Äôs Day weekend, Chili‚Äôs could only handle the order at 11 a.m. ‚Äî even though Mulkey‚Äôs guests wouldn‚Äôt be eating it until 6 p.m.  ‚ÄúSo we had some time in there,‚Äù Mulkey explained. ‚ÄúWe had to keep things cold and then we had to have our hired servers ‚Äî who were really supposed to be cleaning, serving, preparing ‚Äî really do a lot of the cooking ‚Ä¶ but everyone made it work, thank goodness.‚Äù  Their efforts paid off in the end, Mulkey claimed.  ‚ÄúThe food was amazing and other people said so, too,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut they could have been lying to us.‚Äù  Mulkey‚Äôs video, which has been viewed over 1 million times on TikTok, has garnered praise from users who loved the idea and commended her creativity. One viewer even claimed she catered her own reception with Chipotle, while another said she was inspired to ‚Äúget Olive Garden‚Äù to provide the dinner for her own wedding.  ‚ÄúNormalize this! Weddings are so out of control. Such a great idea!‚Äù another viewer wrote.  Others, meanwhile, were concerned for the servers who were given the additional task of reheating Chili‚Äôs takeout for 99 guests.  ‚ÄúAll I can think [about] is how stressful this must have been for the staff,‚Äù one commenter wrote, while another said she hoped Mulkey ‚Äúgenerously tipped [the] servers for the extra unplanned work.‚Äù  Even with a generous tip, it‚Äôs likely Mulkey‚Äôs fast-casual feast was much more affordable than the average cost of catering of a wedding. In a 2022 study, The Knot found that couples were paying an average of $75 per person for catered wedding dinners.  When reached for comment, a representative for Chili‚Äôs described Mulkey‚Äôs workaround as ‚Äúiconic.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWhen we saw Madison‚Äôs video on TikTok our first thought was ‚Äòiconic‚Äô and there is truly no better way to describe it,‚Äù a spokesperson for Chili‚Äôs wrote in an emailed statement provided to Nexstar. ‚ÄúChili‚Äôs is grateful to have been part of many wedding celebrations, in big ways and small ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs a party platter of our Crispy Chicken Crispers to even hosting both weddings and receptions in our restaurants (true story), it is an honor to be a part of Madison‚Äôs special day. Raising our (margarita) glass to the newlyweds!‚Äù

‚ÄòI spent too much money on your wedding‚Äô: Musician calls out married friend for flirting with other women  (TikTok / @deshawn_sings)  A man has recalled an uncomfortable situation in which he confronted his married friend who was flirting with other women in a nightclub.  In the viral video posted on TikTok, musician Deshawn Harris explains that he faced a dilemma when he noticed his friend‚Äôs behaviour and advised him against ‚Äúmessing up‚Äù his marriage.  ‚ÄúMy homeboy got mad at me, and now he ain‚Äôt talking to me, because we were in the club and wanted to talk to these women but he‚Äôs married,‚Äù Deshawn explained to the camera.  ‚ÄúI told him to cut that out.‚Äù  The musician recalled that his friend became defensive at the accusation, but Deshawn reiterated that so many people had invested ‚Äì their time, love and money ‚Äì into the wedding, that it would be a waste for everyone involved if he was to cheat on her.  ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt spend all my money on your wedding to watch you come into this club and start cheating on her and mess this all up,‚Äù Deshawn said, recalling the conversation to his followers.  He added: ‚ÄúI ain‚Äôt tell you to walk down this aisle, ain‚Äôt tell you to introduce me to this woman and get this ring on her finger.‚Äù  Deshawn continued, adding that he also has loyalty to his friend‚Äôs wife since he considers her a friend.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not gonna lie to this woman,‚Äù he said.  Deshawn concluded that his advice to his friend was to get a drink and sit down.  ‚ÄúYou better go and sit down somewhere because I spent too much money on your wedding,‚Äù he joked.  Viewers of the viral clip agreed, with one writing: ‚ÄúExactly... if you‚Äôre gonna cheat why am I spending on your wedding. I could‚Äôve stayed home.‚Äù  Another added: ‚ÄúReal friends hold you accountable. We need these types of friends.‚Äù  ‚ÄúFacts! What did he get married for if he wasn‚Äôt ready to get married,‚Äù commented another.  Viewers seemed to agree on how ‚Äúexpensive‚Äù friends‚Äô weddings can be, and to end the marriage early on would be a ‚Äúwaste‚Äù.  ‚ÄúI need a minimum of 10 years of marriage due to the amount of money I spent on their weddings,‚Äù joked one viewer about the cost of their friends‚Äô weddings.  Other followers, however, were left divided over why Deshawn made a public video about the events when his friend could be easily identifiable among his close circle.  ‚ÄúLOVE this energy. Hate that he made a public video,‚Äù wrote one viewer.

ABC/Eric McCandless  Lauren Daigle performed her latest hit, ‚ÄúThank God I Do,‚Äù on American Idol‚Äôs finale Sunday, May 21. Chrishell Stause knows she‚Äôs evolved since Season One of ‚ÄúSelling Sunset,‚Äù the Netflix reality show that follows the agents and owners of a luxury L.A. real estate firm.  Six seasons and many confrontations later, she knows who she is ‚Äî and it shows.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just at a different stage in my life, and there‚Äôs going to be things that I‚Äôm no longer willing to put up with. That being said, I don‚Äôt think you have to lose your softness either ‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs just a balance and a blend, and finding that balance is a beautiful thing,‚Äù Stause tells TODAY.com.  Take a moment during Episode Three of the recent season, when Stause spars with new cast member Nicole Young at a beachside brokers‚Äô open. In past seasons, she might have simmered before confrontation. This time, though, she‚Äôs swift and to the point.  ‚ÄúYou give me this energy, I‚Äôll give you this all day back. Don‚Äôt go on about the real me. You don‚Äôt know me,‚Äù Stause tells Young.  She‚Äôs banking on audiences knowing, and trusting, the ‚Äúreal her.‚Äù  Between seasons, Stause let audiences in on her budding romance ‚Äî and now marriage ‚Äî to the Australian musician G Flip, as well as her sexuality journey. Previously, she was married to the actor Justin Hartley and dated Oppenheim Group co-owner Jason Oppenheim (their relationship was detailed on Season Five).  TODAY.com caught up with Stause about this season in the show and in her life.  Chrishell Stause at her desk at the O Group. (Netflix)  Her ‚Äòspur of the moment‚Äô wedding to G Flip  On May 9, Chrishell Stause broke the internet, or at least her corner of it, when she posted an Instagram Reel featuring clips of her and G Flip (the stage name of Georgia Flipo) with the caption, ‚ÄúLove doesn‚Äôt always go as planned ‚Ä¶ sometimes it‚Äôs immeasurably better.‚Äù  The last photo in the reel showed the pair at an altar, confirming they privately tied the knot in Las Vegas.  Speaking to TODAY.com, Stause says the wedding was ‚Äúa spur of the moment decision‚Äù kept secret by her and G Flip‚Äôs loved ones before and after the big day.  G Flip and Chrishell Stause (Alberto E. Rodriguez / Getty Images)  ‚ÄúThe focus was on us and what it meant to us, and that is exactly the way we wanted it. We didn‚Äôt want to stress about details. We just wanted to have fun and have the meaningful part between us. But then obviously, now we can celebrate with our friends and it‚Äôs nice to be able to share,‚Äù she says.  Only a few people attended the intimate ceremony. In fact, Stause says that none of her ‚ÄúSelling Sunset‚Äô‚Äô co-stars were physically there, but ‚Äúsome of them‚Äù watched via a virtual livestream.  ‚ÄúEverybody has their own way of doing things that works for them, and this works for us,‚Äù she says.  ‚ÄòCamera time‚Äô was at the heart of her with conflict with Nicole Young, Stause says  Controversial cast member Christine Quinn may be gone ‚Äî but peace did not reign in ‚ÄúSelling Sunset‚Äù land. Stause and co-star Nicole Young‚Äôs season-long spar begins during a beachside brokers‚Äô open in Episode Three and just keeps growing.  During their first interaction, Young accuses Stause of ‚Äútaking credit‚Äù on a co-listing they shared three years prior; Stause replies by saying she didn‚Äôt take a ‚Äúsingle dollar‚Äù off those commissions.  Stause says Young‚Äôs actions towards her were ‚Äúvery strategic, wanting to come in and make a splash and get a lot of good camera time.‚Äù She says they had a ‚Äúgreat relationship‚Äù before Young joined the show.  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna see me so thrown by that because I really hate that fakeness ‚Ä¶ being one way before we film and another way now all of a sudden. Does it make for great television? One hundred percent because I genuinely am really frustrated by that kind of stuff,‚Äù Stause says.  (L-R) Nicole Young and Chrishell Stause in season 6 of  During a later confrontation, Stause says Young is ‚Äúon drugs,‚Äù which Young denies. A day after their confrontation, Young gets a drug test to prove her sobriety.  Stause says she ‚Äúregrets lashing out‚Äù at Young, but ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt regret standing up for (herself).‚Äù  ‚ÄúAt the point that I really kind of lose it, there had been so many things thrown at me to get a rise out of me. So when she finally does get one, could I have handled that better? One hundred percent. But can I also look at that and be like, ‚ÄòYeah, I‚Äôm human. If you keep barking in my ear, one day I‚Äôm going to bite you back,‚Äô‚Äù Stause continues.  All in all, Stause says audiences will see the pair ‚Äúgo through a journey.‚Äù  ‚ÄúAt the end of the day, I do hope that we all are successful, we want to all be proud of something and build each other up. So I‚Äôm hoping that‚Äôs where we can land ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs quite a bumpy ride to see if we‚Äôll get there or not,‚Äù Stause says.  She has ‚Äògenuine love‚Äô for Mary Fitzgerald  Throughout Season Six, Stause also navigates a new chapter with her friend Mary Fitzgerald. In the wake of her breakup with Jason Oppenheim, Stause felt Fitzgerald gave Oppenheim more attention. Fitzgerald and Oppenheim are exes, too, adding to an already complicated workplace dynamic.  Although Season Six seemingly shows distance between the two, Stause tells TODAY.com that ‚Äúnothing would ever come between my genuine love for Mary.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI feel like she‚Äôs one of the girls that no matter how much time has passed, I don‚Äôt feel like we‚Äôd ever wish anything but the best for each other,‚Äù Stause continues.  ‚ÄúIt sometimes can be frustrating to work on a show and do things where it‚Äôs in the better interest to not have his talk off camera and make sure we have those conversations on camera, but I think that it does a disservice to an obvious love that‚Äôs there,‚Äù Stause says.  Is Bre Tiesi really Christine Quinn‚Äôs successor?  This season, Stause is in the middle of one conflict and is a close onlooker to another: Chelsea Lazkani and newcomer Bre Tiesi. Lazkani weighs in on Tiesi‚Äôs relationship with Nick Cannon. The pair have a child together but are not in an exclusive relationship. Cannon has 12 children with six women.  ‚ÄúIt really stresses me out because I‚Äôm really good friends with both of these ladies, and I love them dearly,‚Äù Stause says. ‚ÄúDo I agree with everything that was said? Absolutely not. But we‚Äôre on a show where we are being asked our opinions and things like that. So I think that it‚Äôs tough.‚Äù  Stause likens filming the show to ‚Äúwalking through a landmine and just trying as hard as you can to make it through.‚Äù  Fans have drawn comparisons between Tiesi and Stause‚Äôs former co-star Christine Quinn, who departed ‚ÄúSelling Sunset‚Äù after last season. Stause isn‚Äôt sold.  ‚ÄúI think people say that because Bre is so beautiful and she‚Äôs got the fashion. If you don‚Äôt know Bre, then yes, you could easily make that correlation because obviously, as we know, Christine is beautiful and she always had the fashions. With that being said, I actually think they‚Äôre opposite otherwise personality wise," she says.  Stause says she‚Äôs moved on from Quinn. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs such old drama. I literally don‚Äôt have any ill will (towards Christine), I wish her the best. I think everybody‚Äôs kind of moved on, and I think that‚Äôs great.‚Äù  Chrishell clarifies her future with the Oppenheim Group  The final moments of Season Six show Stause and Fitzgerald debating over Stause‚Äôs future involvement at the Oppenheim Group. She indicates she‚Äôd like to take a step back.  Stause says she isn't leaving the show, but is prioritizing herself.  Chrishell Stause and G Flip in season 6 of  ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs OK to be honest, where it‚Äôs like, I‚Äôm not out looking for new clients, I have a list that I‚Äôm happy with. And obviously I‚Äôm super happy in my personal life. When we started filming this season, (real estate) wasn‚Äôt my main focus, and that can always change," she says.  If she could tell a younger version of herself anything, Stause says it would be: ‚ÄúTrust your instincts. Don‚Äôt second guess yourself, and if you get it wrong, that‚Äôs OK, too. You can come back from that, but really, lean in. Stop leaning back.‚Äù  This article was originally published on TODAY.com

Wedding on the beach? Priory Bay gets makeover before summer season starts  Priory Bay Boathouse and event space, including one of the yurts available to stay in. (Image: Isle of Wight Beach Homes)  The wedding venue at Priory Bay beach is being given a makeover and will re-launch before the summer season.  The combination of sandy beach, sea views and stunning woodland setting near Nettlestone and Seaview makes it arguably one of the most romantic venues the Isle of Wight has to offer.  The well-known former Priory Bay Hotel is adjacent and is under private ownership.  Alongside Andrew Palmer, previous owner of the Priory Bay Hotel, Kirsty and Trudy Wastall are the venue hosts of the wedding venue next door, on the site of the former Priory Oyster restaurant.  The existing marquee is being replaced by a yurt designed and built by Paul Wastall from Island Yurts.  Beach Homes continues to own and manage the site which includes the rental properties, yurts and the Boathouse, which is licensed for beach weddings.  The event space in the woodlands seats 110, with a woodland spire bar and catering space alongside. The deck is still there, facing the sea with uninterrupted views of the Solent.  Island hospitality businesses, including caterers, are being invited to the launch in early June.

Saturday, June 3rd will mark a cause for celebration as outdoor wedding and event venue Northview Gardens celebrates its 10-year anniversary. Located in Selwyn Township just north of the Peterborough city limits, Northview Gardens is a hidden oasis on County Road 19 between Chemong Road and Hilliard Street that locals have lovingly labelled ‚Äòthe secret gardens‚Äô.  Tucked behind an unassuming sign and trees and down a narrow road, you‚Äôll find a lush garden of greens and perennials, an outdoor ceremony area with a natural wooden archway, a 150-seat reception hall, an AGCO-licenced rustic outdoor patio and bar, a cozy garden house, and everything else needed for a picturesque wedding or special event.  Though this is what the property looks like now, it wasn‚Äôt the original plan for the space when owners Rose Farthing and David Quist purchased the property over two decades ago.  We're big gardeners so we were drawn to the two and a half acres of garden space. Rose Farthing Northview Gardens  Tweet this quote  ‚ÄúWe bought the property basically a fixer-upper,‚Äù Rose says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre big gardeners so we were drawn to the two and a half acres of garden space. It was a beautiful location and we wanted to make a nice home.‚Äù  Everything changed for the husband-and-wife duo years later when the couple‚Äôs niece asked if they would host her wedding. It was an intimate family-only wedding that led to a massive change for Rose and David.  ‚ÄúAt the end of the night, that little voice on my shoulder said ‚ÄòYou should do this, Rose.‚Äô And the following week I was at the township office asking what comes next.‚Äù  The whole theme is really whimsical vintage. All the settings on the grounds are meticulously placed. Rose Farthing Northview Gardens  Tweet this quote  After starting small by using temporary tents to host weddings and events, Rose says the ‚Äúreal fork in the road‚Äù was when the couple found their tents ‚Äúblown to smithereens‚Äù in an afternoon storm. Rose and David had two options: go big or go home.  They decided to go big. In 2012, Rose quit her day job and the couple began construction on their 2,000-square-foot venue. All the unique finishing touches, from the ceremony grounds to the iron carriage and double swing, continued to expand from there.  ‚ÄúThe whole theme is really whimsical vintage,‚Äù Rose explains. ‚ÄúAll the settings on the grounds ‚Äî all the white iron, the glass tops, and every cushion ‚Äî are meticulously placed.‚Äù  On June 3, 2013, Northview Gardens held its grand opening and Rose and David have never looked back.  Joking that David calls her ‚Äúheadquarters,‚Äù Rose explains she and David have very different roles in the business: she‚Äôs the creative one who envisions the ideas, and David is the handyman who brings them to life.  ‚ÄúWe make a really great team,‚Äù she says.  For a while, Northview Gardens was a full family affair, with the couple‚Äôs son Nigel the venue‚Äôs original bartender. While Nigel has since moved on to other things, the business has continued to grow and succeed thanks in part to the venue‚Äôs dedicated staff.  ‚ÄúI have really good and strong staff that are proud of what we‚Äôre doing,‚Äù Rose says. ‚ÄúI have a working network of people, including bartenders and housekeepers, that I‚Äôm very grateful for. They make Northview Gardens what it is today.‚Äù  After 10 years of hosting other people‚Äôs events, Rose and David will finally be holding their own celebration from May 26 to 28 to thank everyone who has contributed to Northview Gardens‚Äô success over the past decade, from vendors and contractors to friends and past and future clients.  We want to show our gratitude. It's our way of giving back and saying look at how far we've come. Rose Farthing Northview Gardens  Tweet this quote  ‚ÄúWe want to show our gratitude,‚Äù Rose says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs our way of giving back and saying look at how far we‚Äôve come.‚Äù  With an invited guest list of close to 300 people, the three days of anniversary celebrations represent the past, present, and future of Northview Gardens.  Kicking off the celebrations on the evening of Friday, May 26th will be an invite-only VIP event for the contractors, builders, vendors, friends, family, and others who have collaborated and worked alongside Northview Gardens throughout the last decade. The evening will begin from 4 to 7 p.m. with sliders and appetizers cooked on the barbeque and live music by Peterborough singer-songwriter SJ Riley, before the dance floor opens up for live music from local blues musicians Al Black and the Steady Band from 7 to 10 p.m.  On Saturday, May 27th, the venue will be hosting the future bride and grooms who have already secured their wedding dates at Northview for the 2023 or 2024 seasons. The day will begin with a brunch and charcuterie from Lisa‚Äôs Catering, one of Rose‚Äôs long list of local vendors, while DJ Shawn Hurd will provide on-site music all day long. Then, throughout the afternoon, the venue will be set up like an open house, allowing the guests to browse samples and vendors.  ‚ÄúThe room and ground will all be staged at that point to just really awaken their ability to see what their wedding‚Äôs going to be like,‚Äù Rose says.  For the final day of celebrations on Sunday, May 28th, Rose and David have invited couples from the past decade to return to Northview Gardens. With help from long-time sponsor 96.7 Oldies, on-air personality Roger Ashby will be on hand to provide an afternoon of entertainment.  I really prioritize supporting the community where I can. Rose Farthing Northview Gardens  Tweet this quote  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve made some nice connections with couples and their families,‚Äù Rose says, explaining that some former brides have already shown excitement at seeing how the venue has changed since their own wedding.  As Northview Gardens has since first opening, Rose and David continue to support other local businesses during their anniversary weekend celebrations.  ‚ÄúI really prioritize supporting the community where I can,‚Äù says Rose, noting that pieces from Katherine‚Äôs Flower Shop, a new floral shop in Bridgenorth, will be on display for the weekend.  In the future, Rose and David plan to use their beautiful venue to offer even more support back to the community. Once a month or so, they hopes to host live music events to give a stage to local performing artists.  Though she‚Äôs already planning the next 10 years, Rose holds closely all the memories of the previous decade. One of her most memorable moments, she recalls, was hosting a Habitat for Humanity event with royalty in attendance. As an ambassador for the organization, Canadian Autumn Philip ‚Äî the wife of Queen Elizabeth II‚Äôs oldest grandchild Peter Philip ‚Äî spoke at the event.  ‚ÄúI met royalty right here at Northview Gardens,‚Äù Rose says, joking that she always kept the house tidy since that day in case the Queen herself stopped in for a visit.  The important thing for us is making sure we create lasting memories for people. Rose Farthing Northview Gardens  Tweet this quote  Even when Northview Gardens isn‚Äôt catering to royal dignitaries, Rose is grateful for all the couples she has been able to support. Couples have come from across Canada and from around the world ‚Äî including England, Europe, Australia, India, Pakistan, South Korea, and South America ‚Äî to celebrate their special day. She recalls a couple who drove five days from the Yukon to have their wedding, without ever having seen Northview Gardens in person before.  ‚ÄúThe important thing for us is making sure we create lasting memories for people,‚Äù Rose says, adding their three-day anniversary celebrations are sure to do the same. ‚ÄúThis is one of those proud moments where we get to look around at what we‚Äôve accomplished and see the kind of support we have. I‚Äôm just so grateful.‚Äù  While Northview Gardens is primarily a wedding venue, they also host other special events including life celebrations, parties, milestones, anniversaries, corporate events, vow renewals, photo shoots, and more. The venue, including the grounds and gardens, are also available for artists, church and community groups, and local entrepreneurs and businesses for their event needs.  Northview Gardens is located at 994 County Road 19 in Selwyn Township. For more information, call 705-768-9742, email celebrate@northviewgardens.ca, or visit northviewgardens.ca. You can also follow Northview Gardens on Facebook and Instagram.  This branded editorial was created in partnership with Northview Gardens. If your organization or business is interested in a branded editorial, contact us.

A Vernon winery withheld $3,150 of a $3,500 damage deposit to cover damage it claimed was caused by firing confetti cannons.  B.C.‚Äôs Civil Resolution Tribunal has ordered an Okanagan wedding venue to pay a man $2,685 after it withheld part of his damage deposit claiming confetti cannons violated a wedding reception contract.  Daniel Webbe held his June 30, 2022 wedding at a winery owned by the 50th Parallel Estate Limited Partnership near Vernon.  During dinner, two confetti cannons were fired in violation of the parties‚Äô contract. As a result, 50th Parallel withheld $3,150 of Webbe‚Äôs $3,500 damage deposit to cover damage it claimed was caused by firing the confetti cannons.  Webbe, however, told tribunal member Megan Stewart that 50th Parallel hadn‚Äôt proven it sustained damage allowing it to keep the $3,150.  ‚ÄúIt also says it lost business revenue well above the amount it withheld, as the confetti rendered the hall unusable for some time after the wedding,‚Äù Stewart said in her May 23 decision.  Stewart said it was undisputed that there was a prohibition on confetti at the winery and that the cannons were fired.  Webbe acknowledged 50th Parallel might have incurred some extra cleaning costs due to the confetti. He put that amount at $700 and claimed $2,450 of the $3,150 50th Parallel withheld from his damage deposit.  Stewart said 50th Parallel provided no evidence of the level of damage caused, such as photographs, video, or witness statements.  Also, she said, three invoices 50th Parallel did provide didn‚Äôt support the cost of remedying the mess or damage. Further, Stewart said 50th Parallel provided no proof of lost business revenue in excess of the cash withheld.  jhainsworth@glaciermedia.ca  twitter.com/jhainswo

The Year Two pupils took part in the celebration to learn about the Christian faith. Photo: Oswestry School at Bellan House  Year Two pupils at Oswestry School's Bellan House have learnt the significance of saying ‚ÄòI do‚Äô after taking part in a mock wedding ceremony complete with bride, groom and reception.  The students played the parts last week to help them understand marriage ceremonies, one of several Christian rites of passage they are studying for religious education.  Pupils were assigned roles for the mock wedding, which took part at St Oswald‚Äôs Church on Upper Brook Street, Oswestry and was conducted by Reverend Cranston.  The Year Two pupils took part in the celebration to learn about the Christian faith. Photo: Oswestry School at Bellan House  As well as a bride and bridegroom, pupils were given roles of best man and bridesmaids and the whole class joined in by putting on smart clothes to be wedding guests.  Their teacher, Kallista Skelton said: ‚ÄúI was immensely proud of how much effort the children and their parents made with finding suitable outfits for the entire wedding party along with bouquets and buttonholes, they looked wonderful.  ‚ÄúA lot of children have never been to a wedding, especially after all the restrictions which existed during Covid, so it was lovely to be able to get them really involved in the process.  ‚ÄúIt sparked some really interesting conversations about things such as the role of a best man, and if he should give away any secrets about the groom in his speech!"  Bellan House headteacher Claire Belk said: ‚ÄúOur school motto is that we learn not for school but for life and this is a great example of how the two things come together in a fun way.  ‚ÄúRather than just reading about a ceremony, the children were able to take part in a mock one, which they might even find themselves doing for real at some point in the future.  ‚ÄúMiss Skelton went above and beyond to help the children engage with the topic, even making a wedding cake for the bride and groom to cut and all the children to try at the reception, which was held in the classroom after the ceremony.‚Äù

After emergency surgery, an American expatriate now carries the baggage of a five-figure bill. Costs for medical care in the U.S. can be two to three times the rates in other developed countries.

Listen 6 min Comment on this story Comment Gift Article Share  Jamie West‚Äôs wedding day at a fast-food hamburger restaurant in Arizona earlier this month was a celebration she said she couldn‚Äôt have imagined when she was growing up. In the 1990s as a homeless teen, West said, she didn‚Äôt dare to think beyond ‚Äúgetting through just one more day.‚Äù Wp Get the full experience. Choose your plan ArrowRight She said she found hope, though, in an unlikely place, when an employee at a White Castle restaurant handed her several bags of free hamburger sliders after she asked for a glass of water.  ‚ÄúAfter that, whenever I was hungry, I knew where to go,‚Äù recalled West, now 41. ‚ÄúEvery White Castle I went to treated me the same way. I‚Äôd come out from washing in their restroom and I‚Äôd find a big bag of sliders waiting for me.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt was a kindness I‚Äôll never forget,‚Äù she said.  About 25 years later, when she became engaged to Drew Schmitt, West said she knew exactly where she wanted their wedding: a White Castle that had recently opened in Scottsdale, about 20 miles from where they live.  Advertisement  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve eaten here at least twice a month since they opened,‚Äù West said of the 2019 opening, adding that White Castle allowed them to use the restaurant for their wedding at no charge.  On May 5, she and Schmitt said their ‚ÄúI do‚Äôs‚Äù at a medieval-theme ceremony that included stacks of sliders for 150 guests, a giant burger-shaped cake and flower girls who threw dehydrated onions instead of flower petals.  West wore a bright-blue and gold ball gown with a full skirt, and Schmitt suited up in a kilt topped with custom-made leather armor. To continue with their royalty theme, the couple wore crowns as a tattoo artist put the finishing links on the Celtic ring tattoos they‚Äôd chosen instead of traditional wedding rings.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre so thankful that we found each other and have become each other‚Äôs partners and best friends,‚Äù said Schmitt, 57, who runs a roofing company with West.  ‚ÄúJamie has been through a lot of tough challenges in her life, so it‚Äôs wonderful that she‚Äôs now in this happy place,‚Äù he said.  West said she grew up in Arizona and was put into the state‚Äôs foster-care system when she was 4 because her parents struggled and could not care for her.  ‚ÄúOver eight years, I was in and out of 94 foster homes ‚Äî some of them were really abusive and neglectful,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhen I was 12-and-a-half, I finally climbed out a bathroom window to run away, and I got good at hiding.‚Äù  She said that she formerly lived with other teens at a homeless camp near Arizona State University in Tempe, then hitchhiked to Southern California and lived in beach communities with counterculture members of the Rainbow Family.  Advertisement  ‚ÄúWhen I got tired of that, I started hitchhiking all over the country,‚Äù West said. ‚ÄúIt was pretty rough ‚Äî I was abusing alcohol and drugs and I was truly on my own.‚Äù  She was 16 when, she said, she walked into a White Castle restaurant for a glass of water one day in one of the many nameless towns she‚Äôd wandered through. She does not remember exactly where she was, she said, but she believes she was in Kentucky or Tennessee.  ‚ÄúThis woman working there said, ‚ÄòOh, Sugar, you poor thing ‚Äî go get yourself cleaned up in the bathroom,‚Äô‚Äù she recalled. "I went in there and cried, then washed up. When I came out, there were these big sacks filled with slider hamburgers waiting for me.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThe lady told me they were cleaning the grill and were going to throw everything away and she wanted me to have them,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúI remember sobbing, then hugging her and grabbing the food and running away.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt sure whether it was real,‚Äù West explained.  She said that scenario happened repeatedly at various White Castles across the country, no matter how rough-looking she was when she walked in.  Advertisement  ‚ÄúI was always so grateful to them for treating me like a human being," West said. "It was a shiny spot at a very bad time.‚Äù  When she was 17, West said, an aunt in Arizona took her in for a year and she was able to stop abusing illegal substances and begin to live a more stable life.  ‚ÄúShe helped me to leave that street mentality I‚Äôd been locked into,‚Äù said West, noting that she eventually found a job as a kennel technician at an animal shelter and was able to move out and find a place of her own.  There were no White Castles in Arizona at the time, but when she traveled to states that had the burger chain, she would make it a point to stop by, and was happy to pay for her food now that she could afford it.  Although her mother died five years ago, West said, she was recently able to reconnect with her father and is hoping to repair their relationship.  Advertisement  ‚ÄúDrew is the one who inspired me to do that,‚Äù she said of her husband.  She said it took years to put her painful past behind her, but she finally found love and acceptance after meeting Schmitt near Scottsdale in 2006.  ‚ÄúWe were both dating other people who were football fans, and we were all together at a bar one day watching a game,‚Äù West recalled. ‚ÄúAfter our relationships broke up in 2007, Drew and I started dating.‚Äù  When White Castle opened its first location in Arizona in 2019, they camped in the parking lot to be the first in line to go inside, and they have since become regulars.  In March 2020, Schmitt asked West to marry him after they were both inducted into White Castle‚Äôs Cravers Hall of Fame at the burger chain‚Äôs headquarters in Columbus, Ohio, during a gathering for the company‚Äôs biggest slider fans. West decided to publicly tell the audience about her difficult past and her history with the restaurant chain.  Advertisement  ‚ÄúJamie was onstage telling her story, and when she turned around, I was on one knee with a sword, asking her to marry me,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt was pretty epic.‚Äù  The coronavirus pandemic caused them to delay their wedding plans, but the wait was worth it, West said.  As she walked up the aisle to the music of Journey‚Äôs ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Stop Believin‚Äô,‚Äù ‚ÄúI thought about all of the strangers who helped to feed me and got me to this moment,‚Äù she said of her wedding.  ‚ÄúI want other girls out there who are going through what I went through to know that it‚Äôs going to get better, and they can find hope,‚Äù West added. ‚ÄúI was able to break free of the pain and be happy, and they can too.‚Äù  GiftOutline Gift Article

Home > Viral News > Influencers > TikTok Source: Getty Images Wedding Cake Capers Steal a Baker's Car in Broad Daylight ‚Äî and Then She Saves the Day! One baker's day took a turn for the worst after her car ‚Äî and her clients' wedding cake ‚Äî were stolen. Read on to find out how she saved the day! By Pretty Honore May 23 2023, Published 6:40 p.m. ET  One couple‚Äôs big day took a turn for the worse when their baker‚Äôs car and their wedding cake were stolen. In a viral TikTok video with more than 500,000 views as of this writing, the baker broke down exactly how the confectionary catastrophe occurred. In the end, she proved that not all heroes wear capes ‚Ä¶  Article continues below advertisement  A baker‚Äôs car and cake were stolen hours before a wedding ‚Äî and then THIS happened!  If you think you‚Äôre having a long day, you should let us tell you about Nederland, Texas‚Äìbased bakery owner Anita Ngyuen. The entrepreneur was quite literally minding her business when her car was stolen. To add insult to injury, so was her client‚Äôs cake. ‚ÄúCome with me to not only get my car stolen but also the wedding cake I had just made. So here I am putting the cake in an insulated box in the back,‚Äù Anita narrated the video.  Article continues below advertisement  As for why she left her car on while she went inside in the first place, Anita has an explanation. ‚ÄúUnless y‚Äôall have delivered wedding cakes in the Texas heat, do not come at me for needing to keep my car on," she said, adding that it was ‚Äúhot as hell outside‚Äù at the time of the burglary.  ‚ÄúSo I go inside for one minute to grab my water and my lunch ‚Äî and mind you, I‚Äôm parked right outside my bakery, it‚Äôs broad daylight, and we do have cameras ‚Äî and these two little s---heads see my car running,‚Äù Anita shared along with security footage from the incident. ‚ÄúBut at this point, I‚Äôm walking out the door and I do see the boys hop in the car.‚Äù  Article continues below advertisement  She tried her hardest to stop them from escaping, but her efforts were made in vain. Luckily, cops were able to locate the suspects and her car, which was later towed back to her bakery. While her whip was still intact, the same couldn‚Äôt be said for the wedding cake in the trunk. ‚ÄúMy heart sank,‚Äù she recalled. But the destroyed dessert didn‚Äôt deter her.  Article continues below advertisement  With little time to work her magic, Anita put on her thinking cap and got to work. Ultimately, she was able to salvage what was left of the original wedding cake and make it look like new. ‚ÄúAnd honestly, it didn‚Äôt look too bad for only having 30 minutes,‚Äù Anita bragged in the video. ‚ÄúThey did have a backup plan but I was determined to get there. I hauled a-- and got there exactly at 6:00, right when the ceremony started.‚Äù

The Real Housewives of New Jersey beauty wore a fiery frock for a friend‚Äôs nuptials.  When it comes to rocking an incredibly stylish dress, Jennifer Aydin knows how to slay.  How to Watch Watch The Real Housewives of New Jersey on Bravo Tuesdays 8/7c and next day on Peacock. Catch up on the Bravo App.  We recently caught up with The Real Housewives of New Jersey cast member when she attended New York City‚Äôs Gotham Ball on May 10 with fellow RHONJ ladies Danielle Cabral, Dolores Catania, and Jennifer Fessler. Jennifer accessorized the red-hot style with sparkly red strappy heels by Rene Caovilla, a silver sequined handbag by Cult Gaia ($428), and sterling silver and Swarovski crystal Tracy earrings by John Michaels Jewels ($445).  Jennifer posts a photo of herself in a red floor-length dress, sparkly red heels, and a silver shoulder bag to Instagram Stories. Jennifer posts a photo of herself and Bill at a wedding to Instagram Stories. Photo: Jennifer Aydin/Instagram  Related  Jennifer‚Äôs bright and bold dress made us think of another recent occasion where the New Jersey mom made our jaws drop: the Season 13 RHONJ reunion.  For the sit-down with her castmates, Jennifer tapped the Estrada Twins (the East Coast duo who also designed her Season 12 gold sequined number) for an elegant long-sleeved blue gown. The gorgeous sheath featured bejeweled embellishments and a sheer side train flowing from her right shoulder. Jennifer stayed true to dripping-in-designer form with a pair of Chanel logo earrings.  Jennifer in a blue fitted gown with a cape and silver appliqu√©s at the RHONJ Season 13 reunion. Photo: Jocelyn Prescod/Bravo  After a turbulent Season 13 reunion, Jennifer was definitely in need of some recovery time.  Earlier in May, the New York native had some additional R&R when it came to a ‚Äúsmall‚Äù cosmetic procedure performed by her plastic surgeon husband, Bill, ahead of Mother‚Äôs Day. Nothing bad, just a small procedure, ‚Äôcause I guess I‚Äôve lost a lot of weight, and I had some loose skin on my love handles,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúBill, from Aydin Plastic Surgery, he cut off my loose skin that was [on] my love handles. This was all day yesterday, guys, so I wasn‚Äôt around.‚Äù

Mattie Jackson, the daughter of country star Alan Jackson, has found her happily ever after. Source: Getty Images  Article continues below advertisement  Carl Radke spills all about his upcoming wedding to his 'Summer House' co-star Lindsay Hubbard. The Bell Tower On 34th Announces Wedding Packages For Spring, TX Residents  The Bell Tower on 34th has announced wedding event packages for couples in Spring, Texas, looking for spacious venues suitable for a large number of guests.  Houston, Texas--(Newsfile Corp. - May 23, 2023) - As part of its series of offerings for customers around Houston, The Bell Tower on 34th has launched custom event packages for couples in Spring, Texas, who are looking for large venues near Houston. When planning a wedding, there is so much to check off on your to-do list. The registry. The bridal party. The dress!  Even those on your invite list have to do some prepping before the big day. Macy‚Äôs can help take away the stress by sharing all the ways they can be your wedding destination!

Wedding dresses are often a single-use garment, with many brides thinking of the gown hanging, unworn, in their wardrobes with regret.  At the Chelsea flower show, which is on this week, one grower has attempted to solve this problem by weaving biodegradable wedding dresses out of the roots of wheatgrass.  Zena Holloway, who makes the designs, created the sustainable material after spending years as an ocean photographer and witnessing plastic pollution.  She said: ‚ÄúI saw the growing amount of plastic in the ocean over the years and became upset about the materials we were using.‚Äù  Holloway hopes her work will inspire others to use sustainable, biodegradable materials. Photograph: Jim Powell/The Guardian  After growing mushrooms in her basement, she became fascinated by the mycelium ‚Äì the root-like structure of a fungus ‚Äì noticing ‚Äúhow it grew into the substrate and the roots, and how it joined up to form new materials. And then I was in the river doing a river cleanup with my camera and through the lens I saw bright red willow roots that were growing into the water.  ‚ÄúAnd because my head was in that place, thinking about the binding property of roots, or binding of mycelium, the penny dropped.‚Äù  Holloway began growing roots at home to understand ‚Äúhow it might mesh together and how it could be a new material‚Äù.  She grows wheatgrass over different materials, such as corals and beeswax, so it will adopt the shape of the natural moulds. When enough roots have grown, she treats it with beeswax, to give it a natural strength. The resulting pale, twisting material looks ethereal, like bleached coral.  ‚ÄúThe concept for this dress,‚Äù Holloway said, ‚Äúis a sustainable wedding dress. If they got married by the ocean, for example, she could sustainably trash the dress and ‚Ä¶ get in the water and all the fish would just eat it, and it would just become part of the ocean.‚Äù  Holloway hopes that her work will inspire others to use sustainable, biodegradable materials. The fashion industry is responsible for between 2% and 8% of global greenhouse gas emissions but despite pledges to curb emissions, according to the World Resources Institute the sector‚Äôs environmental footprint is expected to grow by 60% by 2030.  The flower show, put on by the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS), is focusing more than ever on sustainable growing, with gardeners tasked with demonstrating how their work is eco-friendly. For the first time, every garden has to have a relocation plan for after the show, rather than being thrown in a skip.  There is a competition for sustainable gardening product of the year, which this year has been won by Lindum Wildflower Turf, the first to be grown without plastic matting. Its compost is peat-free and recycled and it supports a range of pollinators and insects with its 27 species of wild flowers, perennials and herbs, all native to the UK.  After last year‚Äôs drought, there has also been a focus on resilient plants, with the Chelsea flower show plant of the year accolade awarded on Monday to the deep purple agapanthus black jack, which is heat and drought tolerant and favoured by pollinators.
