A newlywed couple's first dance has gone viral after they were joined by their former Riverdance castmates.  Singer Emma Warren and her husband Shaun Kelly tied the knot in early May and marked the occasion with a party in Donegal, where they celebrated with family and friends.  As part of the reception, Emma, who joined the show 11 years ago and was its lead singer for five years, and Shaun, who also worked with the dance troupe, treated their guests to a performance - and surprised everyone by getting their former castmates involved.  Almost two dozen of both male and female 'Riverdancers' took to the dancefloor and hopped and tapped to the show's theme song - with the newlyweds front and centre.  The sweet video went viral on TikTok, where it was shared by LadBible Ireland. The bride later revealed that they are the 70th couple who met through the show and tied the knot.  Singer Emma Warren and her husband Shaun Kelly tied the knot in early May and marked the occasion with a party in Donegal, where they celebrated with family and friends and treated their guests to a Riverdance performance  The clip started as Shaun and Kelly took to the dancefloor and twirled to the tune of the iconic Riverdance soundtrack.  Both newlyweds had a friendly face off with the bride's moves answering her husband's, before they were joined by several friends who took their positions, forming a half circle behind them.  As the music sped up, the group of dancers could all be seen performing the world famous choreography, with all the ladies dancing in their colourful gowns and barefoot.  As the song went on, yet more dancers joined to the rapturous cheers of the wedding guests.  The talented group danced in lines across the ballroom, as the couple took centre stage, twirling together while their friends kept the chorus choreography going.  Finally, the song reached its triumphant climax, with both newlyweds raising a fist in the air to a standing ovation from their loved ones.  Emma and Shaun tied the knot in Lake Como, but held their party in Donegal, where they are based.  Speaking of the dance on her Facebook page, Emma wrote: 'Riverdance Reunion‚Ä¶ so much craic dancing together again after touring the world with these wonderful friends for many years.  Almost two dozen of both male and female 'Riverdancers' took to the dancefloor and hopped and tapped to the show's theme song with the newly weds front and centre  Emma revealed that she and Shaun have been members of the Riverdance cast for 11 years, and that they were the 70th Riverdance couple to get married  The dancing party, which grew bigger as the music paced up, eceived a standing ovation at the wedding's reception  The video went viral after it was shared on TikTok, with many praising the couple and their friends' dance skills  '11 years since myself & Shaun Kelly first joined the show and 70th Riverdance couple to marry,' she wrote.  The video went viral after it was shared on TikTok, with many praising the couple and their friends' dance skills.  'Goosebumps moment for sure, pure class. Congratulation to the Bride and Groom on their wedding day,' one wrote.  'Friggin amazing,' another said.  'The way she twirled in that dress was stunning. This is absolutely magic, just brilliant,' one said.  'Very talented wedding party,' another approved.  'I wish I had done this for my wedding' one said.  'Every time I hear Riverdance it makes me emotional - amazing,' one wrote.

Jordanian security forces have performed a practice run for the convoy that will accompany Crown Prince Hussein to his wedding next month, as final preparations for the event take place.  The June 1 wedding of the Crown Prince to Saudi architect Rajwa Al Saif is expected to be attended by senior figures from the Arab Middle East. It will offer rare a close-up of the Hashemite monarchy, whose members have ruled Jordan since it was established as a British protectorate in 1921.  "Security personnel lined up on main streets in a practice procedure for the wedding," state-owned Al Rai newspaper reported.  Read more A closer look at Rajwa Al Saif's Harry Winston engagement ring  Footage shared online showed the convoy led by a Mercedes S-class.  It was followed by the main car, a Toyota Land Cruiser, surrounded by 14 open-top red army Land Rovers and seven red army motorcycles. Support vehicles drove at the rear of the convoy, including another Land Cruiser carrying communication equipment.  The army's red Land Rovers and motorcycles are only used on special occasions, such as when King Abdullah II goes to open the parliament's annual sessions. The king, who has ruled since 1999, holds all significant powers in Jordan.  Jordan's Crown Prince Hussein gets engaged to Rajwa Al Saif  A religious wedding ceremony for the Crown Prince and Ms Al Saif will take place on June 1, followed by a banquet and reception at another palace on the western outskirts in Amman, where the king lives. The convoy will transport the groom and the bride between the two palaces.  The streets will be lined by security personnel but people will be able to watch the convoy, Jordanian officials said.  The last Jordanian Hashemite to be married was Princess Iman, the eldest of the king's two daughters, in March. Unlike the upcoming wedding of the Crown Prince, that event was not officially declared as a royal wedding.

A former Strictly Come Dancing star has revealed he has postponed his wedding day on Instagram on Sunday following the death of a family member.  Retired British track and field athlete Greg Rutherford, 36, revealed the devastating news on social media by sharing three pictures of his fiance.  The former MasterChef contestant has been engaged to partner Susie Verrill, 33, since May 2019, and they share three children together.  He said the happy celebrations have had to be pushed back after the couple lost a close family member.  Greg explained: 'Today was meant to be our wedding day.  'We postponed the big day': A former Strictly Come Dancing star has revealed he has postponed his wedding day on Instagram on Sunday  'We‚Äôll have an even better wedding when we finally manage to do it': Retired British track and field athlete Greg Rutherford, 36, revealed the devastating news on social media by sharing three pictures of his fiance  'I love you so much': The former MasterChef contestant has been engaged to partner Susie Verrill, 33, since May 2019, and they share three children together  'Due to the loss of someone so close and important we postponed the big day - In typical fashion the UK weather is going to be perfect we‚Äôre a bit miffed.  'But we get to plan it all again and hopefully really put together exactly what we want.  '@susiejverrill I know today will be frustrating, but I love you so much and we‚Äôll have an even better wedding when we finally manage to do it.'  His fiance Susie saw the bright side and commented on the post: 'Thank god I started opting for longer nails because these hand photos are giving me male tradesman had a manicure.'  Susie and Greg have been together since 2012 and they got engaged in May 2019.  The couple have three children, a daughter Daphne, two, and two sons; eight-year-old Milo, and five-year-old Rex.  Greg is an Olympic champion who won long jump gold at London 2012, and also competed on Strictly Come Dancing in 2016.  He remains Britain's record holder in both indoor and outdoor long jump, and won gold in the World Championships in 2015.  Rutherford retired from long jump in September 2018. A bride and groom in Chania arrived at their polling station to vote immediately after their wedding.  Babis and Anna married on Sunday, May 21 at the Holy Church of Agia Sophia. Immediately after the sacrament, they rushed to the ballot box to vote, according to Zarpa News.  See video and photos:  Greece‚Äôs ruling New Democracy party scored a crushing victory in parliamentary elections Sunday but fell short of winning an outright majority in a vote dominated by the cost-of-living crisis, a wiretapping scandal and anger over the country‚Äôs deadliest-ever train crash.  With more than 99% of votes counted, ruling center-right party of Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, surpassed all expectations garnering more than 40% of the vote in a result he described as a ‚Äúpolitical earthquake.‚Äù  His main opposition, Alexis Tsipras‚Äôs centre-left Syriza party, suffered major losses, coming in second with just over 20% of the vote.  However, Mitsotakis did not win enough votes to secure a single-party government. The vote was held under a new proportional representation system that requires a threshold of around 45%.  Greek President Katerina Sakellaropoulou will now give the top three parties up to three days to form a coalition, though Mitsotakis has already indicated he‚Äôs not interested in sharing power.  ‚ÄúWithout a doubt, the political earthquake that occurred today calls on us all to speed up the process for a definitive government solution so our country can have an experienced hand at its helm as soon as possible,‚Äù Mitsotakis told jubilant New Democracy supporters massed outside party headquarters in Athens.  If he fails to form a coalition, a caretaker government will be sworn in and a second vote will take place in late June or early July. That round will be held under different rules requiring the winning party to achieve just 37% of the votes.  Greece‚Äôs economic future on the ballot  Greeks headed to the polls with the future of the economy and their strained personal finances topping their priorities.  New Democracy‚Äôs bid for a second term focused on the country‚Äôs successful economic recovery since coming to power in 2019 with Mitsotakis portraying himself as a safe pair of hands to further boost growth.  ‚ÄúThe numbers speak for themselves,‚Äù Mitsotakis told CNN while on the campaign trail. ‚ÄúWe were laggards when it came to growth back in 2019 and now we are one of the best-performing economies in the eurozone.‚Äù  The country‚Äôs economy has staged a stunning turnaround in the last decade, and is now on the brink of returning to investment grade on the global market for the first time since it lost market access in 2010.  Significantly for the elections though, the country‚Äôs financial gains have not yet been felt by many Greeks struggling with high inflation and living costs.  A belt-tightening financial crisis throughout the 2010s saw the country‚Äôs GDP slashed by a quarter and people‚Äôs salaries and pensions severely cut leading thousands to the breadline.  Asking for a second chance is main opposition leader Alexis Tsipras, who came to power in 2015 promising radical change that saw bank runs and capital controls fall short of convincing voters.  ‚ÄúGreeks did not vote feeling optimistic,‚Äù says political analyst Petros Ioannides, managing partner of aboutpeople pollsters. ‚ÄúNeither of the two main parties are new to the scene. They have both been in government during the last 10 years,‚Äù he said.  ‚ÄúIn 2015 people voted for change, and a newcomer prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, and there was hope in that. In 2019 there was a different kind of hope, a yearning for a return to stability, again with a first-time prime minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis.  ‚ÄúIn these elections, the parties and leaders are known and so are their perceived shortcomings.‚Äù  Backdrop to election  The elections also took place in the shadow of a wiretapping scandal in which the government was accused of spying on opposition politicians and journalists, raising overall concerns over the rule of law.  The turmoil, which one political party referred to as ‚ÄúGreek Watergate,‚Äù forced a number of high-profile departures.  But potentially, the most severe blow for the government came in the form of a head-on train collision that killed 57 people in February, many of them university students.  The country‚Äôs deadliest railway disaster saw tens of thousands of people take to the streets across Greece, venting their anger against corruption and chronic lack of infrastructure. It also pushed some voters away from established parties.  Young protesters were seen on national television crying, saying they felt betrayed by their politicians. Out of a total of 9.8 million registered voters, there were around 440,000 first-time voters in this election, and many may have been influenced by the rail disaster.  What next?  Despite not gaining enough votes in the first round, New Democracy has indicated that it does not want to enter a coalition government.  The most likely scenario is that a caretaker government will be sworn in and a second vote will take place, most likely, in early July.  This vote will take place under a bonus system that benefits the winning party by giving it a bonus of up to 50 seats in parliament calculated on a sliding scale depending on the percentage of votes won.  Wolfgango Piccoli, co-president at financial advisory firm Teneo, said markets and investors are looking for strong leadership and political stability, and would prefer a single-party government.  ‚ÄúA coalition government would raise concern about political stability. That would certainly increase the risk from a market perspective that there will be bickering and not much will get done,‚Äù he added.  With many Greeks having already factored in a second ballot, analysts say some of Sunday‚Äôs voters chose to vote for smaller parties, to show their discontent with the political establishment.  They are expected to rally behind the main parties in a second election where they will want to see a strong government emerge.  READ MORE: Greek PM Wins Most Votes But Needs New Ballot to Rule Alone.

Moby (handout)  Two decades ago, the world‚Äôs most famous electronic musician met a doctor who changed his life. Moby ‚Äì named after literature‚Äôs most famous whale, which was created by his great-great-great uncle ‚Äì met Oliver Sacks, who helped open the Institute for Music and Neurologic Function in 1995. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd been a musician since I was very young,‚Äù Moby says, ‚Äúbut until meeting Dr Sacks, I hadn‚Äôt thought that what I did was anything more than light-hearted entertainment.‚Äù  That the formerly wild music star had an epiphany after meeting the neurologist famous for writing The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat, may seem like an odd clash of cultures. But Moby is a complex creature, a man whose past debauchery stands in contrast to his smart, meticulously calculated music. In conversation too, he‚Äôs intellectually precise; if it weren‚Äôt for the tattoos on his arms and neck, it‚Äôs easy to picture him in a lab coat.  Today, Moby sits on the board of the Institute, which has lent scientific gravitas to the idea that music can be palliative. He tells me he‚Äôs no longer interested in his career per se, but rather in creating songs ‚Äúthat have profundity, beauty, and an ability to transcend.‚Äù  Moby is giving this interview from his kitchen. It‚Äôs a neat, functional space: the architectural equivalent of the sleek sound he pioneered in the Nineties with hits including Porcelain, Go, and Natural Blues. The turn of the century marked his commercial and cultural zenith; he counted David Bowie among his best friends and his 1999 album Play sold 12 million copies worldwide ‚Äì more than any other electronic record ever.  What happened next has been well documented: tales soaked in booze and fuelled by drugs and romantic misadventures pepper the pages of his own memoirs, the aptly titled Porcelain (2016) and Then It Fell Apart (2019).  Moby has also faced external criticism during his career. He‚Äôs been denounced by electronic purists for ‚Äòselling out‚Äô after he licenced all the tracks from Play for commercial use. He‚Äôs been ridiculed for the veganism he so proudly espouses: the slogan Animal Rights tattooed on his arms and Vegan For Life on his neck. And he‚Äôs been called a liar by Natalie Portman, who he claimed to have dated but whose own memory is that of a man loitering around her in a nightclub when she was only 18.  Story continues  Moby admits he‚Äôs often prone to solipsism; but when I ask him whether he feels some of the criticism has been unfair, he shrugs it off. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm aware of how badly both memoirs sold. Do I feel misunderstood? It doesn‚Äôt really matter.‚Äù He‚Äôs learnt to make concessions. You can‚Äôt be everyone‚Äôs cup of tea, so to him, there‚Äôs no use trying to control the narrative.  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt read comments or reviews,‚Äù Moby goes on. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs destructive to let your sense of self be informed by the glib opinions of people you‚Äôve never met ‚Äì especially if they‚Äôre not real people. Why would I hand over my wellbeing to a bot army in Belarus?‚Äù  Moby‚Äôs ditched popularity for causes. This February, he released Punk Rock Vegan Movie, a dive into the Seventies-born movement and its role in inspiring animal rights activism. The film is available to watch for free YouTube: rather than making money from it, he‚Äôs more interested in spreading the message of veganism as widely as possible. Animal rights campaigning, he says, is his ‚Äúethical duty‚Äù.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs excruciating,‚Äù he acknowledges. ‚ÄúI think every activist will agree that no one wants to be an activist.‚Äù  Unlike some, Moby puts his money where his mouth is. ‚ÄúI work with VC [venture capital] funds and invest in companies that offer alternatives to animal-based produce,‚Äù he says. As the founder of production company Little Walnut, he‚Äôs raised funds for films including Slay, about the fashion industry‚Äôs abuse of animals, and the 2021 documentary short Why I‚Äôm A Vegan. ‚ÄúI try to use whatever resources and platforms I have to somehow move the needle towards a more compassionate, more rational future,‚Äù he says.  In 1996, Moby released an album called Animal Rights to draw attention to the issue; but he‚Äôs never successfully written issue-oriented music. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love to be as gifted as Neil Young or John Lennon,‚Äù he laughs. ‚ÄúYou listen to What‚Äôs Going On by Marvin Gaye and think, what a remarkable use of music and lyrics.‚Äù His own attempts to write issue-focused songs always yielded something he felt was ‚Äúdry, pedantic and didactic‚Äù.  Moby measures each of his words carefully; his crisp, clear enunciation feels quasi-academic. He loves an -ism, and name checks multiple philosophers as we explore the motivations behind his new projects. There‚Äôs history behind this: Moby majored in philosophy at university and once thought of making it his career. ‚ÄúI was gonna get my doctorate and teach philosophy in New England at a community college ‚Äì and just make music in my basement that no one paid attention to,‚Äù he laughs.  Moby (handout)  In lockdown, he revisited many texts from his undergraduate days, looking for meaning at a time when life seemed to stand still.  There‚Äôs an existentialist flavour to Moby‚Äôs new album, which rethinks his past material into new, more grandiose compositions. Released earlier this month, Resound NYC transforms songs from across the Moby canon: tracks once known for their electronic appeal have been reimagined as rock numbers, sung by the likes of Lady Blackbird, Gregory Porter, Ricky Wilson, musical theatre powerhouse Marisha Wallace, and Nicole Scherzinger. Moby‚Äôs favourite collaboration, however, isn‚Äôt with a big name.  ‚ÄúOne of the last tracks on the record is Run On, with Danielle Ponder,‚Äù he says. The original song, from the Play album, samples the hook from Run On for a Long Time, a 1949 recording by Bill Landford and The Landfordaires ‚Äì which Ponder‚Äôs father, Elijah, sang while growing up in the deep south. Elijah is now 90 and has advanced Alzheimer‚Äôs; when Danielle visited him in hospital and told him she was singing Run On, he lit up and started singing the 1949 song.  ‚ÄúShe held up her iPhone to him, made a voice note of him singing and sent it to me,‚Äù Moby says. ‚ÄúAnd it was so powerful that I threw away the production I had prepared and rewrote the entire song around his vocals.‚Äù Danielle came to the studio to record her part, and it became a duet. By chance Moby had stumbled onto something profound.  For him, it‚Äôs as much about the sound as it is about the story behind it. When It‚Äôs Cold I‚Äôd Like To Die ‚Äì a song that‚Äôs been featured on both The Sopranos and Stranger Things, he says proudly ‚Äì is another highlight, but one he says was laborious to produce. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a weird song, in that there‚Äôs nowhere to hide.‚Äù He clarifies: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no yelling, no vocal processing, no autotune, no background vocals ‚Äì it relies on one singer being exposed and vulnerable.‚Äù  Moby worked with a numberof gifted vocalists to record this new version, but something always felt off. One day, someone on his team went to a wedding in Texas; he was impressed with the singer there, and asked Moby if he might consider him for the track. ‚ÄúI loved the idea of a wedding singer in Texas being the only one able to do justice to a song so poignant and delicate,‚Äù Moby laughs. The idea soon became reality.  Moby is a born raconteur. Beyond the faux intellectual posturing (which I don‚Äôt think he does on purpose) a man emerges who is in genuine pursuit of the profound. He‚Äôs no longer in the business of trying to be the cleverest or the most successful; he wishes, simply, to tell compelling stories, through music that is lasting and important.  He worries, he says, that his big claims on music and life might sound too self-aggrandising, but ‚Äúwhat better use of a life is there than trying to create music that is profound and transcendent?‚Äù he asks. I‚Äôm still trying to think of a response.  Resound NYC (Deutsche Grammophon) is out now

Wedding invites are usually extended to people who mean something to the bride and groom.  For one couple in Singapore, Darlyn and Agnes, McDonald's mean a whole lot to them.  The fast food restaurant holds such a dear place in their hearts, they sent a wedding invitation to McDonald's.  Meaningful to couple  According to the bride-to-be's Instagram page, she and her fianc√© sent out wedding invitation cards to places that meant a lot to them. The fast food chain was one of the recipients.  "McDonald's is often our to-go place for breakfast/lunch/dinner/suppers üòÇ so we definitely had to send them one!"  While Agnes wasn't expecting a response, she was surprised when she received a message from McDonald's marketing team.  Chicken nugget bouquet  Soon enough, she was greeted with a McNuggets bouquet, decked with chicken nuggets and packs of barbeque sauce and curry sauce.  Of course, the thoughtful bouquet was well received.  Agnes said: "Thank you so much @mcdsg. We had a great time eating it!"  Top image screenshot from @jiaaahuix_ on Instagram.

IT‚ÄôS been 21 years since My Big Fat Greek Wedding burst onto cinema screens - and the trailer for the third film has just been released.  The original rom-com followed Toula Portokalos‚Äôs struggles to find love and accept her identity.  12 My Big Fat Greek Wedding burst onto screens in 2002 and was a surprising box office hit Credit: Alamy  12 The trailer for the franchise's third film has recently been released  It was a massive success at the box office bringing in ¬£296million from a budget of just ¬£4m.  The cast has reunited for the third installment, set for release in September, which sees the family visits Greece after the death of Toula's dad Gus.  While it remains a fan favourite, away from the cameras there‚Äôs been barrel-loads of real-life drama that even the family‚Äôs favourite fix Windex couldn't solve.  From an arrest to marriage breakdowns and a casting row, we reveal what happened next to the My Big Fat Greek Wedding cast.  Antonia Vardalos  12 Antonia 'Nia' Vardalos overcame IVF struggles and wrote a bestselling book  Canadian actress Antonia 'Nia' Vardalos starred as unlucky-in-love Toula, who fell for non-Greek Ian Miller and finally found acceptance for who she was.  In the film, her family were desperate for her to marry and have children - and sadly, fertility was a struggle faced by the star while married to Ian Gomez, who plays Mike in the film.  The actress, now 60, spent nine years trying to conceive, going through 13 rounds of IVF and looking into surrogacy before finally adopting their daughter Ilaria.  She wrote about taking in the three-year-old, who was previously in foster care, in the book Instant Mom, which became a New York Times bestseller.  Antonia and Ian divorced in 2018 but appear to be on good terms with her ex describing the film as a ‚Äúreally sweet franchise‚Äù that helped ‚Äúfamilies get back together‚Äù.  Away from My Big Fat Greek Wedding, she‚Äôs starred in Cougar Town, Grey‚Äôs Anatomy, Helicopter Mom and Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.  John Corbett  12 John Corbett is best known as Aiden in Sex And The City  Floppy-haired John Corbett played heartthrob Ian Miller but is better known as Aidan Shaw, Mr Big‚Äôs love rival, in Sex And The City.  Recently the actor, now 62, came under fire for incorrectly ‚Äúconfirming‚Äù he would appear in ‚Äúquite a few episodes‚Äù of Sarah Jessica Parker's spin-off series And Just Like That.  The show‚Äôs furious writer Julie Rottenberg told Deadline: ‚ÄúJohn Corbett should be writing personal apology notes. We didn't say anything.‚Äù  Thankfully his personal life has had a little less drama. He's been in a relationship with the actress Bo Derek since 2002 and married her in 2020.  They were set up on a blind date by agent Norby Walters when John had no one to take to an Oscars party.  Recalling the matchmaking In 2005, he told Today: ‚ÄúI said, 'I'm not dating anyone,' and he said, 'I'll get you a date, Corbett!' And he set me up with Bo."  John has starred in Portlandia, Sex & Drugs & Rock & Roll alongside Lady Gaga and this year appears in How I Met Your Father - a spin-off of How I Met Your Mother.  Michael Constantine  12 My Big Fat Greek Wedding 3 has been dedicated to Michael Constantine  Tributes poured in after the death of Michael Constantine, who played Toula‚Äôs proud father Gus.  He passed away from natural causes at the age of 94, in September 2021.  My Big Fat Greek Wedding 3 is dedicated to the actor, whose career spanned back to 1959 and notably he was awarded an Emmy for his role in Room 222.  Michael married and divorced twice, first to the actress Julianna McCarthy, who he met on the set of Inherit The Wind and had two children with, and then to Kathleen Christopher.  Lainie Kazan  12 Lainie Kazan had a brush with the law in 2017  Former model Lainie Kazan was already a big name before appearing in the film and previously posed nude for Playboy.  Since playing Maria in the rom-com, she's appeared in Desperate Housewives, Ugly Betty, Grey‚Äôs Anatomy, Modern Family and RuPaul‚Äôs Drag Race.  Lainie, now 83, has battled deep vein thrombosis since the Seventies and in 2016 was hospitalised after a car collision but made a swift recovery.  In 2017, Lainie was arrested for stealing ¬£150 ($180) of groceries which reportedly included cleaning supplies, a hot rotisserie chicken, tomatoes, Jell-O and uncured pepperoni, in California.  She initially denied the allegations but later took a plea deal where she would participate in a Neighbourhood Justice Programme.  In 2021, Lainie revealed her early struggles in Hollywood to Page Six and claimed: ‚ÄúThere wasn‚Äôt a man I met with that didn‚Äôt try to sleep with me‚Äù. She says she turned down their advances.  Gia Carides  12 Gia Carides and her husband split up in 2017  Gia Carides played cousin Nikki in My Big Fat Greek Wedding just four years after her role in Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me.  The actress, 58, was married to fellow actor Anthony LaPaglia for 15 years until 2017, and they share a 20-year-old daughter, Bridget. After their split, Gia hit out at sources who claimed their relationship "failed".  She told The Daily Telegraph: ‚ÄúPeople say it's failed. My attitude is that it didn't‚Ä¶ 20 years is a long time for any relationship and so many positive and great things came out of it.‚Äù  They sold their ¬£6.5m ($8.2m) mansion shortly after Anthony started dating Alexandra Henkel, an actress 31 years younger than him, in 2016.  Ian Gomez  12 Ian Gomez was married to the film's lead star  After playing Mike in the film, Ian Gomez had roles in Curb Your Enthusiasm, Lost, Cougar Town and Grey‚Äôs Anatomy.  The actor, now 58, and his then-wife and film co-star Nia presented The Great American Baking Show for two years together.  Similarly to the My Big Fat Greek Wedding character Ian, the star converted to Greek Orthodoxy so that he could marry Nia but the pair divorced in 2018.  Joey Fatone  12 Joey Fatone is best known for being a member of NSYNC  Joey Fatone was already a huge star before playing cousin Angelo in the film because he was a member of the boyband NSYNC.  After hits including Together Again and No Strings, he branched out into acting and bagged roles in Robot Chicken, Kim Possible and Hannah Montana.  In 2007, Joey placed second in Dancing With The Stars - America‚Äôs version of Strictly - and during a guest appearance 12 years later suffered a wardrobe malfunction.  He told USA Today: "I literally ripped the pants from the front to the back and then I just sat in the judge's chair and said, 'Oh well, you didn‚Äôt notice it.'"  Joey has also appeared in The Masked Singer, Impractical Jokers and Family Feud.  In his personal life, the 46-year-old briefly date popstar Pink in the early noughties before reuniting with his school sweetheart Kelly Baldwin in 2002.  They married two years later and have two daughters, Kloey and Joely, both of whom share NSYNC member Lance Bass as a godfather.  In 2020, Joey confirmed he was "100 per cent" divorced from wife Kelly, in an interview with US Weekly.  He has been dating Brazilian Izabel Araujo for five years.  Andrea Martin  12 Andrea Martin has scores of acting credits behind her  Away from the film, Andrea Martin voiced animated characters in Anastasia, The Rugrats, Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius, The Simpsons and SpongeBob SquarePants.  The star, 76, who has won two Emmys for her screenwriting, went down a storm as Aunt Voula in the My Big Fat Greek Wedding films.  She's also appeared in 30 Rock, Will And Grace, Modern Family, Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt and Black Christmas.  In her personal life, she shares two sons with screenwriter Bob Dolman, and in 2017, the American became a Canadian citizen after living there for 47 years.  Louis Mandylor  12 Before the film, Louis Mandylor was a professional boxer and footballer  Louis Mandylor played Nick in My Big Fat Greek Wedding but before acting was both a professional boxer and footballer in Australia.  Since then the actor, now 56, has also landed small parts including in the TV show Charmed and the film Sinners And Saints.  Stavroula Logothettis  12 Stavroula Logothettis has gone on to appear in other films  Stavroula Logothettis brought the part of Toula‚Äôs big sister Athena to life.  She married writer and activist Danylo Hawaleshka in 1996 and appeared in Kung Fu: The Legend Continues, Earthquake In New York and Harisma.

A company is offering the chance to travel to the edge of space to experience stunning views‚Äîand for couples to have their wedding in space.  Best be careful when you tell someone that you love them to the moon and back because that might be true very soon. Space Perspective, a company based in Florida, is selling the experience of a lifetime: the chance to go to the edge of space. It won‚Äôt be as nerve-wracking as a full-on space flight, but it will bring you high enough that you can still boast you‚Äôve been to space. But that‚Äôs not all. They‚Äôre also offering a couple the chance to have a once-in-a-lifetime wedding by tying the knot in space.  Get married in space with the help of Space Perspective  There‚Äôs a lot of talk about space tourism in the past years, and while the image that comes to mind for many of us is getting on a rocket and being launched out into space, Space Perspective is offering something a little different. They‚Äôre not promising to take you all the way into space but take you to the edge of space where you‚Äôll be ‚Äúabove 99% of the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere‚Äù, according to their website.  Space Perspective doesn‚Äôt also use a rocket as some might assume. Instead, they use what they call a SpaceBalloon, which ‚Äúlaunches‚Äù from land or sea, takes you all the way up, and then descends into the ocean for splashdown. The whole ascent and descent takes six hours, which means there‚Äôs plenty of time for a proper wedding and perhaps a short reception all while having a breathtaking view of Earth from above.  The capsule passengers will be in called the Space Lounge also comes with a number of amenities like drinks, comfortable chairs to watch the view, and wi-fi so you can literally FaceTime or livestream the wedding ceremony from the edge of space. One major limitation couples need to consider, however, is the number of people the Space Lounge can accommodate. With its original layout, nine people can be onboard including the pilot, though the website says the layout can be changed for events like weddings.  Of course, a wedding on the edge of space comes with a price. Space Perspective‚Äôs website says it costs USD $125,000 per seat, though we‚Äôre assuming the price will be higher if it‚Äôs a special wedding flight. If your interest is piqued, you can book now via their website.

By Aya Elamroussi, CNN  (CNN) ‚Äî One couple‚Äôs dream wedding will become reality after a North Carolina man won the first top prize of $150,000 in a newly launched scratch-off game ‚Äì the first time the top prize had been claimed since the game launched earlier this month.  Alfred Harrell had promised his fianc√©e the perfect wedding, according to a news release from the North Carolina Lottery.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been almost a year to the day and those promises will come true now,‚Äù he said in the news release.  Harrell was getting some gas when he pulled into a Circle K in Cary, North Carolina, and purchased a $5 Super Loteria winning ticket.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still trying to process it,‚Äù Harrell said. ‚ÄúIf I went the other direction and didn‚Äôt get gas there, I wouldn‚Äôt have won.‚Äù  Now Harrell and his fianc√©e are looking for venues to accommodate what he hopes will be a ‚Äúbig family celebration.‚Äù  ‚ÄúMay has definitely been good for us,‚Äù he said, noting he also met his fianc√©e two years ago in the same month. ‚ÄúI want to take care of her first.‚Äù  Harrell took home $106,876 of the $150,000 prize after taxes.  As for the lucky game he played, the Super Loteria debuted on May 2 with six $150,000 top prizes, the news release said. Five $150,000 prizes remain up for grabs. Hungary's high inflation is taking a toll on the country's wedding market. According to European Union statistics, the number of couples seeking to get married has plunged to a nine-year low at the start of this year.  The country's inflation is currently 25.2 percent, the highest among EU countries. That has led to skyrocketing food prices and high energy costs ‚Äì driving up the cost not just of day-to-day living, but also milestone events like weddings.  Julianna B√∂rzsei and Bal√°zs Gerlics plan to spend the rest of their lives together. They're counting down the days until their wedding at the end of May, but since their engagement, they've had to make some hard choices about their big day.  "A wedding dress starts at $500 going up to $3,000 and beyond," says bride-to-be B√∂rzsei. "For an average Hungarian, it's too much. So I said to myself, if I can make the dress of my dreams on my own, I can save thousands."  The couple says they're trying to trim as much as possible from their original wedding budget, but they're still 50 percent over.  "We started to negotiate with ourselves on how to shrink everything to the original budget," says groom-to-be Gerlics. "In the end, we said that we wanted a good wedding, so we extended that budget." May 21, 2023 08:22 pm | Updated May 22, 2023 06:06 pm IST - New Delhi  Yashpal Rawat alias Yashpal Benam, a BJP leader in Uttarakhand who is the Nagar Palika chairperson of the Pauri Garhwal district, cancelled his daughter‚Äôs wedding with a Muslim man due to protests from religious leaders and right wing groups.  The wedding, scheduled on May 28, became the talk of the town after the invitation card went viral. It mentioned the names of the bride and groom who met during their engineering course in a college in Roorkee. As the news spread, Mr. Rawat started receiving ‚Äòwarnings‚Äô to call off the wedding.  During a public event organised in the State capital Dehradun by a religious leader, Swami Darshan Bharti, the public was asked to boycott Mr. Rawat because by marrying his daughter to a Muslim, he was supporting ‚Äúlove jihad‚Äù.  ‚ÄúHe should be the first one to oppose ‚Äòlove Jihad‚Äô and ‚Äòland jihad‚Äô. But look, how shamelessly he is calling Muslims to come to ‚ÄòDevbhoomi‚Äô (land of gods) and marry our daughters,‚Äù said Mr. Bharti and asked the attendees if Mr. Rawat should be taught a lesson. The audience raised hands in affirmation followed by more ‚Äòhate speeches‚Äô.  A right-wing group from Haryana, whose members were on their way to Char Dham yatra and got to know about the wedding via social media, stopped at Pauri, especially to raise ‚Äòobjections‚Äô. They went to Nagar Palika‚Äôs office to threaten the chairman who fled seeing the group.  NGOs memorandum  Some NGOs also gave a memorandum to District Magistrate (Pauri) expressing concern over the wedding.  ‚ÄúSuch inter-religious marriages will disturb the peace of the land of Uttarakhand. We request you to ensure that even if this wedding happens, Mr. Rawat should go outside the State to do the same,‚Äù the memorandum given by EK Prayas, the NGO, said.  After facing a weeklong protest, Mr. Rawat called off the wedding on Saturday. Speaking to The Hindu, he maintained that he could name many big leaders of his own party and Opposition who married off children into other communities and expressed shock at the kind of protest that he faced when he did the same.  ‚ÄúDue to people‚Äôs outrage, both in person and on social media, I have to cancel the wedding of my daughter,‚Äù Mr. Rawat said. He will be meeting the groom‚Äôs family in Amethi soon to decide the next course of action.

This is the incredible wedding dress that Gemma Winter will be walking down the aisle in as Coronation Street gears up for its second wedding of the year. Her big day hasn't been far from her lips for months now after Gemma got Chesney Brown to agree to tie the knot.  The couple's romance has been a series of ups and downs, from the high of giving birth to quads on a cable car to the lows of struggling to make ends meet, one thing that has stayed strong is their love for each other and their big blended family.  And getting the wedding together hasn't been easy for the cash-strapped couple, however, and Gemma's twin brother Paul Foreman has been helping out despite his own money woes after making a promise to his sibling. But next week on the ITV soap, it's finally Gemma and Chesney's wedding day.  READ MORE: Join the FREE Manchester Evening News WhatsApp community  Everyone is determined to have the best day ever - in particular Paul who is keeping his devastating Motor Neurone Disease diagnosis a secret so his family can enjoy the big day. But as his condition worsens, questions are hanging over whether he'll be able to walk her down the aisle as promised.  There is, however, one thing that is for certain and that is that all eyes will be on Gemma as she walks down the aisle in what could be the most extravagant wedding dress Weatherfield has ever seen.  In first-look pictures, Gemma, played by Dolly-Rose Campbell, can be seen sporting the impressive two-metre wide dress, with a stunning seven-metre long train and complete with fairy lights, alongside her groom, whose suit has been bought by his son Joseph's grandmother, Linda.  The kebab shop worker, played by Sam Aston, looks dapper in the navy three-piece which has been worn over a crisp white shirt and is complete with a matching silk orange tie and pocket square. The loved-up couple are also seen alongside their children with Joseph wearing the same as his father.  (Image: ITV)  The quads, meanwhile, are simply adorable with Aled and Bryn sporting white shirts and navy trousers with orange dickie bows and matching braces while Carys and Llio continue the theme in white leotards with tutus to match their mum's dress and added multi-coloured. fairy wings.  But back to Gemma's dress and on screen, the mum-of-four has bought a charity shop dress which has been dyed and customised by her pal, seamstress Izzy Armstrong, played by Cherylee Houston. However, in reality, the huge jaw-dropping orange wedding gown has been co-designed and made by drag queen and fashion designer Liquorice Black.  Famous for their stunning unique creations for shows such as RuPaul‚Äôs Drag Race, Liquorice Black has teamed up with Coronation Street's head of costume Alex Hatzar to create the impressive gown which was crafted at Liquorice Black's studio in Manchester.  (Image: ITV)  The dress has 125 metres of tiny fairy lights on wire an the lights on the train are activated by a remote control. There are approximately 10,000 stones all individually glued on by hand and the dress took over 200 hours to make. In addition, the train is seven metres long, and Corrie revealed Dolly wanted it even longer, but joked she had to be reined in.  Speaking about the first time she put the dress on, Dolly told the Manchester Evening News and other press: "I was just blown away by the dress. It's an absolute work of art. The detail that's gone into is just beyond anything I ever imagined and it was comfortable. Compared to a lot f Gemma's other costumes, because it was made to fit me from scratch, it was comfortable."  Dolly said she was 'overjoyed' to get Liquorice Black, whose real name is John Roberts, involved with the dress and shared some of the inspiration and the process behind the final look. "I based the idea off weddings I had seen as a child because these would have been the weddings Gemma would have seen as a child, growing up in the nineties.  (Image: ITV)  "But then, added extra touches such as the fairy lights which were a little bit extra and that's quite Gemma." And on the orange, she revealed: "The colour was the idea of our costume designer Alex. She really wanted it to be orange because it's the most Chesney colour which we all found so funny. We agreed!"  And on how they got Liquorice Black involved, Dolly said: "Myself and Alex in costume had lots of discussions about what Gemma would want as her dream dress and had put some ideas together. We decided on orange as a nod to Gemma and Chesney being ginger and also Gemma loves bright colours.  "Liquorice and I have a mutual friend and I had seen an exhibition of their work and knew they had worked on RuPaul‚Äôs Drag Race UK so I knew that they would be the best person to make the dress, I was absolutely delighted when they said yes."
