A new study has revealed some shocking bachelor and bachelorette party statistics.  A new study has revealed some shocking bachelor and bachelorette party statistics.  t appears pre-wedding shenanigans aren‚Äôt always an innocent night with your nearest and dearest.  A new study in America has revealed more than 70 per cent of soon-to-be spouses have cheated on their partner while indulging in bachelor and bachelorette night festivities.  The New York Post has reported a survey of 6000 people - conducted by Bonus Finder - found that an overwhelming majority of almost husband‚Äôs and wife‚Äôs used the night as a last night of freedom and engaged in usually frowned upon activities like flirting, sexting or sleeping with someone else.  The survey found the main act of cheating came in the form of lap dances, which 33.1 per cent of people said they had received before their wedding, while 21.3 per cent of people said they had kissed someone that wasn‚Äôt their partner.  Bachelorette parties are also known as hens nights in New Zealand. Photo / 123RF  Meanwhile 11.2 per cent of people said they had slept with someone other than their partner.  Speaking to the US news outlet, Bela Gandhi, founder of Smart Dating Academy said the reason why people indulge in the activities at their pre-wedding party can come from a lot of different factors, ‚ÄúThese events are often fuelled by alcohol, controlled substances, peer pressure, and a lack of communication between partners.‚Äù  She added, ‚ÄúIt just goes to show what people think is OK culturally at these events, versus having these conversations with their partners.‚Äù  Bachelor and Bachelorette parties are also known as stag and hens nights in New Zealand and are a celebration of a person before they get married.  The party is seen as a ‚Äúlast night of freedom‚Äù however it‚Äôs more a space for the hen (bride) or stag (groom) to celebrate their upcoming nuptials with their friends and bond with them. The parties can last a night or a weekend and can happen anywhere from the week before the wedding to months before.

Love is known to spark a fire between two people, and occasionally it blurs the borders of propriety. A unique wedding photography that defies convention is revealed in a social media video that is exceptional. The bride and groom exchange a vape-infused kiss in this mesmerizing expression of passion, producing a visually arresting and thought-provoking moment.      The Unconventional Exchange  The groom is holding a vape device, which adds an unusual twist to the image against a background of magic. In an unexpected turn of events, the groom exhales a cloud of vapor, softly passing it to the bride as the couple leans in for a passionate kiss. She then exhales the vapor, creating an amazing visual display.This unusual action has deep symbolic meaning. The exchange of vapor represents the fusion of two diverse people as they harmonize their lives and passions. This pair bravely embraces their uniqueness, inspiring us to think about our own particular love stories and muster the confidence to show affection in ways that are true to who we are.This nontraditional wedding picture session sparks our imagination in a society that frequently sticks to formulaic stories. The bride and groom's vape-inspired kiss serves as a potent reminder that love is a tapestry made of various strands. It exhorts us to treasure and celebrate the beauty of each special love story, embracing the unusual and savouring the inherent sincerity.

Last updated on: May 21, 2023 11:39 IST  Under pressure from Hindutva outfits, a Bharatiya Janata Party leader in Uttarakhand on Saturday said he has cancelled the marriage of his daughter to a Muslim man, which was scheduled to be held on May 28.  Image used for representational purpose only. Photograph: Wikimedia Commons  Talking to reporters in Pauri, Yashpal Benam, the bride's father and Pauri municipal chairman, said he thought of getting his daughter married to a Muslim youth for her happiness.  But in view of the way social media users reacted to the proposed marriage, it has been postponed, he said.  "Now I have to listen to the voice of the public as well," Benam said.  The wedding to be held on May 28 in Pauri city has now been cancelled, he said.  Hindutva outfits on Friday here at Jhanda Chawk burnt the effigy of BJP leader Benam in protest against his daughter marrying a Muslim.  The Vishva Hindu Parishad, Bhairav Sena, and Bajrang Dal took part in the protest.  "We strongly oppose such a marriage," the working president of district VHP Dipak Gaud had said.  A photo of the wedding card of the BJP leader's daughter turned up on social media on Thursday.

Photo Credit: Twitter  Destination weddings are always trending and couples all around the world are always hunting for the best possible destination wedding location on Earth. But what if I tell you that now you can say "I do" or tie the knots in space?  By 2024, a space travel company called Space Perspective plans to revolutionize the wedding market by delivering space weddings. Couples will travel for six hours to the edge of space where they would exchange vows in front of the Earth's curvature, according to the company's plans.  Eight passengers and one pilot will be able to travel on the six-hour Spaceship Neptune trip in cozy, reclining chairs. But it can also be altered to accommodate unique demands.  The Neptune spacecraft from Space Perspective is distinguished by its dedication to giving couples a secure and tranquil experience. Space travel is as safe as boarding a regular airplane with a 19 kmph gradual rise.  The spacecraft Neptune is launched into orbit by the company's SpaceBalloon. It then uses renewable hydrogen to propel itself without the need for rockets or leaving a carbon footprint. With no rockets or related carbon footprint, the spacecraft is driven by renewable hydrogen, providing an environmentally friendly trip to the stars.  Additionally, it has enormous porthole windows, which will make a unique setting for wedding photos. The windows of Neptune are "the biggest windows flown into space" & have a unique anti-UV coating in addition to being made of highly durable material.  What is Space tourism and Possibilities India might have it  For individuals seeking to create a genuinely one-of-a-kind and unforgettable event for their wedding day, this new endeavor is an exciting development. Many people have always found the thought of traveling to space fascinating, and now it is practical for couples to do so on their wedding day.  The six-hour Neptune journey can carry passengers 100,000 feet above the Earth before lowering them back to it. It will start official operations in 2024 and as per reports they have sold around 1,000 tickets already.  Photo Credit: Twitter  But do you know the cost and waiting list for it?  It is $1,25,000 (INR 1 crore) and the waiting list to get married among the stars, according to Jane Poynter, co-founder of Space Perspective, is already light-years long.  Two former Biosphere 2 crew members created Space Perspective to investigate the feasibility of closed ecological systems to sustain human life during space voyages. Biosphere 2 is an Earth system scientific research facility located in Arizona.  Anyone who is medically qualified to fly on a commercial airline can experience space travel thanks to the Neptune spacecraft's modest liftoff speed of 12 mph.

Rita Ora continues to tease fans with stories about her super-private wedding to Taika Waititi!  The caramel-toned beauty and her filmmaker hubby secretly tied the knot in a low-key ceremony sometime in 2022. Following the revelation of their nuptials, the songstress slowly satisfied the public‚Äôs curiosity with little details about her love story.  After months of mystery, the ‚ÄúHow We Do‚Äù hitmaker recently dived into the dynamic duo‚Äôs romance, sharing new information about the lovebirds‚Äô journey down the aisle. Keep reading to learn more about the elusive couple.  Rita Ora Reveals Her Wedding To Taika Waititi Did Not Follow The Conventional Route  In a recent heart-to-heart discussion with ‚ÄúGlamour UK‚Äú for the magazine‚Äôs cover story, the ‚ÄúSoul Survivor‚Äù singer got candid about her relationship with the Hollywood icon. The chart-topper, who refused to reveal the couple‚Äôs wedding date, confessed the pair did not have a formal proposal.  ‚ÄúWell, honestly, there was no real getting down on one knee. It was more like, ‚ÄòI want to marry you. Let‚Äôs just do it,'‚Äù the entertainer explained, noting that she favored the lovebirds‚Äô decision to skip the engagement phase.  Despite being known for serenading thousands at her concerts, the Bambi Award winner admitted she disliked having an extravagant wedding ceremony. Sharing her thoughts on the matter, the 32-year-old stated:  ‚ÄúSome women like to feel that real special attention that day. And everyone‚Äôs different. And for me ‚Äì I think with my job, it is all‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs very attention driven ‚Äì I wanted to keep it private because my life and my career aren‚Äôt.‚Äù  Because the English songwriter wanted a low-key ceremony, her preparations for the wedding were tied to two crucial factors ‚Äî her career and Waititi‚Äôs two daughters from a previous marriage.  Opening up about their importance to the ceremony, the entertainer said: ‚ÄúThe wedding was planned in two to three days, when I was out of cycle, which is what I call it when I‚Äôm not in album cycle mode. And his kids were there, and I really wanted them to be a part of it.‚Äù  The MOBO Award recipient continued, ‚ÄúIt was either then or we had to wait for ages. I didn‚Äôt want to do it without my stepkids there. So, we just figured it out, and we did it. And it was perfect.‚Äù  Still raving about her ‚Äúdream‚Äù wedding, the ‚ÄúBody on Me‚Äù artist explained that her sister made it to the ceremony while her parents gave their blessings via Zoom. Meanwhile, the groom‚Äôs guest list only included his two daughters, which Ora claimed was ‚Äúamazing‚Äù for the filmmaker.  All About The Teen Choice Award Nominee‚Äôs Wedding Dress & Second Ceremony Plans  For her big day, the 32-year-old rocked a stunning wedding dress from one of her favorite designers, Tom Ford. The songstress revealed that she always dreamt of involving the famous stylist in her ceremony after falling in love with one of his earlier outfits.  According to Ora, she had never forgotten the white lace dress and full-length veil ensemble she saw at Ford‚Äôs 2018 fashion show. As fate would have it, the same attire was present when she shopped for her wedding dress.  ‚ÄúI went to Tom Ford‚Äôs shop to see if they had any wedding dresses. And they had this one wedding dress. So bizarre. I‚Äôm not even joking; it was on my mood board. Not that I‚Äôm crazy,‚Äù the entertainer exclaimed. ‚ÄúBut it was the one dress I wanted, and it was there, ready. And it fitted. It was meant to be.‚Äù  Aside from the luxury brand founder, the ‚ÄúYou Only Love Me‚Äù singer confessed that none of her friends knew about her wedding to Waititi. The 32-year-old told her pals after the ceremony. However, no one seemed shocked about her decision.  ‚ÄúNo one knew. No one was surprised. They were like, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm so happy for you. And when can we just throw a big rager?'‚Äù the caramel-toned beauty explained. Regarding the possibility of a second wedding ceremony, the Glamour Award honoree had no specific plans.  ‚ÄúMaybe sometime this year. We haven‚Äôt even thought about it,‚Äù the chart-topper confessed. ‚ÄúBut by the time we throw it, it‚Äôll be old news. My friends won‚Äôt care anymore.‚Äù  This isn‚Äôt the first time the ‚ÄúFifty Shades of Grey‚Äù star has shared important details about her nuptials and love story. Earlier in February, the sensational songstress flaunted the wedding ring she was given by Waititi on ‚ÄúThe Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon.‚Äù  Raving about the large emerald stone jewelry, Ora confessed: ‚ÄúI just wanted it to feel really right, and so I may have taken him to the shop, and I may have pointed out exactly what ring I wanted.‚Äù

Fans enthusiastically showered Chrishell Stause (41) and G Flip (29) with congratulations upon hearing the news of their supposed marriage. However, it has come to light that their union may not have legal recognition.    View this post on Instagram A post shared by Chrishell (@chrishell.stause)    TMZ has reported that despite one week passing since their 'ceremony', there are no official marriage records for Chrishell Stause and G Flip in Clark County, Nevada. This suggests that their wedding may not be legally recognized by the authorities.    According to sources familiar with the situation, it has been confirmed that Chrishell Stause and G Flip are not legally married, despite speculation online. However, they are reportedly planning to have an official wedding in the future.    The couple first revealed their relationship during the Selling Sunset reunion in May of the previous year. Since then, they have been admired as a couple, with Chrishell even appearing in G Flip's music video for "Get Me Outta Here," and G Flip making an appearance in the new season of Selling Sunset on Netflix.    Although the details of their upcoming wedding remain unknown, Chrishell previously mentioned to E! News that they are likely to avoid having a televised wedding.    Although Chrishell Stause has shared some details about their Vegas "wedding," they managed to keep it a secret from the public on social media. However, a few of their friends were present at the chapel for the surprise ceremony.    Chrishell revealed that it was a small group in attendance, with some friends and family watching the event through a live stream. She described her attire for the ceremony, wearing a stunning floor-length gown in pearlescent white and holding a bouquet of white roses. G, on the other hand, opted for a black suit and added a cool touch with sunglasses and white trainers.      FAQs  Q1. Are Chrishell Stause and G Flip legally married?  A1. No, there are no official marriage records for them in Clark County, Nevada.    Q2. Will their wedding be televised?  A2. They are likely to avoid having a televised wedding. Hello from my very own sofa, which of course those of you who watched Scotland Sings will be well acquainted with!  So much has happened in the past week since we spoke that I‚Äôm having a hard time believing it‚Äôs only been seven days.  I very excitedly boarded my flight to Venice from Dallas for the big society wedding we had been invited to.  I can‚Äôt remember the last time I was in Venice but I‚Äôm thinking it might have been around 45 years ago on a school trip with Ellon Academy. Anyone who was on that Italian school trip please correct me if I‚Äôve got my wires crossed.  I remember St Mark‚Äôs Square and the Doge‚Äôs Palace from the 70s but not a lot more.  I don‚Äôt suppose on a school trip we could have afforded a trip on a gondola and this time around we didn‚Äôt feel the need, we just watched other people on theirs. That‚Äôs not to say we didn‚Äôt spend a lot of time on the canals.  When we landed in Venice we went to find a taxi and realised that wasn‚Äôt so easy.  Water taxis were the way to go and being a true Scot I had no intention of paying for a private one if I could pay substantially less for the public one.  Here is a warning, if you ever go to Venice just suck it up and pay the price or you will spend hours on a boat and end up having to drag your cases from where you are dropped off.  On the way back to the airport suffice to say we booked a private water taxi which was expensive but was so enjoyable and just seemed such a fitting way to finish a wonderful trip.  We stood up with the wind in our hair and I sang every Italian song I know as we bumped across the water. I think the boat driver was pretty amused and deafened by the time we got there!  Anyway back to day one! Once we finally arrived at our hotel we didn‚Äôt have too much time to chill as the first event of the wedding which was a pre-wedding dinner was that evening.  We were whisked away by water taxi to an incredible venue, to eat fabulous food and drink cocktails.  The great thing about a pre-wedding party is that you get to meet everyone the day before so we spent a lot of time chatting to members of the bride and groom‚Äôs families.  I had packed a case for myself and for Gordon before I headed to America to make sure that we had all the outfits for each party with us.  Otherwise the smart velvet jacket that Gordon wore that night would have been forgotten and I couldn‚Äôt have trusted him not to turn up in an Arsenal hoodie!  This party went well into the night but like Cinderella on the stroke of midnight we slipped away to the boat as tomorrow was the big day.  As the time for the ceremony approached we were yet again taken in boats down the Grand Canal. The scene was just perfect, like something from a Hollywood movie. And this time I‚Äôd packed a dinner suit for Gordon so he looked fabulous.  Chloe Stroll, the bride, is one of my singers. Her manager rang me from New York during Covid and asked if I would take her on.  We did some online lessons in the early days and then eventually started to work regularly in person. It soon became obvious to me that she is special.  Walking down the aisle  Hopefully we will be bringing out her music very soon so I will proudly get to share her with the world.  We have become very close over the past couple of years and when she walked down the aisle with her dad looking exactly like a fairytale princess, I couldn‚Äôt hold back the tears.  The groom, Olympic snowboarder Scotty James, was looking every bit her Prince Charming as he waited at the end of the longest aisle I‚Äôve ever seen.  It‚Äôs not surprising that the image of Chloe and Scotty walking back down the aisle made the front cover of Italian Vogue.  Day Three dawned and we all congregated for a more relaxed get together although I‚Äôm amazed we were all still standing.  What a wonderful weekend was had by all. I was so grateful to be a part of such an event but now I need to sleep for a week.  I did however have the energy for a quick trip to say Happy Birthday to Auntie Agnes!  Have a good week,  Yvie x

By Francis Ewherido  Last Monday was my 24th wedding anniversary. When I went into marriage 24 years ago, it was a mystery. Twenty-four years later, I am not close to unravelling the mystery called marriage. I have gained a lot experience as a participant, a counsellor and an observer, but I remain a student. That is why I am quick to correct anyone who calls me a marriage expert. I acknowledge that I have accumulated a body of knowledge on marriage, but I remain a learner.  Marriage is not an institution where you pound your chest that you have mastered the art. It is an endless sea of water. I see marriage the way I see surfing. Your knowledge of the art and commitment are crucial, but there are other factors outside your control for its success. When Joseph found out that Mary was pregnant with the child Jesus, the marriage was effectively over, but for God‚Äôs intervention. I sincerely believe in the God factor in the sustenance of marriage. But there are atheist whose marriages lasted for decades till one spouse died, how did such marriages endure? I do not know. But I know that the God factor has helped to keep my marriage alive.  Also, no single spouse can pound his/her chest for the success of his/her marriage because only one spouse cannot make a marriage work, no matter how good he/she is. I met a woman who went into marriage with a firm resolve to make it work. She did everything possible to make her marriage work, but it failed. If your spouse wants out, the marriage is as good as over. That is why everyone whose marriage is still on should stay humble.  You are only one of the contributory factors; you are not all in all. You cannot look down on others whose marriages failed. Even if you are an atheist, you must acknowledge the contribution of your spouse. Without his/her continuous consent, there will be no marriage. When a 99 year old Italian man filed for divorce of his 96-year-old wife of 77 years, the marriage ended. The wife had an affair over 60 years before, but the man only stumbled on the evidence at that time. When he confronted her, she owned up to the affair. Swiftly, the man filed for divorce.  In 1998 the 38 years marriage of Frederik Willem de Klerk (last President of apartheid-era South Africa) to his wife, Marike de Klerk, collapsed due to his infidelity. But former US President, Bill Clinton, committed the same adultery, and his wife, Hilary Clinton, forgave him and the marriage lives on till date. I am just trying to drive home the point that some factors that are responsible for your continued married status are beyond you. Clinton was lucky to escape. Notwithstanding, infidelity remains a major reason for marital breakups.  Money is another major reason why marriages breakup. These days, many girls say on social media that they cannot be in a relationship with a broke man. Money is crucial in marriage, but it is not all in all. The marriage of Bill Gates and Melinda Gates broke up after 27 years together. The same thing happened to Jeff Bezos and MacKenzie Bezos after 25 years of marriage. Both men were at different times the richest men in the world. Yet money did not save their marriages. Marriage is a wonderful institution created by God. I cherish it and at the same time look at it with suspicion and trepidation. It can be so slippery. You have to be permanently on the alert. Inertia can lead to doom.  Time has flown by in the last 24 years. It makes me to ask if we have actually lived together for 24 years. Facts do not lie. My first generation of children are in their 20s. They were born after marriage, so we are 24 years old in marriage.  I see marriage as two sides of a coin. The people going into it are good, bad and ugly. They bring all these traits into marriage. A marriage where one or both spouses are totally good is utopian. Such marriages do not exist. Even if they did, I am not sure I will be interested. Conflicts and the unexpected are parts of life and by extension marriage. What is important are mechanisms to resolve conflicts and weather the storm. For me, during conflicts, do not overstep boundaries: I have seen spouses call their other half fool, idiot, agbaya, mumu, short devil and other acidic words. Somehow, they resolve their differences and life goes on. But I am not sure my marriage would endure such acidic words. My wife and I are two strongly opinionated people, so disagreements are inevitable, but knowing each other‚Äôs sensitivity, we are careful, but hurtful words, not abuses, do ‚Äúleak out‚Äù sometimes. I know I have said to myself (I dare not say it out because it would make reconciliation more difficult):‚Äùwetinsef? Anywhere cloth like, make e tear (let whatever wants to happen, happen). But even as I say it inwardly, I add, ‚ÄúGod, na joke I dey o! Forgive me o!‚Äù  I do not belong to the school that makes rules that the sun must not set or dawn meets an unresolved disagreement. I am not mechanical. I dey vex my vex complete, then I carry eraser clean am.Married people should not take critical decisions in the heat of anger. Decisions taken in the heat of anger have ended some marriages. Even when there was window to remedy the situation, pride stood in the way. Sometimes pride for spouse when don see you finish nor make sense to me.  While growing up, one of the sayings my mother used to mold us was: ‚Äúyou see, in this life if you look in only one direction, your neck will become stiff, so look in all directions.‚Äù This has been very useful to me in marriage and in life generally. If you remember only the good things done for you, you are‚Äùeserinone(Someone who remembers only today‚Äôs good deeds).My wife does get on my nerves and drives me up the wall sometimes (and vice versa). But I never forget that she has stuck to me through thick and thin, in sickness and in health. I read the story of a marriage which broke up recently. The woman‚Äôs only reason was that she was tired of the marriage. I went through the same health challenges as her husband and my wife was a rock all through. When I remember her steadfastness, her faith even when I lost faith and thought I would not pull through, letting go becomes easy. I am not perfect, so I expect no perfection from my wife.  But I still believe forgiveness by spouses should not be taken for granted. Do not cross the red line. That is taking your luck too far. After 24 years, we know the no go areas. They should not be crossed. But every wrongdoing cannot be sacrilege. That is why your core values should be well spelt out at the beginning and in the course of the marriage.

Stephanie rates dresses with family and believes she may have found the one  There is a lie at the heart of the search for the perfect wedding dress. It is a lie that causes many brides-to-be weeks, sometimes months, of unnecessary stress as they try to unearth ‚Äòthe one‚Äô.  Because there is no one perfect outfit ‚Äì and it‚Äôs time we all admitted it.  As I‚Äôm planning a woodland wedding for next June with my partner of ten years, part of the difficulty with finding the one is that our sense of style is forged by opposing forces and, at 30, I‚Äôve got the matriarchs of my family to thank for that.  My nana, 83, is all pea coats, cigarette trousers and dainty cardigans, whereas my mum, 59, honed her style on the streets of London‚Äôs Camden and the King‚Äôs Road in the 1980s.  It was these two clashing matriarchs I decided to take shopping when I began the search for that elusive, perfect wedding dress.  My nana, 83, is all pea coats, cigarette trousers and dainty cardigans. Pictured: Stephanie and her nana  Stephanie's nana in a tulle dress on her wedding day in 1960. Her nana gave her judgement on the dresses she tried on  If I don't buy this, my mum will  Where? Temperley London, Phoenix Studios, Ilminster, Somerset; temperleylondon.com  Known for romantic styles made using artisanal techniques and featuring intricate details.  I wanted something a little bit different. Temperley‚Äôs beautiful, colourful dresses are far from traditional and definitely make a statement.  Nana wanted lace and beads galore, and if there was anywhere she‚Äôd find her dream dress it would be here. However, styles with all that detailing are too much for me as they bulk out my curves. Upon seeing the embroidered dress (opposite), she did admit it was ‚Äòvery me‚Äô.  Dress, ¬£3,200, Temperley London  Mum wanted me to choose this embroidered dress for my big day. It was the only one that got her excited. Part of me thinks if I hadn‚Äôt tried it on, she would have.  I discovered that despite really loving this gorgeous dress, I felt worried that it didn‚Äôt look ‚Äòbridal‚Äô enough (after all, no one wants to blend in with their wedding guests). Shockingly, my inherited and conflicted style is slowly starting to understand what it wants and, it turns out, much to Nana‚Äôs delight, it‚Äôs a touch of classic. But where to find it?  'Too busy!' Says Nana  Where? Halfpenny London, 10 Woburn Walk, London WC1; halfpennylondon.com  Known for bold dresses and separates that add drama, plus multiple styling options. Think Brit cool meets playful vintage.  I wanted lots of tulle but with edge to showcase my personality ‚Äì though nothing too extreme.  Dress, ¬£5,950, Halfpenny London  Corset, ¬£2,495, and skirt, ¬£3,995, Halfpenny London  Nana wanted tulle, too ‚Äì which she wore for her wedding, aged 21 ‚Äì but she had strict rules. A tulle shrug was ‚Äòtoo busy‚Äô but a dress with tulle wing-style shoulders bigger than my head got the thumbs-up. I agreed. It was sleek, flattering and oh so different! I‚Äôll be back to try this one on again.  Mum wanted to go off-piste with Halfpenny‚Äôs separates, picking an off-the-shoulder corset top with a densely ruffled skirt (above). I think she was going for a punky Vivienne Westwood vibe.  I discovered that being just five foot two means tulle isn‚Äôt always my friend and also that Nana, despite loving pretty details, draws the line at puffball skirts, saying ‚ÄòOh gawd, no!‚Äô when I tried one on.  Sorry, not for me  Where? The Fall, Dalston Works, Ground Floor, 9 Martel Place, London E8; thefallbride.com  Known for its mix of designers offering fresh takes on bridalwear.  I wanted a chance to play with contrasting styles and test what I thought I wanted. Like a veil, which at first I didn‚Äôt care for. But when that sheer piece of fabric was placed on my head, I felt like a princess!  Nana wanted a dress decked in intricate lacework or laden with beads. This dress elicited a very passionate response: ‚ÄòNow that‚Äôs the kind of bride I want my Stephanie to be!‚Äô she bellowed, all teary. I loved how excited she got at finding the dress she wanted me to wear, but the look was not for me.  Dress, ¬£2,150, and skirt, ¬£1,375, Jessica Bennett, and veil, ¬£200, AM Faulkner, from The Fall  Dress, ¬£3,700, Prea James, and veil, ¬£150, AM Faulkner, from The Fall  Mum wanted me to try on a column dress with a huge, detachable skirt and pockets (above) ‚Äì it was a game-changer. Swishing around with my hands in those pockets I looked like a totally different version of myself.  I discovered you do yourself a disservice when you write off a style of dress without trying it. However, while I loved the column dress I was worried that it would suit a city wedding rather than my woodland one.  Have I found the one?  Where? The Own Studio, 374-378 Old Street, London EC1; theownstudio.com  Known for sleek and minimalist silhouettes.  I wanted a surprise. The Own Studio‚Äôs contemporary twist on classics piqued my interest.  Dress, ¬£1,650, and cape, ¬£600, The Own Studio  Nana wanted way more drama! ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs the point in these boring, plain dresses?‚Äô she asked.  Mum wanted to leave ‚Äì until the stylist pulled out a cape. Paired with a slip dress, it added an ethereal touch that would work perfectly with our woodland wedding. Mum stared at me with a glint in her eyes that said: ‚ÄòCould this be the one?‚Äô  I discovered that capes aren‚Äôt just for superheroes, but brides, too! In fact one may end up being my big-day secret weapon.

The Princess of Wales' youngest son Prince Louis is known for his cheeky expressions, but it was her eldest son Prince George who was attracting all the attention at Pippa Middleton's wedding.  The then-three-year-old was a page boy alongside Casimir Tatos, Edward Sebire and William Ward, while his younger sister Princess Charlotte, two, was one of four flower girls for Pippa's big day with James Matthews, which took place on 20 May 2017 at St Mark's Church, Englefield. To mark Pippa's sixth wedding anniversary, we've looked back at one funny moment between Kate and her kids which was caught on camera.  ¬© Getty Kate was pictured leading the page boys and flower girls into the church  Before the bride arrived and cameras caught sight of Pippa's stunning lace Giles Deacon wedding dress and handmade Maidenhair Fern tiara, her sister and maid of honour Kate helped shepherd the young bridal party inside the church.  But even the short journey from the car to the doors was enough to catch sight of the Princess' parenting skills as she calmed the children down ahead of the ceremony ‚Äì a task she had previously admitted worried her.  Dressed in cream shorts and a white collared shirt, Prince George was spotted making his way through the other page boys and flower girls to the front to grab hold of his mother's hand. He then held onto Charlotte, who looked cute in a Pepa & Co white dress with a pink sash, with his other hand. Watch the moment Kate tried to keep the group, led by George, quiet in the video below‚Ä¶  WATCH: Princess Kate shushes Prince George at Pippa Middleton's wedding  At the Queen's garden party just days before the wedding, Kate told one guest that she was "a bit worried" about how her children would behave while carrying out their starring roles.  Pippa and James got married on 20 May 2017  Partygoer Andrew Bates said: "[Kate] said that they were all really looking forward to her sister's wedding at the weekend but she was a bit worried about how her children might behave. She said she was hopeful that they would be good but you never know at that age."  After the ceremony, Kate's efforts to make sure her children were behaving were visible once again. She followed behind newlyweds Pippa and James down the path while trying to keep hold of Charlotte's hand, but the tot was too engrossed in emptying the petals out of her wicker basket to listen.  ¬© Getty Princess Kate was Pippa's maid of honour  As they gathered outside the church, the Princess crouched down to share a few words with Charlotte before George came wandering over to his mother waving around his basket in the air.  Pippa and James and their guests then headed off for a lavish reception at nearby Englefield House, a romantic Elizabethan manor where movies such as The Kings Speech and 2012's Great Expectations were filmed.  Guests had been asked to bring a change of clothes for the adults-only evening reception, which started at 7.30 pm at Bucklebury Manor. Set on 18 acres, the grade II-listed Georgian house where Carole and Michael Middleton live served as an idyllic backdrop for the reception, which was attended by about 350 guests.  See more photos of Princess Kate at Pippa's wedding...  ¬© Getty The royal adjusted Pippa's wedding dress and veil before she walked down the aisle  ¬© Getty A sweet moment between Kate, George and Charlotte  ¬© Getty Kate was spotted crouching to share some words with Charlotte  ¬© Getty The royal beamed behind the newlyweds following the ceremony  LOOK: Pippa Middleton's twinning fashion moments with stylish sister Princess Kate  Planning your wedding? Sign up to HELLO!‚Äôs Bride Guide newsletter for expert advice, budget help, wedding inspiration and real life stories delivered straight to your inbox.

One chaperone service will look after your dog during the ceremony and reception and take it on two walks to 'shake off nerves' during the big day  Gary Jude remembers the first time he photographed a dog at a wedding. It was 2018, in the Essex countryside, and the bride and groom had brought their pet beagle to the reception.  'They were quite outdoorsy people,' he says. 'The dog had on a wax Barbour jacket.' Jude wanted to take group pictures, but the beagle wasn't looking at the camera. 'I had to try to get this dog's attention. I thought, well, I might do what I do with my dogs at home, and I'm going to sound like an idiot, but I went‚Ä¶'  At this point, he takes a deep breath and then makes a string of incomprehensible, high-pitched noises and gurgles. Apparently, the dog loved it.  'He started doing a head tilt and everyone was cracking up.' The 39-year-old wedding photographer might have been 'in a room of 50 people that I'd never met and doing stupid baby dog talking', but he enjoyed himself nonetheless. 'I'm a massive dog person.'  These days, canine-friendly weddings are big business. More venues let dogs attend ceremonies and receptions  Lucky for him, then: last year Jude photographed 40 dogs at one wedding.  The bride and groom had rented a field in North Devon and let guests bring their pets. 'There were dogs running around everywhere,' says Jude.  'I was in my element.' Still, the pet-positive day was not without its issues. Halfway through the groom's speech, one of the hounds cocked his leg against a table in the marquee. Luckily, the bride was fixed on the groom and didn't notice.  These days, canine-friendly weddings are big business. More venues let dogs attend ceremonies and receptions; wedding photographers have dedicated 'dog' sections on their websites, and dog groomers offer pre-wedding pooch pampering.  Smarty Paws, in Nottingham, sells a gold package from ¬£250: dogs have their fur clipped, nails trimmed, ears cleaned and, according to the website, 'cologne applied, if you wish'. (Jude, for what it's worth, didn't have dogs at his own wedding because it was 2013 and the venue didn't allow it.  He was, however, permitted to have a trained barn owl called Rosie swoop down the aisle and deliver the wedding rings ‚Äì swings and roundabouts.)  In 2018, professional dog trainer Lizzie Benge set up Here Comes The Hound, a chaperone service for dogs at weddings.  Benge, 39, is based in Kent, but she and her business partner Claire travel around the country to work the wedding canine circuit. Their services aren't cheap: a full-day package costs ¬£550.  So what do you get for your money? First, Benge offers a pre-wedding 'consultation' with the bride, groom and dog, to get to know the animal and find out what the couple want.  On the wedding day, Benge will look after the dog throughout the ceremony and reception, drive it between venues, get it to cooperate during photos and take it on two walks  Then, on the wedding day, she will look after the dog throughout the ceremony and reception, drive it between venues, get it to cooperate during photos, and give it two hour-long walks ‚Äì one in the morning and one in the afternoon ‚Äì 'to shake off the big-day nerves'.  She also can, if requested, release the dog down the church aisle with the wedding rings attached to its neck.  And, for an extra ¬£100, there's an overnight service, 'including sofa cuddles, yummy dinner, sleepover fun, a morning-after 90-minute walk and taxi back home or to the honeymoon holiday home'. Last year,  Benge worked at 16 weddings; she promises all the dogs behaved immaculately.  Naturally, I have a lot of questions. How does Benge get the dogs to behave for photographs? 'We come armed with squeaky toys, balls and treats.'  How many dogs can she look after in one go? It depends on how big and well behaved they are; she once chaperoned three labradors, with the aid of a colleague.  Which breed is the most popular? 'Cockapoos are everywhere. Or some variation on poo: cavapoo, shih-poo.' Are there any breeds she hates working with?  'I would never say no to any type of dog,' she says, diplomatically, before adding:  'I wouldn't particularly want to work with chihuahuas. Only because they're normally quite nervous. People want them in their day, but I'm not really sure that chihuahuas want to be a part of their day.'  I WOULDN'T WANT TO WORK WITH CHIHUAHUAS ‚Äì THEY'RE NERVOUS  And the biggest questions of all: why would someone want their dog at their wedding? And why would they pay north of ¬£500 to do it?  Lockdown, probably. If the country was already dog mad, spending endless hours trapped with our dogs has only made us dog madder.  Between March and September 2020, 2.2 million dogs were bought in the UK; by 2021, Britain's canine population had risen by more than ten per cent. And, thanks to working from home, so many of those lockdown puppies grew up never being on their own.  'It's a double-edged sword,' says Benge. 'I think it's lovely that people care so much about their dogs. But I also believe that, from the animals' point of view, they need to learn to be left by themselves.'  Still, your wedding isn't an ordinary day, and, if you want your pet there, you may as well do it in style.  That said, there are some animals that Benge thinks are best left at home ‚Äì wedding day or not. When I ask if she would consider expanding business to chaperoning cats any earlier displays of diplomacy are abandoned.  'No!' says Benge, laughing. 'I just don't think that's a good idea.'  A who's zoo of animal guests  Alpacas  According to nuptials website Wedition, the curly-haired camelids are ‚Äòextremely sociable and inquisitive animals‚Äô that ‚Äòmake for very polite wedding guests ‚Äì they will very rarely spit!‚Äô  From ¬£300 for two alpacas, tedandbessie.co.uk  According to nuptials website Wedition, the curly-haired camelids are ‚Äòextremely sociable and inquisitive animals‚Äô (stock image)  Doves  They‚Äôre a symbol of love and peace so it‚Äôs a classic choice. Plus, Victoria and David Beckham hired bird breeder Warren Foster to release one at their 1999 wedding (and Foster named two of his own Vicky and Becks in their honour).  From ¬£170 for two doves, thewhitefeatherco.co.uk  Doves are a symbol of love and peace so it‚Äôs a classic choice. (stock image)  Shetland ponies  For a bit of variety, they can be used as ring bearers, confetti carriers or rides for children. Or they could pull a carriage to escort the newlyweds from the church.  From ¬£200 for two ponies, lollipopponyparties.co.uk; from ¬£3,575 plus VAT for a shetland-drawn carriage, hartlandcarriages.co.uk

THE rule of thumb when it comes to choosing a wedding guest outfit is to not wear white.  White is a popular colour for brides to wear and it is important that the bride stands out on her wedding day.  1 A bride has revealed how her friend wore white lace to her wedding Credit: Reddit  Regularly a guest wearing white can be seen as an attempt to upstage the bride, the same rule applies to wearing white lace too.  So unless the bride and groom have specifically requested for guests to wear the colour, it is best to avoid.  But for one bride, she was left in shock after her guest decided to wear a white lace dress to her wedding.  In a post on Reddit, she shared a picture of the guest and said: "My tenth wedding anniversary is approaching, and as I was going through photos, I stumbled across this one of one of my husband's groomsmen and his wife, who wore a literal white lace dress to our wedding.  ‚ÄúTo be fair, it was incredibly, incredibly short and very, very tight, so I'm not sure anyone mistook her for 'the bride,' but it was‚Ä¶ something."  This left many Reddit users stunned, and some even rushed to the comments section to share their thoughts.  Some even admitted they mistook the woman for the bride.  One wrote: "Sometimes I think people are too strict about the white rule, but holy hell, if you told me that was YOU in your wedding dress I would have believed you. It's even lacy!!!!"  A second replied: "There is no such thing as too strict. There are millions of colors. Pick any of them but white. Too strict would be banning white dress shirts."  Someone else added: "Yes, I'm the same. Sometimes I'm like 'nah that's fine, or mother of the brides are fine,' but this dress is absolutely ridiculous for a wedding guest.  "I thought it was the bride!"  Another questioned: "This was from your own wedding and this is the wife of one of the groomsmen? She's wearing a wedding dress, hands down."  The post's author replied: "Yeah‚Ä¶ They were a special pair. We asked the wedding party to wear something nice they already owned, because most of them were early career veterinarians with student loans who travelled from out of town. For the most part, people looked amazing and the photos are wonderful.  "This dude showed up looking like he was going to a funeral and his wife showed up looking like she was at her own wedding."

Oasis singer Liam Gallagher and manager girlfriend Debbie Gwyther had previously been set to tie the knot in 2020 but called off their nuptials during the COVID pandemic  Oasis frontman Liam Gallagher has set tongues wagging that he may have sectedly wed girlfriend Debbie Gwyther in Italy.  The couple got engaged in 2019 on the Amalfi Coast had been previously set to wed in 2020 but postponed their marriage plans during the pandemic. Wonderwall singer Liam told the world the reason they postponed the wedding was because he "didn't want to hide his pretty face in a mask".  However the pair could now already be husband and wife, after family and close friends joined them in Italy at Lake Como although brother Noel Gallagher was nowhere to be seen.  Image: MEGA) MEGA)  Liam's sons Gene and Lennon joined him and his fianc√©e at the wedding hotspot in Italy as well as close friends, with speculation rife that the group gathering was ahead of Liam and Debbie finally tying the knot.  Liam's son Lennon is from his first marriage to actress Patsy Kensit with son Gene coming from his second marriage to All Saints singer Nicole Appleton. He also has daughter Molly from an affair in 1998 and another daughter Gemma from another affair in 2011.  Mirror contacted Liam's and manager girlfriend Debbie for comment.  Speaking in an interview with Q magazine, Liam revealed he wished he did things differently and that he would have changed how his personal life unfolded.  Image: Richard Young/REX/Shutterstock) Richard Young/REX/Shutterstock)  He said: "Probably personal stuff. Breaking up marriages, being a bit of a f*****g idiot with the kids. D*****g people about, upsetting them."  The potential wedding also comes after Liam delighted fans by teasing a possible Oasis reunion, but on the condition of his beloved football team Manchester City winning the Champions League tournament.  A fan asked the star if the band would ever reform, he responded with: "I‚Äôm ready to go."  He isn't the only one who is ready for the Britpop band to make its return to touring, as former rhythm guitarist Paul 'Bonehead' Arthurs confirmed to Radio X he would be keen for a comeback.  Image: Getty Images Europe) Getty Images Europe)  On his own special episode for Radio X, he revealed: "Some days you wake up and think Nah, there's no need for it. It's been done. But when I'm on stage with Liam Gallagher as a solo artist, and I come out and we play Rock 'N' Roll Star and the place erupts. People are bouncing higher and harder than they did at some of the gigs back in the day.  "I look at that first ten rows when I'm playing an arena with Liam, and they're like 16 or 17 years of age. These people weren't even born until well into Oasis' career.  "So if there was a reunion, wouldn't it be worth it for them? To come and witness that band? In that sense it would be worth just one gig next year for those kids at the front, who are jumping and bouncing at Liam's gigs."  Do you have a story to sell? Get in touch with us at webcelebs@mirror.co.uk or call us direct 0207 29 33033.

A couple in the UK has gone viral and won hearts for holding their wedding in a care home for the bride's great-grandmother to walk her down the aisle. (Credit: Care UK)  KEY HIGHLIGHTS Bianca Suarez and Mark Rodgers got engaged in more than 13 years ago in February 2009. For some reason or the other, they had to keep delaying their wedding.  But when Bianca's great-grandmother Margaret Ripley fell ill, the couple decided to finally pick a date.    The decision came through after they were told by a staff member of a care home that Margaret might not live long enough to see the wedding.    A couple in the UK has gone viral and won hearts for holding their wedding in a care home for the bride's great-grandmother to walk her down the aisle.  Bianca Suarez and Mark Rodgers got engaged in more than 13 years ago in February 2009. For some reason or the other, they had to keep delaying their wedding.  But when Bianca's great-grandmother Margaret Ripley fell ill, the couple decided to finally pick a date.  The decision came through after they were told by a staff member of a care home that Margaret might not live long enough to see the wedding, according to a Metro report.  The staff also suggested that the two have their big day in the care home as it would allow 99-year-old Margaret to walk Bianca down the aisle.  And without any reservations or doubts, the pair organised their wedding on May 12 at Care UK's Kingsleigh facility in Woking, Surrey  Photos shared online shows Margaret posing with Bianca and watching her dance with her partner. There is also a group photo in which the 99-year-old was seated in the middle of all the guests and family members.  "We were going try to save up money this year to get married next year, but it was looking like nan might not be here. First, we decided to do a pretend wedding where we dress up and get the staff pretend to be the vicar. But then we decided to do it properly - with her walking me down the aisle," Bianca was quoted as saying by Metro.  She added that the decision to marry in the care home was sudden and it resulted in a rush to get everything together in time.  The couple were helped by the care home staff and their loved ones in organising the wedding. Bianca said their budget was low but they could borrow things from others  "We didn't have a lot of money so we asked if we could borrow things from people - and the outcome was so, so overwhelming," she said.  On the big day, a generous friend lent them his car and Bianca borrowed her dress from a local hospice. They also got marquees, chairs and a gazebo from friends.  "Getting married in a care home isn't something you do - so everyone on the day was really shocked at how beautiful it looked," said Bianca.

Let's Be Honest, Wedding Cakes Are Over  Wedding trends come and go, especially when it comes to food. The beef, chicken, or fish-plated dinners have gone by the wayside in favor of non-traditional options like a taco food trucks or pasta bars. But surely the crown jewel of the wedding dining experience, the wedding cake, will endure the test of time, right? It seems less and less likely over time as folks reject many of the nuptial rituals and look for customized dessert menus.  Engaged couples are also likely to reject wedding cakes because they are astronomically expensive, costing $350 on average, says Brides. And the tiered masterpieces that have been a staple in weddings also have a reputation for being a tad flavorless and boring, not to mention generic. For a while, that meant the soon-to-be-wed would go for modern cake styles, favoring bold floral decorations, distinctive techniques like stucco frosting, and unique flavors such as pumpkin spice latte cake with cream cheese frosting. Now those are very common and read as just as nondescript as their predecessors. And as the general trend in weddings is that most couples want each aspect of the wedding to be catered to their unique tastes and interests, the traditional wedding cake is out in favor of more quirky, memorable dessert options.

A fitness influencer is receiving backlash after she shared that offered her wedding guests anti-bloat pills.  TikTok user @TheFitFatale, real name Sam Cutler, posted a video to her account with the title, "What I ate on my wedding day as a #glutenfree & #dairyfree health focused #bride." She showed that she indulged in diet and health-centered foods including a smoothie, grain salad, lettuce salad and vegetables.  During the actual reception, she offered guests oysters, plantain avocado bites, chopped salad, gluten free bread and salmon. What sent users over the edge was the fact that at "every table" for the bride and her guests, she offered Arrae bloat pills and the fact that she chose a specific wine because of the minimal sugar in it.  ‚ÄúLMFAO I cannot imagine having an eating disorder themed wedding,‚Äù the top most-liked comment on her TikTok read. "Can you imagine going to a wedding and on the tables are anti bloating gummies?! Byyyyeeeeeeeeee," another read. Others categorized it as an "almond wedding," meaning a person who buys into diet culture.  "You're wedding day it's supposed to be enjoyable," someone added. Others said that they would go to Taco Bell after the reception and that their family would be offended by the offering of the diet pills.  With all of the negative comments including, "not laxatives as the wedding flavor," Cutler fired back in another video where she criticized the negative comments and people "labeling someone as having mental health or body image issues for the purpose of bullying is extremely low."  Cutler noted that the "fact that a comment like this [about her wedding having an eating disorder theme] can get 15,000 likes only reinforces the need for women to connect and inspire each other to feel their best and learn what works for their individual body."

A bride has left people aghast after claiming the guidelines stipulated on her wedding invitations led to her losing a close friend of seven years, but she has no regrets  A woman has opened up about how guidelines specified in the FAQs section of her wedding invitations ultimately led to the end of a seven-year-long friendship, leaving people stunned.  Lifestyle influencer Cora Breilein recently shared how she'd made her answer to the question 'can I bring a date?' crystal clear in the invite, specifying that they would not be including a plus-one option for guests as they wanted their wedding to be "intimate".  In a screengrab of the guideline shared in a TikTok post, Cora's guests were advised: "If your partner is invited their name is included on your Save the Date and formal invitation." This rule, unfortunately, didn't go down too well with everyone.  Cora, who goes by the username @corabrei, revealed: "Lost a 7+ year friendship over not inviting a bf I never met. Our wedding felt so special and intimate knowing everyone there. It's worth weeding people that aren't interested in being part of your life, out."  Although many understood where she was coming from, a number of people were left startled by this revelation, and just couldn't understand why a person would risk losing a friendship over a plus-one rule.  One person commented: "Pure INSANITY if you can't bring your partner to a wedding if you're not married. So my partner of four years wouldn't be welcome? Wouldn't even attend."  Clarifying her position in a follow-up post, Cora addressed the criticism head-on, explaining: "It [was] just about [inviting] people who will be in our lives long-term.  "If I never met their boyfriend or girlfriend, I did not feel comfortable inviting them. I think what everyone needs to understand is the FAQs were there because we wanted to have an intentionally small wedding and we wanted to know every single person there.  "But a lot of people have a 'no ring, no invite' rule, and we were not that strict about that."  Do you have a wedding-related story to share? Email us at julia.banim@reachplc.com

Sophie-Alexandra Evekink, 33, tied the knot with Prince Ludwig in a stunning wedding dress as hundreds of well-wishers lined the streets, before heading to a Palace for the reception  Prince marries Oxford student in lavish royal wedding as hundreds line the streets  An Oxford student has tied the knot with a European prince in a lavish wedding ceremony.  Hundreds of well-wishers were seen lining the streets when 40-year-old Prince Ludwig of Bavaria married 33-year-old Oxford student Sophie-Alexandra Evekink in Germany.  Sophie, who is studying for a PhD in criminology, paired a classic white floral dress with a princess-cut skirt as she walked down the aisle at St Kajetan in Munich on Saturday.  This was accompanied with a long veil, which was embroidered with delicate lace flowers to match the sleeves and the bodice of her dress.  She also wore a diamond, botanical headpiece and carried a small posy of flowers.  Image: Robin Utrecht/dana press/REX/Shutterstock) Robin Utrecht/dana press/REX/Shutterstock)  After their vows, the couple - who announced their engagement in August 2022 - headed to a luxury reception at Nymphenburg Palace, the ancestral home of Bavaria's former monarchy.  The UK-based student's new husband, Ludwig, is the eldest son of Prince Luitpold and the great-great grandson of Bavaria's last ever King, Ludwig III.  Sophie was born in Singapore to a Dutch-Canadian family in 1989, and has spent several years working on human rights issues.  She has a Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Politics and East European Studies from University College London (UCL) and a Masters in Science from the University of Oxford.  Image: Robin Utrecht/dana press/REX/Shutterstock) Robin Utrecht/dana press/REX/Shutterstock)  The keen scholar is currently working towards a PhD at University of Oxford, which focuses on securing justice for victims of conflict-related sexual violence.  Speaking to Germany's Bild newspaper last summer, Prince Luitpold revealed his admiration for his new daughter-in-law and said he hoped they would "start a family soon".  He commented: ‚ÄúLudwig made a good choice. My future daughter-in-law is a very intelligent and educated woman.‚Äù  Despite Germany's former aristocracy being abolished in the early twentieth century, Sophie will receive a title through her marriage ‚Äì though she plans to only use this while she is in Bavaria, reports the Bild, as she already has academic papers published under her former name.  Instead of giving them wedding presents, he couple reportedly asked guests to donate towards humanitarian initiatives targeted at helping the victims of the war in Ukraine.

A group of Cape Hatteras Elementary third-grade students made a remarkable and unexpected discovery of a 17th-century wedding ring while on a field trip to the new Lost Colony Museum and Gift Shop in Buxton.  Scott Dawson, museum owner and author of The Lost Colony and Hatteras Island, engaged the 18 students and their teacher Jordyn Fenner with a few interactive activities during their visit, and that included an opportunity to sift through some of the residue of previous archaeological digs from a site in Buxton.  ‚ÄúWhen we do archaeology in the field, we get the big artifacts, and we catch the really small stuff through a mosquito screen so we can sift through it later,‚Äù said Dawson.  Archaeological digs have been conducted several times a year at an undisclosed Buxton site since 2009, under the guidance of renowned experts from around the globe.  The timeframe of the artifacts is determined by the layer of subterranean turf where they are found, and the bucket of small pieces that the students sifted through was from the 1610s-1640s.  Among the tiny animal teeth and fish vertebrae, the students discovered a few new treasures.  ‚ÄúThey ended up finding a musket ball, and a blue Venetian bead, and a piece of silver which we think is part of a wedding ring,‚Äù said Dawson. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not unusual to find a musket ball or a bead, but a wedding ring is something else entirely.‚Äù  The small half-sliver of metal had a portion of a setting intact, and while Dawson recognized the find as a rare ring, he contacted Professor Mark Horton of England‚Äôs University of Bristol ‚Äì one of the top archaeologists in the world ‚Äì to confirm the discovery. ‚ÄúHe wrote back and said ‚ÄòI think it could be a ring‚Äô‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs sterling silver, and that‚Äôs not something that‚Äôs Native American,‚Äù said Dawson.  ‚ÄúThe kids took [the project] very seriously, so it‚Äôs exciting that they found something so unusual.‚Äù  The Lost Colony Museum officially launched in the spring of 2023 as an initiative to share Hatteras Island‚Äôs distinctive place in the familiar story of the early English colonists.  Filled with hundreds of artifacts, documents, and interactive displays that share insights from global experts, the museum uncovers the major role that Hatteras Island and the original Croatoans had in the English‚Äôs initial visits and later colonization of America.  ‚ÄúWe should be more famous than Plymouth Rock,‚Äù said Dawson. ‚ÄúWe are Manteo‚Äôs hometown. So we‚Äôre trying to be a little more inclusive, and to tell the story from a new, native perspective.‚Äù  The museum also aims to erase a decades-old myth that no one knows what happened to the Lost Colonists of Roanoke Island, who disappeared in 1587 after carving the word ‚ÄúCROATOAN‚Äù into a palisade ‚Äì an indication that they were heading south to Hatteras Island.  Per Dawson, there were multiple English journeys to the Outer Banks prior to the Lost Colony, with the first English visitors landing in modern-day Buxton in 1584. Manteo was actually from Hatteras Island, and instead of warring with the colonists, Manteo served as an ambassador, making two trips across the pond to build relationships with the new English arrivals, and earning a Lordship in the process.  ‚ÄúThe English made multiple journeys to Hatteras Island before [the Lost Colony], so having a story where we don‚Äôt talk about what happened in 1584, 1585, and 1586 is like telling the story about the Titanic, but leaving out the iceberg,‚Äù said Dawson. ‚ÄúPeople would wonder how the Titanic sank, and would debate how it [disappeared], but it‚Äôs a fact that we already know.‚Äù  Since opening, the museum has continually expanded, with a new display case arriving soon, and donations being collected for a second display case to showcase the many local artifacts. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good problem to have when you have so many artifacts that you need two cases,‚Äù said Dawson.  And while the CHES third grade class was the very first school group to visit the museum ‚Äì making a remarkable discovery to boot in the process ‚Äì Dawson hopes that they won‚Äôt be the last.  ‚ÄúI would like for all the Dare County Schools, and any school really, to come and visit, but especially our Hatteras Island [students],‚Äù said Dawson. ‚ÄúThis is their heritage, and if they come away knowing a little bit more about how important Hatteras Island and the Croatoans were in history, it is very much worth it.‚Äù  For more information, and how you can help:

A group wedding combining "microfilms" and "musicals" was held for 52 couples on the stage of the Lingang Performing Arts Center on Saturday.  Ti Gong  A group wedding was held for 52 couples on the stage of the Lingang Performing Arts Center on Saturday.  The immersive wedding ceremony is part of the 2023 Lingang Youth Love Festival to help young people find their Mr/Mrs Right.  Ti Gong  During the ceremony, the Lingang Special Area also released the 20 measures for promoting the youth development-oriented urban areas in the Lingang Special Area.  The "20 measures" focus on enabling young people to develop faster in Lingang, and proposes 20 support measures on six aspects: employment services, innovation and entrepreneurship, housing, life services, education services and youth guidance.  Ti Gong  Ti Gong  An art installation, a huge red heart, was illuminated at the north islet of Lingang, while the newlyweds took new-energy wedding cars to embark on a wedding parade around the lake after the ceremony.    At the same time, 520 single young men and women gathered by Dishui Lake to establish connections and enhance friendships through activities.  In the future, the Lingang Special Area will launch a dating platform.  Ti Gong
