By Josh Katzowitz, WCI Content Director  Need to get caught up on the first two parts of our From Fourth Year to the Real World series? Here‚Äôs part 1 which introduces the ones we follow and part 2 which tells the tale of them transitioning from medical school to residency.  In the months before their friends and family joined together to raise a toast in appreciation and optimism, Ariel was super stressed about the party that was to celebrate the marriage between her and Danny.  It was her intern year, so her medical training was already intense and sometimes overwhelming, and the couple owe hundreds of thousands of dollars in combined student loan debt. Ariel‚Äôs father had agreed to pay for their April 2023 wedding celebration, but she was mostly the one to plan it and to try to keep it within the $80,000 budget.  Ariel felt herself in a downward spiral, caused by the stress of the party, the steep learning curve of her intern year, and the guilt that her retired father was the one paying the bills.  ‚ÄúIt was horrible,‚Äù Ariel said. ‚ÄúThe crux of the problem was the financial stress on my dad. Knowing he could handle it but still feeling bad and burdening him with such a large amount of money in such a short amount of time. I went to therapy every week in that two- or three-month time frame.‚Äù  Growing up, Ariel didn‚Äôt care about having such a grand wedding, but when her wealthy father a year earlier had given her a choice between him paying off the remainder of her medical school loans (about $90,000 worth) or an extravagant wedding, she chose the latter. In the leadup to it, she began having doubts.  ‚ÄúI thought it was such a waste of money,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIf he had paid for school, even if it was $20,000-$30,000 more, I would have been fine with it.‚Äù  Ava and Patrick also had separate awakenings this year. In the month leading up to her intern year in 2022, Ava, even with a new job and impending imposter syndrome on the horizon, was calm. You could have even described her as ‚Äúchill.‚Äù A year later, Ava can‚Äôt believe how na√Øve she had been.  Meanwhile, a year ago, Patrick‚Äôs wife had just welcomed their third child into the family, and with an enormous amount of student loan debt, a new house in a new part of the country, and a $14,000 IRS refund check that seemed to be lost in the mail, his life was full of stress‚Äîand this was even before he started his new job. Now, even with a fourth child on the way, Patrick has never been more comfortable with his financial standing and what he sees as his family‚Äôs future.  In the time since WCI last caught up with the four medical-students-turned-interns, they‚Äôve all made incredible strides in their lives, in their careers, and in their finances. Their attitudes, though, run the gamut from unprecedented comfort to unyielding burnout. For all of these interns, the last year has been filled with bumps and bruises, and yet, all of them have survived their first year of residency intact. They can all smile about it now.  The First Year of Residency  In February 2022, we started a new series called From Fourth Year to the Real World where I write about a quartet of graduating medical students who have begun their residencies.  Since they‚Äôre completely transparent with how much they owe and how much they make‚Äîand with how they‚Äôre mapping out their financial futures‚Äîwe aren‚Äôt using their real names. We check in with these newly minted doctors occasionally, and today, they‚Äôre reminiscing on their intern years and how they utilized their new resident‚Äôs salaries while, in their own words, they began learning how to adult.  Here‚Äôs a quick introduction to the ones we follow:  Ariel and Danny: This newly married couple owe close to $400,000 in student loans, and they‚Äôve just officially joined their lives (if not their financial accounts) together in matrimony. They earn about $100,000 together, and they‚Äôve come through a stressful year while maintaining their individuality.  Ava: For the first time in her life, Ava made a solid salary (she earned $60,000 as an intern, and that will bump up to $65,000 in her second year), but she‚Äôs learned plenty about herself in the past 12 months. She‚Äôs not a big spender, and the new money was nice, particularly since she doesn't have any student loan debt. But she also nearly burned herself out during her intern year.  Patrick: He won‚Äôt become an attending until he‚Äôs in his mid-30s, and Patrick owes nearly $500,000 in medical school loans. Patrick will soon be a father of four boys, and he juggles his parental responsibilities with his wife, Brittany, who makes more money than him as a nurse.  Ariel and Danny Bonded Together While Maintaining Some Separation  There‚Äôs little doubt that Ariel and Danny are comfortable with their new financial status. She‚Äôs enjoying her annual pass to one of the country‚Äôs top-notch amusement parks, and Danny bought season tickets to the local major college football program. They sit together on the couch of their $1,900-per-month apartment on this day, and they look at ease. They have jobs. They have friends. They can do what they want when they want because they have money and because they‚Äôre not currently having to pay off student loan debt.  They‚Äôre married, so they‚Äôre bonded together. But they‚Äôve maintained separate accounts. No joint checking, no joint savings, no joint brokerage account. One pays for groceries, and the other reimburses them through Zelle.  There have been discussions about possibly opening an account to which they both have access, especially now that they received $13,000 in wedding gifts (at the moment, that total is in Ariel‚Äôs account). But they eat separate dinners‚ÄîAriel will make a big batch of chicken that she then can use for lunch over the next few days; Danny is more content with a ground beef offering that he might scarf down all at once. And their money is isolated as well.  ‚ÄúHaving checks with the same name, that would be nice,‚Äù Danny thought aloud. Said Ariel: ‚ÄúMy aunts and uncles think it‚Äôs strange. But we have different habits. I‚Äôm not bothered by his. He‚Äôs not bothered by mine. We make the same amount of money. We just don‚Äôt need to put it in the same pile.‚Äù  Maybe the decision to keep their finances separate is generational. Born in the mid-1990s, they‚Äôre among the youngest millennials, and perhaps that generation is more apt to remain financially independent from their spouse. Or maybe it has something to do with how they were raised.  Danny‚Äôs father was a truck driver‚Äîhe‚Äôs still working in his mid-60s on overnight shifts‚Äîand his mom was a stay-at-home spouse before finding work as a grocery store cashier. His family didn‚Äôt have wealth. Danny worked while he was in college, and he lived at home to save money. He comes from a blue-collar upbringing.  Ariel‚Äôs father, meanwhile, was rich.  Danny made it clear before they were married that his student loan debt was his alone. He didn‚Äôt want Ariel‚Äôs money (or, indirectly, her father‚Äôs wealth) to pay off what he owed. Even though they both make the same amount of money as residents (together, they earned $98,000 as interns), they are simply more comfortable with this setup.  How and when to pay off those student loans is still a question. Thanks to the federal government‚Äôs student loan holiday and the frozen interest rates, Danny has been making $0 payments. When student loan payments resume, potentially later in 2023, he figures he‚Äôll pay about $370 per month. He‚Äôs considering trying for Public Service Loan Forgiveness. It might not be worth it for Ariel since she‚Äôs only in a three-year residency and might not want to work for the government or a nonprofit. But Danny‚Äôs residency is a year longer, and he might add on a fellowship that could take him 50%-60% of the way toward PSLF and getting his loans forgiven 10 years after he graduates from medical school.  Otherwise, the two are secure. Ariel is budgeting (and up until the wedding, she was actually sticking with it), but they‚Äôre not aggressively saving. They‚Äôre contributing to their 401(a) retirement plans‚Äîunfortunately, they‚Äôre not getting a match from their employer‚Äîand they‚Äôre contemplating opening Roth IRAs.  ‚ÄúI have a cushion now,‚Äù Danny said. ‚ÄúIf anything comes up, we can afford it. If the car goes out, we can afford it.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd we have that $13,000,‚Äù Ariel reminded.  The two have newfound financial freedom, and they don‚Äôt have to answer to anybody (not even each other). They‚Äôre joined together in matrimony, and they have separate accounts. They‚Äôve worked hard, and they‚Äôre not necessarily looking to skimp.  ‚ÄúI hear all the attendings say that we‚Äôre going to be a two-physician household,‚Äù Ariel said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs just spend the money now.‚Äô‚Äù  In a Better Spot Than Ever Before  Spending money now? Yes, Patrick knows a little something about that.  Though Patrick and his wife Brittany have maintained an emergency fund of at least $5,000 in his first year of residency, the costs continue to get more intense. Patrick grew up in a household that was always worried about money (he heard his father vomiting from stress in the middle of the night, and if he would have asked his dad for a snack at a gas station, ‚Äúthere was no way in hell that was going to happen‚Äù).  But now, he can realistically say that he‚Äôs in a more comfortable financial spot than ever before.  Patrick earned $58,500 last year (that‚Äôll increase to $64,000 for second year), and‚Äîthanks to her full-time salary, her signing bonus, and her moving stipend‚ÄîBrittany made about six figures at her nursing job in the past year. Yes, their student loan debt of $460,000 is still sitting there untouched, but Patrick hasn‚Äôt felt pinched by paying their bills and splurging on the occasional vacation.  As he‚Äôs talking, his second-oldest child is playing with the remote control to the ceiling fan, popping his head in and out of view of the computer‚Äôs camera. Patrick is working nights this week, so he‚Äôs taking care of his two youngest kids. But childcare is still expensive, and it‚Äôs about to cost the family even more when Brittany has their fourth child and transitions to part-time work in the next several months.  Their oldest child is in kindergarten, and though there‚Äôs a childcare center right in their neighborhood, that convenience costs $3,000 per month. They‚Äôve eschewed that and instead pay a babysitter $20 per hour for two of the kids and $25 if she‚Äôs watching all three. That costs them $300 per week, but even more stressful is the fact that they‚Äôve already burned through a few babysitters this year until they found the right fit.  Patrick figures he averages fewer than five hours of sleep per night with Brittany getting even less. When she‚Äôs on an overnight nursing shift, she gets home at about 8am, falls asleep by 9, and then awakens at 2pm to pick up the oldest from kindergarten.  Stress, exhaustion, and burnout? Yes, Patrick and Brittany know a little something about that.  ‚ÄúWe are burnt out,‚Äù Patrick said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not sustainable any longer.‚Äù  Patrick, though, remains appreciative and optimistic.  Although the family will lose some of her salary when Brittany transitions to part-time work, Patrick plans to moonlight as much as possible a year from now when third year begins. If he covers one inpatient unit for the weekend, he can make $2,000. Do that a couple of times per month, and he‚Äôs suddenly replaced Brittany‚Äôs income (and maybe she can even stop working altogether). Plus, when he‚Äôs a third-year, he can arrive at work an hour early and make $160 to see a new patient or $80 to follow up with one who‚Äôs already established. He can stay two extra hours after his shift and earn the same money. He can eventually conduct ED admissions while working from home and make $115 per hour through the wonders of telehealth.  ‚ÄúOnce third year rolls around, I‚Äôd be fine working from 7am to 8pm if I need to 2-3 days a week and do 2-3 weekends a month,‚Äù Patrick said. ‚ÄúIf my wife is still working, we‚Äôd have more than enough money. But it has not been nearly as stressful as I anticipated it would be. We have that surety of a stable income.‚Äù  But what about his loans? For now, it‚Äôs all in deferment, but he‚Äôll likely try for PSLF eventually. While he‚Äôs in residency and a possible fellowship, he figures he‚Äôll end up paying close to $9,000 a year. By the time he can apply for PSLF, he‚Äôs hoping about $240,000 would be forgiven.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not scaring me nearly as bad it was before,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBefore, it was this huge number; how can I attack it? But once you get looking at the attending salaries, you realize that as long as I don‚Äôt upgrade my life extravagantly, I could pay this off pretty reasonably within 5-10 years. I‚Äôll finish residency at 36, so I‚Äôd be in my 40s when I pay them off. I‚Äôd probably be getting greedy; I‚Äôd want a nicer house and a Tesla. But it‚Äôs those extravagant wants that you need to check.‚Äù  Growing up, his parents worried about where the next paycheck was coming from, and no matter how hard they worked, they didn‚Äôt have much earning potential. They didn't have much room to breathe. Patrick has a different mindset.  No. 1, he‚Äôs not scared of intense labor. In college, he worked at a moving company, and sometimes he put in 80-90 hours per week of schlepping furniture around. No. 2, he knows that in a few years, he‚Äôll be earning hundreds of thousands of dollars.  That‚Äôs why his future is so freeing.  ‚ÄúWe still have to exercise some restraint,‚Äù Patrick said. ‚ÄúThere are things we want that we‚Äôre not getting right now. But that‚Äôs different than saying, ‚ÄòShoot, the credit card bill is running up. We have to pay for this soon, but we don‚Äôt have the money.‚Äô That‚Äôs a different feeling than us saying, ‚ÄòOh, we can‚Äôt buy a hot tub yet.‚Äô‚Äù  Patrick and Brittany have never been at a point where they have this little amount of financial stress. But a new baby is coming. The mortgage on their 1,800-square foot house still needs to be paid. Diapers and baby wipes could be as much as $200 a month. Baby formula is astronomical.  Yes, Patrick, who knows residents who can earn up to $200,000 of extra income, has grand plans to moonlight as much as possible by the fall of 2024. But the specter of true physician burnout is never far away; it can still pop in and out of view before you realize what's happening. Patrick still needs to figure out a way to make space in his life to relax and spend time with his growing family. He still needs to figure out a way to breathe.  What Ava Didn‚Äôt Know About Life and Medicine  When looking back at her first year of residency, Ava takes in a deep breath, reminisces about her mindset only 11 months earlier, and exhales in wonder at how little she knew about what was to happen.  Ava was supposed to move into a newly built apartment only a few days before she started her first rotation of intern year. She was fine with that. But the move-in date kept getting pushed back, and eventually, she realized that she was going to be homeless unless she acted soon. With a week to go before she started her neuro-radiology rotation, she began frantically searching for another apartment to sublet.  The stress of her intern year never subsided.  ‚ÄúI was,‚Äù Ava says now, ‚Äúa little bit na√Øve.‚Äù  Ava grew up as a world traveler, living in wealthy countries like Oman and the UAE and in poorer areas in Bolivia and Venezuela. Her family avoided a lifestyle of big spending and they saved their money, habits that have followed Ava into her mid-20s. She‚Äôs in a better financial position than most, because thanks to a half-scholarship to medical school and her parents‚Äô willingness to cover the rest of her tuition and living expenses, she has no student loan debt.  Her parents didn‚Äôt teach her much about money, but she is still utilizing their indirect lessons on saving. She‚Äôs putting 5% of her salary into her Roth 401(k), and she gets a match from her employer. One paycheck a month goes toward paying her rent. The other is hers to spend and save. She likes seeing at least $5,000 in her checking account, so even though she might occasionally buy a $300 dress or spend $200 on a haircut, she‚Äôs still driving the same 2016 Volkswagen she‚Äôs owned since college. She‚Äôs also never had to ask her parents for money, and for that, she feels proud.  Those relatively sparse spending habits allowed her to buy a $2,000 plane ticket so she could spend a month in her native Argentina in 2022. She‚Äôs going to Mexico on vacation soon, and when we spoke, she was in the process of planning a trip to Portugal ‚Äîafter her $1,600 plane ticket, she‚Äôs budgeted $2,000 for two weeks as Ava and two of her pals drive the Iberian peninsula coast while avoiding fancy hotels and dinners.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a big spender,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never had a big budget to spend. And if I‚Äôm working 12 hours a day on six-day work weeks, I don‚Äôt have time. That‚Äôs been helpful, too.‚Äù  Well, that intense workflow has been helpful in some ways. In other ways, though, it‚Äôs forced Ava to reckon with her work-life balance and how to navigate her intern-year burnout.  ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize how sheltered I was in medical school,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMedicine is really glorified in medical school, and you start residency and you think, ‚ÄòThis isn‚Äôt as magical as I thought it was going to be.‚Äô‚Äù  This year, Ava has learned about the failures of the healthcare system; how some people don‚Äôt have access to care; the insurance costs of medicine; and how difficult it is to find, build, and sustain relationships when you‚Äôre not working. She learned a $3,000 mistake when she went to an urgent care this year for help with a gastric ulcer. She was shucked into the real world without an apartment, where she‚Äôd work long hours and then collapse into bed after she got home. Her one-year relationship with a boyfriend fell apart.  At the same time, she likes residency more than she enjoyed medical school. She‚Äôs made connections with patients. She‚Äôs been motivated by them. She‚Äôs felt rewarded by them.  ‚ÄúYou have this incredible opportunity to be by people‚Äôs side at their most vulnerable,‚Äù Ava said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs incredibly rewarding. That‚Äôs what has kept me motivated.‚Äù  Like all the fourth years who have now spent a year in the real world, Ava has grown as a doctor and learned more about herself as a person. She and Patrick battled through burnout. Ariel sought weekly therapy. Danny had to reckon with the economic help he received from his father-in-law.  They‚Äôve all lived to talk about it, and their transformation as doctors and as people since the last time we caught up with them is striking.  They‚Äôve got money in the bank. They can enjoy their lives away from work, or they‚Äôre trying their best to learn how. They‚Äôre appreciative and optimistic, and they‚Äôre grateful that the journey ‚Äîand all of the unforeseen barriers that are sure to keep coming their way ‚Äîwill continue.  Make sure to get caught up on part 1 and part 2 of our From Fourth Year to the Real World series.  [Editor's Note: For comments, complaints, suggestions, or plaudits, email Josh Katzowitz at [email protected]]

Following months of PDA-filled red carpets, Fox sparked split rumors in February when she deleted all photos of her with MGK on her social media and cryptically captioned a slideshow, ‚ÄúYou can taste the dishonesty/ it‚Äôs all over your breath.‚Äù  The couple started dating in early 2020. machinegunkelly/Instagram  The ‚ÄúTeenage Mutant Ninja Turtles‚Äù star then took off her engagement ring shortly after. DEAR MISS MANNERS: We received a last-minute virtual invitation to a wedding from a family from out of state with whom we used to be close.  They had previously advertised the wedding on social media, including the date, and we wondered if we would be invited. We weren‚Äôt, which was totally fine because of our limited budget.  Then, two weeks before the wedding date, we received an email inviting us to watch it virtually. We already had plans that night, but because we care for this family, we tried to bend things so we could watch it. Unfortunately, the video feed for the reception was all goofed up. We couldn‚Äôt really see it, and then we just got a replay reel at the end.  What would you say the suggested gift amount is in that situation?  Related Articles Advice | Miss Manners: I tried to fix the shoddy bouquet and ended up embarrassing my friend. Was I in the wrong?  Miss Manners: I tried to fix the shoddy bouquet and ended up embarrassing my friend. Was I in the wrong? Advice | Miss Manners: I want to talk about my problems, not listen to theirs  Miss Manners: I want to talk about my problems, not listen to theirs Advice | Miss Manners: What‚Äôs a polite way to make sure I get the painting when she dies?  Miss Manners: What‚Äôs a polite way to make sure I get the painting when she dies? Advice | Miss Manners: Why is it rude to wash your hands in the kitchen?  Miss Manners: Why is it rude to wash your hands in the kitchen? Advice | Miss Manners: Can I dance in the aisle while my husband sits? For a normal wedding, I think it‚Äôs $200, but that is a bit out of our league, and the whole thing was very hodgepodge. My husband wants to send $25, but I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs an insult.  GENTLE READER: It is if you send it in cash. But the monetary equivalent, in the form of an even minimally thought-out present, will be far less obvious in its intended message. Which is, of course, that a virtual wedding was not worth a higher price of admission.  DEAR MISS MANNERS: My mother has an active social life, with multiple friendships that have lasted decades. I have been assured that I have met these ladies, but that I was ‚Äújust a baby‚Äù at the time.  I have been blessed with two children in the last two years, and these kind ladies give my mother presents for my children. My mom brings some present from them practically every other week.  Some presents become a beloved favorite toy, while others miss the mark. That‚Äôs to be expected of gifts from strangers. My mom then urges me to write thank-you notes to her friends.  These are unsolicited gifts from strangers. I have two young children and I do not have the time to sit down and write thank-you notes to people I don‚Äôt know.  I feel that these gifts are actually meant for the grandmother to give the grandchild ‚Äî not for the mother and the child, with the grandmother acting as a delivery service. Thus, I feel that if my mom wants them to receive a thank-you note, she should be the one to write it.  GENTLE READER: Has it become so commonplace to explicitly solicit presents that we have become resentful when people give them spontaneously ‚Äî and for the sheer pleasure of it?  Never mind; Miss Manners knows the answer all too well.  Yes, these inconsiderate strangers are using your children as a conduit for expressing their affection for your mother. How rude.  If you really want the presents to stop, by all means, make your mother look bad and cease writing thank-you letters. But know that since the relative success rate of these presents is fairly high (although it should not matter), you will also be punishing your children.  The good news is that if you just hold out a couple more years, your children will be old enough to write the letters themselves. Then you can have the pleasure of nagging them.  Please send your questions to Miss Manners at her website, www.missmanners.com; to her email, dearmissmanners@gmail.com; or through postal mail to Miss Manners, Andrews McMeel Syndication, 1130 Walnut St., Kansas City, MO 64106.

A Southern California bride is desperately seeking the public‚Äôs help in finding her missing wedding dress.  Rebecca Nguyen of Mission Viejo is on the hunt for her wedding dress after a family member accidentally donated it to Goodwill.  Nguyen got married in 2017 and she left her wedding dress at her parents‚Äô house to keep it safe.  Her parents later divorced, and in the process of them moving, her wedding dress was accidentally donated to Goodwill in Brea.  In a Facebook post that has been shared over 2,000 times, Nguyen shared her story and pleaded for the public‚Äôs help in finding her dress.  ‚ÄúIf you have it, please consider selling it back to me,‚Äù Nguyen wrote. ‚ÄúI will pay more than you paid for it. You can even wear it for your wedding! I don‚Äôt mind sharing the joy and beauty of the dress. Please feel free to share this so I can get as many eyes on this post as possible!‚Äù  Orange County bride seeking public‚Äôs help in finding a missing wedding dress.  When Nguyen reached out to Goodwill, an employee informed her that the dress had been transferred to a different location and they have not been able to track its exact location.  The dress was originally purchased from Casablanca Bridal in Newport Beach.  Anyone who happens to come across the gown is encouraged to contact Goodwill and they will contact Nguyen.

A beautiful wedding at Meadowbrook Ranch last Saturday when Taylor Collins and Chase Bunn were married. For years I have driven past the bronze bucking horse statue as we drove to and from our Susanville ranch when the cattle were shipped to the mountains. This was the first time to be on the ranch, and it was amazing. It is much larger than what we see from Highway 36E as we drive up the hill. We were at the far eastern end of the meadow with a creek flowing past, and Angus cattle grazing in a pasture to the south of where the wedding was held. Across the creek were beautiful bluffs rising to the north.  It was an outdoor wedding, and the sun was hot at 4 p.m. but it wasn‚Äôt raining like the previous week when we were at the Junior Livestock Auction.  Years ago I attended a wedding when the bride arrived in a horse drawn carriage, however Taylor arrived in a viper red Peterbilt 389 with brushed black strips, powered by a high-torque X15 hooked to an 18-speed, a 280 inch wheelbase, and it lowered when stopped. The truck license plate was ‚ÄòMrs Cone.‚Äô Bruce and Kellie Cone of Cone Trucking, Redding, had loaned Mike Collins the beautiful truck for the wedding. Their arrival had a rhythmic sound coming from the truck. It was awesome!  For newcomers to Tehama County, grandfather Mike Collins has a truck and has hauled livestock across the nation, as well as known for the delicious meals at many brandings and social functions. Mike and Teri also have a fence building company as does the groom.  When we arrived, the guestbook on table was near a stock trailer where gifts were placed. Then we were asked to sign a cloth square for a quilt that will be made.  The officiants of the wedding ceremony were JB Stacy and James Miller. Best man was Garret Boyd, with groomsmen Jack Simonis, Jake Cunningham, Ben Urricelqui, Kent Johnson, and Zack Cunningham.  Ring bearers in white shirt, red suspenders and Levis were Meyer Cunningham and Ayker Fitze.  Maid of Honor was Sami Stabile and Matron of Honor was Alek Fitze. Bridesmaids in burgundy gowns were Kilee Birt, Macey Bunn, Madison Waelty and Courtny Grames.  Three little girls in white dresses were the flower girls. The tiniest was Stevi Birt, daughter of Brian and Lynsie Collins Birt, with Quincy and Karsyn Cunningham, cousins of the groom.  Taylor is the daughter of Jenifer and Bryon Waelty. She has been a Chamber Ambassador and I see her at Good Morning Red Bluff each month. She works at Summit Funding.  Chase is son of Wade and Gwen Bunn, and has Bunn Fencing.  There were many children at the wedding and there was a Bounce House for them to enjoy, while we enjoyed beverages or bottled water in the shade.  When Linda Walker and I started to bring our chairs over to the shade. James Boyd rescued us and carried the chairs.  Our table was near the dance floor and bridal table, where I had an opportunity to visit with Mike‚Äôs 93-year-old aunt Joy White from Yuma, Arizona. Guests at the wedding had also come from Florida, Oklahoma, Nevada, Colorado, Idaho and multiple other states.  Mike‚Äôs kitchen crew prepared the delicious beef dinner. Taylor and Chase greeted each guest as they handed the dinner plates to usWhat a clever idea, to be able to greet everyone and we could say ‚ÄúCongratulations‚Äù to them!  It was a beautiful wedding.  Teri Collins used social media to express her thoughts and say thank you.  ‚Äú‚ÄùThe Lord saw fit to bless us in so many ways, that we would like to take the opportunity to Thank some of the most amazing people for helping bring Taylor & Chase Bunn‚Äôs day from a drawing on paper to reality‚Ä¶.to the cooking crew that kept their promise to Taylor for keeping Mike out of an apron: Tony & Linette, Casey & Clint aka Big Fella, Larry & Dolores, John & Candie, Greg & Jenny, Roy & Casey, Alex, Katlin, Amy, Nichole, Felicia & John. Last but not least, Lee Shope for everything he did the whole week before the big day. The Cline family for giving us one of the most beautiful places in Red Bluff to celebrate a dream come true. Thank you Brian Birt for doing everything you could to bring Taylor‚Äôs day full circle. Thank you to Shanna & Dusty deBraga for sharing your wonderful table tops, bridal party table & bar. Kellie & Bruce Cone for sharing such an amazing work of art, Clifford, the Red Truck. We are truly Blessed to have such amazing people in our lives. Being able to share this day with so many wonderful friends & family from Nevada, Oklahoma, Colorado, Oregon, and places that I probably don‚Äôt even know about, not to mention all those friends & family right here in California is truly a blessing. From ages, 93 to just a few months old. The weather started out a bit warm, but ended amazing. A big shout out to Scott Stabile, Merak & a buddy for picking up the chairs before they left for the night. With all that said, I hope I didn‚Äôt hurt any feelings for forgetting them. Thank you again to each & every one that shared the day with us in every single way possible.‚Äù‚Äù

It won't be too much longer before Conor McGregor gets married to long-term partner Dee Devlin and fans have long been intrigued as to what sort of wedding the Irish couple will decide to have.  McGregor is currently the richest MMA fighter in the world, which means that if anyone can throw a lavish wedding to catch the eye then it is him.  'McGregor Forever': UFC star drops trailer for highly anticipated series about his life  He is also known for ensuring all the attention is on him and his lifestyle at any given time, so that is another reason to think it could be a pretty jaw-dropping wedding.  Are Conor McGregor and Dee Devlin married?  Fiancee Dee Devlin has played a huge role in McGregor's successful fighting career and will, of course, have her own say as to what kind of wedding the pair have.  They first met back in 2008 and have now got three children together. It wasn't until 2020 that McGregor finally popped the question and they have been planning their wedding since then, although the coronavirus pandemic hasn't helped.  Conor McGregor's wedding update  Conor McGregor has now discussed the upcoming wedding, of which details have been fairly sparse.  "My wedding is going to be extravagant, that's for damn sure," he said in an interview with Extra TV.  "We are going to have the best of the best of the best, and then more to the best.  "We have got to find the location, but it's going to be Ireland, I'm going to get married in the Emerald Isle, and then figure it out, so it's a big process.  "Let's see what happens, I'm ready for it all."  The key detail there is that the pair will be getting married in Ireland rather than in the USA.  As for the exact date and guest list, this still has to be worked out, but eventually the pair will tie the knot at what will be one of the biggest wedding parties in years.

Doug Stout  Guest Columnist  On June 17, 1919, First Lieutenant Frederick Fleek Wright boarded the U.S.S. Antigone at the port of St. Nazaire, France for his return to the United States. He arrived in New York on June 28. On July 29, he received his discharge from the Army and returned to his job at the First National Bank in Newark.  On Monday evening, Jan. 24, 1921, Frederick married Mary Elizabeth Carl at the Second Presbyterian Church in Newark. ‚ÄúThe bride,‚Äù according to The Newark Advocate, ‚Äúis the only daughter of Mr. Louis F. Carl of West Church Street. She was a student at Ward Belmont school [in] Nashville, Tennessee.‚Äù  Mary‚Äôs mother, Fannie, had passed away but was from a well-known family in Newark. Fannie was born in Newark in 1866 to Eli and Jemima Hull. Eli became a major developer in Newark. She had a much older brother who was a minister, and a younger sister that the Hulls had adopted, Laura Mae. Laura married William Wehrle, the cofounder of the Wehrle Stove Company.  In 1888, Fannie married Louis Carl. Louis was employed by the Logan Gas Company and eventually became the head of that business. Mary was born in 1898, their only child.  Tragedy struck the family 10 years later when they were living at 116 West Church Street. Fannie was raking and burning leaves in the yard when her dress caught fire. She was severely burned and died of her injuries on Dec. 17, 1908, just two days before her 20th wedding anniversary. According to family historian Gill Miller, ‚ÄúLittle Mary was, of course, in the custody of her father, but was cared for by mother‚Äôs sister, ‚ÄòAunt Laura Wehrle,‚Äô who had had only one child who died immediately post-birth in 1905.‚Äù  But Mary and Frederick's wedding day in 1921 was a happy one, according to the article that covered the prestigious families in the social column of The Advocate.  The colors for the wedding were described as a ‚Äúdeftly harmonizing rainbow‚Äù with ‚Äúcolors [of] green, gold and lavender. The altar was banked with a profusion of gorgeous palms and ferns, while large garlands of southern smilax were used in every available space. Loops of the smilax caught on the pews outlining the aisles. In the bower of greenery on the altar, candlelight glowed from numerous tall silver candle sticks. The bridal gown was of white chiffon velvet, fashioned with the short skirt and [a] full-length panel train that was caught at the shoulders. The only trimming was a touch of real lace. A great shower of a bouquet of orchids, lilies of the valley, and white sweet peas completed the costume.‚Äù  The family names mentioned in the column were a veritable who‚Äôs who of Licking County at the time.  The newlyweds left for the East Coast and took a ship to Europe. According to their passport application, the couple planned to return in about six months. They listed the countries that they wanted to see as Italy, Spain, Greece and France. Turkey was also listed but appears to have been crossed out.  The trip seems to have been successful. In March of 1922, the Wrights presented a program to the ‚ÄúMonday Talks‚Äù club at the library where Frederick was to present on, ‚ÄúThe Mediterranean Trip,‚Äù while Mary provided ‚Äúmusical selections.‚Äù  The trip also produced a son, Frederick Wehrle Wright. He was born in Newark on Dec. 3, 1921. Unbeknownst to the family, ‚ÄúLittle Frederick,‚Äù as he was known, would be the next soldier in the family.  Doug Stout is the Local History Coordinator for the Licking County Library. You may contact him at 740-349-5571 or dstout@lickingcountylibrary.org. His book "Never Forgotten: The Stories of Licking County Veterans" is available for purchase at the library or online at bookbaby.com & Amazon.com

CLEVELAND, Ohio ‚Äì I received this letter from Steve (not his real name):  ‚ÄúWe have been planning my youngest daughter‚Äôs wedding for the past year. A month before the wedding ‚Äì on the plane home from her bachelorette party ‚Äì she received a text message from a woman informing her that her fianc√© has been cheating on her. Wedding canceled.  ‚ÄúMy daughter‚Äôs heart is broken in half. Our family devastated. Her friends devastated. Wedding guests informed. Thousands of dollars in wedding expenses non-refundable. There are worse things, but this is hard. We will support and love our daughter to get through it.‚Äù  As I read Steve‚Äôs email, my first thought was, ‚ÄúWas the woman who texted the report of cheating telling the truth?‚Äù  I emailed Steve for more information. He wrote:  ‚ÄúThe text was from the woman my daughter‚Äôs fianc√© cheated with. We have since found out she contacted my daughter because she was trying to ‚Äòdo the right thing.‚Äô The fiance‚Äô told her his real name, so she curiously looked looked him up on Facebook and saw he was engaged to my daughter.‚Äù  THE COST OF A WEDDING  I called Reverend John Lentz of Forest Hill Presbyterian Church in Cleveland Heights, and read him Steve‚Äôs emails.  ‚ÄúMy heart breaks for her and her father,‚Äù said Lentz. ‚ÄúThey obviously did the right thing calling it off. That can be hard, because some of these elaborate weddings are planned two years in advance. It‚Äôs a huge industry and can be very expensive.‚Äù  Canceling a wedding can lead to embarrassment and a financial loss, even if it‚Äôs for all the right reasons.  A story by cleveland.com‚Äôs Jane Morice states the average cost of a wedding nationally is $30,000. In Ohio, it‚Äôs $26,000.  Lentz insists meeting with couples for counseling before he marries them. A few times, it was clear one of the people had substance-abuse problems.  ‚ÄúI refused to do the wedding,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI pushed for the person to go into counseling.‚Äù  Some of the couples didn‚Äôt get married. A few did, and it was disaster.  IN LOVE WITH THE IDEA OF A WEDDING  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no such thing as a perfect couple,‚Äù Lentz said. ‚ÄúBut there are obvious warning signs, and too often people ignore them. When there is physical, substance and other forms of abuse, you can‚Äôt go through with the with wedding.‚Äù  Steve‚Äôs daughter was already sharing an apartment with her supposed husband-to-be. They were splitting the rent. She convinced him to move out, and now she pays the rent. The temptation would be to get married anyway, or at least keep living together.  ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt marry someone unless you can trust them,‚Äù said Bishop Roger Gries. ‚ÄúSo many times, I‚Äôve sat through sessions with a couple where one person believes, ‚ÄòI can change him.‚Äô Or the person thinks, ‚ÄòAfter we get married, she‚Äôll change.‚Äô People do that more often than you‚Äôd think.‚Äù  If a couple is fighting with each other and their families about nearly every detail of the wedding, that‚Äôs also a piercing warning siren.  ‚ÄúThey have these destination weddings,‚Äù said Gries. ‚ÄúI was asked to do a wedding on a Florida beach. I refused. Most of the family couldn‚Äôt afford to attend. The wedding should be about a man and woman coming together, growing together, helping each other. Start praying with each other before you‚Äôre married ‚Äì and then keep praying. God needs to be in the center of it.‚Äù  Don‚Äôt be in love with all the trappings and fantasies involved in the wedding. You can spend months, even a year, planning it ‚Äì and it‚Äôs over almost faster than you say, ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù  Gries has been a priest for 60 years. He says people can‚Äôt worry about how it looks or what others will think if they realize they need to back out of the marriage.  The big point of this story: It‚Äôs not the wedding that‚Äôs life-changing, it‚Äôs the marriage.  READERS: As I was writing this column, I was stunned by the cost of a wedding. Can you tell me what you‚Äôve paid for your own or for someone in your family? How about destination weddings? I‚Äôll use some of your feedback for my next column. I need your full name to be used in the story.  Please send comments to terrypluto1234@gmail.com  - Read more of Terry Pluto‚Äôs columns.  TERRY PLUTO‚ÄôS FAITH & YOU COLUMNS  Readers have lots of ideas about tipping:  What does our tipping say about us and our faith?  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel like it!‚Äù The battle with our feelings and how to win it.  Easter and feeling like ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt forgive myself!‚Äù  Think before saying: ‚ÄúGod won‚Äôt give you more than you can handle.‚Äù  The Arizona Desert, Bruce Springsteen and experiencing God  How should we show our faith at work? COLUMBIA, S.C. (AP) - Aric Hutchinson wishes he could remember the crash, but he said he does remember his bride‚Äôs last words to him before the golf cart carrying them along a South Carolina beach road from their wedding reception was hit by a car driven by a woman who authorities say was drunk.  ‚ÄúThe last thing I remember her saying was she wanted the night to never end,‚Äù he said in an interview broadcast Friday by ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúGood Morning America.‚Äù  The bride, Samantha Miller, 34, was killed in the April 28 crash and Hutchinson and two other passengers were injured. A toxicology report showed the driver of the car, Jamie Lee Komoroski, 25, had a blood alcohol level of 0.261 ‚Äî over three times the legal limit. She is charged with reckless vehicular homicide and three counts of driving under the influence causing death or great bodily injury. Komoroski is currently being held without bond at a local jail, according to Charleston County Sheriff‚Äôs Office online records.  In a statement, Komoroski‚Äôs defense attorneys, Chris Gramiccioni, Deb Gramiccioni and Nathan Williams, asked the public not to rush to judgment.  ‚ÄúOur court system is founded upon principles of justice and mercy and that is where all facts will come to light,‚Äù they said.  Hutchinson said he remembers waking up in the hospital and knowing something was wrong when he saw his mother‚Äôs face.  ‚ÄúI asked her, ‚ÄòWhere‚Äôs Sam? Where‚Äôs Sam?‚Äô and that‚Äôs when she told me there was an incident and that Sam didn‚Äôt make it,‚Äù he recalled.  Hutchinson remembers Miller‚Äôs calmness on their wedding night despite all the stresses of wedding planning. Family and friends came from all over the country and everyone, including Miller, was so happy.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still trying to wrap my head around it, that night, going from an all-time high to an all-time low,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty rough to try to comprehend.‚Äù  Being back at the home he and Miller shared is hard, ‚Äúbut also nice,‚Äù Hutchinson said.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs got Sam written all over the house,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs nice to be here and have good memories.‚Äù  Hutchinson said he doesn‚Äôt have anything to say to Komoroski at this time.  ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt right now,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to. I mean, she stole an amazing human being that should not have been taken.‚Äù  In addition to the criminal case, Komoroski faces a wrongful death lawsuit alongside several businesses accused of overserving her on the night of the crash.  Four bars gave ‚Äúcopious amounts of alcohol‚Äù to a ‚Äúvisibly intoxicated‚Äù woman ‚Äî Komoroski ‚Äî last month before she drove 40 mph (64 kph) over the speed limit into a golf cart carrying the couple away from their wedding reception, according to a new lawsuit filed Wednesday by Hutchinson and his relatives.  A taqueria that had recently hired Komoroski is accused of negligence and recklessness. An unnamed Taco Boy supervisor coerced the new server into consuming ‚Äúa dangerous amount of alcohol‚Äù at an employee function before the crash, according to the complaint.  In a statement on its website, Taco Boy denied that an ‚Äúofficially organized employee function around drinking‚Äù occurred. The statement said video footage, staff interviews and sales receipts confirm that Komoroski, who has since been fired, did not enter the restaurant on the day of the accident. It's a happy ending for a woman in Buckingham County who was going through a bride's worst nightmare - a missing wedding ring. With the help of social media, she was reunited with her ring in Lynchburg on Saturday.  Casey Johnson and her family were on a Mother's Day getaway in Virginia Beach last weekend when she lost her wedding ring in the sand.  "My daughter wanted me to walk her down to the water, so I stood up, and just not thinking, brushed the sand off my hands, and right when I did, I felt my ring fly right off," said Johnson. "We sat there for hours just hands and knees raking through the sand trying to find it, eventually we just gave up," she added.  PHOTOS:    Billy Robb and Michelle Salisbury of Bedford County were helping Johnson look for her ring. They didn't have any luck when they were all looking together, but Robb and Salisbury decided to give it another go a few hours later.  "I just thought, you know, I'm gonna walk by where they was, you know, and just happened to look, and she was walking up to me [Salisbury], and I literally looked down and I seen it right away," recounted Robb.  They immediately searched for Johnson up and down the downtown area of Virginia Beach, but couldn't find her. They thought, might as well try to spread the word using TikTok.  "And I said, you know, well it's a shot in the dark but by why not, crazier things have happened," said Salisbury. "I posted it and the next day it just started going crazy," she said.  SEE ALSO:  Click here to watch .  Nearly 500,000 views later, it finally made its way to Johnson.    "My mother-in-law sent me Michelle's TikTok and it was just amazing that she found it and went to that extent to give it back to me and I'm really thankful for her," Johnson shared.  "It was such a good feeling to finally reunite with my ring. I didn't think I would ever get it back," she said.

Weddings are expensive, and not just for the bride and groom.  As more couples choose to go all out on their nuptials, the average guest will spend $611 on travel and accommodations, gifts and special-occasion attire and preparation this year, according to a recent report by Bankrate.com. Wedding gifts alone average $180.  "Like just about everything else, inflation and higher interest rates are taking a toll on wedding attendees," said Ted Rossman, Bankrate's senior industry analyst.  More from Personal Finance:  Credit card debt nears $1 trillion  How to get started with investing, budgeting  How much emergency savings you really need  At a time when many households are already stretched thin, every "yes" RSVP poses a potential financial strain.  About 21% of wedding guests feel pressured to spend more than they comfortably are able to, and 18% must lean on credit cards just to attend, Bankrate found.  According to a separate survey by LendingTree, 40% of those who attended a wedding in the past five years have taken on debt to cover the cost.  For members of the wedding party, it's even costlier: Nearly two-thirds, or 62%, have spent more than they could afford to celebrate with the bride and groom, and 32% went at least $500 in the red, LendingTree found.

Last weekend at Paul Choi and Ashley Austin Morris‚Äôs wedding in a little stone church on Roosevelt Island, there was the sort of giddiness in the air that you might expect to find at an actual island destination wedding. That‚Äôs because most of their guests, despite years of living in New York City, had never stepped foot onto Roosevelt Island, the residential waterfront Manhattan community sitting in the East River.  ‚ÄúI took the cable tram here once and then I went right back,‚Äù said David Wodka, a groomsman. ‚ÄúI never thought there was anything noteworthy on Roosevelt Island. But now that I‚Äôm here, I can see why they picked this venue. It‚Äôs beautiful, and you can see people jet skiing on the water.‚Äù  The ceremony was held at the Sanctuary, a wedding and events venue that took over this old church on the island‚Äôs north side over two years ago, rescuing it from ruin. With a leafy outdoor dining space that offers a plumb view of Manhattan‚Äôs skyline and an Instagrammable concrete pier that juts out into the East River, the Sanctuary has since become an unlikely matrimonial hot spot. Its pitch is that it is a destination wedding within city limits, reachable via a scenic tram ride from Midtown for the cost of a MetroCard swipe.

Courtney Sneddon, 26, a personal assistant based in Edinburgh, let her hair grow for two years in anticipation of her wedding in November 2022. ‚ÄúI was counting down to when I could cut it off for my honeymoon,‚Äù she said. But when Ms. Sneddon‚Äôs hairstylist, Christopher Laird, offered a mid-wedding cut instead, she thought, ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù Ms. Sneddon added: ‚ÄúIt was either this or another dress, and since I wanted a cut anyway, it was an easy decision.‚Äù  While guests enjoyed dessert, Ms. Sneddon sneaked away with Mr. Laird, who cut and styled her long, straight hair into a soft and wavy collarbone-length bob in just 20 minutes. ‚ÄúThe first thing she did after we cut it was head to the dance floor and headbang,‚Äù Mr. Laird recalled. ‚ÄúShe felt amazing, fierce and really liberated.‚Äù  Olivia Lopez, 26, a labor and delivery nurse in Edmond, Okla., opted to change both her outfit and her hair for her wedding last August. Ms. Lopez stole away for a few minutes during dinner, swapping her dress for a white sequin jumpsuit and her long ponytail for a wavy, shoulder-length bob.  ‚ÄúMy husband knew I was changing into a different outfit for the reception but had no idea I planned to chop my hair off, too,‚Äù said Ms. Lopez, adding that her husband, Luis Lopez, 28, who oversees alumni engagement and fundraising for Oklahoma Christian University, was stunned by her transformation. ‚ÄúI was completely caught off guard,‚Äù Mr. Lopez said. ‚ÄúOlivia looked gorgeous. It was such a memorable moment.‚Äù

Uttarakhand: The wedding invitation card of a BJP leader‚Äôs daughter has gone viral on social media. The reason for that is that the daughter of BJP leader Yash Pal Beynam of the Pauri region of Uttarakhand is ready to marry a Muslim youth.  The marriage invitation of Beynam‚Äôs daughter has attracted attention on social media, and BJP supporters and netizens have expressed their objection.  Hindutva group has trolled former MLA Beynam. According to the report, criticism has been expressed on the internet about someone else accusing someone else of marrying a Muslim youth as love jihad.  The movie ‚ÄúThe Kerala Story‚Äù has been given tax exemption in BJP-ruled states where the daughter of a BJP leader is getting married to a Muslim youth. A Facebook user has expressed his displeasure that such dual policies by the BJP will weaken the morale of the party workers.  BJP leaders and activists of right-wing organisations had accused Muslim youths of converting Hindu women by marrying them and termed it ‚Äúlove jihad.  There is a lot of discussion about conversion in India. But the BJP leaders are throwing their daughter away to Muslim youth. It is reported that a member of the Pauri temple management board said that the Vishwa Hindu Parishad and Bajrang Dal should oppose this.  Beynam‚Äôs daughter‚Äôs wedding will be held on May 28. BJP and Congress leaders have been invited to this wedding event, reports said.

Not only are this bride and groom from opposite ends of Ireland, but they also travelled to the opposite end of the globe to meet.  Sin√©ad O'Leary, from Killarney, County Kerry, and Brian McGrenaghan, from Larahirl, Culdaff, County Donegal, happened to be living in Australia when their paths crossed in Coogee, Sydney, in January 2015.  Sin√©ad O'Leary and Brian McGrenaghan at Muckross Abbey  And it was during a summer stroll, back in the bride's home town, that they got engaged, four years later, on the shores of Lough Leane. ‚ÄúIt was a beautiful warm sunny day and we took a walk with our daughter Lyla-Rose, who was almost two at the time, and our son Jack, who was only eight weeks old,‚Äù says Sin√©ad. ‚ÄúBrian had the ring box tucked away under his jumper and when I was admiring the view he got down on one knee and asked me to marry him.‚Äù  Sin√©ad O'Leary and Brian McGrenaghan with their wedding party  That June proposal led to a November wedding, three years later, as they exchanged vows a little further along the road, in the Muckross Park Hotel & Spa, holding their reception in the same five-star venue.  Killarney National Park created the picture-perfect on their big day, which was precisely what the couple wanted, as they could pay tribute to the bride's father, the late Paudie O'Leary, in a special way.  Sin√©ad O'Leary with Donnchadh O‚ÄôLeary, Lyla-Rose McGrenaghan, Stacey MacSweeney, Sueanne Bedggood, Muireann O‚ÄôLeary and Naomi O‚ÄôConnor  Nearby Muckross Abbey was one of the most important locations to which their wedding photographer, Miche√°l O‚ÄôSullivan, (osullivanphotographyirl.com), led the bride and groom for their photoshoot. ‚ÄúMy dad was the head park ranger for many years in the Killarney National Park and is also buried in Muckross Abbey so this was a very special place for us, as we felt we had my dad‚Äôs presence with us in spirit on our wedding day,‚Äù says the bride.  Those who played a key role in the ceremony and celebrations were the bride‚Äôs mother, Geraldine O'Leary, and the groom‚Äôs parents, Margaret and Brian McGrenaghan.  Sin√©ad O'Leary and Brian McGrenaghan at Muckross Abbey  "My lovely brother, Donnchadh O'Leary, walked me down the aisle," says Sin√©ad.  The couple‚Äôs daughter, Lyla-Rose McGrenaghan, was their flowergirl; and their sons, Jack and Killian McGrenaghan, were their pageboys.  Sin√©ad‚Äôs friend, Stacey MacSweeney, was her chief bridesmaid, while her sister, Sueanne Bedggood, and Muireann O‚ÄôLeary joined forces with another friend, Naomi O‚ÄôConnor, to take on bridesmaid duties.  Sin√©ad O'Leary and Brian McGrenaghan with Margaret and Brian McGrenaghan and Geraldine O'Leary and Donnchadh O‚ÄôLeary  Brian‚Äôs friend, Christopher Gibbons, was by his side as his best man while his friend, Phil McElhinney, was groomsman along with his brother, Sean McGrenaghan, and nephew, Sean Donaghy.  The couple wanted their wedding to have ‚Äúan outdoor feel inside with seasonal flowers and fauna‚Äù. ‚ÄúWith it being a winter wedding we wanted candles to bring warmth into the reception and ceremony and deer antlers as a representation of my dad and the national park,‚Äù adds the bride.  Sin√©ad O'Leary and Brian McGrenaghan with their wedding party in Muckross Abbey  What made the occasion extra-memorable was that they could share it with family and friends, adds Sin√©ad, in particular, ‚Äúour three beautiful children‚Äù.  Sin√©ad looked elegant in Spanish bridal label Pronovias, which she sourced in Sydney and the bridal hair and makeup were by Joanne Henderson and Sandra Flynn.  Sin√©ad O'Leary with Lyla-Rose McGrenaghan Stacey MacSweeney, Sueanne Bedggood, Muireann O‚ÄôLeary and Naomi O‚ÄôConnor  The groom and his party were dapper thanks to Esquire Formal Wear, Co Derry.  ‚ÄúOur son Jack, who was three-and-a-half at the time, didn't want to wear his wedding shoes. He wanted to wear his work boots ‚Äî ‚Äòlike Daddy's workboots‚Äô!‚Äù says Sin√©ad.  Sin√©ad O'Leary and Brian McGrenaghan at Muckross Abbey  ‚ÄúI really would not have cared really once Jack was happy but he wore the wedding shoes in the end.‚Äù Brendan Reidy, videographer, was also behind the lens, while Tie the Knot Weddings created the floral arrangements.  ‚ÄúWe have yet to go on a honeymoon ‚Äî not easy with three small kids! ‚Äî but the honeymoon can wait for now!‚Äù jokes the bride. ‚ÄúWe only moved home from Australia almost a year ago and are currently based in Donegal. We will see what the future holds for us as to where we will end up living.‚Äù  Sin√©ad O'Leary and Brian McGrenaghan with their wedding party  If you would like your wedding featured in Weekend email eve.kelliher@examiner.ie

Tina Rae's coffee cart at the wedding that ended up at the Disputes Tribunal.  A bride who took her wedding caterer to the Disputes Tribunal said she received platters two hours late, was left with just one scantily-clad waitress serving 100 people and ‚Äúcountless excuses‚Äù.  The caterer, Tina Rae, feels she's been unfairly criticised online but is getting out of the wedding business for good.  Her business has 20 one-star reviews accusing her of cancelling events at the last minute, or providing sub-par platters.  Rae bought Fare Food Boutique Co, which provides catering services from a coffee cart, in October.  She was hired by the bride to provide food platters, some drinks, and bar services for her wedding on February 3 at a cost of $2000.  Supplied/Supplied Tina Rae's coffee cart at the wedding that ended up at the Disputes Tribunal.  After the wedding, bride Aleshia Scott posted a critical Google review and went to the Disputes Tribunal to seek a $1500 refund. She said Rae did not provide the services she paid for with reasonable care and skill.  The referee agreed and ordered Rae to pay before June 11. Rae said she was asking for a rehearing because repeated phone calls from the tribunal referee did not connect.  In a counterclaim, Rae sought $3500 for stress and derogatory comments she alleged caused her to lose work. The referee dismissed Rae‚Äôs claim because the tribunal did not have jurisdiction to hear it.  In her decision, the referee said she tried to call Rae‚Äôs cellphone number seven times over 35 minutes to connect her to the hearing, but Rae did not answer. The absence of one party does not prevent a hearing going ahead.  The referee said she accepted Scott‚Äôs ‚Äústraightforward and plausible‚Äù evidence.  Supplied/Supplied Scott‚Äôs bridesmaid, sister-in-law and celebrant having to work the bar.  Scott told the hearing she arranged for Rae to bring out platters for her guests at 4pm, but they didn't arrive until nearly 6pm, when the guests were about to start their main meal.  She had paid for three bar staff for six hours, but just one staff member was on site for several hours and they did not seem competent, resulting in her family feeling they needed to step in and serve drinks themselves, she said.  ‚ÄúI actually just had to try my hardest to ignore it, everyone told me not to worry but my bridesmaid, sister-in-law and celebrant had to work the bar,‚Äù Scott told Stuff.  Scott said she had put everything in writing for Rae so that the day would run as smoothly as possible and there would be no room for faults.  Glassware was not cleared away from tables as promised, and drink dispensers, barista-made coffee, tea, ice, lawn games, a dessert platter, a candy station and a generator were not provided as arranged, the referee said.  She acknowledged Rae had ‚Äúresourcing and illness issues‚Äù, but said it was her responsibility to have backup plans to deliver what she promised.  Scott‚Äôs Google review included issues with the way Rae‚Äôs staff were dressed, and Rae leaving with her daughter for two hours without telling anyone.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs already a stressful day to begin with and to have my grandparents come up and ask me why that girl was dressed like that, it was embarrassing,‚Äù Scott told Stuff.  ‚ÄúOne of the young girls was wearing short shorts, a crop top and a crop top/bar and were all rude to the guests, we had many complain to us about their attire and their attitudes,‚Äù she wrote in the review.  Rae told Stuff she answered the referee‚Äôs calls but couldn‚Äôt hear anything, so asked for a rehearing.  Rae said, and put in a statement to the tribunal, that the wedding did not go as planned because two staff were sick with Covid and her daughter, who was one of the backup wait staff, started to feel very unwell in the extreme heat that day and she had to take her to hospital. The person who did work was called in at the last minute and had no time to dress differently.  She alleged some of the wedding guests were drunk and rude to the worker.  Supplied Rae was to provide bar services for guests, but sickness meant she was short-staffed. (File photo)  Rae told Stuff she agreed to stay two hours later to make up for the time she spent taking her daughter to hospital and was unable to do a hen party also booked for that night.  ‚ÄúLots of different things went wrong. It‚Äôs not an excuse, it‚Äôs just what happened. It‚Äôs been an absolute palaver. I will never do any other wedding ever, not even for friends.‚Äù  While she gave the hen party a full refund, she said the guests all went online to give her one-star reviews, which, along with Scott‚Äôs Google review, prompted another upcoming bride to cancel. The contract meant she was not entitled to get her non-refundable deposit back, Rae said.  That bride, Monique Sara, told Stuff she cancelled because she lost faith in Rae‚Äôs ability to provide the service she expected. She said she booked Rae based on photographs she saw of the platters online, which were taken before Rae bought the business.  ‚ÄúIt looked incredible but by the looks of things it was an old owner,‚Äù Sara said.  UNSPLASH Rae failed to provide platters for a 70th wedding anniversary at short notice but did pay a refund. (File photo)  Amanda Rait said she paid Rae $375* for two platters for her grandparents 70th wedding anniversary in January. However, Rae cancelled three-and-a-half hours before the event, which caused stress and disappointment. She received a full refund eventually, she said.  Rae said she had to cancel that event because she was assaulted the night before by people trying to steal her carts. She had two coffee carts previously and an ice cream cart that she bought and resold. She now hoped to sell the Fare Food Boutique Co cart and buy a smaller one to continue a smaller-scale coffee business.  Rae said the bad reviews had prompted rude messages and comments all over social media ‚Äì ‚Äúso much so we have ceased all business‚Äù.  ‚ÄúSo currently there is no way of being able to pay anyone due to the online harassment and dressing down,‚Äù she said.  *A previous version of this story incorrectly said Amanda Rait paid $750 when she paid $375.

Need help getting those wedding guest ‚Äòfits lined up? We‚Äôve got you.  Many social calendars are overflowing with celebrations this summer as the wedding boom kicks into high gear and couples are back on track throwing multi-day celebrations. When it comes to wedding guest dressing in 2023, not only do you need an outfit to wear to one event, but possibly two or three. That means you‚Äôll do yourself a favour if you start your pursuit to find looks for these events, like, now.  Taking cues from the season‚Äôs top fashion trends, from tailored suits to floral dresses and cut-out designs, we‚Äôve put together 20 perfect wedding guest outfits that you‚Äôll be able to wear again and again, plus 5 essential accessories to finish off your look.  The floral dress  Colours are bold, patterns are simple or statement. This season, flower patterns are in full bloom.  The retro chintz Laura Ashley fabric and the modern drop sleeve design make this dress a dream.  The easy silhouette and light cotton fabric of this toile de jouy garden-print dress makes it a beautiful yet comfortable choice. Pair it with whimsical Mary Janes or a block-heel knotted sandal.  This slinky column gown is the epitome of elegance. Our favourite statement detail: shoulder bows with trailing tails.  If you love a bold print, this colourful, curve-hugging dress is a perfect choice. This dress is also beautifully size inclusive, available in sizes XS to 2X.  Our new obsession at Simons is its collection of pieces made with Liberty of London fabrics. This floral shirt dress is lovely for a casual garden or lakeside wedding party.  The cut-out dress  This is the way to flash a little skin in a subtle, alluring way.  This dress feels very mermaid-chic, a vibe that is definitely trending. The seafoam shade and ruffled skirt are so ethereal, and the side cutouts show just a sliver of skin.  This sweet pink midi dress with spaghetti straps and a bodice bow detail is a fashion classic and a piece you will be wearing for event seasons to come.  We love the lightweight linen fabric of this dress as well as the rich crimson colour. It‚Äôs perfect for a summer or early fall wedding‚Äîwrap up with a cozy pashmina when the nights get cooler.  From influencer Sarah Nicole Landry‚Äôs new collab with Reitmans, this two-piece top and skirt set is a super chic way to wear the cut-out trend.  This sleek sage-hued jersey dress not only looks like a knockout, but is an incredibly cost-conscious buy.  The suit  Power dressing has spilled over into wedding guest attire. We love a colourful suit that can be sleek, or a little slouchy.  This Tencel suit is super-soft and has a beautiful draped cut. Pair it with white mules for a look that‚Äôs pure quiet luxury.  Men‚Äôs suiting experts Indochino have launched a women‚Äôs line of made-to-measure pieces and this bold yellow double-breasted suit is a standout style.  This boxy suit is giving the best ‚Äô90s vibes. The poppy pink shade make this suit a star and a perfect choice for casual cool or more formal elevated events‚Äîjust switch up your accessories.  This wide-leg poplin jumpsuit is finished with the most perfect shoulder bows! It‚Äôs available in four stellar shades: lilac, marigold, denim and black and comes in a wide range of sizes.  Navy is always a crisp and cool colour choice for a wedding. This easy linen suit is a smart buy that can take you from a wedding day to a business event to date night.  The maxi dress  A longer midi or maxi style always looks elegant and can strike a more casual or formal note.  The Camden dress features a sleek strapless design with a cut-out back detail. The satin fabric drapes beautifully and it‚Äôs available in a range of solid shades and patterns like this abstract floral motif.  This knife-pleat batwing sleeve dress brings the drama. It‚Äôs also one of the brand‚Äôs signature Curve styles which means it‚Äôs available in a wide range of sizes.  Hill House Home‚Äôs iconic nap dresses have become synonymous with fresh summer style. The Ellie midi dress is a fan favourite and we love it for a destination beach wedding or brunch celebration.  This pretty pink ruffled gown is so easy to wear and the fabric has a beautiful swooshing effect when you move. It will look amazing on the dance floor as you boogie into the wee hours.  If you love a black gown but crave a little added interest, this Alessia dress from Ba&Sh is a gorgeous as it gets. The metallic pattern and open back line are simply stunning.  Essential wedding guest accessories  Five fashionable extras that pair well with every look  The Large Dome Croissant Hoops are a favourite of The Kit editors‚Äîwe love them for their versatility and bold design. These work with almost anything you can imagine.  Beloved Canadian shoe brand Poppy Barley has just introduced its first wedding collection and we are smitten. The Esther heeled sandal is a stunner and in addition to this beige tone is available in ivory and gold.  This freshwater pearl bracelet with a modern paperclip link chain is a cool piece with purpose. One hundred percent of the net proceeds from the sale of the Paris Jewellers Asian Heritage Hope Bracelet will be donated to the Canadian Asian Solidarity Fund and Stop AAPI Hate.  The croissant bag is the most coveted style of the season and A Bronze Age‚Äôs Kiki bag in satin is a perfect pick. Available in five fabulous shades: citrus, butter, lavender, black and magenta  This sleek mule is the perfect height and we love the wicker-effect finish on the heel. The shoe is part of Aldo‚Äôs new Pillow Walk collection which means it‚Äôs comfy, too! All our journalism is independent and is in no way influenced by advertising. By clicking on an affiliate link, you accept that third-party cookies will be set. More information.

A brawl erupted at a wedding in HCMC on Thursday between friends of the bride and groom, resulting in several being injured.  Video footage of the dispute at the wedding at Dam Sen water park in District 11 showed dozens of people getting into a verbal disagreement, before one member of the group left the venue and returned with sticks and pitchforks.  As they were trying to get back into the venue, they were blocked at the door. The group then smashed down several doors and a chaotic brawl ensued.  The entire ordeal lasted about a minute, with several people receiving mild injuries.  District 11 police on Friday summoned several people related to the incident.  An initial investigation revealed that the dispute was over a business disagreement between two friend groups of the bride and groom.

The Ottawa Senators have been a fairly lean operation for some time now. With new ownership about to arrive this summer, apparently spending close to $1 billion for the franchise, it will be interesting to see if they expand staffing throughout the organization.  At the rate the players are going this off-season, the team may need to consider hiring a wedding planner.  We already know that Sens captain Brady Tkachuk is getting married this summer to his partner, Emma Farinacci.  And now, in the past month alone, at least three other members of the Ottawa Senators have bent the knee to propose to their longtime girlfriends, all taking to Instagram to announce their big news to the world. In each case, their happy hockey teammates, past and present, jammed their replies with congratulatory messages.  Sens defenceman Thomas Chabot took a knee on a beautiful beach in Anguilla this week to propose to his longtime partner, Marion Pandreau.  Sens centre Jake Lucchini, who played 11 games for the Senators this season, also proposed this week to his girlfriend, Abbie Botz, back home in Madison, Wisconsin.  Senators winger Parker Kelly got the ball rolling in April. While on vacation in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii, Kelly popped the question to his longtime girlfriend, Kiarra McMullan.  The answer, by the way, was yes on all counts.  ‚ÄúAh, spring, when a young man‚Äôs fancy lightly turns to thoughts of love.‚Äù  ‚Äì Alfred, Lord Tennyson

Brides and grooms-to-be have spoken of their fury after a four-star hotel closed suddenly and cancelled their weddings so it could house 230 migrants.  Needham House Hotel in the village of Little Wymondley, near Hitchin in Hertfordshire, shut its doors earlier this month after the Home Office booked the property out completely for a year.  Jade Kolonics and her fiance Danny Neal were due to get married at the venue on August 25 and the couple were putting the finishing touches on their preparations.  Ms Kolonics said: 'Our invites have been sent and RSVP'd to, guests have booked hotel rooms - we have family coming down from all over - and now, only 15 weeks away from the big day, we have no venue, no food and no hotel rooms.  'I am beyond stressed and it has had a massive impact on my mental health.'  Jade Kolonics and her fiance Danny Neal were due to get married at the venue on August 25 and the couple were putting the finishing touches on their preparations  Nicola Harmel was supposed to be tying the knot at the hotel next summer but now wants to find another venue  Needham House Hotel in the village of Little Wymondley, near Hitchin in Hertfordshire, shut its doors earlier this month after the Home Office booked the property out completely for a year  Nicola Harmel was supposed to be tying the knot at the hotel next summer but now wants to find another venue.  She is demanding a refund by Needham House but bosses say they can still hold the ceremony as the hotel should be free by then.  Ms Harmel fumed: 'We have our wedding booked next August and no refunds can be made because they have the government contract for one year.  'Needham House said the wedding will go ahead. However, the Novotel in Stevenage had a one-year government contract and it's now one and a half years and they still haven't opened the doors to the public.  'I cannot risk having three months to go for them to say they are extending the contract. We need the money from the deposit to put on another location.'  HAVE YOU BEEN AFFECTED BY THE CLOSURE? Email: tom.pyman@mailonline.co.uk  Meanwhile, customer Lewis Male said: 'My partner and I are due to get married in July and had over 25 rooms booked at this venue for our wedding for family and friends travelling up from Somerset.  'We are devastated and not sure what to do at all.'  Rob Close has his wedding booked at Needham House in 2024 but was given a nasty shock when he saw the state of the hotel after driving there recently to seek assurances his big day could still go ahead.  The Needham House Hotel (pictured) closed up earlier this month after the Home Office booked it out in its entirety for 230 migrants  The hotel (pictured inside), whose website is no longer in use, has cancelled 11 weddings and two proms since it was forced to shut up shop  He jumped in his car after getting no answer on the phone and said: 'I found the hotel starting to be stripped down, furniture moved out the way and being organised into different areas.  'We had a meeting at the venue on May 4 to discuss upgrades to our package, booking further rooms, and layouts, with no inclination of anything like this happening.  'I have heard deposits paid for 2024 will not be refunded as this contract is only for a year and Needham House could still honour these bookings, despite no way of telling what condition the facilities and rooms will be in.  'We are devastated as it the perfect venue for us but we are yet to have even heard from them.'  Miss Kolonics is expecting a refund of several thousand pounds for the disruption and has luckily now found a new venue for her big day at Knebworth Barns.  She said: 'I don't know who is to blame - is it the Government for taking over the hotel or is it Needham House Hotel for accepting it?  'But it isn't great to be told that you can't have your wedding there at such short notice when we've paid thousands of pounds and had much of the preparation work done.  'The Hotel have offered us a full refund - although they are not giving us any kind of compensation. They have also helped find another venue.  'It's been really tough but I'm of a more positive outlook now and in a better frame of mind.'  MailOnline has made multiple attempts to approach Needham House Hotel for comment.

Snapping turtles are not typically dangerous to humans; they tend to be fearful and paddle off into the depths as soon as they spot you, notes columnist Ralph Gardner Jr. They only present danger if you find one on land and are foolish enough to try to pick it up.
