On the beauty checklist for your wedding day, nails tend to be the last priority ‚Äî because, really, how much can a nail look really matter amid all the other to-dos? But as nail enthusiasts, we're here to make the case that the right wedding nail design can make all the difference in your overall look, making it something to keep in mind when considering your beauty agenda for the big day.  That's partly because nail art is the easiest way to elevate any beauty look, especially for a wedding. While you can go classic in your designs, opting for a timeless French manicure with a bridal white tip, other options are more outside-the-box ‚Äî such as full-on, bedazzled jewels or bold colors that will pop in photos.    To help narrow it down for you, we turned to the experts to share the best wedding nail designs to consider.

(CHARLESTON, S.C.) ‚Äî A South Carolina groom whose bride was killed on their wedding day by an alleged drunk driver is sharing his story for the first time.  On the night of April 28, a golf cart carrying four people was struck from behind by an alleged drunk driver near Charleston, South Carolina, killing 34-year-old Samantha Miller and critically injuring her new husband, Aric Hutchinson, and two others.  The couple had just celebrated their wedding earlier that day, ABC News reported previously.  Hutchinson spoke to ‚ÄúGood Morning America‚Äù in his first interview since the tragic accident that killed his wife, sharing how he‚Äôs coping with the immense loss after what he says had been a perfect day.  ‚ÄúShe was so happy. I mean, planning a wedding, as most people know, is extremely stressful. And she just had a weird, like, calmness that night,‚Äù said Hutchinson, who added that the wedding and the reception were one of the best nights of his life.  According to a GoFundMe set up by Hutchinson‚Äôs mother, Hutchinson broke both legs, parts of his face, and his back, and suffered brain bleeds and numerous cuts in the accident. The two others in the golf cart with Hutchinson and Miller suffered injuries including severe road rash and open wounds, according to Charleston ABC affiliate WCIV.  The driver of the vehicle that struck the golf cart, Jamie Komoroski, 25, was arrested and charged with three counts of DUI causing serious bodily injury/death and one count of reckless homicide. Komoroski was allegedly driving 65 miles per hour in a 25 miles per hour zone when the crash happened, according to a police report released by the Folly Beach Department of Public Safety.  Hutchinson said he‚Äôs not ready to address the driver at this time.  ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt right now,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to. I mean, she stole an amazing human being that should not have been taken.‚Äù  ABC News‚Äô Will McDuffie contributed to this report.  Copyright ¬© 2023, ABC Audio. All rights reserved.

Parker Palm Springs provided a whimsical, mid-mod backdrop for Angela and Julie‚Äôs happily ever after ‚Äî a long twime coming after a two-year engagement and 13 years together pre-proposal. ‚ÄúWe met 27 years ago,‚Äù Angela recalls. ‚ÄúI immediately knew she was the one, and I proceeded to tell all my friends that I would be with her someday. Timing is everything.‚Äù  ‚ÄúHer zest for life inspires me and definitely keeps me on my toes,‚Äù says Julie, who proposed to Angela at home in Phoenix, Arizona, the day before the couple left for a getaway to Spain. She handmade a book documenting their love story in which the final page popped the question. ‚ÄúCompared to our wedding festivities,‚Äù Julie says, ‚Äúit was perfectly simple, private, and romantic.‚Äù  Working with the Parker‚Äôs catering/sales manager ‚Äî and ‚Äúplanner extraordinaire‚Äù ‚Äî Randy Araiza, the pair went all out to make the long weekend super personal and packed with activity for the whole family. ‚ÄúThe first time we walked into the Parker, we felt it captured us,‚Äù Julie says, ‚Äúthe desert feel of Arizona; the midcentury, funky feel of Palm Springs; and the easy-going yet top-scale vibe.‚Äù

Elizabeth Ayer and Brad Nordman were a ‚Äúmatch‚Äù made in heaven when they connected via the dating app Coffee Meets Bagel in July 2014. ‚ÄúOur first date was chatting over drinks, and then an impromptu outdoor movie,‚Äù Elizabeth remembers. Almost exactly four years later, they took the next big step when Brad got down on one knee in Santorini, Greece.  The duo got right to wedding planning. ‚ÄúWe chose our venue and most vendors in 2018, and it was smooth sailing‚Äîuntil we called it off in April 2020,‚Äù Elizabeth remembers. ‚ÄúThe hardest part of the planning process was postponing our wedding and trusting that things would come together the following year. It turned out to be such a blessing in disguise and I‚Äôm grateful we had the extra time to make our wedding weekend outstanding. In the end, we were engaged for 1,117 days‚Äîwhich became a bit of a joke among our friends and family, but it worked for us! When you‚Äôre vowing to be together forever, what‚Äôs another year or three?‚Äù  Timing aside, it was the vision that mattered, and it came together flawlessly. For Elizabeth and Brad, the wedding was more than one day. It actually turned into a whole weekend affair. ‚ÄúI think I decided I‚Äôd get married at Roche Harbor when I was about 13,‚Äù the bride laughs. "So, I was quite relieved when Brad enthusiastically agreed. San Juan Island is one of my favorite places on earth, and Roche Harbor Resort in particular holds special significance for my family.‚Äù Her family has been visiting there since the 1960s. Now, there was a chance to show off this sliver of the Pacific Northwest to all of their family and friends joining from out of state.  ‚ÄúWe wanted the weekend to feel like an all-inclusive, elevated summer camp experience,‚Äù Elizabeth says. ‚ÄúMany of our guests arrived by seaplane, which set the tone for a unique adventure. We created a calendar of events and wanted each night to feel distinct and slightly more formal than the previous, and provide ample quality time to mix our friend groups.‚Äù Festivities began on Thursday, when the bridal party kicked off the weekend with a luau dinner at Westcott Bay Shellfish Co., complete with lawn games and root beer floats. There was a whale-watching excursion for guests arriving Friday, a welcome dinner, and a send-off brunch on Sunday.  Of course, there was also the main event. ‚ÄúOur Saturday wedding day was a marathon,‚Äù Elizabeth adds. Read on to see all the incredible details, planned by Kaleb Norman James and photographed by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography.  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  ‚ÄúWe began our wedding day with a 7 a.m. ‚Äòpolar plunge‚Äô into the 55-degree water of Puget Sound,‚Äù Elizabeth recounts. ‚ÄúIt was such a fun and memorable way to kick off the big day. My mom brought everyone doughnuts, and then my bridesmaids and I dashed back to our room for hair and makeup.‚Äù Her beauty vision was natural and understated, with eyelash extensions for a little extra oomph. ‚ÄúMy updo matched the simplicity of my dress; it felt very bridal."  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Wedding dress shopping was a family affair. She found her off-the-shoulder Carolina Herrera gown at the since-shuttered Nordstrom Wedding Suite in Seattle. ‚ÄúMy mom and I found not only my dress, but also hers and a new suit for my dad!‚Äù Elizabeth says. ‚ÄúI knew this dress was the one as soon as I put it on: It was an elegant yet simple design that let me shine through.‚Äù  She went all in on the something old, new, borrowed, and blue tradition, with her most meaningful accessory being a veil. ‚ÄúMy mom handmade it from the lace and layers of her own wedding dress, which she cut up to create my veil,‚Äù Elizabeth says. ‚ÄúIt was gorgeous and such a meaningful addition to my look.‚Äù  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  ‚ÄúBrad wore a blue suit with a subtle windowpane pattern,‚Äù Elizabeth describes. ‚ÄúHe stood out from the groomsmen who wore navy, but they all had matching ties, white shirts, and chestnut-brown shoes.‚Äù  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  The couple was playful with their first look‚ÄîElizabeth tried tricking Brad by tapping the wrong shoulder, but he couldn‚Äôt be fooled. They share, ‚ÄúAs we finished our photos, we looked up and realized my dad was standing on the balcony above us, so he was able to witness the moment as well!‚Äù  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  ‚ÄúMy bridesmaids represented women from different stages in my life. It was so inspiring to see new friendships blossoming between girls I‚Äôd known separately for a long time, but had yet to meet each other.‚Äù She gave the girls autonomy in selecting their dress, as long as it was full-length in a blue-green color palette.  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  A custom ceremony arch featured florals that played up their vibrant citrus palette, and 160 white chairs amped up the garden vibe.  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Elizabeth walked down the aisle to ‚ÄúHere Comes the Sun‚Äù alongside both of her parents. A friend officiated the ceremony, and the couple exchanged personalized vows. ‚ÄúAs the world‚Äôs biggest Michigan football fan, Brad was impressed that I ended my vows with a quote from Coach Bo Schembechler. His were very sweet as well,‚Äù Elizabeth says. Readings at the ceremony excerpted from James Kavanaugh, Bell Hooks, and Jeanette Winterson.  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  After cocktail hour, the newlyweds led guests in a second-line parade to the reception space, one of Elizabeth‚Äôs favorite moments of the day. Once they arrived, everyone found their seats with illustrated cards on a floral-filled escort card wall.  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Lush floral centerpieces were set between rattan hurricanes and wooden bowls of citrus fruit beneath the sailcloth tent. ‚ÄúTables were set with powder-blue linens, which accented the Italian ceramic place settings and matching blue dinner plates,‚Äù Elizabeth says. Custom embroidered napkins and runners featured the couple‚Äôs monogram, which they also had emblazoned on corn hole boards on the lawn, and slippers for guests.  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  From behind a custom bar, servers slung signature his-and-hers cocktails: spicy margaritas and Aperol spritzes.  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Their first dance song selection was an easy choice. ‚ÄúWe danced to ‚ÄòCan‚Äôt Take My Eyes Off Of You‚Äô by Frankie Valli,‚Äù Elizabeth says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been our song since our second date, when we sang it together at a karaoke bar!‚Äù  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Their wedding cake‚Äîuniquely flavored with pink Champagne and banana bread‚Äîwas decorated to mimic the bride‚Äôs bouquet, with trailing clematis vines and organic florals. Lemons were also added to tie in the tablescapes.  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  We were all scream-singing to Backstreet Boys while wearing silent disco headphones!  Photo by Janine Licare Fine Art Photography  The live band played until the area‚Äôs 10 p.m. noise curfew‚Äîbut that didn‚Äôt stop the party. ‚ÄúWe ended the night with a silent disco,‚Äù the bride says. The next day, an onlooker from the yacht dock nearby told the couple, ‚Äú‚ÄòI was loving the free concert, but was confused when the music suddenly stopped and the singing continued. What happened?‚Äô Well, we were all scream-singing to Backstreet Boys while wearing silent disco headphones!‚Äù Guests could set their headphones to a pop channel curated by the bride or a classic rock channel created by the groom. Late-night pizza arrived and guests posted up at the outdoor bar for cigars and a nightcap to end the incredible evening.

Polite Society (PG-13)  At the Myrna Loy  Grade: B+  ‚ÄúPolite Society‚Äù takes us on an impolite Bollywood roller coaster ride.  What starts out as a frivolous romcom about a jealous sibling trying to sabotage her big sister‚Äôs wedding, evolves into light-hearted thriller with ninja ladies flying through the air with Pakistani panache.  ‚ÄúPolite Society‚Äù blends Jane Austen with ‚ÄúHouse of the Flying Daggers.‚Äù  Two sisters pledge to defy arranged marriage and arrange their own lives instead. Young Ria longs to be a stunt woman. Elder sis Lena attends art school.  But when her parents invite a handsome young doctor for dinner, Lena‚Äôs resolve melts.  To Ria‚Äôs disgust, Lena says yes to Salim‚Äôs proposal.  Ninja wannabe Ria gathers her BFFs, Clara and Alba, to concoct a multi-phase scheme to disrupt the marriage by any means necessary ‚Äì up to and including spin kicks in wedding dresses.  Ria‚Äôs inept kung fu moves just add to the fun.  The amusing marital mash up ends in preposterous fashion with a sci-fi twist.  Usually such silliness annoys me, but two qualities saved ‚ÄúPolite Society.‚Äù  First, Nida Manzoor‚Äôs British film about a traditional Pakistani family takes pointed, but loving shots, at the submissive role of women in their culture. Ria and Lena both intend to forge their own path.  All goes well until Lena opts to trade her feminist sensibility for the accoutrements of gold digging.  Outraged, Ria, the kick-ass-sister, pledges to fight the good feminist fight, with BFFs Alba and Clara at her side.  But it‚Äôs the love between sisters that holds ‚ÄúPolite Society‚Äù together.  Ria‚Äôs war against her sister‚Äôs marriage is partly adolescent jealousy (‚ÄúI‚Äôm prettier!‚Äù), but partly separation grief. Ria senses their deep friendship will likely end as sis sells out and moves away.  Ria‚Äôs clumsy kicks hide a broken heart.  The ninja shenanigans that cover up tears are actually quite sweet.  In the end, Ria establishes her own YouTube brand: ‚ÄúI am the fury!‚Äù Bruce Lee beware.  My runner-up in the ‚Äúone liner‚Äù raffle was ‚Äúgive me that womb!‚Äù  That demand refers to Salim‚Äôs secret pursuit of the perfect repository for his perfect sperms.  The title ‚ÄúPolite Society‚Äù is a subversive stab at rules that try to keep young ladies from breaking the glass ceiling. Manzoor‚Äôs script is incisive, clever and outrageous in equal portions.  She‚Äôs blowing up movie norms at the same time she revolts against patriarchal Pakistani values.  So what have we here, anyway?  ‚ÄúPolite Society‚Äù is an irreverent attack on Pakistani patriarchy crafted with love and affection for all ‚Äì and including lots of kung fu action.  ‚ÄúBend it Like Beckham‚Äù has a sequel: Bend it like Ria!

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. (WAVY) ‚Äì The search is on for the owner of a wedding ring lost at the Virginia Beach Oceanfront.  It started with a normal day at the beach for Michelle Salisbury. Her family was visiting from Bedford, Va.  ‚ÄúWe were out playing with the kids, hanging out. We noticed they were looking all over the place like panicked, looking for something,‚Äù she said.  They were told a woman lost her ring in the sand.  ‚ÄúThis woman was just brushing sand off her hands and her wedding ring flew off,‚Äù Salisbury said.  She lent the group some sand tools for the search, but nothing helped.  The group canceled the search and left the area.  Once Salisbury‚Äôs husband came back from the bathroom, she relayed the unfortunate news to him.  That‚Äôs when he noticed something sparkly in the sand.  ‚ÄúHe looked down and the ring was right there. We took off to the boardwalk trying to see if they were still up there,‚Äù Salisbury said.  The people searching for the ring were nowhere to be found.  Salisbury turned to the internet for help.  ‚ÄúYou know what it‚Äôs a shot in the dark, but crazy things have happened. Maybe they‚Äôll see it,‚Äù she said.  More than 400,000 people have viewed the Tik Tok, but it hasn‚Äôt led to a perfect ring match yet.  ‚ÄúIf it was me, I would want someone to help. It‚Äôs important. It‚Äôs your wedding ring. That‚Äôs deep. That‚Äôs in your heart,‚Äù Salisbury said.  She‚Äôs hoping to return the ring as soon as possible.  Salisbury said if someone recognizes the ring to contact her on social media.

RALEIGH, N.C. (WTVD) -- A Wake County man can fulfill his promise to his fianc√©e of a dream wedding after a big lottery scratch-off win.  "It's been almost a year to the day and those promises will come true now," said Alfred Harrell of Cary.  Harrell bought a $5 Super Loteria ticket from Circle K on Walnut Street in Cary and won the first $150,000 top prize in the new scratch-off game.  He said he made a promise to his fianc√©e last May, mostly about hosting their dream wedding.  Alfred Harrell NC Education Lottery  "It will be a big family celebration," he said. "We are looking at parks all around the area."  Harrell met his fianc√©e in May about two years ago.  "May has definitely been good for us," he said. "I want to take care of her first."  Harrell collected his prize at lottery headquarters on Wednesday and, after state and federal tax withholdings, took home $106,876.  "I'm still trying to process it," he said. "If I went the other direction and didn't get gas there, I wouldn't have won."  The Super Loteria game debuted this month with six $150,000 top prizes. Five $150,000 prizes remain to be claimed.

The Inn at Harbor Shores Hosts Wedding Open House This Sunday  This Sunday, May 21st, 2023, visit the Inn at Harbor Shores on the water in St. Joseph, and get those wedding planning ideas flowing! The grounds of the Inn will be arranged as if today were the day, and you can view just how special everything will be, during their Wedding Open House.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve hosted wedding shows in the past, but nothing quite like this one,‚Äù says ElizaBeth Hacker, Director of Sales at the Inn at Harbor Shores. ‚ÄúWe will have everything set up as if it were your actual wedding taking place! The ceremony space will be set up in our Riverside Tent, tables and chairs will occupy the second floor Harborview Ballroom, and our Waterside Room will host a bar set up for cocktail hour. A Bridal Room set up will also be located in our Marina View Boardroom.‚Äù  With the anticipation of over one hundred guests passing through during the afternoon, the Inn at Harbor Shores can‚Äôt wait for you to see the gorgeous space. Complimentary hors d‚Äôoeuvres will be passed around by the friendly staff, and a cash bar will be available. Attendees will receive a complimentary ticket for their signature wedding cocktail, so you can sip deliciously while you peruse the venue.  ADVERTISEMENT Your content continues below    There will be many vendors on site during the open house, offering a little taste of everything you‚Äôll need to picture your perfect day. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll have a photo booth provided by Freeze Frame Photography, one of our favorite DJ‚Äôs Jelliefish Productions, a new local floral and event design company, Sara Rentz Designs, and Mimi‚Äôs Cupcakes offering samples,‚Äù ElizaBeth says. ‚ÄúIn the Riverside Tent, we will have an officiant from Weddings by Kelly, the talented harpist Meg Rodgers, showcasing ceremony music, and the cutest mobile bar you‚Äôve ever seen, Classy Coupe!‚Äù Couples are able to use whichever vendors they choose, though these are some off of the Inn‚Äôs preferred list.  ‚ÄúWe have this beautiful ballroom and event space with fantastic views of the harbor, but we also do all of our own in-house catering and beverages,‚Äù says ElizaBeth. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one less thing for busy couples to have to worry about. Offering group blocks of guest rooms to our couples takes the guesswork out of where their out of town guests are going to stay, and with Plank‚Äôs Tavern and our Dockside Bar, we have many other amenities that make the Inn so great!‚Äù  The Inn at Harbor Shores hosts multiple weddings, rehearsal dinners, and day-after brunches, and they‚Äôd like you to come see for yourself. The Wedding Open House takes place at 800 Whitwam Drive in St. Joseph from 1 p.m to 4 p.m this Sunday, May 21st, and is free to attend, though your RSVP is requested. The staff and event planning team at the Inn are ready to answer questions and direct you through the grounds! The Inn is also offering a special incentive of $1000 off the venue fee for guests of the open house, for any remaining 2023 or 2024 summer dates (there are quite a few Saturdays still available!). RSVP here! Contact the Inn at events@innatharborshores.com.  By Jocelyne Tuszynski, MOTM Contributor  jocelynet@moodyonthemarket.com

GALWAY ‚Äî The town‚Äôs code enforcement officer has issued a stop work order on a 5,222-square-foot wedding barn because the owners built it without Planning Board oversight, permits and environmental or traffic studies.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a legal building,‚Äù said town code officer Treavor Gilday concerning Star Farm Blueberries‚Äôs barn, owned and built by Chuck and JoAnn Fetter. ‚ÄúThey built it without a permit. They are operating without a CO (certificate of occupancy). We summonsed them to court. The court will decide if there are fines. There are a lot of issues.‚Äù  Those issues also include disregarding fire code regulations, which landed Chuck Fetter on Wednesday in front of the Albany Regional Board of Review, a committee of the Department of State, where he was questioned about bypassing the installation of sprinklers and other fire suppression items like lit exits and silent alarms in the bathroom.  Chuck Fetter argued that he shouldn‚Äôt need all the fire safety measures as the food is brought in, not cooked on site. Besides, he argued, wedding guests come for the ceremony, not the food.  ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt primarily come to eat,‚Äù Fetter argued to the board. The meeting was held in Albany, but could also be viewed online. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the main focus. They go primarily for a wedding.‚Äù  Sign up for the Saratoga Now newsletter Keep up with the latest happening in Saratoga Springs, Clifton Park, Ballston Spa and other communities in Saratoga County. Sign up here.  However, the board dismissed his appeal to keep the wooden pole barn fire-suppression free. They adjourned to discuss the case at a future meeting.  While Chuck Fetter did not immediately return a Times Union phone call on Wednesday, he admitted to the board that his approach to building the venue ‚Äúwas a mistake,‚Äù but ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think it was catastrophic.‚Äù  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good spot for weddings,‚Äù Chuck Fetter told the board.  There are other problems, too ‚Äî mainly noise emanating from Fetters‚Äô Galway Road farm that is upsetting neighbors. Donna Miller said music plays loudly throughout receptions, and many of the events include fireworks.  ‚ÄúI hope they will be conscientious and recognize their neighbors,‚Äù Miller said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs assumed that they would take into consideration what their wedding venue clients are requesting in regards to noise, particularly to take notice if fireworks are to be used.‚Äù  Fireworks require permits, said town Clerk Margaret DeFoe, and she said the couple has never sought a permit for their firework displays.  Noise is the same issue that plagued the neighbors of S&S Saratoga Farm in Saratoga. After a long court battle, the town, which was considering changing the zoning to allow weddings there, finally dropped the idea. Weddings, the town said, were not a permitted use in that area.  Galway resident Tom O‚ÄôBrien said he‚Äôs not happy the Fetters never notified neighbors of their plans. While not completely against a wedding venue there, he has said he is concerned about what could happen next if the town allows Star Farm to build what it wants without oversight.  ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs to say that doesn‚Äôt change to be a brewery or a bar with (Fetter‚Äôs) lack of respect for the town and its regulations,‚Äù O‚ÄôBrien said at a February Town Board meeting. ‚ÄúHow does the town keep people from building anything they want?‚Äù  Some Town Board members also appear concerned. Councilman Fred Arnold said in an April Town Board meeting, minutes show, that Fetter continues ‚Äúto do what he wants‚Äù even with a cease-and-desist order.  Meanwhile, Star Farm Blueberries continues to advertise as a wedding venue, giving its wedding packages as much play as its blueberries on its website.  ‚ÄúThe residents of Galway need to know that there are local laws about construction that are to be adhered to,‚Äù Miller said. ‚ÄúIf not, it will otherwise open the flood gate and people will get away with just constructing anything without permits.‚Äù

Why Philly Bridal Designer Jovan O‚ÄôConnor Wore Three Different Gowns for Her Wedding  Her couture ceremony dress was inspired by Sex and the City.  Delivering the latest in style, inspiration, helpful tips and tricks, and everything else you need to know to plan the perfect Philly wedding.  Remember when we told you bridal designer Jovan O‚ÄôConnor would don two wedding gowns for her Big Day? Well, she ended up sporting three. It‚Äôs not too, too much of a surprise, though. She hinted at a bonus look when we chatted with her shortly before her September 2022 wedding. All of them were fabulous ‚Äî much like Jovan and her groom, whose Morris Arboretum & Gardens wedding was sweet but stylish. Petronella Photography snapped the fashionable festivities below.  It pays to strike up a conversation with a stranger every now and again ‚Äî at least for Philly-born designer Jovan O‚ÄôConnor and Kevin Keller, a contractor who hails from Wisconsin. The two met on a sweltering day in August 2010 at Starbucks. He joked that her Frappuccino was not real coffee. She mentioned the heat wave. And that broke the ice. A decade after that, in July 2020, Kevin proposed.  They were engaged for two years before saying ‚ÄúI do‚Äù at Morris Arboretum & Gardens in Chestnut Hill. They chose the picturesque spot for its beautiful landscape and history. Their theme was garden chic, and they worked with women-owned businesses and creatives to pull off their dream day.  ‚ÄúAs a business owner, it was very important to me to highlight the talents of women,‚Äù says the bride.  It was also important to her to dress the part for her own wedding. ‚ÄúAfter designing for so many others‚Äô special days, I was thrilled to be able to wear something that I created for the biggest day of my life,‚Äù says Jovan. She‚Äôd designed a bridal collection prior to the wedding, but Kevin had seen the gowns already ‚Äî and even helped create them. So she needed something new. And not just one, but three.  Let‚Äôs start with the bride‚Äôs favorite ‚Äî her couture ceremony dress and veil. They were inspired by the first Sex and the City movie. ‚ÄúI wanted to re-create that moment when Carrie tries on different wedding dresses,‚Äù she says. Jovan‚Äôs dress was made of feathers and ivory silk taffeta, with a pleated drape and bubble hem.  Kevin didn‚Äôt miss the significance of the style. One of his favorite wedding details was seeing Jovan come down the aisle in her gown.  As for the other two? The first was a Justin Alexander design that she‚Äôd altered. She decided to wear it on the way to the venue ‚Äúinstead of something like a casual outfit because I was in full bridal mode‚Äù and for the first look.  The final costume change was for the reception, into a pearl-filled stunner. Think pearl hand-embroidered lace from Brussels, stringed pearls on the shoulders and sleeves, pearl buttons down the back, and a fishtail bottom filled with pearl-adorned draped godets.  Of course, it wasn‚Äôt just about the fashions. There were also sentimental decor touches ‚Äî the couple used Jovan‚Äôs grandmother‚Äôs dinnerware, with its pretty floral detailing, at the reception.  And Jovan and Kevin felt all the love from their 76 guests.  ‚ÄúEveryone we invited has a special part in our story, and to see people who have known and supported our love from the beginning was exactly the vibe we were going for,‚Äù says Jovan.  THE DETAILS  Photographer & Videographer: Petronella Photography | Venue: Morris Arboretum & Gardens | Planning/Design & Catering: Ashley Power of Power Events | Florals: DNA Floral | Reception Tent Decor: Wild Stems | Bride‚Äôs Gowns, Bridesmaids‚Äô Dresses & Flower-Girl Frock: Jovan O‚ÄôConnor (first-look dress by Justin Alexander) | Bride‚Äôs Shoes: Jimmy Choo | Bridal Stylist: Aaliyah Taylor | Hair: Dominique Nicole | Headpiece: Marrow Fine | Bridal Accessories: Hairs2U Wig Bank | Makeup: Jasmine Carter | Eyebrows: Nicck Townsend | Nails: Brown Sugar Nail Spa | Groom‚Äôs Attire: The Black Tux | Entertainment: Manuela Romero (ceremony violinist); DJ Lady FX (reception) | Cake: Two Ladies Bakery | Invitations: The Knot | Officiant: Carvella Jackson | Welcome Gifts: The Muckle Water | Rings: Alyssa & Anna (bride‚Äôs engagement ring and groom‚Äôs wedding band); The Jeweler (bride‚Äôs wedding band) | Photo Booth: Philly Snap Booth | Portrait Artist: Dori Spector Fine Art  Get more great content from Philadelphia Wedding:  FACEBOOK | INSTAGRAM | NEWSLETTER  Getting married? Start and end your wedding planning journey with Philadelphia Weddings' guide to the best wedding vendors in the city.

Oh, baby back!  A frugal feast of Chili‚Äôs Grill & Bar chicken tenders, sliders, cajun chicken pasta, salads and more delicious Tex-Mex grub wound up stealing the show at Southern belle Madison Mulkey‚Äôs wedding.  The practically minded Savannah, Georgia peach turned to the chain restaurant as a thrifty alternative to traditional catering ‚Äî which can cost an average of $75 per guest, according to wedding website the Knot.  The spread, which Mulkey shared with her followers on TikTok, where the video has been viewed more than 1.3 million times, wound up a steal at $1,950 for 99 guests ‚Äî a far cry from the $7,500 Mulkey says she would have had to spend on the usual chicken-or-fish extravaganza.  ‚ÄúFirst of all, we loved the price point,‚Äù Mulkey said in the TikTok. ‚ÄúYou really can‚Äôt beat that price point. You just can‚Äôt.‚Äù  But, saving thousands of dollars on her big day came with some surprising hidden costs ‚Äî Mulkey said she had to spend more time and energy coordinating pickup for the food than if she‚Äôd hired someone to worry about it for her.  Savannah, Ga., bride Madison Mulkey‚Äôs Chili‚Äôs-catered wedding has gone viral on TikTok. TikTok/brideisapersonality  Guests at the wedding enjoyed a wide selection of Chili‚Äôs classic Tex-Mex fare. Chili's Grill & Bar  ‚ÄúWe had to pick it up pretty early because we didn‚Äôt want to pay for the delivery fees,‚Äù Mulkey noted.  That meant the bride-to-be wound up waiting at her local Chili‚Äôs at 11 o‚Äôclock on the morning of her wedding day. Luckily, she was able to corral the crew at her reception location, who made sure the food was hot, ready, and artfully presented that evening.  ‚ÄúThat was just a lot more work than we had anticipated,‚Äù Mulkey admitted, noting the added pressure placed on venue staff.  And while plenty of Mulkey‚Äôs followers saluted her savvy, others expressed concern over the undue burden borne by workers who perhaps weren‚Äôt properly trained to prepare and present someone else‚Äôs food.  ‚ÄúAs someone who works in the industry, this sounds like a nightmare for your staff and coordinator,‚Äù one La-Z-Boy labor expert sniped, calling out the bride for skimping.  Mulkey followed up her first video with a clarification ‚Äî she did tip the Chili‚Äôs kitchen staff $300, and that the venue employees were paid hourly, including for any extra time they may have spent on preparation.  The total bill was an entirely resasonable $1,950.04 ‚Äî plus the $300 tip Mulkey says she handed to kitchen staff. TikTok/brideisapersonality  Some skeptics remained unconvinced.  ‚ÄúServers aren‚Äôt cooks, they serve people, not serve whatever purpose you need,‚Äù a commenter complained.

SAN DIEGO ‚Äî With wedding season in full swing, the planning is on for many couples looking to tie the knot and cement their promise of forever.  Before couples decide on color schemes, flower arrangements and dessert options, the feat of selecting the perfect venue is at the top of most wedding-planning checklists.  There‚Äôs good news for those looking to get married in Southern California: San Diego County is isn‚Äôt slacking when it comes to majestic landscapes perfect for saying ‚ÄúI do.‚Äù  From coastal cliffs overlooking the Pacific Ocean to green valleys tucked between mountain ranges, here are five wedding venues with a view in the region:  The Condor‚Äôs Nest Ranch  This rustic wedding venue sits on a 15-acre property in Pala that beholds panoramic views that span all the way to the coast. Couples can share their vows beneath a 200-year-old ash tree as it sways in the wind to the expression of love. This venue is ideal for those who wish to get married surrounded by nature and views of the countryside.  The Coaster Terrace at Belmont Park  Couples who choose this venue to celebrate their big day can expect white sand views of Pacific Beach. With direct view of the westward ocean, this post could make for a perfect sunset wedding. Another quirky yet #SoSanDiego feature is that the venue is just steps from the giant Dipper roller coaster, which adds to an unforgettable view.  Wild Weddings at San Diego Zoo Safari Park  For some, love can be a wild adventure. Couples can enjoy a ‚Äúromance safari‚Äù with wedding day views of giraffes, zebras and rhinos on an African-like savannah located right here in Southern California at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park. The venue area has lush green foliage and there are even options to add-on ‚Äúwow-worthy wildlife animal presentations,‚Äù according to the park‚Äôs webpage.  Coronado Cays Yacht Club  This venue offers up a tranquil setting with direct views of the San Diego Bay and Coronado. It‚Äôs located right at the edge of the sandy shore, making for great lighting and photo opportunities. This spot could have sailboats poised in the background, birds flying overhead and is simple enough to make the newlyweds the main focus.  Lakehouse Hotel & Resort  This North County venue is located on the edge of Lake San Marcos, offering less salty yet still awing views of the water. Also surrounding the area ‚Äî green upon green ‚Äî with golf courses that create a quaint and clean wedding day vibe. Wedding day sights may even include some boating passersby or some lakeside wildlife.  If there‚Äôs one thing that‚Äôs for certain when it comes to saying ‚ÄúI do,‚Äù no matter which San Diego County venue you choose ‚Äî the view will be a fairytale come true.

CINCINNATI ‚Äî From its lush gardens to its historic charm, the Pinecroft Manor at Crosley Estate is beloved by brides looking for the perfect backdrop for their wedding. But property owners are looking for a divorce from uninvited guests.  It‚Äôs springtime and, without notice, a black cloud takes over the skies. Made up of tens of thousands of black dots flying in seemingly every direction at once, the cloud settles into a nearby tree branch.  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll hear it before you see it and then there‚Äôs a tornado of bees around. That‚Äôs how they reproduce, and good luck talking an animal out of reproducing, right?‚Äù beekeeper Phil Hucky said.  The bees are searching for their new home and a new place to create a new hive.  Standing inside the attic of Pinecroft Manor, Hucky is faced with cutting out a nearly 100-year-old floor to retrieve a beehive that has built up between the joists.  ‚ÄúThis is really the only way to get into a hive like this there‚Äôs no access from the outside from underneath anything like that,‚Äù Hucky said. ‚ÄúHoneybees are cavity dwellers so they‚Äôre looking for a space roughly this big which is perfect between the first and second floor houses the joist space is that size and so they‚Äôre looking for those spaces to move into.‚Äù  Swarms on trees in a yard or ones that show up on the side of a home or car can often be captured for free by an area beekeeper from the Southwest Ohio Beekeepers Association or SWOBA. Hucky says the association‚Äôs website has the resources homeowners need.  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a very large list of people broken up by region local beekeepers that will come and assist you and take that hive off your hands, typically free of charge,‚Äù he said.  However, once the bees have found a quarter-inch hole or larger on the side of a home and move into the eaves or walls it can become pricey. There‚Äôs no set price within the industry and cutout services can range from a couple hundred to a few thousand dollars.  Hucky said homeowners want to make sure they hire someone that understands the construction and has the proper tools for the job.  While someone‚Äôs first response to a honeybee swarm might be to grab the insect spray and kill the bees, Hucky said please don‚Äôt do it for a variety of reasons.  ‚ÄúIf the spray was to kill the hive you still have all that brood and all that honey and it will be like having a large dead animal in the wall,‚Äù Hucky said. ‚ÄúIf that hives been poisoned, you‚Äôre not only poisoning that hive you could potentially poison other hives in the area.‚Äù  He said other honeybees will pick up the scent left behind by the propolis in the hive and could visit the poisoned hive and then carry the pesticide to other hives in the area several miles away.    The good news is while honeybees can swarm at any time, they predominately swarm between April and June, which means we‚Äôre about midway through this year‚Äôs swarm season.  If you find the need for a beekeeper to take care of a swarm in your area, visit the SWOBA website and click the 'Swarm Removal' link at the top of the page.  SWOBA's President Yaser Almusawy encourages property owners to plant bee-friendly flowers. A list can be found on their website.

Miss Maine USA Juliana Morehouse is married!  The pageant contestant, 23, who is pursuing her master's degree in theology, wed her long-time partner Taylor Reed Locklear in a "romantic" ceremony in Charleston, South Carolina on April 29.  The couple exchanged vows in front of 350 family and friends at the historic St. Philip's Church, where they also got engaged a year earlier.  "My favorite moment on our wedding day was when I walked down the aisle. For me, time stopped," Morehouse tells PEOPLE exclusively.  "As I draped the blusher of my veil over my face, I held onto my dad's arm. The doors to our church sanctuary opened, and Highland Cathedral began to play. While the bagpipes and the trumpet echoed throughout the church, the moment felt very regal."  The pair's love story began when Morehouse was a high school senior and Locklear had just graduated from the Citadel Military College of South Carolina. They ran into each other at Morehouse's family's annual Christmas party.  The next day Locklear asked Morehouse out to dinner, and the rest was history. "Since that first dinner, Taylor has always been a constant in my life," she says. "He never lets a day go by without telling me he loves me, and that is a gift I will never take for granted."  Taylor Rae Photography  The pageant star walked down the aisle on the arm of her father in a custom lace gown featuring a ruffled skirt created by Israeli designer Pnina Tornai, whose designs have been featured on Sex and the City and Say Yes to the Dress. Morehouse carried a bouquet of pink and white flowers and her stunning veil featured a long train that trailed behind her.  Following the nuptials, the newlywed's reception was held at the nearby Hibernian Hall, where guests were led by a bagpiper dressed in a traditional kilt.  "As the first Miss USA contestant to get married during her reign as a state titleholder, I hope to show women that it is possible to get married and still chase your dreams," says Morehouse.  In August 2022, the Miss USA organization announced in a press release that they were changing their rules for contestants. "Effective with the 2023 Miss USA competition and state preliminary competitions, women who are or have been married, as well as women who are pregnant or have children, will be able to compete," read the release.  "Marriage is a wonderful institution, and I am pleased that the Miss Universe Organization is empowering women to do both," says Morehouse. "My husband's love and support has refined me into the woman I am, so he is certainly on the road to Miss USA with me."  Juliana Morehouse and Taylor Reed Locklear. Taylor Rae Photography  The couple's reception hall was decorated with pink, lilac and red florals where guests were served signature cocktails ‚Äî the Queen's Rose for her and the Gentleman's Old Fashioned for him ‚Äî and treated to a champagne tower poured by the bride and groom.  Meanwhile, their wedding menu consisted of food stations that featured oysters, sushi, beef tenderloin with green beans and potatoes, mac and cheese with the option to add extras such as crab and grits, and scallops with risotto. And to fuel the late-night dancing ‚Äî with a soundtrack provided by the Soul Psychedelique Orchestra ‚Äî the celebrations ended with mini cheeseburger sliders.  Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from juicy celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.  Miss Maine USA Juliana Morehouse marries Taylor Reed Locklear. Taylor Rae Photography  "We wanted southern comfort food to reflect the incredible food Charleston has to offer," Morehouse adds of the day, which was planned by Meredith Tanton of Sweetgrass Social.  When it came to dessert, the couple served mini key lime pies and banana puddings as well as their gorgeous, floral-covered wedding cake ‚Äî a four-tier classic vanilla cake with buttercream icing and carrot cake with cream cheese icing.  For the evening celebrations, Morehouse changed into a party dress and as a nod to her pageant career, she added a light-up tiara and her Miss Maine USA sash.  Taylor Rae Photography  Some of the couple's guests who have a Miss USA connection ‚Äî including Morehouse's mom, who is a former Miss North Carolina USA ‚Äî also brought along their sashes and posed for a picture. Other guests were also gifted their very own sashes and tiaras and were snapped tossing a cardboard cutout of Morehouse being crowned Miss Maine USA into the air as they danced.  When planning her nuptials, Morehouse says she wanted a "romantic, spirit-filled, fun" day. "Most of all, I hoped for a day that my husband and I could enjoy with our loved ones, and that we did," she adds  The newlyweds are now enjoying their honeymoon in Italy, with stops in Rome, Positano, and Capri, and they are looking forward to their future together.  Juliana Morehouse and Taylor Reed Locklear's evening reception. Taylor Rae Photography  "Becoming husband and wife has been one of the most mystical, impactful experiences of our lives," she says.  "We feel very privileged to have found each other while we are young, and we look forward to navigating the hills and valleys that life will bring as a team. We are teammates, companions, and lovers. While the big moments in life are wonderful, being married makes the simple moments in life more splendid. Two is better than one."

Scroll To See More Images  If your Instagram feed turned into a bridal page the second the calendar hit May 1, you‚Äôre not alone. The prime time of wedding season is upon us and that includes proposals, bachelorettes and of course, the big day. If you fall into one of those wedding categories or just love all things bridal, consider the next few months your opportunity to admire (and silently judge) every wedding trend, choice and dress that you see IRL or online. Weddings are kind of like individual Met Galas‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre attending, participating or just watching from afar it‚Äôs fun to have an opinion! Approach the subject with expertise by getting familiar with all of the new wedding trends for 2024. If you‚Äôre planning a 2024 wedding, now is the time to understand what themes and trends are on the horizon.  Weddings are, of course, a highly personal event which means that nobody is required or even encouraged to follow trends. These new wedding trends for 2024 simply exist to provide additional inspiration for the wedding day and wardrobe. That being said, the wedding dress trends for 2024 deserve your attention. They are playful, daring, and even a little bit dramatic.  If there‚Äôs anyone that‚Äôs ahead of bridal trends it‚Äôs Hope LaVine, a Los Angeles-based bridal stylist and influencer with over 360k followers across socials. LaVine exclusively covers bridal trends and tries on and reviews new collections herself for an honest first-person perspective. She just returned from bridal fashion week in Barcelona and New York City where she was one of the first to see the designer bridal collections for spring/summer ‚Äô24.  According to LaVine, the biggest and most innovative trend to hit the bridal scene in 2024 will be wedding dress separates. And if you‚Äôre a 2024 bride, this may work in your favor.  ‚ÄúSocial media has told brides that they need to change out of their wedding dress and have a second look or reception outfit. One dress or ‚Äòlook‚Äô is no longer enough these days,‚Äù LaVine explains. ‚ÄúThe bridal designer‚Äôs fix for this is offering separates. Gloves, neck scarfs, detachable sleeves, hooded veils, and even transformative dresses. These separates are giving brides their two bridal looks, all within one dress.‚Äù  ‚ÄúGalia Lahav is a great example of this.‚Äù LaVine continues. ‚Äù They have multiple jackets that can be worn with lace long-sleeve jackets, and overskirts and they even have a mermaid wedding dress that becomes a mini dress (pictured above)‚Äù.  Versatility is becoming a top priority for brides, especially when a wedding budget comes into play. Another way brides are incorporating multiple looks into their wedding wardrobe is by repurposing older family members‚Äô dresses and accessories. The search for ‚ÄúRepurposing mom‚Äôs wedding dress‚Äù has over 38.8 million views on TikTok with dozens of viral videos showcasing the process and transformation of vintage pieces.  This viral TikTok video has amassed over 240k likes and documents the process of repurposing a wedding dress from 1988 into a short rehearsal dinner dress with a more modern feel. There are plenty of other videos on the app showing different versions of the same process so it is a great place to look for inspiration if you‚Äôre considering doing the same.  If you don‚Äôt have a perfect ‚Äô80s hand-me-down ready to repurpose, don‚Äôt fret! Plenty of designers are incorporating vintage designs into their new collections. The style Hope LaVine is most excited about? Drop waist.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so interesting seeing the trends cycle back around. Drop waist was very early 2000s, think classic Vera Wang ‚Äì Victoria Beckham wedding dress. But bridal design trends often mirror fashion trends. With everyone‚Äôs resurgence in their obsessions with corsets, it‚Äôs no surprise that brides are wanting that snatched look in their wedding dress as well.‚Äù LaVine says.  In addition to drop-waist dresses you can expect to see the revival of elegant princess-style gowns, the emergence of capes down the aisle, and the evolution of accessories with a shortened veil in 2024. The good news is that plenty of the trends for 2024 can be incorporated with any wedding aesthetic, so you won‚Äôt have to revolve your entire look around one to be able to participate.  Keep reading for the five biggest wedding dress and bridal accessory trends for 2024. Before you know it, these will be on your IG feed too.  Fairytale Princess Gowns  While sleek and modern trend-driven wedding dress silhouettes have been having a moment over the last couple of years, the princess gown has slowly but surely been regaining its power. This dress silhouette capitalizes on the drama and grandeur associated with fairytale romance. The focal point of a princess dress is the large skirt that juts out at the waistline. Beyond this distinguishing feature, there‚Äôs plenty of room to customize the style to fit your happily ever after. Monique Lhuillier, for example, featured a dress with a multi-layer tiered skirt and a lace bodice with high-neck and long sleeves in the most recent collection. The dress is reminiscent of old royalty while the skirt detailing makes it more modern. Designer Liz Martinez took a different approach with a simple silhouette but used textured fabric to add dimension to the look.  Dramatic Capes  You don‚Äôt need an entire outfit change to make a statement at your wedding. Capes have made a dramatic entrance on the bridal scene. Whether it‚Äôs tulle, lace or silk, a cape will elevate your entire bridal look. As presented by Elie Saab, a cape (especially one with a hood) is also a cool alternative to a veil. It will add movement to your look when you walk down the aisle or through cocktail hour and will also look great in photos. One of the best parts about a cape is that they work over a variety of dress silhouettes‚Äîif you already have your dress picked out, try a cape over it for good measure.  Flower Appliqu√©s  The flower appliqu√© or rosette trend is a main character in fashion right now. On any piece of clothing, whether it be a swimsuit, skirt or as demonstrated here, a wedding dress, you can find bold flowers added for extra detail. This is by far the most general trend-driven bridal trend for 2024 but one could argue it‚Äôs easily the most natural fit. Choosing a dress with flower detailing can help tie together the overall aesthetic of your wedding. If you‚Äôre envisioning a garden party, flower appliqu√©s will obviously fit right in. On the contrary, if you have a very minimalist aesthetic or dress, a large rose, like the one seen at Badgley Mischka, or a cluster of flowers on your shoulder, as shown by Ines de Santo, can add dimension to your look.  Short Veils  Short wedding dresses, specifically for a reception look, are an increasingly common choice for brides‚Äîand right along with it we have the emergence of the short veil. The short veil silhouette is both elegant and modern which also makes it a popular choice for the untraditional bride. Unlike a classic long veil, a short veil acts as more of a hair accessory rather than a part of the dress silhouette which is why it‚Äôs most usually worn with a shorter or fitted dress style. If you‚Äôre planning on changing for the reception or taking a romantic trip to city hall, a short veil is the way to go.  Something (Or Everything) Blue  The tradition of wearing something blue is far from being a trend but having the color incorporated as a main feature in a bridal look definitely is. Brides are embracing the shade and wearing it to compliment classic white bridal pieces. Sareh Nouri‚Äôs latest bridal collection does an excellent job of showing how blue can be paired with wedding dresses by adding oversized blue bows, printed fabric or embellished gloves. Oscar de la Renta also has a gorgeous blue lace gown that would work as a wedding dress. The difference between this trend and previous iterations of ‚Äúsomething blue‚Äù is that these blue pieces are a part of the primary ceremony look and not just used as a subsequent reception accessory.
The chair of the panel concluded that if she was "in service... we would have directed dismissal and it follows then that she would go on to the barred list".

Advertisement White Castle wedding: Couple ties the knot at fast food restaurant Share Copy Link Copy  Love is in the air for newlyweds Drew and Jamie Schmitt, who tied the knot this month at a White Castle fast food restaurant in Scottsdale, Arizona.The two lovebirds had already gotten engaged when they were inducted into the White Castle Hall of Fame in 2019, so logically, this was just the next step."I have to do this," Drew Schmitt told KPHO-TV. "It's a necessary thing."The Schmitts had been together for 15 years before finally tying the knot. But they both have long accepted that White Castle will always have a piece of their heart. "If you really, really, really love sliders, and you crave your partner as much as you do the sliders, then it's a match made in heaven," Jamie said.Drew and Jamie said "I Do" to each other, but also to a giant slider wedding cake, crowns and armor, and around 150 family and friends joining them at their happy place."I couldn‚Äôt wait any longer," Jamie said.For Jamie, White Castle isn‚Äôt just a place she and Drew eat at hundreds of times per year ‚Äì it's a home from a time when she didn‚Äôt have anywhere else as a physically and sexually abused teen. "I truly would not exist right now without this company," she said. "I had been kicked out of everywhere I went into. I went into a White Castle; I was welcomed. I was fed, I was given water, I was allowed to use a bathroom. I was treated like a human being.""When I found out that they were the safehouse for Jamie, before there were safehouses, I became a superfan," Drew added. They know a White Castle wedding isn't in the cards for everyone. But they have a message for those that have their own unconventional special spot:"If you have an idea, just go with it," Drew said. "Go bold, do it big, do it exactly how you want."For their honeymoon, Drew and Jamie plan on traveling to Drew's hometown of Columbus, Ohio. It also happens to be the headquarters of White Castle. So they plan on spending several days going to as many White Castles in the area as possible.

When Luke Kelly saw Hanna Siverling‚Äôs photo on Hinge in late 2019, he thought‚Äîin his words‚Äîthat she was the most beautiful woman he‚Äôd ever seen. ‚ÄúAt the beginning of our conversation, she used a madcap opening line that elaborated on her life of crime and murder leading her to be on the run in London,‚Äù Luke, who ran the literary estate of his grandfather Roald Dahl for about a decade before it was acquired by Netflix, remembers. ‚ÄúIt sold me on her immediately.‚Äù Then, at the wedding, Luke found out from a speech by one of Hanna‚Äôs friends that the line was actually stolen from a man who had previously used it on the same app. ‚ÄúEverything is built on lies,‚Äù he jokes. ‚ÄúI am filing for divorce!‚Äù  Having first connected online, the couple‚Äôs relationship accelerated quickly once the pandemic hit, and they were ‚Äúforced‚Äù to move in together in London‚Äîat first, only temporarily. ‚ÄúOur friend Jenna, who I had been living with prior, accidentally flooded our house in Brixton, an incident we very lovingly now refer to as ‚Äòthe Great Flood,‚Äô‚Äù Hanna says. ‚ÄúJenna takes full credit for fast-tracking our relationship.‚Äù  The two ultimately became engaged while on a road trip up the East Coast of the U.S. visiting family during the holidays. ‚ÄúWe stopped in New York City, and he proposed in Central Park after several attempts over the preceding two days were inadvertently squashed by me, completely unaware of what he was doing!‚Äù Hanna remembers.  ‚ÄúShe was a nightmare,‚Äù Luke says. ‚ÄúFor days, every time I tried to propose, she would unknowingly throw a wrench in the gears with changes to plans, like an unscheduled nap, headaches, hangovers, or films. Eventually, I had to move to the backup plan‚Äôs backup plan: a little walk in Central Park as the sun set and the park‚Äôs night creatures started to come out of the shadows to greet our newly engaged life in a giant rat-and-cockroach-themed musical number.‚Äù  Their wedding was held at the Inn at Perry Cabin in St. Michaels, Maryland, where Hanna‚Äôs parents have spent many wedding anniversaries over the years. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also very close to where I grew up in Maryland,‚Äù she adds. ‚ÄúAnd where Wedding Crashers was filmed!‚Äù  The rehearsal dinner at the Chesapeake Maritime Museum kicked off the weekend‚Äôs festivities. Guests, with cocktails in hand, took boat shuttles over from the Inn at Perry Cabin to a picturesque old boat barn overlooking the water. For this‚Äîand the welcome party that followed‚ÄîHanna wore a slip made from an antique pattern at Jane Bourvis in Notting Hill that her sister-in-law Sophie Dahl helped choose, and she accessorized with vintage pearl drop clip-on earrings that belong to her grandmother.

The groom whose wife was struck and killed in a car crash in South Carolina on the couple's wedding night has sued the alleged drunk driver and the bars she allegedly drank at before she got behind the wheel, according to court documents obtained by NBC News.  The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in South Carolina's Ninth Judicial Circuit Court, accuses driver Jamie Komoroski, 25, and the owners of five South Carolina bars ‚Äî Snapper Jacks, The Drop In, The Crab Shack, El Gallo Bar & Grill and Taco Boy, where Komoroski was employed ‚Äî of negligence and wrongful death in the crash on Folly Beach on April 28 that killed Samantha Miller, 34, of Charlotte, North Carolina, as she and her husband, Aric Hutchinson, 36, were leaving their wedding reception in a golf cart.  The suit alleges that employees of the bars Komoroski allegedly visited the night of April 28 overserved her even though she was ‚Äúnoticeably and visibly intoxicated‚Äù and that she got behind the wheel after an alleged ‚Äúbooze-filled day of bar hopping.‚Äù  Hutchinson, the groom, was seriously injured, sustaining a brain injury and broken bones. A witness reported that Komoroski ‚Äúwas dazed and confused‚Äù at the scene and repeatedly said ‚ÄúI did nothing wrong‚Äù and that she wanted to go home, according to the incident report.  Aric Hutchinson and Samantha Miller at their wedding. via GoFundMe  Hutchinson said Saturday at a memorial in Miller‚Äôs honor on Folly Beach that he is feeling ‚Äújust as good as I can feel with the situation.‚Äù He filed the suit both as the representative of Miller's estate and on his own behalf, the complaint says.  Danny Dalton, the attorney representing Miller‚Äôs family, said in a statement that the case ‚Äúis about keeping our community safe from drunk drivers, and an important part of that effort is making sure the establishments we entrust with liquor licenses live up to their responsibility to serve alcohol responsibly.‚Äù  A spokesperson for the state Revenue Department‚Äôs alcohol beverage licensing bureau said the state does not require businesses to mandate training for alcohol servers but maintains a list of recommended training programs on its website.  Many states, including South Carolina, allow people to pursue civil actions against businesses that serve intoxicated customers who subsequently cause harm.  Komoroski was arrested and charged with one count of reckless homicide and three counts of felony DUI resulting in great bodily harm, according to online court records. She remains in custody.  Komoroski‚Äôs attorney, Christopher Gramiccioni, said in an email Thursday morning that he was not representing her in the civil case. He said in a statement: ‚ÄúWe cannot fathom what the families are going through and offer our deepest sympathies. We simply ask that there not be a rush to judgment. Our court system is founded upon principles of justice and mercy and that is where all facts will come to light.‚Äù  The lawsuit also names Komoroski‚Äôs workplace, Taco Boy, and an unnamed supervisor of the Folly Beach restaurant as defendants, alleging the supervisor organized a night of drinking for employees before the tragedy unfolded and pressured Komoroski and other attendees to drink heavily. The complaint says the supervisor knew that ‚ÄúKomoroski had a previous history of alcohol abuse,‚Äù but it does not elaborate further. It also claims her employers allowed Komoroski "to simply leave and drive away after having consumed a dangerous amount of alcohol."  Melissa Reardon, the communications director for Taco Boy, said in a statement that there was no "organized employee function around drinking" the day of the crash and that 16 hours of video and interviews with staff members show that Komoroski did not go to the restaurant that day. She added that it was "untrue" that Komoroski's supervisor knew anything about an alleged "previous history of alcohol abuse," as the complaint alleges.  Reardon said Komoroski had recently been hired and had trained for only two days before April 28, adding that her employment has been terminated.  "Our hearts are with the family and friends impacted by this tragedy," Reardon said in the statement. "Beyond the many visitors we receive, Folly Beach is a close-knit community of locals and businesses, and we share in the heartbreak of this senseless loss."  The complaint also alleges that the management of Taco Boy and the managements of the bars Komoroski allegedly visited that night failed to properly train employees to recognize signs of intoxication and prevent overserving.  Reardon said in her statement that restaurant staffers are "committed to serving alcohol responsibly" and are required to complete training programs to prevent overserving.  A representative for Snapper Jacks declined to comment and directed calls to a corporate phone number, which no one answered.  Representatives for The Drop In and El Gallo Bar & Grill declined to comment.  A representative for The Crab Shack could not immediately be reached for comment.  Allegations of an alcohol-fueled evening  The lawsuit alleges that Komoroski began her evening drinking at El Gallo Bar & Grill in Charleston before she drove 26 miles south to the city of Folly Beach, where she allegedly drank at three more local bars: The Drop In, The Crab Shack and Snapper Jacks.  ‚ÄúOver the course of several hours, Jamie Komoroski slurred and staggered her way through each of these bars, consuming an assortment of alcoholic beverages, including beer, tequila shots, shift shots of liquor on the house, etc.,‚Äù the suit alleges.  ‚ÄúBy the end of the night, Jamie Komoroski was grossly and dangerously intoxicated,‚Äù it says.  Jamie Lee Komoroski, 25, only briefly hit the brakes before her vehicle smashed into the golf cart in Folly Beach, S.C., on April 28. Folly Beach Police Department  Komoroski's blood alcohol content was more than three times the legal limit in South Carolina, which is 0.08%, according to a toxicology report.  The incident report says she told a sergeant at the scene of the crash ‚Äî on the 1200 block of East Ashley Avenue in Folly Beach ‚Äî that she had two drinks that night, a beer and a ‚Äútequila pineapple an hour ago or so.‚Äù Komoroski refused to perform any field sobriety tests, and she was swaying as a sergeant asked her to stand up, according to the incident report.  A sergeant said he ‚Äúsmelled an odor of alcohol coming from her breath and person,‚Äù the incident report says, adding that Komoroski was driving 65 mph per hour in a 25 mph zone ‚Äî and in the opposite direction of her home ‚Äî at the time of the crash.  A quest for accountability  The lawsuit also names as defendants 20 unspecified ‚ÄúJane Does‚Äù who may have contributed to the events.  Also named as plaintiffs, alongside Hutchinson, are Benjamin Garrett, Hutchinson's brother-in-law, and his son, a minor, who were driving the newly married couple in a golf cart back to their accommodations for the evening and suffered "terrible and permanent injuries," the complaint says.  Andrew Gilreath, the director of the Folly Beach Public Safety Department, has told The Associated Press that the golf cart had lights and was authorized to drive at night.  Hutchinson and the other plaintiffs are seeking a jury trial and unspecified damages, according to the lawsuit.  Dalton, the family's attorney, said the family hopes filing the lawsuit will allow it to learn more about what happened in the hours and minutes before the fatal crash and who should be held responsible.  ‚ÄúThere are still many details we don‚Äôt know about the sequence of events leading up to the tragic crash, but by filing a lawsuit, we can begin the legal discovery process that allows us to get the answers that Samantha‚Äôs family deserves," Dalton said in a statement.

When wedding vendors gather, it is usually in the thick of event planning, when every spare moment gets eaten up by a loose tablecloth, an out-of-place flower or an errant dining chair.  This week, professionals involved in wedding and event planning on Martha‚Äôs Vineyard had a chance to sit back and enjoy Martha‚Äôs Party, a three-day conference and networking event at the Winnetu Oceanside Resort in Edgartown presented by Island Weddings magazine and sponsored by PartySlate.  Panel discussion with (from left) Susie Middleton, Chef Ting, Dan Martino and Jaime Hamlin. ‚Äî Ray Ewing  Off-Island planners mingled with on-Island planners and vendors to compare notes, share ideas and get inspiration. Panel discussions included talks on finding local venues, preparing for temperamental Island weather and making the best use of social media. In the evenings, conference attendees enjoyed Island-themed parties ‚Äî a welcome excuse to sample the many catering options the Vineyard has to offer.  ‚ÄúVendors are so busy from now until fall that they‚Äôve never have a chance to just sit and talk,‚Äù said Alessandra Hagerty, marketing director for the Vineyard Gazette Media Group, which publishes Island Weddings.  Ms. Hagerty planned the conference with Kharma Finley-Wallace of Hoverfly Media after spending 10 years in the Island wedding industry and noticing how few on-Island networking opportunities there were.  More than 50 professionals attended the conference, with a range of vendors to the wedding industry participating in various ways. When not talking wedding shop, attendees cavorted with alpacas courtesy of Island Alpaca, practiced yoga with Yoga on the Vine‚Äôs Lora Ksieniewicz, and got a B-12 boost at the Drip Hydration shot bar, among other activities.  A highlight of the conference was a wedding-themed party Tuesday evening at the Grange, featuring a sampling of food and drink from more than a dozen vendors.  ‚ÄúPeople had the best time,‚Äù said Ms. Hagerty. ‚ÄúThey were all telling me that this should have been done so long ago.‚Äù

PRESS RELEASE Published May 17, 2023 Press Advantage  Jacksonville, FL - Rainbow Mobile Notary and Nuptials Wedding Officiants Network offer inclusive Wedding Services in Jacksonville, Florida.  It is the company's way of promoting equality in love in Florida, one of the states that allow same-sex marriage. With this, clients may sign documents from anywhere worldwide and then email them to the Rainbow Mobile Notary and Nuptials Wedding Officiant Network. Once received, documents are promptly sent to the Florida Secretary of State and returned to clients through FedEx. To learn more, interested parties may go to https://rainbownotaryandnuptials.com.  "We are an inclusive and affordable solution to your wedding planning," they say.  To learn more about Wedding Officiant in Florida, clients may call (904) 333-7311 or email at [email protected].
